DOC.HEAD: Mutinous Cadets Fire on Troops in Azerbaijan, Mourning Rally Held
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 5th graf `The political scientist...' to UPDATE with Mulazade saying more gunfire, but Soviet forces appear to control Baku. Pickup 6th graf `Mutinous Azerbaijani...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserColor NY10
DOC.TEXT: Mutinous military cadets in Azerbaijan fired on Soviet troops patrolling their capital Sunday, and tens of thousands of people mourned victims of a bloody crackdown on their republic's nationalist uprising. A general strike was called for Monday to protest Soviet troop presence, said a political scientist speaking by telephone from Baku, the Azerbaijani capital where the fighting was reported. It was not immediately clear who called the strike. The dozens of cadets, joined by comrades from the neighboring Caucasus republic of Georgia, battled sporadically Sunday with Soviet soldiers at Baku's garrison and military academy, reported Arif Yunusov, a member of the Azerbaijani Social Democratic Group. The downtown garrison was the scene of some of the fiercest fighting when thousands of Soviet troops Saturday broke through barricades erected by militants and stormed Baku, the southern republic's capital. The political scientist, Jahun Mulazade, who teaches at the Azerbaijan Academy of Sciences, said from his apartment Sunday night that he could hear shooting at the garrison. He estimated about 200 Azerbaijani cadets, 50 Georgians and members of other ethnic groups were fighting the soldiers. Early Monday, Mulazade reported scattered gunfire but that Soviet military forces generally appeared to ``control the situation in Baku.'' Mutinous Azerbaijani sailors also reportedly exchanged gunfire with Soviet troops on Sunday. Mulazade and Yunusov's wife, Leila, said that battle raged at the naval academy on the outskirts of Baku. Occasional shots rang out elsewhere in the Azerbaijani capital Sunday, Yunusov and Radio Moscow said, but it appeared that fighting was concentrated at military posts. Rebels threw grenades and Molotov cocktails at soldiers' military vehicles, the official news agency Tass said. A correspondent for Moscow's state-run TV and radio service was briefly held hostage. The Interior Ministry reported 51 civilians and six soldiers dead, and 287 civilians and 36 soldiers wounded in Saturday's action. That brought the total number of casualties for the week to 129 dead and more than 500 wounded. Activists reported much higher figures, and Interior Ministry officials said they received too many conflicting accounts to confidently update their figures. Foreign reporters were barred from Armenia and Azerbaijan, so it was difficult to reconcile the conflicting information. Moscow sent thousands of troops and other forces to Baku after fighting flared between the Moslem Azerbaijanis and mainly Christian Armenians this month. The neighboring republics are locked in a decades-old dispute over the region of Nagorno-Karabakh, which is inside Azerbaijan but populated mainly by Armenians. The total number of Soviet forces tackling the violence is reported to be 29,000, including troops, police, cadets and interior forces. The number of militants has been reported to be in the thousands. The bloodiest wave of violence erupted Jan. 13 with anti-Armenian rioting in Baku that killed 67 people by official count and forced thousands of Armenians to abandon their homes. It escalated into open warfare elsewhere in Azerbaijan and led to the worst fighting in the ethnic feud in two years. A tabloid TV newscast called ``Seven Days'' began a 25-minute wrapup of the week's ethnic violence Sunday night with red lines spreading from the top of the screen, simulating dripping blood, as pictures of soldiers and victims of the violence flashed by. Anchorman Eduard M. Sagalayev told millions of viewers the ethnic warfare was the Soviet Union's biggest tragedy since World War II. Tens of thousands of Azerbaijanis gathered outside the Communist Party headquarters in Baku to mourn those killed when Soviet troops moved in, Yunusov said. They also demanded that the state of emergency imposed in the capital early Saturday be lifted and that Soviet troops pull out, according to the Azerbaijan's People's Front, which has organized anti-Armenian protests. Baku's city council made identical demands. The republic's Supreme Soviet convened an emergency meeting late Sunday night and was to remain in session until Monday morning, said Namida Vitulova, whose husband, Yusif Samedogly, attended. She and Mulazade said they expected the legislature to show its anger over the crackdown by considering secession. Azerbaijan's premier, Ayaz Mutalibov, said in a Baku Radio broadcast he met Saturday with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and discussed what steps were required for troops to be withdrawn. In the address, monitored by the British Broadcasting Corp. in London, Mutalibov did not elaborate but said: ``We were promised that provocations will be prevented in Azerbaijan's districts bordering Armenia.'' He appealed to his countrymen ``to save our people from disaster'' by restoring law and order. Residents said flags with black mourning ribbons were draped on cars, balconies and windows throughout the city, which was in the middle of three days of officially declared mourning. A mass funeral was scheduled Monday. Mulazade said the road to Baku's airport, strewn with corpses after the Soviet troops stormed through, was covered with flowers. Soldiers continued to patrol the Caspian Sea port of 1.8 million people in armored personnel carriers. The Interior Ministry in Moscow said extremists massed on a dock in Baku near the tanker Ivan Zemnukhov and threatened to blow up the ship unless Soviet troops were withdrawn from the capital. Ali Asker, a People's Front member in Baku, said in a telephone interview that workers aboard oil tankers and other ships anchored in Baku's port threatened to set fire to their vessels unless troops were withdrawn. The seamen also threatened to ignite oil facilities, Asker said. The threat could not be immediately confirmed. In Moscow, thousands of Azerbaijanis, many wearing black armbands and waving black flags of mourning, marched to the headquarters of the official Tass news agency. They claimed official news coverage of the events in their republic was distorted, and they carried signs critical of Gorbachev. Hundreds of Armenians gathered at a small brick church and cemetery in Moscow to mourn their dead. Volunteers sat a table on the snow-covered sidewalk outside the church to collect donations for the 15,000 Armenian refugees who fled Baku, and demonstrators held protest signs, including one that blamed Moscow for the deaths. Iran's Islamic Republic News Agency said two helicopters Sunday flew over barricades erected by residents of the Soviet border city of Lenkoran and fired at a crowd. IRNA said a provincial Soviet television station that broadcast a declaration of independence from Moscow was knocked off the air, apparently by a powerful explosion. Iran reiterated its call on the Soviet Union to stop the ``violent clashes'' with Moslems in neighboring Azerbaijan, IRNA said. Tass said Armenians fired at an Azerbaijani village in an area called Wolf's Gate on the border between the two republics, killing 12 civilians before troops stepped in. The dispatch did not say when the attack occurred. On Saturday, it said, people attacked an anti-aircraft and missile unit near the Armenian capital, Yerevan, but that government forces repulsed them. On Monday, the British Broadcasting Corp. reported talks in Yerevan aimed at seeking an end to hostility between the rival ethnic groups and an exchange of hostages held by both sides.

DOC.HEAD: One-Day Car Ban Changes Milan's Look, Improves Air Quality
DOC.TEXT: Milanese breathed easier and turned to unusual means of transportation after authorities ordered a one-day ban on private cars. Bicycles, skateboards and roller skates replaced cars on the streets of Italy's business capital on Sunday as private traffic was banned between 9:30 a.m. and 6:30 p.m. to combat air pollution. The region's 300 electric car owners met downtown with their vehicles, while part of the police went on horseback. Authorities in the city of 3 million people doubled the number of buses and streetcars and tripled the number of subway trains usually in use on Sundays. ``I think the citizens took it well,'' Mayor Paolo Pillitteri told reporters. ``Maybe a Sunday spent differently will make people think about what's happening to our city.'' It was the longest ban on cars in Italy since driving was forbidden throughout the country on holidays at the height of the oil crisis in 1973. Dry, windless weather has increased air pollution across northern Italy. In the most polluted areas of Milan, carbon monoxide readings reached dangerous levels on Saturday. City officials said they might repeat Sunday's ban or take other measures if air pollution remains at alarming levels.

DOC.HEAD: Tug, Freighter Collide; Injuries, Possible Leakage Reported
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with two injured, no coke spilled into ocean. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A freighter carrying petroleum coke collided with a tugboat Sunday off Delaware, damaging both vessels and injuring two people, the Coast Guard said. Authorities said there was no indication any of the coke spilled into the Atlantic Ocean. The 593-foot freighter Doo Yang Leader and the 113-foot tug Socrates collided around 6:30 p.m. 35 miles due east of Cape Henlopen in southern Delaware, Coast Guard spokesman Breck Smith said in Philadelphia. The freighter stopped because it had a ruptured tank believed to be leaking engine fuel, said Coast Guard Petty Officer Richard Minnich. ``When they noticed the leak, they transfered that fuel back to another tank,'' Minnich said. ``There's a one-meter hole on the starboard side. The hole is above the waterline,'' said James Graham, a spokesman for the Coast Guards's 5th District headquarters in Portsmouth, Va. The ship was carrying petroleum coke, a residue from a process that breaks down petroleum products. The freighter is owned by Doo Yang Shipping Lines in South Korea. Investigators from the Coast Guard's Marine Safety Office in Philadelphia were dispatched to the collision site. Graham said the Coast Guard cutter Point Franklin, with emergency medical technicians aboard, was in the area and was en route to the tug to assist one of the injured, but said the injury didn't appear to be life-threatening. He said authorities believe the other man had a back injury, and did not require major medical attention. The tug was towing a 300-foot barge of sugar from West Palm Beach, Fla. to Yonkers, N.Y., just north of New York City. The tug is owned by Allied Towing Corp. of Norfolk, Va., Minnich said. Minnich said the tug received damage to its cabin, but was able to continue on its route and was being accompanied by another tug owned by the same company. Neither ship lost any of its cargo, Graham said.

DOC.HEAD: Earlier Immigrants Asked to Help Resettle New Refugees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES extraneous material at end.
DOC.TEXT: A sign on a freeway here reads ``Little Saigon,'' marking an enclave that is home to many of the 250,000 Vietnamese settled in Southern California. Now the region is receiving the first wave of 100,000 political prisoners allowed to leave Vietnam, and experts are calling on Vietnamese-Americans to help the refugees survive and thrive in America as government funding dwindles. ``My argument to them is look, you've been helped by the American government, the American people and others,'' said Loc Nguyen, director of the refugee resettlement program for the Catholic Charities of Los Angeles. ``You keep pushing the government to allow more refugees, and say we need more help. I say they are our people. ... We have to take care of them,'' said Nguyen. The refugees themselves are cautioned about economic realities. ``We explain to them that real life in the United States does not look like on television,'' said Rev. Bao Xuan Nguyen of the Saigon Christian Reformed Church in Westminster. ``I ask them, come back with a realistic view. ... If they want to build their own life, everything must start at the beginning.'' The Vietnamese community in Los Angeles is estimated at 150,000, and at up to 100,000 in adjacent Orange County, officials say, the largest concentration outside Vietnam. About 7,000 prisoners of communist Vietnam's ``re-education'' camps _ some of whom spent more than a decade imprisoned after the war's end _ are expected to be resettled by September. Of the total 100,000 or so eligible to emigrate to the United States in the next five years, most are expected to settle in Southern California, said William Gayk, demographer for Orange County. Texas, Florida and Washington, D.C., also have large Vietnamese populations, Gayk said. The amount of federal money available for an individual's resettlement in 1983 was $12,000, according to Dianne Edwards, director of adult and employment services for the Orange County Social Services Agency. In 1989, it was less than $4,000, she said. There are government programs in place to help such refugees as the former political prisoners, she said, including cash assistance, medical aid and language and job training. ``We are not anticipating a major drain on county resources as a result of the former POWs,'' she said. ``The issue we are seeking to address is that refugee funding has gone down considerably in the last 10 years.'' Leaders in the Vietnamese community say the decline in funding presents an opportunity to unite in support of their newly arriving countrymen. ``The local and federal government has been doing a lot of work to resettle the refugees. We feel we should do our part,'' said Tony Lam, a businessman who has been active in refugee resettlement in Orange County since his arrival 15 years ago. The Rev. Nguyen is working to enlist even recent refugees in the cause. ``I say, `You wanted me to sponsor you, how about when you have a stable life, you sponsor others,''' Nguyen tells his parishioners. ``Do for them what people did for you.'' Those involved in resettlement agree that a number of the former prisoners _ many of whom were military officers who fought for South Vietnam against the communists and politicians _ are arriving with advantages their predecessors lacked. ``This group is the easiest to work with,'' said Loc Nguyen of Catholic Charities, which handles up to 40 percent of the total Vietnamese refugee caseload in Los Angeles and works under an agreement with the State Department, as do a dozen other volunteer agencies. ``They have an above-average education, and often are college-educated. Their English is much better than other groups. They may have been government or military officials, or been associated with U.S. firms,'' he said. Loc Nguyen and others said the refugees need help adjusting to a lower standard of living than they might have expected here, and the limits of public assistance. That might mean a man who was an engineer or high-ranking military officer in Vietnam will have to start out here as a minimum-wage assembly line worker, he said. Loc Nguyen said he encourages refugees to take such jobs while educating themselves for more skilled positions, so they can stay off welfare. ``I tell them with welfare you lose your confidence, you lose your energy. You become merely a welfare receiver who waits for the check,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Faces Possible Chilly Reception on Latin American Trip
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle, facing a possible chilly reception in Latin America as he offers to explain the U.S. invasion of Panama, would not be the first presidential emissary to run into trouble in the region. Such esteemed former Latin America travelers as Nelson Rockefeller, Richard Nixon and Rosalynn Carter were sent by presidents on goodwill trips and all encountered stormy receptions _ in some cases violence. Quayle leaves Saturday on a mission to try to quell the resentment left in Central and South America by President Bush's Dec. 20 military invasion of Panama. None of the countries in the region has officially rebuffed Quayle, but some officials have let it be known his visit would be less than welcome so soon after the invasion. Many are upset that U.S. invasion troops remain in Panama. Instead of receiving Quayle at home, some leaders plan to meet with him at three presidential inaugurations _ on Saturday in Honduras, and in Chile and Brazil in mid-March. Quayle himself acknowledged ``there's a matter of timing'' involving ``diplomatic sensitivities'' over when he should go. Past efforts by Washington to be chummy with Latin America have encountered problems stemming from a variety of sources, including Latin resentment over the historical U.S. pattern of manipulating the region's internal political and economic affairs. The most volatile trips in recent history were that of Vice President Richard Nixon in 1958 and a series of trips by New York Gov. Nelson Rockefeller in 1969. In contrast to those times, when most of the region was under dictatorship and military rule, Quayle will visit a region that has turned overwhelmingly to democratic government. On an 18-day goodwill mission for President Eisenhower, Nixon was the target of violent, anti-U.S. demonstrations in Peru and Venezuela, and lesser outbursts and heckling by university students in Argentina, Uruguay, Paraguay and Colombia. Rock-throwing mobs confronted Nixon in Lima and Caracas. Rioters shattered the windows of his limousine in Caracas and tried to drag him and his wife from the car before their motorcade managed to escape. Eisenhower ordered U.S. military troops to stand by in Puerto Rico and the Guantanamo Bay base in Cuba in case Nixon needed protection. In Lima, shouting demonstrators threw rocks and fruit at his speaker's platform. In Bogota, police broke up several anti-Nixon demonstrations. When Nixon became president, he dispatched Rockefeller to help formulate a new policy toward Latin America. Voicing sentiments much like those stated by Bush in the first year of his presidency, Nixon talked about the region's importance and U.S. hopes for cooperative ties with its hemispheric neighbors. But Rockefeller's mission was marked at nearly every stop by violence _ riots, bombings, gunfights or terrorism. Eight people were killed in incidents directly or indirectly connected to the visit. The first trouble signs came in Guatemala where newspapers blasted his visit as useless, and in El Salvador where placards read ``Rockefeller go home.'' In Nicaragua, students burned a U.S. flag. Peru then canceled Rockefeller's trip to Lima, annoyed that the United States had suspended arms sales to Peru following seizures of U.S. fishing boats. Following violence in Ecuador, Colombia and Honduras, word came that Venezuela and Chile wanted to be stricken from Rockefeller's itinerary. In Montevideo, Uruguay, rampaging students, protesting both Rockefeller's visit and their government's economic austerity program, smashed car windows and threw firebombs. After returning home, Rockefeller submitted to Nixon 83 recommendations on how to improve hemispheric cooperation and help solve the region's social, political and economic problems. All but a few were ignored. When Rosalynn Carter toured seven nations as her husband's emissary on a 13-day trip in 1977, the dissension was mostly less overt. But students in Quito, Ecuador, threw stones and bricks and shouted anti-American slogans near where she met with government officials. The noise at times nearly drowned out her voice in the Legislative Palace. Elsewhere on her tour, there were private diplomatic rumblings, complaining that Carter had sent his wife rather than a high-ranking official who would have more appropriate stature to conduct diplomatic talks. In Brazil, Mrs. Carter trod on delicate ground by raising the Carter administration's unhappiness with the military government's human rights record, and ruffled feathers by announcing she would meet there with two American churchmen who had reportedly been beaten by police.

DOC.HEAD: Eye Color Made Basis For Discrimination
DOC.TEXT: When Amber Yarger arrived at school recently, she had to sit in the back of her classroom and couldn't play with her brown-eyed friends at recess. She and the other blue-eyed third graders had to drink from a fountain with warm water, use a restroom without paper towels, and stand in the back of lines. It was part of a first-hand lesson in discrimination devised by faculty at Driscoll Elementary School to teach 60 third-graders the meaning of discrimination, as part of the celebration of Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday. ``I had this one friend who had blue eyes, and she started crying because she didn't know what was happening,'' Amber said Sunday. Blue-eyed children were snubbed one day in the program that began Jan. 9; those with brown eyes and those with hazel and green eyes were discriminated against on subsequent days. Some children were upset at their separation from friends and classmates for a day, teacher Cathy Pedersen said, but she hopes they learned the lesson. ``The goal really was to get them to understand just how unfair prejudice is. .. I wanted them to say, `This is unfair. I can't help the way I was born.' If they can grow up without prejudice, they can carry that on with their children,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Sponsors Songs to Dampen Third World Sex
DOC.TEXT: In languages from West African pidgin English to the Tagalog of the Philippines, popular music financed by the U.S. government aims at discouraging young people from having sex. Critics have long complained that many pop songs promote sex, but the songs commissioned by the U.S. Agency for International Development seek to do the reverse. ``Wait for Me,'' the title song of a best-selling album in Nigeria last year, says in pidgin English: ``Dis tin them call love ``Na serious affair, ``Make you think well ``Before you gree.'' Translation: ``This thing they call love is a serious affair. Think well before you agree.'' The song was recorded by King Sunny Ade, known in West Africa for a style called ju-ju, and Onyeku Onwenu. He has three wives and 12 children. She is a graduate of Wellesley College who tried journalism before turning to the stage. The agency said she wrote both music and lyrics, in pidgin and traditional English. Another song, ``Choices,'' presents an alternative policy: ``Yes we shouldn't make children ``We cannot take care of ``There are ways of making love ``Without making children.'' Many people who work to raise the living standards of poor countries see the rapid growth of their population as the chief obstacle. ``Growth rates in developing countries will remain high for several decades even if couples have fewer children,'' said a study by the World Bank, the chief source of aid for the Third World. ``Absolute annual increases will be close to ... 80 million people a year ... well into the next century.'' The U.S. agency's population program also provides donations of contraceptives, including 6.9 billion condoms over the past two decades. The Nigerian album's popularity has spilled over into neighboring countries. The next step will be another record for nearby French-speaking republics like Zaire, Senegal and the Ivory Coast, the agency says. The agency said it was too early to say what effect the African music has had, but a study will be made later. Two songs recorded earlier for Latin America were the subject of an analysis by the Population Communication Service of Johns Hopkins University. The idea for the project came from a conference of the service in 1983. With the government agency's support it blossomed into two musical videos, television commercials, radio spots, records and jackets, posters and press materials. The songs were recorded by Tatiana Palacios of Mexico and Johnny Lozada Correa of Puerto Rico. The agency said the songs topped the charts in Mexico and Peru and reached the top 10 in nine other countries. ``We made an investment of about $350,000 and got about $5 million worth of free air time,'' said Duff Gillespie, the agency's director for population. The university's study said that although no data were collected, attitudes about delaying sexual relations may have been strengthened, especially among young women in Mexico. ``One of the most important conclusions from this evaluation is that popular songs and the broadcast media can be successfully employed to reach young people with a positive social message about sexual responsibility, even if the message contradicts the theme of the majority of competing popular songs,'' it added. In the Philippines one song was called ``I Still Believe'' and Lea Salonga sang in English: ``I don't think it's right to need me ``Just for a lonely night.'' To which, according to the agency, Charlie Masso replied in Tagalog: ``I'm willing to wait for a while.'' The song was number one in the Philippine charts for two months, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Skiff Capsizes in Washington State River, Leaving One Dead, Six Missing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with one dead, six missing, other information. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A chartered fishing boat with nine people aboard capsized and broke up in 15-foot swells in a river's mouth Sunday, leaving one person dead and six people missing, Coast Guard officials said. The 45-foot Gambler capsized around 4 p.m. while crossing a sandbar in the mouth of the Quillayute River as it headed for the harbor of this village by the Pacific Ocean, the Coast Guard said. A Coast Guard helicopter plucked three people from the water, but one was dead on arrival at Forks Community Hospital, officials said. Jerry Wilson and Ron Wilson, both in their 20s and both of Aberdeen, were listed in stable condition at the hospital, said hospital nursing supervisor Barbara Enos. The name of the person who died was not released pending notification of relatives. A 44-foot Coast Guard motor lifeboat from LaPush searched through heavy fog Sunday night for possible survivors or bodies in the water, Chief Petty Officer Dave Edwards said in a telephone interview from the Quillayute River Coast Guard Station. The helicopter also searched but returned to Port Angeles 80 miles east of LaPush after running low on fuel. The Clallam County sheriff's office sent a 10-member search and rescue team to LaPush to search the beach, said sheriff's communications officer Bill Logan. The entrance to LaPush's harbor is a narrow waterway at the mouth of the Quillayute. The Gambler was from Tacoma, but has been moored lately in LaPush, Edwards said.

DOC.HEAD: Weicker Considers Comeback as He Builds Research Organization
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Research! America in 2nd graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: The dome of his former haunt, the U.S. Capitol, looms seven miles up the Potomac River as Lowell Weicker, his 6-foot-5-inch frame a little thinner than when he patrolled the Senate, ponders returning to politics. Weicker, the Nixon antagonist and maverick Republican from Connecticut, has dropped off the radar screen of politics in the year since his upset loss to Democrat Joseph Lieberman. He has been quietly building a public outreach group, Research! America, an association of universities, hospitals and philanthropies devoted to promoting biomedical research, where his job is ``to sell the priority of biomedical research to the American people in the same way you sell a hamburger or a can of beer.'' But the 58-year-old millionaire says he misses the political battlefield and is considering a run for governor of Connecticut. ``One could compare Research! America to Elba if one wanted to,'' said Dick Foley, the Connecticut GOP chief and no supporter of Weicker, referring to the island where Napoleon was exiled. Weicker says he never wanted to use Research! America as a platform for political self-promotion. But as he considers returning to politics, the organization is preparing a media blitz featuring Weicker that will promote research for cures for such diseases as multiple sclerosis and cystic fibrosis. Weicker closes out each of the TV ads by saying, ``To me, it's outrageous that a country as prosperous as America doesn't spend more on medical research.'' The organization has a $1 million budget this year and hopes to triple that figure within three years through contributions from its member organizations. ``The big part of our budget is going to be advertising,'' Weicker says. In the meantime, Weicker says he misses the political fray and predicts he could win the state's top office. But he is also realistic. ``The last time I asked Connecticut, `How am I doing?' I didn't get a very good answer,''' Weicker said. The speculation about Weicker has been fueled by the absence of any declared candidates of statewide stature. Incumbent Democratic Gov. William O'Neill has yet to decide whether he wants another term, and other potential contenders are either regional politicians or businessmen. Weicker, who inherited a fortune from his grandfather's pharmaceutical business, says he could easily stay where he is. He spends more time with his family, has a nice view of the Potomac and doesn't have to attend late night Senate sessions. In fact, he has hardly been on Capitol Hill since losing his seat. ``When I accepted the job for Research America, I made it very clear that I would not lobby, period,'' Weicker said. ``When I was in the Senate, I used to really look with disdain ... on my ex-colleagues who used to lurk in the dining room and gymnasium and the halls doing their thing.'' Even if he did lobby the Senate, Weicker wonders whether he would have much impact. His outspoken, often undiplomatic style, which first gained prominence during the Watergate hearings when he lambasted President Nixon for what he viewed as that administration's abuse of the Constitution, frequently earned him enemies. Nevertheless, Weicker says he doesn't plan to change his manner, even though he has little doubt it cost him his Senate seat. ``The approach stays the same,'' he says. ``We'd all like to go ahead and call the manner of our leaving, whether it's the Senate or it's the earth,'' Weicker said. ``Would I have preferred to have retired undefeated from the Senate? Sure, nobody likes to get beat. But you don't run the risks that I ran on a variety of issues without understanding that somewhere along the line you're going to catch a bullet.''

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts From DC Mayor's Public Statement on Treatment Plans
With PM-Barry, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from Mayor Marion Barry's statement to reporters Sunday in the wake of his arrest last week on drug charges: ``The events of the past few days have been the most difficult of my life. More difficult than fighting my way out of poverty as black youth, born in the segregated Deep South. More difficult than the fear and hatred I faced as a civil rights leader in the 1960s. More difficult than I could have imagined. ``Because this time I have come face to face with my deepest human frailties. I've had to look my human weaknesses straight in the eye. I have realized that I've spent so much time caring about and worrying about and doing for others. I have not worried enough or cared enough for myself. ... ``I have realized that God made Marion Barry the same as he made other people, a flesh and blood creation, who rises and falls just like any other human being. ``I've just spent the last hour or so with a group of clergy people, including my own minister, David Eaton, who are friends of mine. We have prayed and they have counseled me. And I have taken their counsel. ``It helped me feel good about the fact that in the final analysis, it's not the title that a person holds that's important, it's not Marion Barry mayor that counts, it's Marion Barry the person _ a human being with a body, mind and spirit like any other person. ``I've felt for some time that I could do any and everything. But they have helped me to realize that God put each of us on earth for a purpose. We may not always understand what that purpose, but when we put ourselves in God's hands, our way is made clearer. ``These ministers have helped me keep the strength that I need. ``So I announce today I am going to find a way to begin to heal my body, mind and soul. ``To all the people who love me and worry about me, the best way to show your appreciation for me and our city and our family is to join together as a united community. We must at this hour be willing to forgive, to love, to reach out to each other and to serve our city. ``I realize that I am going to have to walk this journey by myself. It's going to take Marion Barry walking this journey. But I say to others who are pained and hurt as I am _ join me, brothers and sisters. We can make it. We can make it. We will make it. It's going to be a lonely journey. But I stand, and God stands with me.''

DOC.HEAD: Foley Declines to Endorse Social Security Tax Cut
DOC.TEXT: A Democratic plan to cut the Social Security payroll tax poses a problem because it would increase the federal deficit, says House Speaker Thomas S. Foley. Foley, D-Wash., said he probably would oppose the plan by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., if he had to make an immediate decision on it. The Bush administration opposes the proposal. ``I wouldn't be ready to say that I was in favor of it today,'' Foley, D-Wash., said Sunday, appearing on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press.'' ``If I had to make a decision today to do it or not do it, I'd probably say don't do it.'' Moynihan's plan is aimed at keeping the surpluses generated by the Social Security system from artificially lowering the federal deficit. The Social Security system made $52 billion more last year than it paid out, allowing the government to report a $152 billion deficit rather than a $204 billion shortfall. ``Rightly or wrongly, these funds are used to meet the costs of the deficit, or part of them, and we'd have a problem if we cut the tax, of having a very large increase in the federal deficit,'' Foley said. Other Democrats, though taking pleasure in the way Moynihan's politically appealing tax cut has put Republicans on the defensive, have also voiced reservations about what effect it would have on the nation's deficit. Moynihan, appearing on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation,'' said he didn't know why so few Democrats had endorsed his plan. ``If we can't get behind an issue like this, a principle, I'm not sure who needs the Democratic Party.'' he said. ``If we won't protect the integrity of the trust funds, well, what are we?'' Moynihan's plan could provide 111 million working Americans with a tax cut of up to $600 a year. It would benefit lower- and middle-income Americans most of all, since the payroll tax does not apply to earnings above $51,300. Foley said he thought it was wrong for the surplus to be used to mask the deficit, but he did not want to endanger Social Security benefits for future retirees. ``I'm not ready to oppose it. I think we ought to study it very carefully,'' Foley said. The speaker noted it took Congress more than a year's work before it agreed on a way to strengthen the system's financial structure in 1983. ``We shouldn't go running around changing it dramatically without time to examine the alternatives,'' Foley said. Foley had been silent on the issue before Sunday. Other key players in revenue legislation who have not been heard from are Senate Finance Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, and House Ways and Means Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, reiterated Sunday that he is undecided on Moynihan's plan and is awaiting studies about how it would affect the deficit. Mitchell, appearing on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley,'' said Moynihan's plan was significant because it exposed how ``unfair and regressive'' the American tax system had become. President Bush is pushing for a cut in the capital gains tax, which is seen by many Democrats as benefiting only the rich. Supporters say it would stimulate much-needed investment. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., appearing with Mitchell, predicted the Moynihan plan is ``not going anywhere.'' Budget Director Richard Darman, also appearing on the ABC program, said Congress should be more concerned with lowering the nation's $3 trillion debt than cutting the Social Security tax. ``Senator Moynihan has, in effect, thrown a grenade into the middle of the House and Senate,'' Darman said. Moynihan's plan would cut the 7.65 percent payroll tax _ paid separately by workers and their employers _ by 0.14 percent immediately and by 0.96 percent more next January. The tax would begin to rise again in the year 2015 so the Social Security system could begin building up a reserve to pay for the 75 million baby boomers who will begin to retire at around that time.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Unlike his second wife, Lee Iacocca's third bride-to-be won't need any cooking lessons from the mother of the Chrysler Corp. chief. Darrien Earle is a gourmet. The pair announced their engagement Thursday, but have not set a date for the wedding _ Earle's second. Antonietta Iacocca taught Iacocca's second wife, Peggy Johnson, to cook Italian food. The marriage ended in 1987 after 1{ years. Earle, 41, studied at the prestigious Cordon Bleu cooking school of France and owned several Mexican restaurants in the Los Angeles area. Although Earle sold her restaurant interests last year, her brother, Steve Loomis, said she still cooks at home. ``She's been in Italy to study food and to France and also Los Angeles and San Francisco,'' Loomis said. ``Her kitchen looks like a restaurant.'' Her specialties? Tex-Mex, French and Italian.

Polish-born Barbara Piasecka Johnson, who has offered to save the bankrupt Polish shipyard that gave birth to the Solidarity trade union, is still interested despite reports of the deal's demise, an aide said. Mrs. Johnson, heir to the Johnson & Johnson fortune, offered in May to invest up to $100 million in the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk if certain conditions were met. Her letter of intent set a deadline of Dec. 31 to complete negotiations. John Peach, an aide to Mrs. Johnson, dismissed the deadline set in the letter of intent: ``December 31 was just not a practical deadline, as complicated as the deal was.'' ``Mrs. Johnson is still very interested and enthusiastic about the shipyard,'' Peach said Thursday in a telephone interview from Princeton, where Mrs. Johnson lives. ``We plan to be over there as soon as the government says, `Come on over.''' Poland's then-Communist government decided in October 1988 to close the shipyard as an austerity measure. Mrs. Johnson's offer initially heartened the economically distressed port city, but the enthusiasm of shipyard representatives cooled as the details of her bid became clearer. She sought a 55 percent interest in the shipyard, a five-year ban on strikes and a wage contract of 50 cents an hour, according to Solidarity and shipyard officials.

Two decades of movie-making have left Richard Dreyfuss at a comfortable level of fame. ``I have the right-size celebrity,'' the 42-year-old actor said in February's Fame magazine. ``Not as much as some and a lot more than others. And I'm known but not worshiped. ``I can always get a good table at a restaurant, but when I get to the table they let me eat in peace,'' said Dreyfuss, star of the current film ``Always.'' In the 1970s, Dreyfuss starred in such blockbusters as ``American Graffiti,'' ``Jaws'' and ``Close Encounters of the Third Kind,'' and won an Academy Award for ``The Goodbye Girl.''

Ex-drug addict David Crosby is helping alcoholic teen-age actress Drew Barrymore stay straight. Barrymore, 14, lived with Crosby and his wife, Jan Dance, for three months as part of her program of recovery from alcohol and drug abuse, according to this week's People magazine. ``I'm an old Hollywood kid and I knew her story. I felt she had been dealt a short deck, you know, a fifth-generation alcoholic, and I didn't want to see her go down the tubes,'' Crosby told People. Crosby, 48, of the rock group Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young, has a well-documented history of cocaine addiction, hitting bottom in 1983 with an 11-month prison term on drug and weapons convictions. But now he's straight. Barrymore, the lovable moppet of the movie ``E.T.,'' announced last year that she had struggled with drugs and alcohol since she was 9. When she left a clinic in October, the Crosbys took her in. Barrymore has rejoined her mother, Ildiko Jaid, is back in school and is free of drugs and alcohol, People reported.

White House Chief of Staff John Sununu and his wife, Nancy, returned to their home state to lead a field of 75 sports and media celebrities in a ski event to benefit children. Proceeds from Saturday's ski-in at Attitash Ski area went to the Genesis Fund, which provides money for special care for children with birth defects, genetic diseases and mental retardation. Sununu, a frequent skier when he was New Hampshire's governor, said he enjoyed the trip back. ``We like it in Washington,'' Sununu said, ``but we really miss it in New Hampshire.''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version moving on sports wire
DOC.TEXT: John McEnroe, who has tried to tone down his bad boy image in recent years, threw a tantrum at the Australian Open and became the first player ejected from a Grand Slam event for misconduct. So much for Mr. Nice Guy. Rattled by missed shots, close calls and a baby's cries, he threw his racket and defaulted at a point when he was leading two sets to one against Mikael Pernfors. ``If I'd known the rules, I would probably have still broken my racket, but I probably wouldn't have said what I said to the guy,'' McEnroe said Sunday. The 30-year-old former champion came here determined to win his first major tournament since the 1984 U.S. Open. After McEnroe smashed the court with his racket in the fourth set, the umpire called a code violation for racket abuse. McEnroe responded by swearing at him and asking for Ken Farrar, the Grand Slam chief of supervisors. Farrar came onto the court and talked with McEnroe, but the American continued complaining and swearing. Farrar later described McEnroe's harangue as the most vile language he'd ever heard in a tennis match. McEnroe brushed silently past reporters at the airport today and left to fly home to California with his wife, actress Tatum O'Neal, and their two sons.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Deficit, Eastern Europe Head Congressional Agenda
DOC.TEXT: Congress returns to Washington this week for a 1990 session preoccupied with two issues that have taken on an unusual linkage: the federal budget deficit and the starkly changing face of Eastern Europe. Lawmakers will be caught between a desire to reward countries emerging from more than four decades of Soviet domination and the need to shrink spending in an unyielding budget that already is being asked to make room for improving programs at home. ``The year will be consumed with this discussion'' of how the United States deals with a host of new relationships _ with Poland, Hungary, East Germany, Romania, Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia _ said Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., a senior member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Congress and President Bush will have to reach agreement on what the U.S. role should be in encouraging and aiding those emerging new democracies as they struggle with economic stagnation. Almost certainly there will be a political consensus that some kind of aid should be extended, as there was last year on aiding Poland and Hungary. ``The real question will boil down to the availability of funds, and what kind of agreement will be reached between the administration and Congress,'' said Rep. Dante Fascell, D-Fla., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. Bush has renewed his no-new-taxes vow for this year, meaning any money for newly eligible recipients in Eastern Europe and Panama will have to be found by cutting current programs. The aid budget is already so tight that some U.S. friends and allies may come away empty-handed. Congress will have to grapple with reducing the budget deficit while seeking to pass legislation mandating cleaner air, subsidizing child care for working parents, reforming campaign finance laws, extending farm programs and stepping up the war on drugs. There will be fights, as well, over Bush's proposal to cut the tax rate on capital gains and over a proposal by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to cut the Social Security tax rate. A key to the budget battle will be how deeply defense spending can be cut, which in turn depends heavily on progress in talks in Vienna on a conventional arms control treaty for European forces. All of these thorny issues will be faced in the context of an election year. Voting will come in November for all 435 House seats and 34 Senate seats. To fund new foreign aid needs overseas, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., has suggested trimming large aid recipients like Israel and Egypt, which have politically potent lobbies. Many Democrats are countering that the money should come from cuts in Pentagon spending. ``We should look carefully at reducing military aid programs premised on a communist threat orchestrated from Moscow,'' said Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Claiborne Pell, D-R.I. ``Economic aid to Eastern Europe is a highly effective form of `defense' spending.'' Others are saying the United States should be wary of promising too much. ``We are not in the situation ... after the second World War, when the United States was totally dominant ... and we financed the recovery not only of our wartime allies, but our wartime enemies,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. ``We can't do that now, and we shouldn't do that now. It ought to be a multilateral effort.'' On the foreign affairs front the year will start on a discordant note _ an attempt to override of Bush's veto last year of a bill allowing Chinese students in the United States to extend their stays to avoid political persecution in their homeland. Republicans have abandoned the president in droves on the issue, saying he has been callous toward the bloody crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators last year. ``I don't think there's any chance they will be able to sustain the president's veto,'' said Rep. William Broomfield, R-Mich. ``It would be obviously sending the wrong signal to the rest of the world about what took place just a few months ago.'' A House vote on the issue will come Wednesday, and the Senate is expected to act soon afterward. The White House is putting heavy pressure on senators to support Bush, pointing out that he has taken administrative steps to protect the more than 30,000 students. Congress also will be keeping a close eye on El Salvador, where soldiers have been charged in the murders of six Jesuit priests, for signs that human rights violations can be dealt with by the judicial system, and Nicaragua, where national elections are scheduled for Feb. 25 and the campaign of the U.S.-backed opposition coalition has been flagging.

DOC.HEAD: Pump Prices Up Nearly Two Cents Per Gallon, Cold Weather Blamed
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline prices rose nearly 2 cents per gallon at the pump in the last two weeks, primarily because refiners cut back on gasoline processing in favor of heating oil during the cold weather, an analyst said. The average price of gasoline, including all grades and taxes, rose 1.97 cents per gallon to 113.06 cents per gallon between Jan. 5 and Jan. 19, Trilby Lundberg said Sunday. ``That's the highest level since late July 1989,'' she said. ``I'm attributing this to the effect that home heating oil price rises due to extreme cold weather had upon gasoline and other refined petroleum products.'' The retail gasoline prices on Jan. 19, according to the biweekly Lundberg Survey of 13,000 gas stations: At self-serve stations: Premium unleaded, 118.98 cents per gallon; regular unleaded, 101.65 cents and regular leaded, 100.19 cents. At full-service stations: Premium unleaded, 142.85 cents per gallon; regular unleaded, 129.42 cents and regular leaded, 126.58 cents.

DOC.HEAD: East Europe Revolution Could Hamper Soviet KGB, Experts Say
DOC.TEXT: The revolution in Eastern Europe may weaken but will not cripple the Kremlin's KGB spy agency, say U.S. and emigre analysts. ``The KGB will have to take over functions'' now carried out by Soviet Bloc allies, said Stanislav Levchenko, a KGB defector who lives near Washington. A non-communist government has been in power in Poland since August, while the East German, Hungarian and Romanian parties have changed their names since hardline rulers were toppled late last year. Also, Bulgaria's ruling Communist Party is attempting reforms. However, the external intelligence services of these Warsaw Pact nations remain largely intact, and they still seem to be spying for Moscow, say CIA chief William H. Webster and non-government analysts. ``It's much too early to tell how quickly those services will erode. My own sense is, not too quickly,'' Webster said in a speech on Nov. 29, after hardliners in all the countries but Romania had fallen. ``Some of them are ... deeply imbedded in the bureaucracies of their countries. So let's not assume that because we are getting friendly, and seeing freedom come up from the streets, that freedom has been endorsed by some of those aggressive intelligence services,'' Webster said. Soviet spy masters have long relied on East European intelligence services to obtain military secrets and advanced technology, say Western officials and Warsaw Pact defectors. The East Europeans were not as closely watched and could travel areas that are closed to Soviets. As evidence of Soviet control over Warsaw Pact intelligence-gathering, Webster cited the cases of Army Master Sgt. Clyde Lee Conrad, charged last August with working for Hungary at Soviet direction, and Army Warrant Officer James W. Hall, charged with spying for the Soviets and East Germans. Now experts say the East European spy agencies might capitalize on friendlier relations with the West, particularly in their efforts to steal advanced technologies, a major Kremlin target. A former chief of Romania's external intelligence, Ion Pacepa, predicted that espionage by that nation might increase after the ouster of Nicolae Ceausescu last month. ``They steal technology, and now they will steal it much more easily, because people in the West will want to help the Romanians and will give them technology, and they will give it to Moscow,'' Pacepa said in a telephone interview. Roy Godson, author of several books on intelligence, agreed that Americans ``will tend to be much more unguarded with East Europeans.'' ``In the technology acquisition area, I would think that the East Europeans would have great opportunities not only in the United States, but in West Europe and Japan,'' he said. Non-Soviet Warsaw Pact intelligence agencies cooperated with the KGB to varying degrees, according to analysts, but U.S. government officials will not disclose much of what they know about the links. According to the agreement that led to Solidarity's victory in Polish elections last year, that nation's military and intelligence services remain in the hands of Communist Party members who were trained in the Soviet Union. Czechoslovakia's Interior Ministry has been transferred out of communist control, but it is unclear to what degree purges have been carried out in the foreign intelligence departments or in espionage operations abroad. Soviet control over these operations will erode eventually, analysts agreed. The most noticeable change may be in East Germany, where the reform government renamed the security ministry, but is now defending its existence against angry mobs demanding an end to domestic spying. Among Warsaw Pact allies, East Germany had been contributing the most valuable information to Soviet intelligence, said Jed Snyder, a senior research fellow at the National Strategy Information Center. To take up the slack, said KGB defector Levchenko, the Soviets must add more agents. ``They can expand the number in a year'' by graduating more people from their intelligence academy, said Levchenko, a product of that institution. Levchenko said that ``35 percent of every Soviet community in every embassy are professional intelligence officers,'' and that percentage is likely to grow.

DOC.HEAD: Tried to Tell Them About Ceausescu, Says Rueful Ex-Ambassador
LaserPhoto RA1
DOC.TEXT: If there's anyone in a position to say ``I told you so,'' he must be David B. Funderburk who as the U.S. ambassador to Romania kept peppering the State Department with descriptions of Nicolae Ceausescu as an evil tyrant. ``It was like beating my head against a brick wall,'' he says. With no success at all, Funderburk struggled from 1981 to 1985 to reverse a U.S. policy that accorded special treatment toward the Romanian dictator on the grounds that here was one communist ruler with an independent streak. In an interview from his home in Buies Creek, N.C., the 45-year-old former college teacher says no one listened because the State Department had put him down as a protege of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., its longtime critic. Funderburk says George Bush, who was then vice president; former President Nixon, ``and members of the cabinet, senators, major businessmen all trekked over to Bucharest to do homage to Ceausescu. I tried to convince them of the extent of the horrors of the Ceausescu regime. ``But most of these officials had been told to just ignore Funderburk and what his people at the embassy were saying. They'd go in and praise Ceausescu to the hilt. It was very upsetting.'' He says he even used his ties to conservatives to go around the bureaucracy and met in 1983 with President Reagan, where he laid out his case against doing business with Ceausescu. ``The president seemed sympathetic and surprised, but unless he heard the same message day after day he wasn't about to act against his own secretary of state,'' Funderburk says; the ``groveling'' continued. The policy had started in the 1970s after Ceausescu distanced himself from Moscow on some issues. He maintained ties with West Germany, refused to break with Israel following the Six-Day War, refused to boycott the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles and declined to support Soviet interference in Czechoslovakia and Afghanistan. The Nixon administration rewarded Romania with most favored nation trading status. Ceausescu was courted with visits by Presidents Nixon and Ford, a lavish welcome to Washington from Nixon and Jimmy Carter and praise for his ``courage'' from a host of visiting U.S. officials. After Reagan's election, Funderburk, who had studied the Romanian language in college and worked in that country for the U.S. Information Agency, pressed Helms and other Southern conservative senators for the job in Bucharest. Upon arriving in Bucharest, he began warning that Ceausescu's stance as a maverick was a sham, that ``behind the scenes he was closely collaborating with the Soviets.'' No one listened, he says, because of the department's distaste for Helms. Career diplomat Francis B. Corry, assigned to serve as Funderburk's deputy, agrees. The ambassador ``had three strikes against him,'' says Corry, now retired. Corry says the Ceausescu policy was based on a dubious assumption _ that Romania could be free of Soviet domination. But reversing policy 10 years later would have given Washington ``the moral high ground,'' but nothing else, he says. ``Ceausescu was blackmailing us.'' With Corry's help, Funderburk says he sent a stream of messages to Washington detailing Ceausescu outrages. ``I told them that he was demolishing churches and synagogues, that he killed pastors and priests on a regular basis,'' says Funderburk. ``Ceausescu had a typewriter registration policy, a `scientific diet' which left the people malnourished, a policy of forcing women to have four or five babies or pay a penalty. Peasants were executed for no crime at all _ for pilfering a few pieces of grain because they were on the verge of starvation. ``But my reports weren't reaching the top people; they certainly weren't being factored into our relations.'' Frustrated, Funderburk quit as ambassador, wrote a book about his experiences and ran unsuccessfully for his state's Republican nomination to the Senate. Ultimately, in 1988, Congress and the administration moved toward revoking most favored nation status for Romania. Anticipating the rebuke, Ceausescu renounced the special status. Funderburk remains appalled at U.S. policy. ``We rushed in with a new ambassador and recognized the provisional government,'' he says. ``Most of those characters are people who worked with Ceausescu. Here we are propping up a communist government composed of people the people hate. We don't learn anything.''

DOC.HEAD: Conservation Group Says Many Farmers Favor Soil-Saving Methods
DOC.TEXT: The American Farmland Trust says soil-saving methods of producing crops rate well among many farmers but that there is a high degree of skepticism about tougher federal restrictions on chemical use. The private, non-profit conservation group said Sunday that ``substantial numbers of farmers across the country are interested in, and currently employing, a variety of environmentally benign, sustainable agricultural practices.'' But the report acknowledged that there are wide variations among farmers, depending on the kinds of crops involved and on geographic locations. For example, only 20 percent in one area used rotation plans while the majority in other areas followed the soil-saving practice. The project was based on personal interviews lasting for more than an hour with 489 farmers randomly selected in five major production areas in Butte County, Calif.; Whitman County, Wash.; Renville County, Minn.; Livingston County, Ill.; and Dooly County, Georgia. Questioners asked about methods used by the farmers in 1988, the most recently completed crop season, including their views on the potential environmental threats that might occur. The American Farmland Trust, which was founded in 1980, said it did not design the questions or interpret results ``with any hostility toward use of chemical fertilizers and pesticides.'' It said the study was undertaken in preparation for the 1990 farm bill debate under way in Congress. Environmental issues, including potential hazards of agricultural chemical pollution, are expected to have high priority. Over many years, report said, chemicals ``have brought great benefits to American agriculture and consumers'' and are ``essential for financial viability'' in most farming situations today. ``However, there is widespread evidence that an over-dependence on (chemical) use has developed and much effort is today devoted to seeking ways to enable farmers to economize on use of chemicals and fertilizer,'' the report said. Last September, the National Research Council issued a 450-page report, ``Alternative Agriculture,'' which advocated reduced use of farm chemicals and more soil-saving practices such as crop rotation. The NRC report recommended changes in farm policies to help encourage the alternative methods of production. The NRC report has drawn criticism from some quarters on grounds that some of its findings and recommendations were based on inadequate research and, in some cases, one-sided assumptions. At its national convention in Florida recently, federation president Dean Kleckner expressed skepticism of ``the concept of low-input sustainable agriculture'' and alternative farming methods. ``Conventional agriculture, so carefully developed through a partnership between our land-grant colleges and farmers themselves, is indicted as inefficient and wasteful,'' he said. ``This simply is not true.'' The Agriculture Department was one of the sponsors of the American Farmland Trust study, although most of the financing came from private foundations. The USDA currently is developing LISA, or ``low-input, sustainable agriculture'' as an alternative to heavy use of crop chemicals and other practices that jeopardize soil and water resources. Some research findings show that many farmers ``apply excessive amounts of fertilizers or pesticides because they lack adequate information about what their fields really need or because they use very high applications as a form of insurance,'' the report said. ``Moreover,'' it added, ``in some situations, the threat or actuality of ground water or surface water pollution is high enough that a reduction in the use of chemicals may be necessary for health reasons.'' Crop rotation, long recognized as a way to build up soils, was used by a majority of the farmers in four of the five areas, with 54 percent to 82 percent employing the practice in 1988, the report said. The exception was in Butte County, Calif., where only 20 percent of those interviewed used rotations. Farmers were also asked whether they followed recommendations of fertilizer dealers or those of the federal-state cooperative extension services. ``Among interviewed farmers, there were many more clients of fertilizer dealers than there were takers of advice from (the) cooperative extension service,'' the report said. Although 75 percent to 90 percent of the farmers favored changes in USDA commodity programs that would permit planting more acres in rotation without losing base acres used to compute federal crop benefits, most drew the line at a regulatory crackdown on excessive chemical use. One option would require farmers have an approved plan for managing pesticide use if crop chemicals were found in their well water. It was rejected in all five survey sites.

DOC.HEAD: Valdez Captain Says He's Gotten Bum Rap
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 2-3 with 2 grafs to include specific trial date, Jan. 29
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Tanker Spill
DOC.TEXT: The former captain of the tanker that caused America's worst oil spill said he's tired of being portrayed as ``a drunken bum with a parrot on my shoulder who drove his ship aground.'' Joseph Hazelwood _ whose trial in Anchorage, Alaska, on charges stemming from the March disaster is scheduled to begin Jan. 29 _ also said he has received death threats at his home in Huntington on Long Island. ``I'm handling infamy reasonably well,'' the Exxon Valdez' former skipper said in Life magazine's February issue. ``But it's amazing how it won't go away.'' He said Exxon Corp. has made him a scapegoat, and said he had been surprised at the time it took to begin cleaning up the spill. Hazelwood, who has a history of alcohol abuse, has been accused of drinking the night the Exxon Valdez hit a reef in Alaska's Prince William Sound, spilling nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil. Prosecutors also say he should have been at the helm since he was the ship's only authorized navigator for the sound. His attorneys say the Coast Guard relaxed the rules in 1986. The 43-year-old mariner faces more than seven years in prison if convicted and $65,000 in fines. Asked if he expected he would get justice, he replied, ``You mean like a Frank Capra movie?'' Hazelwood, who was once Exxon's youngest tanker captain and received two safety awards for his handling of the Valdez, told Life he suddenly found himself depicted as ``a drunken bum with a parrot on my shoulder who drove his ship aground or turned it over to the cabin boy and said `Whoopee, call me when you get somewhere.''' Hazelwood said he was ``flushed down the toilet in two-a-day press conferences'' by Exxon officials trying to give the impression ``that containment and cleanup were my responsibility as well.'' ``For three days, until Easter Sunday night when the wind came up, that big puddle of oil didn't impact the shore,'' he said. ``I was shocked by the lack of response initially. Angry and amazed.'' Since being fired by Exxon, he has made his living lobstering off Huntington Bay. However, having been at sea 15 of the last 20 years, he complains that he can still see the shore. ``These last nine months are the longest I've ever been ashore,'' he said. ``I've always felt more comfortable at sea than I have on land.''

DOC.HEAD: Barry's Wife Promises to be With Him `Every Step of the Way'
With PM-Barry, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry's admission that he needs help following his arrest on a drug charge is ``just the beginning,'' says his wife Effi, who promises to stand by him during the most difficult time of his life. ``Marion, for you to admit to the world that you have a problem ... is truly a burden that has been lifted from our souls,'' she said Sunday. ``Your admission of the fact that you need help is the first step.'' At St. Timothy's Episcopal Church hall, the mayor said he was facing the most difficult time of his life. His wife stood beside him, gazing at him with a pained but respectful expression. Frequently during the emotional event, Barry turned to his wife, took her hand and squeezed it. With a faint smile, Mrs. Barry patted his hand comfortingly and whispered to him. Following her husband's statement, Mrs. Barry announced that she and their son Christopher, 9, would stand by him. ``For our family, this is just the beginning,'' she said. ``And we ... will be with you every step of the way.'' The tumultuous events of the past several days have been nothing new for her. For 12 years, she has defended her husband and blasted his critics and the media. Although she has complained of the strain of being the wife of the mayor of the nation's capital, she has helped smooth the rough spots in her husband's often controversial career. She has said that the best image was control. Friends and reporters who have interviewed her frequently said her strength was derived from spiritualism and the belief that her friends would be there when she needed them. ``She knows she has a lot of friends to call on and can draw on our strengths,'' Ruby McZier, a lawyer and good friend. ``It is a spiritualism plus sisterhood, unspoken, but deeply felt.'' The mayor asked the city of Washington on Sunday ``to be willing to forgive'' him, as his wife has done many times during his tenure. Effi Cowell Barry, 45, married Barry in February 1978, a few months before he was elected to his first term as mayor. A native of Toledo, Ohio, she was working as an environmental health inspector at the time of their marriage, but has also been employed as a school teacher and model. ``I think what gives her strength is her love for Marion and her undying love for Christopher,'' one of the child's godparents, Peggy Cooper Cafritz, told The Washington Post. ``She would lay down her life for him, whether that means suffering, time, holding her family together against all odds or shielding him from the public,'' said Cafritz, chairman emeritus of the District of Columbia Commission on the Arts and Humanities. When Barry was arrested Thursday night in a hotel room, he was with a woman who was cooperating with authorities. During an interview with WRC-TV in 1987, Mrs. Barry talked about Barry's association with other women. ``Since Day One, I mean, since the day we got married, he's always been involved with other women ... so they say,'' she said. ``It's difficult. And there are _ there is _ a caliber of female in this world ... (who) tend to gravitate towards a power figure. This kind of involvement is a necessary nuisance that the wife of a power figure has to deal with.'' During the same interview, she discussed her husband's relationship with Karen Johnson, a convicted dealer who Barry admitted was a personal friend. ``He states that it was a non-intimate affair, and if he chooses to describe it as that, I will accept it,'' she said. ``What I blame him for is indiscretion.''

DOC.HEAD: Career Diplomats Get Two-Thirds of Ambassadorships
DOC.TEXT: Career diplomats got two-thirds of the ambassadorships during President Bush's first year and are likely to receive almost all the embassy openings for the rest of his term, the White House personnel director says. Charles G. Untermeyer said Sunday that despite criticism from Democrats about ambassadorships being awarded as plums to the Republican Party's biggest benefactors, Bush has achieved his goal of putting diplomatic newcomers in no more than one-third of the U.S. embassies. From now on, ``close to 100 percent'' of ambassadorial appointments will go to career foreign service officers, Untermeyer said in an interview. ``Henceforth, for the rest of the first Bush term, I expect very, very few non-career nominations,'' he said. By Untermeyer's count, 97 of the 145 ambassadorships have gone to career diplomats, or 67 percent. Ninety-three are already in place, one is awaiting Senate confirmation and three are still getting cleared before they are formally nominated. Forty-eight ambassadorships have gone or will go to non-career people: 42 have been confirmed, two are awaiting Senate confirmation and four are in the White House clearance process. One of Bush's appointees, Ruth Washington, the ambassador to Gambia, was killed Saturday in an auto accident in New York state. Untermeyer said that 10 or fewer of the non-career envoys ``were what you could call major donors,'' including several who made the GOP's ``Team 100'' by giving $100,000 or more to the party for the 1988 election battle. They included real estate developers Melvin Sembler, now ambassador to Australia, and Joseph Zappala, now envoy to Spain. ``Many of the non-career people are there for past proven loyalty to George Bush,'' said Untermeyer, but their ranks include such ``relatively poor people'' as Evelyn Teegan, a former Republican national committeewoman from Minnesota who is now ambassador to Fiji, and Sally Novetzke, a party activist and longtime Bush loyalist from Iowa who is ambassador to Malta. Sen. Paul S. Sarbanes, D-Md., objected to several of Bush's politically connected nominees last year and managed to block Joy Silverman's nomination to be ambassador to Barbados. She gave $180,000 to Republican causes before the last election. Untermeyer said the White House has not yet decided whether to resubmit her nomination. The percentage of non-career envoys is down from roughly 40 percent at the end of the Reagan administration, said Untermeyer. The 33 percent goal was achieved recently when Bush nominated a career diplomat, Edward Rowell, to be ambassador to Luxembourg, long a post reserved for presidential pals. Originally, Bush nominated his chief campaign fundraiser, Frederick Bush _ no relation _ to the Luxembourg post. But the Senate batted that nomination back in August after Frederick Bush came under scrutiny for contracts he received from the Reagan administration's scandal-ridden Department of Housing and Urban Development. Theodore S. Wilkinson, president of the Foreign Service Association, which represents foreign service officers, said the non-career appointments have been ``very uneven. There's some very good ones and some very inexperienced ones.'' By law, Wilkinson said, even the non-career appointees are supposed to be knowledgeable about the history, economics, politics and language of the country they are assigned to. ``Some don't seem to meet those criteria,'' said Wilkinson. With Congress returning from a two-month recess, Untermeyer said the White House will send up 30 nominations on Tuesday. Some Democrats accused Bush last year of running ``a Swiss cheese government'' and taking too long to fill vacancies. But Untermeyer said only 5 percent of the 659 top jobs in Cabinet departments and independent agencies now are vacant. Untermeyer said 327 Bush nominees have been confirmed or appointed; 142 jobs were filled by Reagan holdovers; 42 are awaiting Senate confirmation; 113 are in the White House clearance process; and 35 are vacant.

DOC.HEAD: Justice O'Connor Stricken by Apparent Involuntary Shaking of Head
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor sometimes seems to be shaking her head involuntarily from the bench, and although other people have noticed and mentioned it to her, she says she is not aware of it. Court spokeswoman Toni House said O'Connor has not seen a doctor about it and ``she certainly in no way believes it impedes her ability to do her job.'' Attorneys and others attending the court's oral argument sessions first noticed O'Connor's head-shaking in 1985. It seems to have become more pronounced in recent months. The justice answered, through her spokeswoman, several questions posed to her by The Associated Press about the matter. ``She has never had it diagnosed. She is not personally aware of any such head-shaking but she has had people tell her so,'' Ms. House said. The shaking, while not constant, is noticeable when it does occur. It is an up-and-down motion, similar to that made by someone nodding in the affirmative. When asked about the shaking in 1986, O'Connor said simply that she was unaware of it.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 37,257.01, up 420.47 points, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Nominate Kolstad Permanent Head of NTSB
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will end a long stalemate with Congress over who should run the National Transportation Safety Board when he nominates James Kolstad as chairman, a White House official said. Bush will make the nomination today, Charles G. Untermeyer, director of presidential personnel, told The Associated Press on Sunday. Kolstad, a former vice president for public relations of Frontier Airlines, has been acting chairman of the NTSB since Aug. 14, 1988, when Jim Burnett failed to win Senate approval for a fourth two-year term as chairman. The agency has been struggling with a shrinking investigative staff and a tight budget as it tries to fulfill its mandate to learn the causes of the nation's worst accidents in the air, sea and on land. One board member, Joseph Tribbe Nall, was killed Nov. 28 in a plane crash in Caracas, Venezuela, where he had gone to give a speech. The Senate failed to act last year on Bush's nomination of Susan Coughlin to the board. Sen. Wendell Ford, D-Ky., chairman of the Senate aviation subcommittee, never held a hearing on her nomination. Ford reportedly favors the Kolstad nomination. Untermeyer predicted that the Kolstad nomination will untie the Coughlin nomination as well.
DOC.HEAD: Survey Finds Alcohol, Drug Use Decline, Activism Increases
DOC.TEXT: A study says college freshmen are becoming more conservative about drugs and crime but more liberal about legalized abortion, environmental issues and student activism. The 24th annual survey of entering college freshmen conducted jointly by UCLA's Higher Education Research Institute and the American Council on Education, released Sunday, found an ``abrupt change'' in student attitudes about legalized abortions. Support for legalized abortion, which had remained fairly stable _ between 53 percent and 59 percent _ since 1977, jumped sharply between the 1988 and 1989 surveys, from 57 percent to 64.7 percent. ``An abrupt change in student attitudes of this magnitude in just one year is most unusual,'' said Alexander W. Astin, professor of higher education at UCLA's Graduate School of Education and the survey's director. ``It may well reflect the students' growing concern about the current Supreme Court's position on this highly charged topic.'' The survey found that six out of every seven of those questioned felt `the federal government is not doing enough to control environmental pollution.'' And 78.2 percent of the students endorsed greater governmental efforts to control handguns _ a new question asked for the first time in 1989. Support for abolition of the death penalty continued its sharp decline, as did student use of drugs and alcohol. The survey found a growing tendency toward greater student activism. The 1989 national survey is based on the responses of 216,362 students at 403 of the nation's two- and four-year colleges and universities. These data have been statistically adjusted to reflect the responses of the 1.6 million first-time, full-time students entering college as freshmen in the fall of 1989.
DOC.HEAD: Schools, Jobs for Women Sought to Hold Down Population
DOC.TEXT: A report by the Population Institute says more schools and more jobs for women would do most to hold down massive growth in the numbers of people in the Third World. The report released Sunday found a link between ignorance and overpopulation. ``The population explosion is no longer a prediction. It's already here,'' according to the institute, an advocacy group on this issue. The study noted that last year the world's population increased by over 90 million people. Wealthy countries like the United States have ignorant people as well as the Third World, though they are fewer. The report said that among people in some industrial countries, one in 10 is ``functionally illiterate,'' meaning they can read and write some but cannot follow printed instructions or write a simple letter. The report said about 900 million of the world's 5.5 billion people cannot read, and that almost two out of every three illiterates are women. The study reported that women who get only one or two years of school tend to have more surviving children rather than fewer, suggesting that even a little education helps a mother keep her babies alive. Women who stay at school longer get married later and know more about contraceptives, the report said. The study was prepared by Harold N. Burdett, the institute's director of information, and Werner Fornos, its president.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Stocks Rocket Up, Dollar Rises Too
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with closing stocks, dollar; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange soared Monday, while the dollar rose marginally against the Japanese yen. The dollar closed at 146.42 yen, up 0.09 yen from Friday's 146.33-yen close. It opened at 146.35 yen and ranged between 146.35 yen and 146.55 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average recaptured the 37,000-point mark, gaining a hefty 420.47 points, or 1.14 percent, to end the day at 37,257.01. The Nikkei, which had nearly reached the 39,000-point level last year, has fallen below 37,000 points after a series of plunges due to rumors and declines in Japanese bond prices resulting from the weak yen. Despite Monday's early recovery in the Nikkei, the market condition has not improved much because of uncertainties over the coming election, dealers said. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is expected to dissolve the 512-member House of Representatives Wednesday, with balloting set for Feb. 18, local media reported. ``The recovery is not for real,'' said a trader with Nomura Securities, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``The index seems to have hit the bottom for now, but the market is still vulnerable and investors have little incentive to buy. This will continue until the election.'' In currency dealings, the dollar opened higher as market players bought the dollar as a safe investment amid uncertainties over the ethnic disputes in the Soviet republic of Azerbaijan, traders said.
