Market players in Tokyo were inclined to buy the dollar and sell the yen ahead of the election, said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. ``The Azerbaijan situation is losing impact on the market here and won't result in more dollar buying unless something extreme happens, such as (Mikhail) Gorbachev's resigning,'' he said. ``But the yen continues to be weak, as the election approaches,'' he said. Another trader with the Bank of Tokyo said, ``The yen is a currency that many investors will avoid buying this week,'' ahead of the scheduled dissolution of Japan's lower house of parliament. Meanwhile, Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno said the dollar's strength will be met with coordinated intervention by central banks of the Group of Seven nations including the United States, Japan, Britain and Switzerland. Speaking at a branch managers meeting Monday, Mieno said the yen's recent weekness is related to international political uncertainties.

DOC.HEAD: Valdez, Once Blanketed in Oil, is Buried Under Many Feet of Snow
With PM-Tanker Spill, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Man and the heavens have teamed up against Valdez, which in March suffered the world's worst oil spill and is buried under record snows _ 29 feet so far this winter. On March 24, the tanker Exxon Valdez piled up on a charted reef about 30 miles south of the harbor, bleeding about 11 million gallons of North Slope crude into the gin-clear waters of the Prince William Sound. Exxon's much-criticized cleanup ended in September. Then winter came. By the new year, drifts reached stocking cap level, plows turned city streets into long, white trenches, and snow crept halfway up first-floor windows. You couldn't say the town's 3,000 residents were surprised, however, since Valdez' average annual snowfall is 303 inches, or 25 feet. Only then it really started snowing. By late Friday, after many days of near-constant snowfall, the white stuff in the middle of town would have buried a bus. And still it came down. The weight of the snow was threatening to cave in roofs, and the city marshaled all able-bodied snow shovelers as quickly as they could be found. ``I'm looking out the window,'' said Jack Chappel, manager of a gas station in the middle of downtown. ``And every building I see except one has people on the roof removing snow.'' As of Friday afternoon, Valdez had received 349.3 inches _ 29 feet _ since October, said Tom Ward of the National Weather Service office. At least two months of winter remain, and the Valdez snowfall record of 384.7 inches could be buried under just one more medium-sized drift. On Jan. 16 alone, 47{ inches _ 4 feet _ of snow fell, a single-day record. The 134 inches so far this month shattered the January snowfall record, Ward said. One storm after another has blown in from the south and stalled over Valdez, trapped by the wall of mountains that rises above the town, Ward said. A weather service measuring stick showed the downtown snow depth Friday at 7 feet. But it was deeper than that in other parts of town. ``The snow is basically up to the bottom of your second-story window sills,'' said Police Chief Bert Cottle. Four vessels in the harbor, including a 40-foot pleasure boat, have sunk from the weight of snow on decks, Harbormaster Tim Lopez said. ``It's all we can do to keep the docks from sinking,'' he said. Valdez building codes require rooftops to withstand loads of 90 pounds per square foot, twice what's required in Anchorage. Whenever weights approach the limit, the Valdez public works department goes on the radio to warn people to get busy. They got on the radio last week. In a town built on economic booms _ from the Gold Rush to the pipeline to the oil spill _ the Big Snow has been a boomlet. At the start of winter, the going wage for snow shovelers in Valdez was around $7 an hour, said Doris Giusti, manager of the state Job Service office. ``Now we're up around $16 and even higher than that,'' she said. ``We've had jobs paying $20 an hour to shovel snow. People are getting desperate to get snow off.'' Workers have been imported from unemployment offices in Anchorage, Palmer, Glennallen and Tok, Giusti said. So much snow has fallen that shovelers are running out of places to stack it. The city, which was moved and rebuilt after the 1964 Good Friday Earthquake, was laid out so most of the streets end in cul-de-sacs along a park strip through the middle of town. Loaders and giant blowers pile the snow into mountains at the end of the streets. By the weekend some snow mountains reached almost as high as utility poles, residents said. Street signs are buried all over town, and cars have collided because drivers couldn't see around corners, police said. No one, however, has been badly hurt. ``We did have an individual fall off a roof yesterday,'' said Cottle, the police chief. ``He wasn't hurt very bad. When the snow's nine feet deep, there's not very far to fall.'' Despite the accumulation, Valdez has maintained its record for never closing school because of snow. ``You're not going to believe this, but it really hasn't caused us that much of a problem,'' said Harry Rogers, the school superintendent.

DOC.HEAD: Long-Exiled Royal Figures Hope for Thrones in Eastern Europe
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The chants of Eastern Europe's pro-democracy protesters as they ousted former Communist overlords have been sweet music to members of long-deposed royal families. The revolutionary changes of the past year have buoyed their hopes, nurtured during decades in exile, to reclaim their national stature and perhaps even return to the throne. Stifled under decades of Communist rule, their aspirations have now even gained some support at home. When a crowd spotted Otto von Hapsburg on a street in Budapest, Hungary, in April, it chanted ``Long Live the King!'' Romania's King Michael I waits for his people's call, and Albania's King Leka I would like to come home from South Africa. Indeed, von Hapsburg and King Michael appear to have a chance at public office _ if only honorary _ in their homelands. The prospect of restoring royalty, of course, is unthinkable to many citizens of Eastern Europe. Monarchists seem to be in the minority. Hungary plans to establish a multi-party democracy this year, and Romania has tentative plans to follow suit. In Romania, even the word ``dynasty'' smacks of repression, reminding most people of the clan of executed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. He ruled like an absolute monarch, installing family members in key positions. Bernd Posselt, von Hapsburg's spokesman, seemed to agree with public speculation that his boss might stand a chance to become Hungary's state president this year. He said ``all options are being kept open, and the matter is again under review.'' The aide spoke to The Associated Press in a recent telephone interview from Strasbourg, France. Hapsburg, the eldest son of King Karl VI of Hungary _ also Emperor Karl I of Austria _ is now a Bavarian deputy in the European Parliament. After the collapse of the Austrian Empire, the Hapsburg family had to leave Austria and settled in Switzerland. Two attempts by Otto's father to restore the kingdom in Hungary in 1919 and 1920 failed. During his first official visit to Hungary in February, von Hapsburg, who is fluent in Hungarian, received a hero's welcome. During the April visit, thousands of Hungarians cheered him again to chants of ``Long Live The King!'' as Otto and members of his family emerged from a church following a requiem for his mother Zita, the last queen of Hungary, who died in March at age 96. In Romania, the return of 67-year-old King Michael is seen by some Romanians as a guarantee that the Communist Party will never again come to power. On Dec. 22, the day Ceausescu was overthrown, the exiled king said he was ready to return to his country as head of a constitutional monarchy. ``I have been waiting for this for 40 years,'' he told a hastily convened news conference in Geneva, near his home in exile. ``If people want me to come back, of course, I will come back.'' Michael was forced to abdicate in December 1947 amid the prospect of civil war and pressure from the Kremlin and its Romanian Communist allies. Two of King Michael's exiled daughters, Sophie and Margarita, were privately visiting Romania on Sunday. Margarita was asked at a news conference whether she was surprised by being met at the airport Thursday by a group of Romanians shouting ``Long Live The King!'' ``I didn't know what to expect,'' she said. ``We were Romanians coming home _ that's the one thing that struck me.'' She stressed, however, that she and her sister ``have not come here in any bid to restore the monarchy _ I want that to be absolutely clear.'' ``My father has waited for 42 years to come back to his country as a Romanian, but as to when or how _ I don't think I can answer right now,'' she said. King Simeon II of Bulgaria, where the monarchy was abolished in 1946, said Wednesday he believes his return to his homeland would be premature. ``I'm no one to dictate or to impose conditions .... It's not up to me .... Anyway, it's too early for this question.,'' he said. ``And in another way I would at this point be much more useful abroad with my contacts and connections,'' the 52-year-old ex-king told the AP from his home in Madrid. By contrast, the Albanian would-be king is eagerly waiting for his hour of triumph at his home in a suburb of Johannesburg. King Leka, an exile for all his 50 years, believes political upheaval in the Soviet bloc will ignite an uprising among the people of Albania, the last hard-line Communist state in the region. Reports in Yugoslav and Greek news media about recent unrest and casualties in Shkodra and other Albanian cities have been denied by Albanian officials. If a revolution comes, Leka says, he would be proud to follow the footsteps of his father, King Zog I. Harold Brooks-Baker, publishing director of Burke's Peerage, the British bible of Europe's bluest blood, said last week that ``this upheaval in Eastern Europe is the last chance, in my opinion, that these contenders have to re-establish their thrones.'' ``The fact that King Michael and Otto von Hapsburg are immensely popular with political groups pushing for their restoration has moved this from fairy-tale stage to world stage,'' he told the AP in London. Grand Duke Vladimir, 72-year-old head of the Imperial House of Romanov and heir to the Russian throne, has even urged restoration of the Russian monarchy. On Friday, at a ball the Russian royal family held in London to raise funds for the Russian Orthodox Church there, Vladimir told a reporter: ``Russian people would think quite seriously about a monarchial form of government. A monarchy would be something for them to rally round.'' During the ball, the Imperial Russian anthem ``God Preserve the Czar'' was played _ over and over.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Mourns Death of Stanwyck at 82
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Stanwyck, the leading lady of film classics whose 60-year show business career began on the chorus line, ended in television and included a rich variety of roles, has died at age 82. ``She was marvelous and unfailingly professional, very demanding that everything be done as well as it could be,'' said Charlton Heston, who starred with Stanwyck in the television series, ``The Colbys.'' Miss Stanwyck died Saturday evening at age 82 of congestive heart failure at St. John's Hospital and Health Center in Santa Monica, said agent Larry Kleno. Stanwyck's career spanned the chorus line, vaudeville, motion pictures and television, earning her three Emmys and four Academy Award nominations. Her versatility _ running the gamut from mercenary murderess in ``Double Indemnity'' to horrified and helpless victim in ``Sorry Wrong Number'' _ gained Miss Stanwyck respect as a matriarch of the entertainment industry. Stanwyck's only Oscar was an honorary statuette presented in 1982 for the body of her work. And the American Film Institute gave her its most prestigious honor, the Life Achievement Award, in 1987. ``She was just the most wonderful (actress) in the whole business, and I worked with a lot of them,'' said Fred MacMurray, who plotted murder with Stanwyck in ``Double Indemnity.'' ``Everyone in this industry looked up to her as such a perfectionist,'' said actress Jane Wyman, a longtime friend. ``Her honesty in everything she did came through on the screen, but she never took credit for it. Her ego was never first. It was always her work.'' Actress Dorothy Lamour said, ``She was a wonderful human being and the industry lost something very great when it lost her.'' The youngest of five children, Miss Stanwyck was born Ruby Stevens on July 16, 1907, in Brooklyn, and was orphaned at age 4. She was raised by an older sister, Millie, a chorus girl who boarded her with other families when she was on the road. By the time she was 15 she was a floor show dancer in New York cabarets and with the Ziegfeld Follies. Playwright Willard Mack rechristened her Barbara Stanwyck after glancing at a playbill that read ``Jane Stanwyck in Barbara Fritchie.'' She married vaudeville comedian Frank Fay in 1928 and they adopted a son, Anthony Dion Fay. They divorced in 1935. She married Robert Taylor in 1939 and divorced him in 1951. Miss Stanwyck appeared in more than 80 movies starting in 1927. She was nominated for Oscars for ``Stella Dallas'' in 1937; ``Ball of Fire'' in 1942 with Gary Cooper; ``Double Indemnity'' with MacMurray and Edward G. Robinson in 1944, and ``Sorry Wrong Number'' with Burt Lancaster in 1948. Her co-stars were top leading men: Henry Fonda in ``The Lady Eve,'' James Cagney in ``These Wilder Years,'' Clark Gable in ``To Please a Lady,'' Errol Flynn in ``Cry Wolf,'' and Humphrey Bogart in ``The Two Mrs. Carrolls.'' She kissed Ronald Reagan passionately in ``Cattle Queen of Montana'' and was teamed with Elvis Presley in ``Roustabout.'' ``The Barbara Stanwyck Show'' ran on television from September 1960 to September 1961. She hosted the program of half-hour plays and appeared in most episodes. ``The Big Valley,'' a Western, ran from September 1965 to May 1969. Miss Stanwyck played Victoria Barkley, matriarch of the Barkley ranch and strong-willed mother of Jarrod, Nick, Heath and Audra. She also appeared on ``General Electric Theater'' during its eight-year run and was in ``The Colbys'' for one season in 1986. Miss Stanwyck garnered Emmys for ``The Barbara Stanwyck Show'' in 1961, ``The Big Valley'' in 1966 and the miniseries ``Thorn Birds'' in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Gordon Dorian looks and sounds like a typical smooth-talking car dealer as he strolls around the showroom of Mel Hambelton Ford, shaking hands with customers. But his name tag reveals he's a salesman of a different kind. It reads: ``Dr. Gordon Dorian, chaplain.'' Dorian is a retired Southern Baptist preacher who spends two or three days a week counseling some of the dealership's 115 employees. Dorian, 67, joined the dealership last May at the invitation of owner Mel Hambelton, who seven years earlier had been converted to the faith by Dorian, then pastor of Olivet Baptist Church in west Wichita. ``What's good for me might be good for other people,'' Hambelton said. Some employees weren't excited about the idea, but Dorian said he doesn't preach at employees and only offers advice when asked. Employees occasionally stop by his cubbyhole-size office to talk about personal matters. At other times, Dorian speaks with workers on the job, sometimes offering a spiritual pick-me-up. ``It may be just a quick prayer,'' he said, snapping his fingers. ``Just so it won't be obnoxiously noticeable.'' For his work, he receives a ``small token'' salary and the choice of any car on the lot to drive. Dorian's job is not limited to counseling employees. Sometimes he tries to soothe ruffled customers waiting for car repairs. ``I talk to people and sympathize with them,'' he said. ``But I tell them I know the guys, and they're doing the very best they can.'' Do customers ever ask him to lay hands on their cars for some less expensive healing? ``Yeah, they have,'' he said, laughing. ``We've had fun with it.''

Frances Leary says a policy of no heavy lifting helped her reach age 104. ``My mother always told me to be a good girl, and if she was here today she'd say `I guess you've been a good girl `cause you made it to 104,''' said Leary, who marked her birthday Friday. Leary, a lifelong Boston resident, worked in a shoe factory for 22 years before getting married at age 39. A music lover, she fondly recalled taking part in Irish dances in Boston ballrooms and remembered when phonographs replaced live music. ``I would listen to that thing for hours,'' she said. ``That's when I gave my piano away.'' Leary said she has never been sick a day in her life. When asked for advice on how to reach her age, she said: ``I just try to go along and not lift anything heavy.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks, Dollar Rise
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index surged back above 37,000 points today, and the dollar edged up against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average gained 420.47 points, or 1.14 percent, closing at 37,257.01. The Nikkei, which nearly had reached 39,000 points at the end of last year, turned around in early January and fell below 37,000 in a series of plunges triggered by rumors and declines in Japanese government bond prices resulting from the weak yen. Today, ``market players were no longer pessimistic about the Japanese government bond prices, and the index finally began rising, after so many losses,'' said Kazuyuki Suzuki, a dealer with Daiwa Securities Co. Suzuki said today's increase came in the absence of active selling. ``Some market players were still reluctant to buy actively, and the market has just begun to make up for the losses. Its energy hasn't returned to the normal level,'' he added. Trading was extremely thin, with only 350 million shares changing hands on the first section. The volume today was the lowest in five months, Suzuki said. ``The recovery is not for real,'' said a trader with Nomura Securities, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``The index seems to have hit bottom for now, but the market is still vulnerable and investors have little incentive to buy,'' he said. ``This will continue until the election.'' The markets are waiting to see the fate of the pro-business Liberal Democratic Party in elections for Parliament's lower house, expected Feb. 18. Last July, it lost its majority in the upper house for the first time in 34 years. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 146.42 yen, up 0.09 yen from Friday's 146.33-yen close. It opened at 146.35 yen and ranged between 146.35 yen and 146.55 yen. The dollar rose quickly in early trading as market players adjusted their oversold dollar positions, traders said. But the market then became concerned about possible central bank intervention to support the yen, and some players sold dollars to take profits, said Yuji Nakao, a trader with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. He said the dollar attracted investors more than any other currency amid ethnic troubles in the Soviet Union and political uncertainties here. ``The dollar was also stronger against the (West German) mark,'' he said. ``Market players sold the mark for profit-taking, as well as for fear of uncertainties in Eastern Europe.'' The German mark had been bought heavily as democratization movements progressed in the East bloc, but market players ``believe the key to such movements is the stability of (Mikhail) Gorbachev's leadership'' in the Soviet Union, Nakao said. About $5.72 billion changed hands in spot trading today.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Set Son Ablaze in Bungled Murder-Suicide Plan Set for Release
LaserPhotos SAN1, SAN2
DOC.TEXT: David Rothenberg is terrified, his mother is frantic and prison officials are uneasy. David's father, who set fire to his son in a bungled 1983 murder-suicide plan, walks out of prison this week. Six-year-old David survived the flames but was horribly disfigured. The jarring crime was portrayed in ``David,'' a 1988 ABC-TV movie starring Bernadette Peters and John Glover. If convicted under current laws, Charles Rothenberg would be imprisoned for life. But sentencing laws in place at the time force the state to release Rothenberg after less than seven years behind bars. ``We are not comfortable with it,'' said Tipton Kindel, spokesman for the state Department of Corrections. ``The crime was absolutely disgusting to the rest of society, and we are not entirely comfortable with him walking free. ``It makes it seem like the Department of Corrections is letting him go, but that isn't so. We have to let him go.'' Rothenberg, 49, leaves the state prison in San Luis Obispo on Wednesday, but prison officials are keeping relocation plans secret, conceding they fear a repeat of the 1987 Larry Singleton hysteria. Singleton, who raped a teen-age girl and left her for dead after hacking off her forearms with an ax, was driven from Northern California communities by an outraged public and eventually served his year on parole in a trailer at San Quentin Prison. After a telephone argument with his ex-wife, Rothenberg set fire to his son in a Buena Park motel room on March 3, 1983. ``If I can't have him, nobody else can,'' Rothenberg said, telling authorities he was going to kill himself but was too much of a coward. ``Do I deserve to be set free? No! It's an unforgivable act,'' Rothenberg said in a December letter to the Los Angeles Times. Rothenberg said he didn't know where he was going to live during his three-years' parole. David, his mother, Marie, and stepfather, Richard Hafdahl, also are not being told where Rothenberg is resettling, except that he won't be within 25 miles of them, Kindel said. Hafdahl, a police officer who met David and his mother while supervising the fire investigation, said Marie and her son were upset. ``She doesn't trust him and David is terrified. We've talked about it and we have security measures I won't go into,'' Hafdahl said. Rothenberg had taken David, who lived in New York at the time, on vacation to Southern California, and checked them into a motel near Knott's Berry Farm. He gave the boy a sleeping pill, poured kerosene on the his bed, kissed him goodbye and struck a match in the doorway. He watched from a telephone booth across the street as flames consumed the motel room. David, dragged from the inferno by motel guests, suffered third-degree burns over 90 percent of his body. The boy, now 13, will have to endure periodic skin grafts until he is fully grown, Hafdahl said. Rothenberg was convicted of attempted murder, arson and other charges and got a maximum 13-year prison term that was halved because of good behavior. He will be closely watched while on parole. ``Although he's not confined to a prison, he will be under intense scrutiny to make sure he is complying with the conditions of parole,'' said Kindel. Rothenberg must stay away from his son, ex-wife and Hafdahl. He cannot leave his parole jurisdiction, must report regularly to his parole officer and he must submit to weekly psychiatric counseling sessions. ``I don't want to ever see you again because, you know, I'm afraid that you'll try to hurt me again,'' David told his father in a 1988 TV interview.

DOC.HEAD: Valdez Captain Says He Got Bum Rap
DOC.TEXT: Exxon Valdez Capt. Joseph Hazelwood has gotten used to the notoriety that came with command of the vessel involved in the nation's worst oil spill, but he's surprised at the tenacity of his critics. ``I'm handling infamy reasonably well,'' he told Life magazine for its February issue. ``But it's amazing how it won't go away.'' Hazelwood, who goes on trial Jan. 29 in Anchorage, Alaska, on charges stemming from the disaster, said he had received death threats at his home and was tired of being portrayed as ``a drunken bum with a parrot on my shoulder who drove his ship aground.'' The oil tanker captain, who has a history of alcoholism, has been accused of drinking the night of the accident, which spilled about 11 million gallons of oil into the Prince William Sound. He denies the claim and said Exxon Corp. has made him a scapegoat. Prosecutors said he should have been at the helm since he was the ship's only authorized navigator for the sound. His lawyers say the Coast Guard relaxed the rules in 1986. Hazelwood has pleaded innocent. He faces more than seven years in prison and $65,000 in fines if convicted. Asked if he expected justice, he replied, ``You mean like a Frank Capra movie?'' The 43-year-old skipper said Exxon has made him a scapegoat. He said he was ``flushed down the toilet in two-a-day press conferences'' by officials trying to give the impression ``that containment and cleanup were my responsibility as well. ``For three days, until Easter Sunday night when the wind came up, that big puddle of oil didn't impact the shore. I was shocked by the lack of response initially. Angry and amazed.'' Since getting fired by Exxon, he has made his living lobstering near his suburban Long Island home.

DOC.HEAD: Tug and Freighter Collide; Injuries, Possible Oil Leak Reported
DOC.TEXT: A freighter loaded with petroleum coke collided with a tugboat off Delaware and ruptured a fuel tank, but there was no indication of a major spill, the Coast Guard said. Two people aboard the 113-foot tug Socrates were injured when the vessels collided in the Atlantic 25 miles east of Cape Henlopen Friday evening. One suffered rib injuries and the other had a three-inch cut across the face, the Coast Guard said. The 593-foot freighter Doo Yang Leader was stopped at sea to check for leaks, said Coast Guard spokesman Breck Smith. The ship was carrying petroleum coke, a residue from a process that breaks down petroleum products. There was no indication of coke spillage, but Coast Guard Petty Officer Richard Minnich said the South Korea-registered freighter apparently had a ruptured fuel tank. ``We dont know how much oil is in the water right now or even if there is any,'' said Coast Guard Petty Officer John Brazelle in Cape May, N.J. The tug _ owned by Allied Towing Corp. of Norfolk, Va. _ sustained damage to its cabin, but was able to continue on toward New York, towing a 300-foot barge carrying sugar.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Patients Should Reach Normal Life Expectancy In 1990s
With PM-AIDS-Children, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: People with AIDS should reach normal life expectancy during the 1990s as treatments become available to make AIDS a manageable disease, a leading government researcher says. ``I have a good deal of confidence ... that we can look forward to the 1990s as the kind of a decade where that goal can be realized,'' said Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the national program to test and evaluate new anti-AIDS drugs. He spoke at the New York-Italy Medical Symposium in New York. Fauci is the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in Bethesda, Md., one of the National Institutes of Health. The institute operates a national AIDS drug-testing program in which some 10,000 people are subjects in experimental tests at 46 medical centers across the country. Learning to manage and control AIDS is not the same as curing it, Fauci said. The treatments of the 1990s probably will have to be contined for life in people infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, that causes AIDS, he said. Fauci said he based his optimistic prediction for the 1990s on the growing understanding of the workings of the AIDS virus, the success in AIDS treatment achieved so far, and a philosophical shift in the way government makes new drugs available. Until now, AIDS drugs have been developed largely by screening available substances for possible anti-viral activity, he said. The increasing understanding of how the virus infects cells, kills them and reproduces is leading to new drugs aimed directly at each of those steps in the virus' growth, Fauci said. ``Already there are several drugs ready to go into (human) clinical trials that have been specifically tailored to HIV,'' Fauci said. Fauci said researchers scored several successes against AIDS during the 1980s. First, they improved care of the sick. In 1985, less than 40 percent of people diagnosed with AIDS survived 18 months. By 1987, 60 percent lived at least that long after diagnosis, Fauci said. Second, researchers discovered that treatment could be helpful in people who are infected with HIV but have not yet become sick. For example, drugs to protect against pneumocystis carinii pneumonia, an often fatal AIDS complication, can now sharply reduce its frequency. AZT, the current mainstay of treatment in people sick with AIDS, has been shown to significantly delay the progression or onset of symptoms in people infected with HIV but not yet sick, Fauci said. There are now ``hundreds of thousands who can benefit from early intervention,'' he said. Third, the government has decided to relax its grip on experimental drugs in cases where the drugs offer hope to people whose lives are threatened and who have few other options, Fauci said. He was referring to the so-called ``parallel track'' program, in which promising experimental drugs are made available to patients who need them before experiments have conclusively determined their effectiveness. ``This is a philosophical change that needs to be integrated into our way of thinking,'' he said. It means that the government will not be able to guarantee the effectiveness _ or the safety _ of those drugs, Fauci said. The responsibility for accepting the increased risks associated with such drugs ``is going to shift to the individuals taking the drugs,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Snow in Northeast; Rain, Freezing Rain in Northwest
DOC.TEXT: Light snow fell today in parts of the Northeast from the remnants of a storm that hurled occasional lightning as it dumped as much as 10 inches of snow. Some airports were forced to close. Parts of the Upper Great Lakes region also had snow this morning, while rain and freezing rain fell in the Pacific Northwest. Dry weather prevailed throughout the rest of the nation. The clash of a warm front moving in from the Atlantic with a cold front coming from the west Sunday created the right conditions for a Northeast snowstorm that sometimes sounded like a summer cloudburst, said forecaster Charlie Foley of the National Weather Service in Boston. ``The two fronts are fighting each other, and that's the result,'' Foley said. ``It's an unusual occurrence, but not rare.'' Light snow continued falling this morning from northern New York to Maine, while rain was changing to snow on Cape Cod in Massachusetts. Snowfall totals by Sunday night included up to 10 inches in central, southern and coastal areas of New Hampshire; 9 inches in coastal communities north of Boston; and up to 8 inches in suburbs of Albany, N.Y. The snow forced Logan International Airport in Boston to close for nearly two hours. The commercial airport in Manchester, N.H., also was closed temporarily. Police throughout the region reported many minor accidents because of slippery roads. Operators of ski areas rejoiced. ``I just wish it had happened Friday,'' said Sabrina Patenaude of Pat's Peak in Henniker, N.H. In the Northwest, a small but energetic Pacific disturbance brought freezing rain to Spokane, Wash., and rain to Seattle this morning. The same system was expected to bring high winds to parts of the north central United States later today. A high-wind watch was issued for the mountains of northwestern Wyoming. Strong Santa Ana winds, meanwhile, developed in Southern California on Sunday. Clouds and light snow were over parts of the Upper Great Lakes region, with snow falling this morning in Sault Ste. Marie, Mich. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation, with clear skies over much of the south central and southwestern United States. Temperatures remained below freezing Sunday across parts of the Upper Mississippi Valley, the Upper Great Lakes region, and the northern Atlantic Coast region, with highs only in the teens and single numbers in Northern New England. The low for the nation Sunday was 6 degrees below zero at West Yellowstone, Mont. Temperatures warmed into the 50s and 60s in California and southern Arizona and across much of the south central and southeastern United States on Sunday, with readings in the 70s and 80s in Florida. Seven Florida cities broke records for high temperatures for the date. The high Sunday in the Lower 48 states was 88 degrees at Naples, Fla. DOC.HEAD: In A Pinch, Employees Of Connecticut City Get To Bring Kids To Work
DOC.TEXT: New administrations usually shake up city hall when they take office, but some municipal employees are worried it's the kids who will turn things topsy-turvy. A few weeks after Mayor Paul Gionfriddo was elected in November, the liberal Democrat announced that municipal employees would be allowed to bring their children to work in an emergency. With three children under age 5, Gionfriddo knew he would have to let his kids join him at the office occasionally, so it was only fair that other city workers have that right. The policy has provoked considerable debate, and employees who say they might take advantage of the new rule are hard to find. ``To be honest, I don't think I'd bring them in here. I don't think I could get any work done,'' said Teresa Milardo, a Tax Department clerk who keeps pictures of her two daughters, ages 2 and 6, in a plastic frame on her desk. ``With the 2-year-old, where would I change her diaper?'' Milardo asked. ``Besides, she'd constantly want to go to the water fountain. It would be a distraction for everyone.'' Gionfriddo's son Timothy, 4, and 3-year-old daughter, Larissa, already have visited at least twice. They spent most of the time coloring or pecking away on typewriters. Once it was because the mayor's wife had to take their youngest child, a 6-month-old, to the doctor on a day when the two others were not in day care. ``Even the best day-care arrangements fall short of the need. When there are sicknesses or holidays, you have to have some kind of backstop,'' said the 36-year-old mayor, whose wife is a consultant and scholar on child development. A police sergeant working as a desk supervisor became the first municipal employee in this central Connecticut city of 43,000 to take advantage of the policy. George R. Dingwall's pregnant wife brought their 3-year-old daughter, Alyssa, to the station for a couple of hours Jan. 10 when she had to make a visit to the doctor's office on short notice. Alyssa showed up with a Barbie doll and other toys, and spent her time quietly watching ``Sesame Street,'' munching cookies and getting a tour from civilians in parking and records, Dingwall said. Reaction was generally favorable, he said, and ``I wouldn't hestitate to do it again if the same circumstances presented themselves.'' The mayor's order stipulates that a child must stay inside with his or her parent or grandparent, as the case may be, and not interfere with anyone's work. When possible, the employee is supposed to get permission of a supervisor beforehand. Political rivals pounced on the edict as an early sign voters erred in choosing Gionfriddo, an 11-year veteran of the legislature, over the incumbent mayor, Republican Sebastian J. Garafalo. The policy was lambasted in The Hartford Courant, which accused the mayor in an editorial of trying to turn city hall into a playpen. But The Middletown Press called the plan a gutsy move that was worth a try. A psychologist at Yale University, who is a colleague of Gionfriddo's wife, also came to the mayor's defense. ``I think it is a kind of experimental effort that ought to be applauded rather than decried,'' said Edward F. Zigler, one of the architects of the federal Head Start program. Gionfriddo's wife, Linda Rammler, is working on her doctorate in developmental psychology and is a fellow at the Yale child development center that Zigler directs. The mayor acknowledged that some workers suggest he instituted the policy only to justify the presence of his own children. And he said he recognizes that many workers have jobs that simply won't allow them to bring their children to work. ``It's clear that a policeman on patrol or a someone riding a snowplow won't benefit from this,'' he said. ``But you don't deny everyone the opportunity because they can't.'' ``It's far better to have the secretary at work with the kids than sitting at home.''

DOC.HEAD: Race-Baiting Alleged In New Orleans Race
DOC.TEXT: In a campaign marked by charges of race-baiting, Sidney Barthelemy, a black mayor seeking re-election in a mostly black city, faces a strong challenge from a white who never ran for office before. Donald Mintz, a lawyer who last year resigned as chairman of the local dock board so he could run for Barthelemy's job, is expected to carry a majority among whites, who make up 44.4 percent of the 237,342 voters registered for the Feb. 3 election. Once an ally of the late Dutch Morial, the city's first black mayor, Mintz has worked aggressively to lure black voters away from Barthelemy. Mintz's campaign first accused Barthelemy of trying to separate the city along racial lines in November, when a coalition of black ministers endorsed Barthelemy. ``The minister that I follow is the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, and he judged a person on the content of their character and not the color of their skin,'' said Mintz' campaign manager, Michael Bagneris, who is black. ``If race-baiting is wrong when white folks do it, it's wrong when black folks do it.'' The issue resurfaced this month, when Barthelemy's campaign ran a series of radio advertisements praising his record of promoting and appointing blacks. ``Let us not be fooled by the claims of a white politician,'' two of the ads say. Mintz replied: ``It's fraud to stand up here and say, `I'm against racism and anti-Semitism,' and then resort to tactics that racially divide the community.'' But Barthelemy's campaign manager, Reynard Rochon, said, ``The only person who keeps bringing up race in this election is Donald Mintz ... He's trying to use a psychological thing on the black community, making them feel like they're racist if they support Sidney.'' Barthelemy said in an interview that the ads just tell the black community what he has done for blacks. He accused Mintz of starting the race-baiting by distributing an anonymous flier showing Barthelemy with a half-white face. ``I know people in his campaign who said they put them out,'' Barthelemy said, though he would not name his sources. Mintz, who was unavailable for an interview, has denied anyone in his campaign published the flier, which he described as trash. While race has played a part in the campaign, high crime, low employment, and the political experience and competence of the candidates have been the major issues. In television ads, the Mintz campaign touts its man as a ``tough, capable leader,'' and cites a Fortune magazine article describing New Orleans as one of the nation's five worst-managed cities. Mintz blames Barthelemy for the city's loss of 20,000 jobs in four years and complains that low police morale has contributed to a rising crime rate. The city had 249 murders in 1989, a record for a single year. Barthelemy, who took office in 1986 facing a $30 million deficit left by the Morial administration, counters that he has brought New Orleans back from its worst depression ever, brought on by the collapse of the oil industry. He says projects begun under his mandate will bring in 12,000 jobs during the next few years. Barthelemy has hit hard at Mintz' lack of public experience, and said the New Orleans port lost hundreds of millions of dollars a year under Mintz. Early polls showed Mintz leading Barthelemy and also gave Morial, mayor from 1978 until 1986, a good chance of retaking the office he was not legally allowed to hold for three consecutive terms. Morial decided against running, however, and died of a heart attack the day before Christmas without making an endorsement. A poll taken for WWL-TV on Jan. 5 showed Barthelemy leading Mintz 44 percent to 33 percent, with the remaining 23 percent of the voters undecided.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``People have been carrying coffins from all quarters of the city and the closest suburbs to what was once called Lenin Square, now renamed Freedom Square.'' _ Leila Yunusov, spokeswoman for an informal Azerbaijani political organization, on a demonstration in Baku at which tens of thousands mourned the Azerbaijanis killed when Soviet troops stormed the city to put down a nationalist uprising.

``I'm going to find a way to heal my body, mind and soul.'' _ Washington, D.C., Mayor Marion Barry, who an aide said would enter a substance-abuse treatment program following his arrest on a cocaine-possession charge.

``Her honesty in everything she did came through on the screen, but she never took credit for it. Her ego was never first. It was always her work.'' _ Actress Jane Wyman on her close friend, actress Barbara Stanwyck, who died Saturday at age 82.

DOC.HEAD: 23 Dolphins Dead on Texas Coast, Cold May be Cause
DOC.TEXT: An expert says the Christmas freeze may be responsible for killing at least 24 bottlenose dolphins that were found floating or washed ashore in Matagorda Bay over the weekend. The kill is the worst on the Texas coast in a decade, officials said. Volunteers on Sunday helped pull the carcasses from Matagorda Bay, about halfway between Galveston and Corpus Christi on the Gulf Coast. Experts from the Texas Marine Mammal Stranding Network planned to examine the carcasses today to determine what killed the animals, said Mike Carvan at the organization's office in Galveston. But tests could take months and the exact cause of death may never be known, officials said. The three-day freeze, which ruined much of the south Texas citrus crop and dumped snow on Houston, killed thousands of fish along the Texas coast. It may have doomed the dolphins as well, said Game Warden Arthur Lawrence. ``Several acres of this bay was covered with ice, a slushy-type of ice material _ and apparently it made it hard for these dolphins to breathe,'' said Lawrence. ``Some of them probably became disoriented and stunned as a result of this cold and icy weather and they can suffocate and suffer pneumonia just like a human.'' Game wardens worked during the freeze to break up ice in the marshy areas around the bay. A helicopter pilot spotted floating dolphin carcasses in Matagorda Bay late Saturday, Lawrence said. After an early morning search of the area Sunday, wildlife officials were unable to find any of the dolphins alive. ``I came out to check if the animals were in stress and found they were already partially decomposed,'' Lawrence said. ``It ain't fair. It ain't right,'' said H.F. Fuselier, a Matagorda fisherman, as he watched Coast Guard members hoist a 7-foot male dolphin's carcass into the bed of a pickup. Rose Folmar, a bartender at Allen's Landing in Matagorda who was helping monitor the recovery effort, said some volunteers doubted the freeze theory because it's been so long since the cold snap. ``That's what's puzzling,'' Ms. Folmar said. ``If the freeze was about a month ago, why are the dead dolphins showing up now? We won't really know until the biologists tell us after the autopsies.'' Others suggested that toxic pollutants from coastal industries might have contributed to the kill. Searchers also found thousands of dead mullet _ tough fish that normally remain in the bay during cold weather while prized redfish and speckled trout instinctively head for deep water.

DOC.HEAD: Newsweek: President, Family Deeply Divided Over Abortion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RESTORES dropped word in 2nd graf, picks up 3rd graf, `Bush opposes...
DOC.TEXT: The Bush family is split along gender lines on the issue of abortion, Newsweek magazine reports, with George and Barbara heading the opposing camps. President Bush and his wife discussed abortion at a recent get-together with their children and spouses and found all the men were anti-abortion and all the women were pro-choice, said the magazine, released Sunday. It did not name its source. Bush opposes abortion except to save the mother's life or in cases of rape or incest. He opposes federal funding of abortions except to save the mother's life. The president planned to address today's annual ``March for Life'' rally on the Ellipse by telephone from the Oval Office. He made a similar call in support of anti-abortionists last year, as former President Reagan did before him. Today is the 17th anniversary of the Supreme Court's Roe vs. Wade decision, which made abortion legal. Some of the women at the Bush family gathering, including the first lady, said abortion should not be without controls, but insisted on a woman's right to choose in certain circumstances, Newsweek said. White House spokesman Sean Walsh declined Sunday night to comment on the article. Mrs. Bush has refused to answer reporters' questions about her personal views on abortion. Some Republican strategists blame the party's hard-line stance against abortion rights for recent gubernatorial defeats in Virginia and New Jersey. Bush has said his opposition to abortion is unwavering, but that the Republican Party is large enough to embrace people with differing views on the issue.

DOC.HEAD: Students Battle Police in Protest Over Labor Arrests
DOC.TEXT: Radical students hurling firebombs and rocks today battled police after rallying with workers who are trying to inaugurate a nationwide union that the government has outlawed. The clashes erupted on five campuses in Seoul and three other cities where students called for a joint effort with militant workers to overthrow the government of President Roh Tae-woo. Hundreds of students and workers were arrested, but no police figures were available. In Suwon, about 25 miles south of Seoul, about 600 riot police rushed into a building of Sungkyunkwan University firing tear gas to break up an indoor rally by about 400 activists. Dozens of radical students brandished clubs and hurled rocks and chairs as police smashed windows and moved in. Yonhap, the South Korean news agency, reported about 100 workers and students arrested. The rally in Suwon was to have been held at Seoul National University by about 1,200 delegates claiming to represent 200,000 militant workers. But workers had to shift the site after about 2,500 riot police sealed the Seoul National campus. Police said about 15,000 riot police were mobilized in Seoul to thwart the rally there and arrest workers. Police were seen checking pedestrians around major campuses and bus terminals. Hard-line workers supported by dissidents and radical students have tried to form a new nationwide union to strengthen their influence. The government outlawed the union, accusing leftists of trying to use workers to strengthen their anti-government movement. In Seoul, groups of 50 to 300 students armed with firebombs mounted street protests in several places and clashed with police. Fighting also was reported from two campuses in Seoul and two others in the cities of Taegu and Chonju involving a total of about 1,500 students. Police arrested four dissidents who brandished firebombs, took a secretary hostage and occupied a Labor Ministry office in Taejon, Yonhap said. Shouting ``Overthrow the suppressive regime!'' the protesters jumped from the second-floor office to mattresses on the ground when police knocked down locked doors and charged in, it said. During the protests, students vowed to join a nationwide anti-government drive with workers to end what they called a prolonged pro-American military dictatorship in South Korea. In a special Cabinet meeting Saturday, Roh ordered firm action against any illegal and violent union activities. He warned that violent labor strikes would hurt the nation's already sluggish economy. Government officials contend some union activists advocate class struggle under an anti-U.S. and anti-government line espoused by radicals. Police have brought charges against 170 of about 6,000 workers rounded up last year for taking part in illegal, violent strikes.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher, Gold Prices Fall
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was higher against other major currencies in Europe late this morning, boosted by the absence of central bank intervention. Gold prices fell. Foreign exchange traders said the dollar was trading calmly after earlier forays higher in Tokyo trading failed to bring out the central banks. The dollar's rally is being fueled by continuing tensions in the Soviet Union and by increasing predictions that U.S. interest rates won't decline in the short-term as previously expected, dealers said. ``The certainty that U.S. rates are heading lower in the near term has disappeared,'' one Milan trader said. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.09 yen to a closing 146.42 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 146.30 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: _1.7185 West German marks, up from 1.7050 _1.5265 Swiss francs, up from 1.5140 _5.8418 French francs, up from 5.6955 _1.9366 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9310 _1,278.50 Italian lire, up from 1,269.25 _1.1815 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1786 In London, the dollar gained against the British pound. It cost $1.6443 to buy one pound, compared with $1.6475 late Friday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $409.00 a troy ounce, down from $410.25 bid late Friday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $408.70. In Zurich, the bid price was $408.65, unchanged from Friday's late bid. Gold in Hong Kong fell $1.50 to close at a bid $407.85. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.21 a troy ounce from Friday's $5.22.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Democracy Group Protests Despite Ban
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Mongolians demanding democratic reform from Communist rulers defied a government ban and rallied in their capital for a second straight week, a Western source said today. The source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said police made no attempt to break up the rally on the central square of Ulan Bator, despite the ban on such unauthorized assemblies imposed Thursday. Sunday's rally by about 5,000 people, organized by the Mongolian Democratic Union, lasted nearly two hours in temperatures of about minus nine. The union, which claims 70,000 supporters, has presented the first open, organized opposition to a government ruled by the Communist Party since 1921, longer than any other country outside Mongolia's patron state, the Soviet Union. The reform group organized two small demonstrations in December and another on Jan. 14 that drew about 5,000. It had official permission for all three of those gatherings. So far, both sides appear to be trying to avoid a confrontation, although the government's ban and the group's latest protest suggests they are hardening their positions. At Sunday's demonstration, people carried banners reading ``If people are rich, the Mongolian nation will be rich,'' and calling for an end to special privileges for officials. One banner written in English read ``We support perestroika and glasnost,'' a reference to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's programs of reform and openness. Another group calling itself the Democratic Socialist Movement and saying it was more radical than the Democratic Union passed out fliers calling for a free press, a multiparty system, adherence to the U.N. Declaration on Human Rights, more independence in the economic sphere and greater protection of the national culture. Mongolia's economy and culture have long been dominated by the Soviet Union. The Russian Cyrillic alphabet was officially adopted in 1946. The traditional Mongolian script was banned until about five years ago. Many of Mongolia's 2 million people, dispersed across grasslands roughly the size of Western Europe, still have deep links to their herdsman traditions, and the nation's small amount of industry sprang largely from Soviet or East European aid. The leader of the Democratic Union, 27-year-old Sanjaasuren Zorig, speaking at a news conference after the rally, did not rule out confrontation with the government. However, he said his group puts ``great hopes on the sober minds'' of government leaders, according to the Western source. Zorig said his group regards itself as a guarantor for developing and deepening democracy in Mongolia and said it stands for a multiparty system. He blamed Mongolia's low level of economic development on central controls over the economy and state ownership of property.

DOC.HEAD: High School Athletes Begin Random Substance Testing
DOC.TEXT: Drug and alcohol tests were administered to 18 staff and school board members at Homewood-Flossmoor High School, and now it is the student athletes' turn. A lottery will select 15 athletes a week, starting this week, to be tested for alcohol and 10 drugs. Two of the samples will be checked for steroids. During the semester a total of 277 athletes will undergo screening in the school district south of Chicago. Football coach John Wrenn said the program already is working. ``Through the grapevine I've heard that some students have gotten help,'' Wrenn said. ``That's what this program is for, not to punish kids, but to get them help.'' Athletic director Ken Schultz submitted the first urine specimen Friday followed by the principal, Charles Smith, and 16 other administrators and school board members. The testing will cost $40,000 to $50,000, school officials said. It will be paid for through donations and increased ticket prices for football and basketball games. Athletes who fail the test will be evaluated by a drug conselor and will be suspended from school for 30 days if considered chemically dependent. They will be reinstated if they follow a treatment plan and pass a new test, but could be suspended for up to a year if they fail the follow-up test.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Readies Columbia and Satellite for Piggyback Ride to Florida
DOC.TEXT: The space shuttle Columbia and the 11-ton satellite it plucked from space are being prepared for travel to Kennedy Space Center in Florida, a NASA spokeswoman said. Ground crews were making special efforts to protect the shuttle's cargo for the voyage atop a jetliner, scheduled to begin Thursday. ``The work is proceeding very well. The orbiter appears to be very healthy, as does LDEF,'' spokeswoman Patricia Phillips said Thursday. She was referring to the Long Duration Exposure Facility, the rescued laboratory satellite. Columbia and five astronauts landed at this Mojave Desert military base early Saturday, ending a record-length shuttle flight of nearly 11 days. During the mission, the astronauts deployed a Navy communications satellite, then used the shuttle's robot arm to retrieve the LDEF, which soon would have fallen into Earth's atmosphere and burned if it had not been rescued. About a third of the LDEF's 57 experiments will help researchers learn what materials can withstand long periods in space and thus might be suitable for building U.S. space station Freedom, which NASA hopes to operate in the mid-1990s. The satellite will not be removed from Columbia's cargo bay until after the shuttle returns to Florida on Friday night, riding piggyback atop a modified Boeing 747. Phillips said NASA hopes the piggyback jet ride will start early Thursday, with a refueling stop at Davis-Montham Air Force Base near Tucson, Ariz., before stopping for the night at Kelly Air Force Base near San Antonio. On Friday, the shuttle will refuel at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida's panhandle before finally arriving at Kennedy Space Center, she said. To protect LDEF from contamination, ground crews started pumping cool, conditioned air and nitrogen into the cargo bay even before Columbia was towed off the concrete runway Saturday morning, Phillips said. National Aeronautics and Space Administration and contractor employees worked on Columbia on Sunday while it sat inside the large steel girder structure called the mate-demate device, where it will be mounted atop the jet later in the week. ``Overall, the vehicle is in excellent condition. Any damage is minimal,'' Phillips said. She said the number of ``dings'' found on the orbiter's heat-shield tiles was below average: 85 dings smaller than one inch, eight larger ones and one tile requiring replacement.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT typo in `American' in lead; CORRECT style on dateline, other minor editing, subs for NEW YORK-dated 2nd item in rdp.
DOC.TEXT: Frederick Charles Shrady, a sculptor who was the first American to create a work of art for the Vatican Gardens, died Saturday of cancer at Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut. He was 82. In 1982, John Paul II commissioned Shrady to do a 12-foot marble statue of Our Lady of Fatima. Another of Shrady's public scultures was in the Washington headquarters of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. A third, a green bronze figure of Mother Elizabeth Seton, the first American-born saint, stands at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York. A funeral Mass by Cardinal John O'Connor was planned for Wednesday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

DOC.HEAD: Priest Relieved of Duties Following Testimony
DOC.TEXT: A Roman Catholic priest who testified on behalf of a former homosexual lover on trial on a rape charge has been relieved of his religious duties. The Rev. David R. Johnson, 36, said he knew testifying would jeopardize his career and devastate his family, but he was concerned Charles Neff, 22, could be imprisoned for a crime he did not commit. ``I thought to myself, if the Lord could be in my position _ bizarre as it is _ what would he do in my situation?'' Johnson said. ``Would he not testify, would he testify and lie, or would he testify and tell the truth? ``The choice I came to was testify, tell the truth, only the truth, and live with what comes afterward.'' Johnson took the witness stand Thursday in the courtroom of Allegheny County Common Pleas Judge Robert Kelly and testified _ as did 11 other witnesses _ that Neff was drinking at a bar Nov. 26, 1988, at the time he is alleged to have raped a 21-year-old woman. Johnson also testified, under questioning by defense attorney H. David Rothman, that he and Neff had been lovers. Johnson met Friday with Bishop Donald Wuerl of the Catholic Diocese of Pittsburgh and requested _ and received _ an indefinite leave of absence. He was relieved of all priestly duties and responsibilities, including his role as chaplain at Forbes Regional Health Center in suburban Monroeville, said the Rev. Ronald Lengwin, spokesman for the diocese. The diocese plans to review Johnson's actions to determine his future as a priest, Lengwin said. Johnson, 36, a priest for 10 years, said he will return to his family's home in Pittsburgh. His decision, he said, is best for the church, his family and himself. ``I feel a sense of relief, like a weight has been lifted,'' he said. ``I want to be there for my parents and my brother.'' Frank said he met Neff a couple years ago during the Three Rivers Regatta. Until about a year ago, Johnson said he served as a counselor, friend and lover to Neff. Neff, 22, was charged about a year ago with rape, indecent assault, simple assault and unlawful restraint. Jurors are expected to begin deliberations later today after closing arguments. Neff has previous convictions for stabbing a girlfriend and soliciting a city detective for sex. He served 23 months in the county jail for the stabbing and was placed on probation for a year for soliciting the detective.

DOC.HEAD: Golden Globe Awards Give `Born on the Fourth of July' Oscar Edge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Another top...', to DELETE incorrect reference to character as a `spinster'; she was a widow. SUBS penultimate graf to CORRECT that Curtis, Danson won for best acting in comedy or musical series, sted best acting in a TV series. Corrects style on `miniseries,' minor recasting throughout.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Golden Globes-List
DOC.TEXT: Oliver Stone's anti-war drama ``Born on the Fourth of July'' got a boost toward Oscardom over the weekend, winning the top four Golden Globe trophies. The Hollywood Foreign Press Association honored ``Born on the Fourth of July'' for best dramatic movie, best screenplay, best director for Stone and best dramatic actor for Tom Cruise. Ron Kovic, the disabled veteran whose story was the basis of the film, accepted a trophy for the screenplay he won with Stone at Saturday's 47th Golden Globes ceremony. ``I didn't even know if I was going to get off the field and live,'' Kovic effused. ``This is the happiest day of my life.'' Cruise thanked Kovic, ``whose quest for this truth really drove this film,'' and all the Vietnam veterans who ``gave their souls for me.'' ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' a chronicle of Kovic's transformation from a patriotic soldier to a war protester, was 12 years in the making, Stone said. ``On nights like this, for just one fleeting moment, you know you did the right thing,'' he said. Golden Globe winners often capture the coveted Academy Awards. Last year, for example, ``Rain Man'' took two top Golden Globes and went on to dominate the Oscars. Nominations for the Oscars will be announced Feb. 14. Another top winner was ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' the account of a white Southern widow's relationship with her black chauffeur. It picked up three awards, including best musical or comic motion picture. Michelle Pfeiffer was named best actress in a dramatic motion picture for ``The Fabulous Baker Boys.'' ``The Little Mermaid'' won for the best original score and best original song. Julia Roberts, from ``Steel Magnolias,'' was best supporting actress in a movie and Denzel Washington won best supporting actor in a movie for ``Glory.'' Italy's ``Cinema Paradiso'' was named best foreign language film. In the television competition, the CBS series ``Murphy Brown'' won as best musical or comic television series, ABC's ``China Beach'' was named best dramatic TV series and ``Lonesome Dove'' won for best miniseries or television movie. The Golden Globe winners for acting in a dramatic series were Ken Wahl, the star of ``Wiseguy,'' and Angela Lansbury, who stars in ``Murder, She Wrote.'' Christine Lahti was named best actress in a miniseries or TV movie for her performance in ``No Place Like Home,'' a drama about a homeless family in America. Robert Duvall won for best actor in a miniseries or TV movie for ``Lonesome Dove.'' Other TV awards went to Ted Danson (``Cheers'') and Jamie Lee Curtis (``Anything But Love''), named best actor and actress in a television comedy or musical series. Amy Madigan captured the Golden Globe for best supporting actress in a series, miniseries or television movie for the TV movie ``Roe vs. Wade.'' Dean Stockwell took the prize for best supporting actor in a series, miniseries or television movie for his NBC show ``Quantum Leap.''

DOC.HEAD: East German Leader Agrees to Let Opposition Into Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with premier agreeing to let opposition in government, denials of coup report; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Communist Premier Hans Modrow bowed to pressure from opposition groups and agreed today to rebuild the East German government to include pro-democracy groups. Modrow's concession came one day after the Communist Party's No. 2 leader quit and called for the party's dissolution. The resignation followed an emergency meeting of the embattled party leadership, which made other moves to placate the populace by expelling ousted leader Egon Krenz and 13 other former Politburo members. The leadership, which replaced Communist hard-liners last year during a peaceful popular revolt, has been trying to appease an opposition movement that is upset with the pace of promised reforms. Modrow and opposition leaders also showed rare agreement in denouncing a report today by the mass-circulation West German newspaper Bild, which claimed army and secret police agents were jointly planning a coup. Ibrahim Boehme of the influential opposition Social Democratic Party told politicians a coalition with Communists and other established parties was possible ``if all parties and groups are prepared to enter the government on an emergency basis, without weeks-long negotiations.'' He made the comment at a session of weekly talks on reform between the government and opposition groups. East Germany's first free elections are to be held on May 6, but broad differences between the Communist-dominated government and opposition groups have delayed economic reform measures and hindered the transition to democracy. Modrow today proposed that the fractious political forces meet Wednesday to consider a new Cabinet. ``It is my intention to give a new quality to our cooperation,'' Modrow told representatives of more than a dozen fledgling parties and reform movements during today's talks between the government and the opposition. ``Our expectation of your constructive advice underscores this intention.'' ``I appeal to the representatives of the new parties at the round table ... to enter the government as Cabinet members in order to form a broad coalition,'' Modrow said. With his offer, Modrow has made clear that the Communists are willing to give up some of the ministerial posts they control to allow groups such as New Forum, the Social Democrats and other unofficial parties to gain a role in government. Communists now dominate the 27-member Cabinet led by Modrow, with 16 ministerial posts compared with four for the officially approved Liberal Democrats, three for the Christian Democrats and two each for the National Democrats and the farmers' party. Opposition groups have indicated they would take part in running the government only if they are offered ministerial posts. The Communists' attempt to keep their party from collapsing were compounded by Sunday's announcement that their No. 2 official, Wolfgang Berghofer, had abandoned the party with an ``urgent demand'' for the party's dissolution. Berghofer, 46, the party's deputy chairman since December and a leading popular reformer, resigned along with 39 other prominent party members from Dresden, of which he is mayor. The moves were expected to trigger mass defections from the party. Its membership in the country of 16.3 million people has plunged to 1.2 million from nearly 2.3 million in 1987. In a statement broadcast on West German's ARD television, Berghofer said: ``The citizens of the German Democratic Republic need trust and courage for the future, since tens of thousands are still leaving their homeland.'' About 30,000 East Germans have moved to West Germany this year, following an exodus of more than 340,000 in 1989. In his statement, Berghofer said he and the other party defectors would support ``social democratic'' principles. He is widely reported to be moving to the opposition Social Democratic party. Government television said Berghofer's move put the party's future in ``extreme danger.'' Modrow also announced the resignation of Communist Finance Minister Uta Nickel, the target of a criminal inquiry into alleged financial irregularities. Ms. Nickel has denied wrongdoing. The Hamburg-based Bild newspaper, in contending a coup was in the works, said a general strike could be used as the pretext for an armed takeover. ``I must decisively reject as provocation a report in today's Bild newspaper,'' Modrow said at the government-opposition talks today. Boehme of the Social Democratic party said the Bild report undermines public confidence in the government. New Forum delegate Ingrid Koeppe also criticized the report. About 60,000 anti-Communist protesters marched across the border Sunday to West Germany and back. ARD said about 60,000 people took part in the march across the border at Duderstadt near the West German city Goettingen. Police in Goettingen put the figure at between 20,000 to 25,000. Through their purges, the Communists appeared to be trying to further distance themselves from the repressive rule of Erich Honecker. At a day-long meeting that ended early Sunday, the Communists rejected demands to disband but offered the opposition ``co-responsibility'' in the government until the May elections. Krenz immediately appealed his expulsion. After replacing Honecker, he quickly opened the Berlin Wall on Nov. 9 and promised democratic reform. But he was ousted after six weeks in office.

DOC.HEAD: Communists In Bitter Debate About Abandoning Their Leading Role
DOC.TEXT: A Communist Party official today called on other disenchanted members to begin talks on forming a new political group more willing to embrace democracy. Slobodan Lang, a delegate to an important party congress to discuss the organization's fate, is among five delegates who have proposed that the party split into a reform-oriented Socialist Party and a traditional Communist Party. Lang called for Communists attending the national congress, which moved into its third day today, to meet and discuss the measure. The congress has been marked by bitter debate between hard-liners seeking to slow the pace of political change and liberals who say the Communists must give up their guaranteed leading role in society or risk intensified popular unrest. Communist government leaders say that whatever the outcome of the congress, they will press on with the introduction of a multiparty system and organize free elections for April in the Balkan nation of 23 million people. Debate was to begin today on amendments to a key reform document that declares the prty's willingness to relinquish its monopoly on power. The daily newspaper Vecernje Novosti said Lang and other reformers want the document also to declare the Communists' intention to divide into two parties. Communists from the liberal republic of Slovenia have urged that the party transform itself into a loose coalition of regional Communist parties in this nation of six federated republics and two provinces. Such a move would radically transform Yugoslav politics, significantly reducing the power of the national Communist Party, which has run the country for all its 44 years but is gradually losing its grip in more liberal regions. Opponents of ending the Communist monopoly in the non-aligned country contend party unity is vital to the unity of Yugoslavia, which is facing its worst economic crisis and is beset by ethnic rivalries. They are led by delegates from Serbia, the country's largest republic, who want to maintain strong centralized control of the economic and political system. Vice Premier Zivko Pregl warned Sunday that the government would not allow the fate of the nation to ``be decided in quarrels among people representing 10 percent of the population,'' referring to the 2 million party members. He said the government intends to press ahead with the April elections under a multiparty system and that the Communists in the future will only ``be relevant to the extent they succeed in elections.'' A draft of the document outlining changes in the party's status declares its willingness to support free elections and the formation of independent political groups. Slovenia has long supported greater pluralism and was the first to announce plans to hold free elections. Its delegation wanted the reform document adopted immediately. But Serbian delegates said they preferred its adoption in a package with other resolutions, in an apparent attempt to lessen its impact. The head of the Communist-led popular organization, Socialist Alliance in Slovenia, Joze Smole said today that Slovenia had a mandate from its party to adopt the document. He said if it were not passed by the congress, there was a strong possibility the Slovenian delegation might walk out of the meeting. In debate Sunday, Serbia's populist president, Slobodan Milosevic, reiterated his support for a strong Communist Party. He charged that those seeking decentralization of the party were calling for ``a war among Yugoslav Communists and ... a war among Yugoslav nations.'' ``We don't have a united Communist Party, it is only a farce,'' responded Slovenian delgate Milos Ciric. ``We don't want to impose our liberal model on Serbia, and we will not allow Serbia to impose its model on us either.'' Delegate Branko Horvat, leader of the newly organized Union of Yugoslavs for Democratic Initiative, suggested the party to divide in two groups _ ``democratic socialists'' and ``non-democratic authoritarians.'' He said the party had ``destroyed unity'' in the country. Several independent political groups and parties announced their formation over the weekend, bringing the number of such organizations to 70.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Closes its Northern Border to Azerbaijanis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Tass reporting more Azerbaijanis crossing border; picks up 3rd pvs, `A trickle...'
DOC.TEXT: Troops were posted along Iran's border with the embattled Soviet republic of Azerbaijan to prevent people from crossing the frontier, Tehran radio said today. The report, monitored in Nicosia, said Soviet Moslems from Azerbaijan who had crossed into Iran for visits would be allowed back, but no one else would be allowed through. It did not specify whether the Soviet Union or Iran deployed troops to seal the border. In Moscow, the Soviet news agency Tass said ``Azerbaijanis and Iranians continue to cross the border en masse in both directions'' on parts of the border but other sections have been ``stabilized.'' It said Soviet and Iranian frontier guard commissars met at the border town of Astara to decide what measures should be taken to secure the frontier, but the report did not specify what agreement, if any, had been reached. A trickle of visitors from the Soviet province _ who share a common language, culture and religion with their kin across the Iranian border _ began after Soviet Azerbaijanis demonstrated in early January to demand the border be opened. Border guards on both sides ignored the crossings. The trickle turned into a flood of more than 20,000 over the past four days, the radio reported, after clashes between Christian Armenians and Moslem Azerbaijanis in the southern Soviet Union erupted in violence and the Soviet army intervened to stop the fighting. While the earlier crossings were on the western part of the 400-mile border across the Araks river, over the past week thousands have come across at the Caspian Sea city of Astara and nearby Bilehsavar. Tehran radio said the troops were deployed this morning to stop the flow, with only those two points open to allow the Soviet Moslems to return home. Iranian leaders had welcomed the Soviet visitors with open arms and cautioned Moscow to use peaceful means rather than violence to stem the fighting. But with thousands of refugees streaming across the border, Tehran fears passions among its own 15 million Azerbaijanis could be aroused. Nationalists in mineral-rich Soviet Azerbaijan want to secede from the Soviet Union and unite with Iranian Azerbaijan. The ethnic region was once part of Persia until Russian expansion under the tsars eventually forced its division in 1828. Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday blamed Moslem fanatics for the violence, echoing long-held Soviet fears that Iran's revolutionary zealots would seek to inflame the 70 million Moslems who live in the Soviet Union's southern republics. Soviet media said Iran had been supplying arms to the Moslems in Azerbaijan, which the Iranian media denied. Iran on Sunday called on the Soviet Union to halt ``violent clashes'' with Moslems in Azerbaijan, Iran television reported. The broadcast, monitored in Nicosia, said President Hashemi Rafsanjani instructed Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati to ``take serious steps to solve problems and end bloodshed and violence'' in the Moslem republic that borders northwest Iran. The violence erupted when a simmering feud between the Azerbaijanis and the Armenians flared again Jan. 13 over control of the Armenian enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh. The region has been part of Azerbaijan since 1923. Iran, which proclaimed itself to be the beacon for the world's 1 billion Moslems, says harsh measures against the Azerbaijanis by Moscow would anger the world's Moslems. But the leadership appears to be also reluctant to damage its relations with Moscow while it seeks to revitalize its battered economy following the 1988 cease-fire in the eight-year war with Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Reynolds Discovers Boundaries of Advertising to Minorities
LaserPhoto PX1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Charyn is cq in 6th graf.
DOC.TEXT: The abortive debut of a cigarette aimed primarily at blacks suggests that there are new limits to tobacco marketing. R. J. Reynolds Co., the country's second-largest tobacco company, announced Friday that it was canceling plans to use Philadelphia as a test market for Uptown, a low-menthol cigarette designed to lure black smokers. The plans had so enraged Philadelphia leaders they organized a grass-roots opposition movement that attracted the attention of the Bush administration. Although Reynolds officials say they haven't given up on Uptown, they concede that they'll have to find another way to market the brand if they decide to keep it. And other tobacco companies may face new criticism over their old strategy of marketing to women. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan, who was among the strongest critics of Uptown, said last week that he also plans to attack cigarette companies that target women. ``We should be doing things to improve the health of our citizens, not impairing the health,'' he said. ``So that when a tobacco company profits from this, indeed the rest of society _ our insurance companies, our hospitals, our companies _ also hurt.'' Charyn Sutton, marketing consultant for the American Lung Association, noted that lung cancer recently became the No. 1 cancer in women. The possibility of a rise in lung cancer among blacks ``is a very scary, scary prospect and especially when you look at a community already overburdened with smoking-related diseases,'' Sutton said. ``If you give black people a cigarette of their own, death rates will go into the stratosphere.'' Black men have a 58 percent higher incidence of lung cancer than white men, according to the U.S. Public Health Service. And compared with whites, blacks lose twice as many years of life because of smoking-related diseases. The Rev. Jesse Brown, president of the Philadelphia-based Committee to Prevent Cancer Among Blacks, said the Uptown protest was designed to say to R.J. Reynolds: ``We do not need another instrument of destruction to come into the African-American community.'' After dropping the Philadelphia test, a spokesman for Reynolds admitted the company's strategy may have been flawed. ``Maybe in retrospect we would have been better off not saying we were marketing to blacks. But those were the smokers we were going after, so why shouldn't we be honest about it?'' David B. Fishel told The New York Times. Rather than simply feature black models in its advertisements for Uptown, Reynolds openly announced its intentions. According to Brown, that may have been Uptown's downfall.
