Brown said he doubted the opponents would have been as enraged if the company had taken a more subtle approach, quietly putting up billboards in black neighborhoods and advertising in black publications. ``We saw something big coming down the pike ... and a lot of people were incensed about it,'' he said. ``The key was that they said they were going to target African-Americans, and it (the cigarette) is deadly.'' The American Cancer Society in Philadelphia started making plans to block the test market around New Year's, shortly after it was announced, said Dr. Carl Mansfield, the local cancer society president. Within a week, the Coalition Against Uptown Cigarettes was formed. Nearly 30 religious, health and black community groups joined. The uproar reached a peak when Sullivan last week asked Reynolds to halt the campaign of ``slick and sinister advertising.'' But marketing consumer products, especially cigarettes, to specific groups is not new. Philip Morris Co.'s Virginia Slims defined women as a lucrative cigarette market. Many have linked the increase in smoking among women with the introduction of Virginia Slims and its competitors. In 1986, lung cancer surpassed breast cancer as the most prevalent cancer in women. ``One of the things we felt clearly was this (the Uptown campaign) was a replication of a marketing strategy they had success with in selling cigarettes to women,'' Sutton said. Unlike the Uptown protest, Sutton said women's groups didn't oppose Virginia Slims in part because Philip Morris underwrote many women's activities, particularly sports. The tobacco industry has been vying for the loyalties of smaller and smaller segments of a shrinking smoking public by offering specialized brands. Reynolds' Premier, a smokeless cigarette that produced few ashes, failed in test markets in 1989 after some smokers complained it had a peculiar taste and aroma. Philip Morris later introduced Superslims, a cigarette the company says emits 70 percent less smoke. With its Uptown campaign, Reynolds ran a risk of reawakening the lingering desires to ban all cigarette advertising, said Jack Trout, a partner in Trout & Ries, Greenwich, Conn.-based marketing consultants. ``For the few tiny dollars they are going to pick up by penetrating the black market they are going to enrage everyone. ... It just gives ammunition to the anti's,'' Trout said shortly before Reynolds canceled the test market. Reynolds spokeswoman Maura Payne said the company could decide on the cigarette's fate sometime this week, although it would not immediately decide the time or location of a test market.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Ready to Send Spacecraft to Moon
DOC.TEXT: Scientists made final inspections of a three-stage rocket today as Japan prepared to become the third nation to send a spacecraft to the moon. ``Our staffs have almost finished the final check of electrical systems of the spacecraft. So far, everything's perfect,'' said Tadashige Takiya, a spokesman for the Institute of Space and Astronautical Science in Kagoshima in southern Japan. If Tuesday's flight is successful, Japan's Muses-A would be the first spacecraft to visit the moon since the Soviet Union landed the unmanned vehicle Luna 24 on its surface in 1976. The United States is the only other nation that has sent spacecraft to the moon. The launch is scheduled at 8:48 p.m. (6:48 a.m. EST) Tuesday from the Kagoshima Space Center, Takiya said. The plan is to send the Muses-A into a highly elliptical Earth orbit that will bring it about 10,000 miles from the moon on March 18. Japanese space centers are incapable of tracing the flight all the way, so centers in Canberra, Australia, and at California Institute of Technology will help, Takiya said. The craft is to release a smaller satellite just before crossing the moon's orbit. A ``kick motor'' aboard the smaller craft will propel it into a lunar orbit, the institute said. The smaller satellite is to send data to the mother satellite on space temperatures and electric fields, while the mother satellite continues circling Earth, swinging by the moon and collecting data on space dust and other phenomena. The government-funded flight will be the 13th satellite launched by Japan and the fifth use of the M3S-2 rocket. The Japanese rocket, an M3S-2 made by Nissan Motor Co., is a three-stage, solid-fuel rocket that weighs 62 tons. Japan's rocket program has shown a high success rate, but last August, the National Space Development Agency had its first failure in 20 launchings when the first stage of an H-1 rocket failed to ignite.

DOC.HEAD: First Actively Gay U.S. Lutheran Pastors Ordained
DOC.TEXT: Three active homosexuals have been ordained as Lutheran priests, an unprecedented act that brought joy to some of their parishioners and threats of expulsion from church officials. Jeff Johnson, 27, was installed Sunday as assistant pastor at the First United Lutheran Church in San Francisco's working-class Richmond District. Ruth Frost, 42, and Phyllis Zillhart, 32, were installed in the same roles at St. Francis Lutheran Church near the largely gay Castro District. ``This is not something new; we are already part of the church ... and now we want to be recognized for the gifts we offer,'' Zillhart said at a weekend news conference. All three of the new ministers were removed from a list of ordainable clergy after they refused to agree to celibacy, often required of known homosexual pastors but not of heterosexual ones in the Lutheran denomination. The dissident churches, one of them with no known homosexual members and both with heterosexual head pastors, agreed to hire the three last month. The congregations have been threatened with expulsion by the 5.2 million Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, which has warned it will not recognize the new ministers. ``We see this as what God is asking us to do,'' said the Rev. John Frykman of First United. ``Our congregation felt this was a social justice issue, that gays are part of the rainbow coalition of God's creation.'' ELCA spokesman Joseph Wagner countered that ordination is ``not a civil right. It is a privilege granted by the church to those who meet its established standards.'' The two congregations hope the gay ministers can bring many homosexuals back to the flock. Among other things, the three endorsed the concept of ``gay marriages.'' Their Saturday ordinations _ along with that of a New Jersey Episcopal pastor last month with an acknowledged male mate _ represent a historic foothold in mainstream Christianity by homosexuals, whose sexual orientation generally has been tolerated only if it wasn't consummated. The ELCA, formed two years ago by the merger of three Lutheran groups, bans ordination of ``self-avowed, practicing homosexuals.'' It is the largest American Lutheran denomination. Lutherans in several northern European countries allow ordination of practicing homosexuals. At the request of Sierra-Pacific Synod Bishop Lyle Miller, a disciplinary committee will consider punitive action against the congregations. The parishes could be censured, suspended, permanently removed from the church organization or exonerated. The Rev. James DeLange of St. Francis said his congregation felt that to deny the ``pastoral ministry of a lesbian couple is akin to denying a black congregation the right to call a black pastor.'' Up to 100,000 gays and lesbians live within a mile of the century-old church. ``We decided that punishment, even expulsion, is a risk we would run for the sake of what's right,'' DeLange said. Zillhart and Frost, a couple who studied together at Luther Northwestern Seminary, and Johnson, who graduated last year from Pacific Lutheran Seminary in Berkeley, Calif., also will manage an outreach program for Northern California homosexuals. George Cooper, a 52-year-old former Roman Catholic priest who left because of his homosexuality, wiped a tear from his eye following the ordination, saying, ``this is Christianity, the triumph of love for each other over ignorance.''

DOC.HEAD: Indian Troops Police City After Clash With Moslems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruoughout to UPDATE with 300 injured when soldiers open fire on crowd, state police mutiny, comment from leader of Kashmir state in Pakistan; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Moslem snipers fired at Indian troops from rooftops today and at least two people were killed and 300 injured in clashes between soldiers and Islamic militants, officials said. About 500 armed state policemen holed up in a police complex after a confrontation with the army and refused to continue the crackdown against the militants. ``The whole city is up in revolt,'' said Srinagar police inspector general Mohammad Nomani. The Islamic militants, who want Kashmir state to become independent or merge with neighboring Pakistan, marched out of homes and mosques in defiance of a curfew. Nomani said at least 40 people, most of them militants, had died since the violence began late Saturday night in Srinagar, a predominantly Moslem city. He said a paramilitary policeman was killed today by a Moslem sniper, and one Moslem protester was shot to death by the army. At least 300 protesters were injured today when troops fired on a crowd of about 5,000 in a suburb of Srinagar, doctors at the Soora Hospital said. The doctors, speaking on condition of anonymity, said all beds in the hospital were occupied and the cafeteria had been converted into a makeshift hospital. Mohammad Aslam, a policeman in the state constabulary, said a fellow officer was killed by army fire. When soldiers refused to hand over his body to the state police, about 500 armed officers took up positions in residential quarters of the police complex and refused to report for duty, Aslam said. State police said they could not confirm the officer's death and refused further comment. Aslam said the army and the paramilitary Central Reserve Police Force wanted to disarm the state police, most of whom are Moslems. The army and the paramilitary forces are mostly Hindu. ``We are not slaves,'' he said as his colleagues chanted in the background: ``Army go back.'' Thousands of Moslems took to the streets starting shortly before midnight Saturday after government security forces rounded up suspected militants. The government said it acted to control escalating violence. Nomani said 251 people had been detained in raids but that all except four had been released in an attempt to stop the violence. He estimated the militants' strength at 1,500 and said they had at least 1,000 weapons, mostly automatic rifles. The city of 1 million was placed under around-the-clock curfew, with only military vehicles and troops permitted on the streets. But bands of 50 to 100 men ignored the curfew today; at least 50 streamed out of one mosque in downtown Srinagar. Some hurled stones at the troops, while outhers beat their breasts and shouted: ``You Indians go back.'' Teen-age boys hauled out an Indian flag and shredded it in front of the soldiers. As the stones continued to fly, the army opened fire. One demonstrator fell to the street dead. Before the weekend, 26 people had been killed this year in confrontations involving Moslem militants and security forces. In New Delhi today, Foreign Minister Shabzada Yaqub Khan of Pakistan conferred with Indian officials during a visit scheduled before the latest violence. India has long accused Islamic Pakistan of supporting the Kashmiri separatists, a charge routinely denied by Pakistan. The old princely state of Kashmir was divided between India and Pakistan when the two countries were partitioned and became independent from Britain in 1947. India and Pakistan have gone to war three times since, the last time in 1971, but the Kashmir frontier is still under dispute. Abdul Qayyum, president of Pakistan's Azad Kashmir state, told a news conference in Islamabad, Pakistan, today that more violence could spark thousands to cross the 840-mile border into India. ``People are becoming deaf to reason and logic,'' he said. He said an alliance of nine political parties in Pakistani-controlled Kashmir would lead a ``peaceful movement across the cease-fire line'' if Indian troops continued what he called a campaign to destroy militant secessionists. Jammu-Kashmir is the only Indian state with a Moslem majority. Moslem militants, led by the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, have demanded independence for Kashmir or union with Moslem Pakistan. Sixty-four percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 5 million people are Moslems, but nationwide Moslems make up only 12 percent of India's 880 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Church Leader Denounces Military Government's Exile of Opponents
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with church leader denouncing crackdown; picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Critics said...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MH1,2
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ A church leader today accused the military government of undermining democratic reforms by ordering a wave of arrests, beatings and the exile of political opponents. ``They have made rubbish of the constitution,'' said Roman Catholic Bishop Willy Romelus on the church-run Radio Soleil. He encouraged his listeners, however, to keep up their spirits. Of Haiti's six main radio stations, only Radio Soleil, the Protestant Radio Lumiere and the state-run National Radio were broadcasting news this morning under a state of siege declared by military ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril. Radio is the main source of news in the country. In its toughest crackdown on the opposition since taking power in a September 1988 soldiers' revolt, the government arrested and forced into exile seven prominent political activists during the weekend. Dozens of others were arrested but were thought to have been released. Port-au-Prince, the bustling capital of more than 1 million people, remained calm. Shops and schools opened as usual and traffic was normal. Critics said the crackdown indicates Avril intends to renege on a promise to hold free elections in October. At a news conference Sunday in Miami, newly exiled activist Hubert de Ronceray said Avril promised the elections only ``to get help from foreign countries.'' ``There's no possibility of a democracy with Mr. Avril. He's a dictator,'' said the conservative leader. The state of siege was declared after an army colonel, his wife and servants were killed Friday by unidentified gunmen just 100 yards from de Ronceray's home. De Ronceray, deported Saturday, claimed he was the intended victim. Other opposition activists speculated Avril was using the killings as a pretext to derail the transition to democracy he promised after coming to power in a September 1988 soldiers' revolt. De Ronceray, 65, said that after his arrest he was kicked, clubbed with guns, and had a cigarette jammed in his eye. The eye was red as he spoke to reporters. The other exiles were also beaten before they were deported, according to the activists and other sources. The government offered no comment on those reports. In Washington, the State Department condemned the state of siege and arrests and urged the Haitian government to reiterate its commitment to free elections. The United States suspended $60 million in aid to the impoverished country after Haiti's last attempt at democratic elections was thwarted by armed thugs aided by soldiers who massacred voters in 1987. Louis Roy, a prominent civic leader and an author of Haiti's 1987 constitution, ``was carrying a small suitcase, kissed the ground two times and mounted the stairway to exile,'' a relative told The Associated Press. Roy, 74, founder of the Haitian Red Cross, flew aboard a commercial flight to Miami. ``I was hit in both ears and full in the face in front of the duty officer at the police headquarters,'' he said upon arrival. Max Bourjolly, second-in-command of the Haitian Communist party, was arrested at his home and exiled, apparently to France, said party leader Rene Theodore. Family members and sources who spoke on condition of anonymity said the others exiled Sunday were Aby Brun of the center-left Congress for Democratic Movement, Sylvain Jolibois of the small radical Jean-Jacques Dessalines Group, and radical activists Michel Legros and Max Montreuil. They said Brun was flown to Miami and the others to the Dominican Republic, which shares the Caribbean island of Hispaniola with Haiti. Popular radical leader Sylvio Claude of the Haitian Christian Democratic Party and Gerard Philippe-Auguste, head of the Movement to Organize the Country party, went into hiding. De Ronceray and Roy are not new to exile. They spent several years in Montreal during the rule of the late dictator Francois ``Papa Doc'' Duvalier, whose son continued the 29-year family dynasty until fleeing to France in 1986 after a popular uprising. In announcing the state of siege Saturday night, the government suspended a law forbidding forced exile and renewed an entry visa requirement for Haitians returning from abroad. De Ronceray claimed the colonel killed near his house, Andre Neptune, was shot by attackers sent out to kill him. He said he had changed his own schedule because of a warning Avril wanted him ``destroyed,'' and the officer was slain while in a car similar to his. Human rights activist Jean-Claude Bajeux, who arrived in Puerto Rico from Haiti on Friday, said he suspected either army rivals or the drug mafia were behind the slayings. ``The coincidence is significant. For this killing to happen now and they immediately use it to round up (opposition leaders), it's a typically Duvalierist scheme.'' He was referring to the network of Duvalier supporters left in this former French colony, where 80 percent of the 5 million people live in poverty. Paul Latortue, a Haitian economist at the University of Puerto Rico, said the weekend crackdown indicates Avril ``has allied himself with the Duvalierists,'' whom he accused of killing Neptune. ``The government will now either show its teeth and demonstrate there'll be no elections, or have elections without the opposition's participation, with controlled candidates,'' Latortue said. Avril rose to power in a revolt that ousted Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy, who oversaw the November 1987 elections that were canceled when at least 34 voters were shot and hacked to death by thugs in collusion with soldiers. Less than two months later, Namphy staged army-run elections that were widely boycotted by voters and denounced by most foreign observers as fraudulent. Several months later, he took back control of the government.

DOC.HEAD: Court To Decide ``Whistleblowers'' Issue in North Carolina Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether nuclear industry ``whistleblowers'' who say they were disciplined for complaining about lax safety may sue under state personal-injury laws. The justices said they will review a North Carolina case in which a federal appeals court said such workers must sue under a special federal law. Another appeals courts has allowed such state-law suits, and the justices' decision is expected to resolve the conflicting rulings. The decision, to be announced by July, will carry a significant practical effect. The federal law does not provide for punitive-damages awards, often the most lucrative part of a successful suit under the corresponding state laws. Bush administration lawyers urged reversal of the appeals court's ruling in the North Carolina case. The federal law ``does not pre-empt an employee's state (suit) for intentional infliction of emotional distress resulting from retaliation for making nuclear safety complaints,'' they said. Vera English of Wilmington, N.C., worked as a laboratory technician for General Electric at its nuclear fuels manufacturing plant there for almost 12 years before she was fired in July 1984. Earlier that year, Ms. English had complained to both the federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission and to her GE supervisors about what she considered serious violations of federal safety standards. When no corrective action was taken, she deliberately failed to clean up radiation contamination at her work station in what she said was an effort to prove that such contamination was not being detected by safety inspectors. Although her efforts led to corrective action, she was disciplined and eventually fired. Ms. English sued GE in 1987. Her suit sought, under North Carolina law, reinstatement with back pay and monetary damages for wrongful discharge and intentional infliction of emotional distress. Despite being based on state law, Ms. English's suit was filed in federal court because GE's headquarters are outside the state. A federal judge dismissed the state-law suit, ruling that it was pre-empted by ``whistleblower provisions'' of the federal Energy Reorganization Act. The federal law bars nuclear industry employers from firing or otherwise disciplining employees for publicly pointing out alleged safety problems. The 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the dismissal of Ms. English's suit last April 3. In seeking Supreme Court review, Ms. English's lawyers argued that she ``was treated outrageously and unfairly by General Electric, yet she has received no compensation for the very serious wrongs she has suffered.'' GE lawyers urged rejection of the appeal, saying that allowing such suits would frustrate ``a pervasive and delicately balanced regulatory scheme'' created by Congress.'' In a recent interview, one of Ms. English's lawyers, M. Travis Payne of Raleigh, N.C., said she no longer has the option of filing a suit against GE based on the federal law. In a separate administrative proceeding, a Labor Department administrative law judge ruled for Ms. English. The judge awarded her reinstatement with back pay, $70,000 in damages and lawyer fees, but the ruling was set aside by the secretary of labor on grounds Ms. English waited too long to file her complaint. The case is English vs. General Electric, 89-152.

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Georgia School Bond Referendum
DOC.TEXT: A Bibb County, Ga., school bond referendum attacked by blacks as a violation of the federal Voting Rights Act was legal, the Supreme Court ruled today. The court, without waiting to hear arguments in the case, upheld a ruling that permitted the county's voters to approve $29 million to air-condition existing schools and build a new high school. The justices' decision was not accompanied by any written opinion. There was no recorded dissenting vote. Blacks in the county, who favored the air conditioning but opposed the new school, said permitting both proposals to be voted on together was racially biased. They said the proposed school in a predominantly white area would require busing black students to attend classes there. The blacks sought, under the Voting Rights Act of 1965, to have the U.S. attorney general review the referendum proposal before it was placed on the ballot _ a process called pre-clearance. But a special three-judge federal court ruled last year that the school board's decision to link the air conditioning and a new school in a single bond issue is not the kind of voting change requiring pre-clearance. The three-judge court acknowledged that the Supreme Court has upheld pre-clearance for setting election dates, changing candidate qualifications and altering voting procedures. But the panel, agreeing with legal arguments submitted by the Justice Department, said defining the scope of a bond issue proposal ``is a routine matter for the (school) board to decide.'' Those who challenged the referendum format said, ``The method the board chose submerged the political will of Bibb County's black voters. Voters favoring all or none of the bond issues were able to cast a fully effective ballot. Those voters who were divided on the issues were not.'' The challengers said there was racially polarized voting over the bond issue and that the school board scheduled the election to reduce the chances of a proportionally larger turnout by blacks over whites. They said the school board rescinded a plan to submit the bond issue to voters on March 8, 1988 _ so-called Super Tuesday in last year's presidential primaries when the civil rights leader Jesse Jackson was on the Georgia ballot. On that date, 11,375 blacks and 23,706 whites in Bibb County voted. When the bond issue was approved on Election Day, Nov. 8, 1988, 14,731 blacks and 35,153 whites voted. The bond issue passed, 21,915 votes to 21,287. Asked for its views in the case, the Bush administration urged the high court to uphold the three-judge court's ruling. The case is Lucas vs. Townsend, 89-400.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Use Haitian Dispute to Decide Legal Fees Issue
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to use a decade-long dispute over the rights of Haitian refugees to decide when the government must pay legal fees to people who sue it successfully. The court said it will hear a Bush administration appeal aimed at limiting such fees. The refugees sued the government in 1981 over its policy of locking up aliens caught while trying to enter the United States illegally. Until 1981, the government generally released aliens on ``parole'' pending hearings on their applications for official admission to the country. The Haitians said they almost never were paroled before their applications were acted upon, a process that can take longer than a year. The refugees accused the government of discriminating against them because they are black, and also contended that the Immigration and Naturalization Service violated federal rules by summarily adopting harsher treatment for Haitians than other aliens. The refugees ultimately won an important, though not total, victory. They did not win on the discrimination claim but the government conceded that the INS may not consider race or national origin in determining parole. New rules were adopted for handling refugees. Federal courts that reviewed the case said there is no doubt the Haitians won their freedom because of the lawsuit. Those refugees later returned to custody were detained under new, fairer rules, the lower courts said. The government has argued that the Haitians did not win key elements of their lawsuit and should not be entitled to recover legal fees under the Equal Access to Justice Act. The act generally requires reimbursement of legal fees for those who prevail in suits against the government. A federal judge ruled against the government on the fees question, awarding more than $1 million to the lawyers who represented the Haitians. The 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last year substantially upheld the judge's decision, while ordering further hearings to recompute the amount owed the lawyers. The appeals court also said the government must reimburse the Haitians' lawyers for fees they incurred litigating the fees issue in the first place _ what the appeals court called the ``fees for fees'' issue. ``We hold that the United States may not oppose a `fees for fees' request solely on the ground that its position in the fee litigation was substantially justified,'' the 11th Circuit court said. That issue prompted the Bush administration's appeal to the Supreme Court acted on today. Justice Department lawyers said the 11th Circuit court ruling conflicts with decisions by other federal appeals courts. The case is Commissioner of INS vs. Jean, 89-601.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Runs Aground in Southeast Alaska; 57,000 Gallons Spilled
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf pvs, `The 400-foot...', to UPDATE with situation early today, gasoline removed, picking up 5th graf pvs, `Coast Guard...'. SUBS 12th graf, `An estimated..', to update reference to gasoline moved to barge.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto KPN2
DOC.TEXT: Coast Guard officials have decided to let nature clean up the estimated 57,600 gallons of gasoline that gushed into Alaska's island-studded Inside Passage from a grounded tanker. The Canadian-owned tanker Frank H. Brown struck Burnt Island Reef on Saturday night. The captain, who was not identified, blamed the grounding on ``a judgment error,'' Coast Guard spokesman Ed Moreth said. The agency said it took blood and urine samples from crew members to test for drug or alcohol use. The 400-foot ship was refloated at high tide Sunday and continued under its own power about 15 miles up a narrow channel to Scow Bay, just south of Petersburg. There, divers found a 2-foot hole in one of its tanks. Lt. Brian Flory of the Coast Guard said the vessel remained at anchor overnight. ``It has boom all around it,'' Flory said early today. ``The remaining cargo was transferred out of the damaged tank. There's no recoverable gasoline anywhere.'' Coast Guard and state environmental officials said damage to fish and wildlife appeared to be minimal. The decision not to clean up the spill was made Sunday as the gasoline quickly broke up into several thin sheens, the largest a mile long. ``It's just not recoverable,'' Moreth said. ``The stuff seems to be evaporating quicker than anyone could pick it up, and it's only in small patches scattered around.'' The spill was a fraction of the size of the Exxon Valdez disaster, in which nearly 11 million gallons of heavy crude oil spilled into Prince William Sound last March in the nation's worst oil spill. The Valdez captain, Joseph Hazelwood, goes on trial next week. The site of Saturday's spill is about 135 miles south of Juneau in a channel called Wrangell Narrows. The tanker carried 1.8 million gallons of gasoline, diesel fuel and heating oil, but only one tank was ruptured. ``It's not a heavy fuel, so it has a tendency to break up easily and it weathers much faster than a heavier oil,'' Coast Guard spokesman Greg Robinson said. The tanker is owned by White Pass Transportation Inc. of Vancouver, British Columbia. It was heading from Vancouver to Skagway, 210 miles north of Petersburg. Wrangell Narrows is a windy, 25-mile long channel between Sumner Strait and Frederick Sound. It is one of the narrowest waterways between the thickly forested and mountainous islands that form the Inside Passage. An estimated 20,000 gallons of gasoline remained in the damaged tank and was removed Sunday night to a nearby barge at Scow Bay. Boom totaling 1,050 feet was placed around the two vessels to contain any further leakage. The vessel may be allowed to continue to Skagway with the rest of its load today. The damage is not enough to affect the tanker's maneuverability, Moreth said. The spill was not expected to pose a health risk to people living along the channel, said Barbara Holian, a spokeswoman for the state Department of Environmental Conservation in Juneau. She said spilled gasoline does not remain highly toxic for long because it evaporates quickly. The state's Crystal Lake Hatchery 15 miles south of Petersburg was not threatened by the spill, said fish culturist Bill Davidson at the salmon hatchery. There are no fish runs in the area until spring, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Require Arbitration for Federal Workers
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to require arbitration for hundreds of thousands of federal workers when they are fired, demoted or otherwise disciplined. The court, without comment, rejected appeals by a labor union and the Federal Labor Relations Authority seeking broader job protection for federal employees. At issue were the rights of as many as 450,000 employees known as ``excepted'' workers because they hold their jobs without having to take civil service tests. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here ruled last May that the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 does not require government agencies to bargain over creation of grievance arbitration procedure for the excepted workers. ``Congress carefully constructed a scheme that would ensure uniformity in personnel decisions and promote efficiency of administration,'' the appeals court said. Requiring arbitration for excepted workers ``would undermine the structure'' of the law, that court said. The May ruling was a defeat for the National Treasury Employees Union, which sought to extend arbitration protection to employees in the chief counsel's office of the Internal Revenue Service. The Bush administration supported the appeals court ruling, but Justice Department lawyers noted that Congress is considering amending civil service law to expand job protection for excepted employees. The cases are National Treasury Employees Union vs. Treasury Department, 89-610, and Federal Labor Relations Authority vs. Treasury Department, 89-758.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Asked for Views on Massachusetts Regulation
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today asked the Bush administration for its view as to whether stockbrokers may be forced to give investors the option of suing, rather than seeking arbitration, over alleged broker fraud. The court said it wants to hear from Justice Department lawyers about a ruling that barred Massachusetts from requiring brokers to make arbitration clauses optional, not mandatory, in brokerage contracts. The justices are not expected to take any action in the Massachusetts case until hearing from the government lawyers, which could take months. The Massachusetts appeal is supported by 30 other states, whose officials said a federal appeals court ruling leaves them ``powerless to protect consumers from being coerced to enter arbitration agreements.'' The Boston-based 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled last Aug. 31 that the Massachusetts regulations are pre-empted by federal law. The prevailing practice in the brokerage industry is to require customers to agree to arbitrate all disputes as a condition to opening an account. The justices ruled 5-4 in 1987 that if such arbitration clauses are in the contracts signed by investors, disputes over alleged fraud are to be resolved in arbitration, not in lawsuits. Massachusetts' secretary of state in 1988 imposed regulations prohibiting brokers from making arbitration agreements non-negotiable conditions for opening accounts. The regulations also required brokers to tell customers about the legal effects of mandatory arbitration clauses. The state's action immediately was challenged by the Securities Industry Association and 10 brokerage firms affiliated with it. A federal judge ruled for the brokers, and the appeals court upheld that ruling. ``The long and short of it is that we can find no evidence of a clear congressional command to override the unambiguous pro-arbitration mandate of the (Federal Arbitration Act) in the securities field,'' the appeals court said. In the state's appeal, Massachusetts Attorney General James M. Shannon said the August ruling ``has national implications for state regulation of mandatory arbitration agreements in banking, health care, (the) automobile and many other industries.'' Shannon said the Federal Arbitration Act does not pre-empt all state regulation of arbitration. Lawyers for the securities industry urged the justices to reject the state's appeal. The case is Connolly vs. Securities Industry Association, 89-894.

DOC.HEAD: Eritrean Guerrillas Release 30 Poles from Destroyed Ship
DOC.TEXT: Ethiopian rebels today released the crew of a Polish cargo ship that had been attacked on suspicion it was carrying arms to Ethiopian government forces, Sudan's official news agency reported. The 30 Poles were turned over to a Sudanese military team at the border with Ethiopia and taken to Port Sudan, the country's major port on the Red Sea, for a flight home on plane provided by the Polish government, the Sudan News Agency said. The report quoted Ali Shummo, minister of information and culture. Guerrillas said they attacked the 8,137-ton Polish freighter Boleslaw Krzywousty on Jan. 3 as it steamed from Port Sudan to Massawa, a port in the northern Ethiopian province of Eritrea. A guerrilla spokesman contacted from Bahrain on Jan. 7 said the freighter was one of two ships the rebels attacked on suspicion they carried arms to Ethiopia's Marxist government. The attacks were apparently from shore gun batteries. The spokesman gave no details of what became of the two ships and their crews. But shipping sources in the Persian Gulf said they received information that the Boleslaw Krzywousty was stranded and ablaze 50 miles from Massawa. It was not clear how the crew members of the Boleslaw Krzywousty fell into rebel hands _ whether the crew was captured after abandoning ship or whether they were seized from the ship by the guerrillas. In Cairo, a Polish Embassy spokesman speaking on condition of anonymity said the released Poles are 29 crew members and the wife of one of them. He said they were handed over to Peter Vanau, who headed a Polish government team that negotiated the release with rebel representatives. The Boleslaw Krzywousty is a general cargo ship owned by the Polish Shipping Association. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front has been fighting for nearly three decades for independence for the Eritrean province.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Revive Suit in California Anti-Abortion Picketing Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to revive a federal civil rights lawsuit by five people prosecuted for anti-abortion picketing outside a San Diego medical clinic. The justices, without comment, let stand a decision dismissing allegations that the clinic's operators violated the pickets' free-speech rights. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last June 23 threw out $11,800 awards each of the five pickets had won in a federal trial. James Collins Jr., Tammy Lee Collins, Kimberlee Huckaby, Joan Patton and Cheryl Sullenger sued over an Oct. 1, 1985, incident at the Womencare clinic. On that day, a group of protesters demonstrated across the street from the clinic. Some of them were subject to a state court injunction, issued about a year earlier, that barred them from demonstrating or picketing ``any closer than across the street'' from the clinic's property. The five people involved in this case picketed on the public sidewalk on Womencare's side of the street. Two clinic employees summoned police who, after talking with the pickets, decided to take no action. But San Diego Police Sgt. Thomas Packer told the clinic employees they could make ``citizen's arrests'' under California law, charging the pickets with violating the 1984 injunction. The two employees, accompanied by police officers, placed the five pickets under arrest. Police detained the group long enough to issue misdemeanor citations for violating the injunction. The five pickets were not subject to the 1984 injunction, and the charges were dropped prior to trial. They subsequently sued, in federal court, the clinic's owners and the two employees who arrested them. The suit, involving a much-used civil rights law, alleged false arrest and free-speech violations. A jury ruled for the pickets, but the 9th Circuit court threw out the jury's award. The appeals court said the arrests made by the two clinic employees did not amount to action taken ``under the color of state law,'' and therefore could not be the basis for the civil rights suit. The appeals court sent back the false-arrest claim for a retrial. The case is Collins vs. Womancare, 89-819.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Rule on Boat Owner Liability in Indiana Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to settle a dispute over how much money pleasure boat owners may be required to pay for damages in some boating accidents. The court said it will hear an appeal by the owner of a yacht destroyed in a fire while docked at a Lake Michigan marina in Indiana. The accident occurred Sept. 24, 1985, when a fire broke out aboard Everett Sisson's 56-foot yacht, the Ultorian. It caused extensive damage to the Washington Park Marina in Michigan City, Ind., and other boats docked there. The fire was believed to have been caused by a defective washer and dryer aboard the yacht. The owners of the marina and the other damaged boats sued for more than $275,000. Sisson, whose boat was valued at about $600,000 before the fire, said he should be required to pay the others no more than $800 _ the Ultorian's value after the fire. His arguments for restricting the damages were based on maritime and admiralty laws that protect ship owners from having to pay big court awards in lawsuits. But the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled last year that the liability limits do not apply when the accident is caused by a pleasure boat moored at a recreational marina. The appeals court said the liability limits only apply ``to cases directly involving commercial maritime activity or to cases involving exclusively non-commercial activities in which the wrong has a potentially disruptive impact on martime commerce and involves ... navigation.'' The appeals court based its ruling in part on a 1982 Supreme Court ruling in a case in which two pleasure boats collided. ``This may be too narrow and mechanical an interpretation of the Supreme Court'' decision, the appeals court said. ``But the specific language of the court seems to support it. If the Ultorian had been under way in the shipping channel when the fire broke out, we might reach a different result.'' Bush administration lawyers urged that Sisson's appeal be granted and his case be used to clear up uncertainty over the issue. The 1982 decision ``provides modest guidance with respect to cases that do not involve navigation or commercial shipping,'' Justice Department lawyers said. The case is Sisson vs. Ruby, 88-2041.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Let Unions Get Addresses from Government
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to let public employee labor unions get from the government the home addresses of federal workers. The court, without comment, left intact a ruling that the workers' privacy would be violated if government agencies are forced to divulge the information to the unions. The Federal Labor Relations Authority, in a series of decisions, said unions are entitled to the names and addresses of the workers they represent in collective bargaining. The authority said withholding the information is an unfair labor practice, noting that labor law requires private employers to give unions the addresses of workers they represent. There is little privacy right in keeping one's home address a secret from the union since the recipient of union mail is free to throw it away unopened, the labor authority said. Disclosing the addresses will ``contribute to the union's ability to communicate effectively with its bargaining unit employees,'' added the authority, which handles disputes between government employee unions and their employers. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here overturned the labor authority's ruling last September, saying workers' privacy rights outweigh the unions' need for the information _ particularly since there are other ways for the unions to communicate with employees. In the appeals acted on today, the unions said they should be allowed to communicate with members in the privacy of the workers' homes and be allowed to recruit new members by mail. In ruling against the unions, the appeals court relied in part on a 1989 Supreme Court decision that said the FBI is not required by the Freedom of Information Act to reveal ``rap sheets'' containing arrest and conviction records of millions of Americans. ``Federal employees have privacy interests in their names and home addresses that must be protected, and the relevant public interest in disclosure, though not nothing, is outweighed,'' the appeals court said. Bush administration lawyers asked the justices not to disturb the appeals court's ruling. In a related case last year, the high court ordered the St. Louis-based 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals to study the issue further. The cases are American Federation of Government Employees vs. Department of Health and Human Services, 89-444; National Treasury Employees Union vs. Treasury Department, 89-566; and Federal Labor Relations Authority vs. Treasury Department, 89-853.

DOC.HEAD: California Church Loses Property-Rights Bid
DOC.TEXT: A California church that won a major Supreme Court property-rights case in 1987 today lost a follow-up bid to be compensated for losing the use of its land. The justices, without comment, let stand a ruling that Los Angeles County officials are not required to pay the church for any losses it suffered. The church, First English Evangelical Lutheran in Glendale, Calif., operated a camp called Lutherglen on 21 acres of land in the mountains north of Los Angeles. Forest fires in the summer of 1977 burned off much of the vegetation there, and flooding from heavy rains the next year leveled the camp's buildings. Floods in the area also killed 10 people, swept away bridges and other buildings, and inflicted million of dollars in damages. Los Angeles County enacted an interim ordinance that barred reconstruction of the Lutherglen buildings while officials looked for a permanent solution to the flooding threat. The Supreme Court in 1987 used the case to rule that landowners can be awarded compensation when government regulations bar them from using their property. But the justices sent the church's case back to a California appeals court to decide whether the church would receive any money. The state appeals court ruled in May 1969 that the church is not entitled to be paid because it was not deprived of all use of its property, even temporarily, and because whatever uses were denied were justified by public safety concerns. The appeals court said Lutherglen still could be used for various camping and recreational activities. Moreover, the state court said, the county was justified in preventing rebuilding because of the threat to life and property from another flood. ``What First English can no longer do is rebuild the bunkhouses and similar permanent living structures which might house the potential victims of a future flood,'' the state court said. ``These zoning restrictions represent a valid exercise of the police power and not an unconstitutional taking (of property) without compensation.'' The church said the state court ruling amounts to ``willful defiance'' of the Supreme Court's 1987 ruling. ``The California courts do not yet appear to have received the message'' that they are depriving property owners of their rights, the church said. The National Association of Realtors, the National Association of Home Builders and the conservative Pacific Legal Foundation supported the church's appeal. The California attorney general's office urged the justices to leave the state court ruling intact. The case is First English Church vs. Los Angeles County, 89-826.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Reinstate Award Massachusetts Hospital Ordered to Pay
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to reinstate a $350,000 award a Massachusetts hospital was ordered to pay the family of a girl who lost sight in her right eye after surgery. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that reduced the medical malpractice judgment to $20,000 under a state law that protects charitable institutions. New England Medical Center in Boston was sued in 1983 by Joseph and Elizabeth English. Their daughter, Kerrie Ann, underwent cataract surgery at the hospital in 1980 at age 8. She developed an infection after the operation. A jury awarded the family $350,000 against the hospital but returned verdicts in favor of two doctors who treated the girl. A judge reduced the damages to $20,000 under a 1971 Massachusetts law that imposes that cap for personal injury lawsuits against charities. The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court upheld the reduced damages last year. ``We are not without misgivings about the paltriness of the $20,000 cap ... but we cannot correctly declare the statute to be unconstitutional,'' the state court said. ``A change in the amount of the cap may be appropriate. But that is a legislative decision.'' Lawyers for the English family said the law violates constitutional equal protection guarantees. Only victims of injuries caused by charities are subject to the discriminatory cap, they said. ``The statute must be seen as the product of a powerful lobby securing unneeded protection from the legislature at the expense of an unrepresented and powerless class of victims,'' the lawyers said. ``The statute fails to make a distinction between victims to whom $20,000 would be a boon and those to whom it would barely be a beginning,'' the appeal said. The case is English vs. New England Medical Center, 89-825.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia Governor, Citing Cost, Calls For End to Racial Demonstrations
DOC.TEXT: Georgia Gov. Joe Frank Harris wants an end to the racial demonstrations that have cost state taxpayers more than $1 million this month. ``Enough is enough,'' Barbara Morgan, the governor's news secretary, said Sunday. ``The point has been made.'' More than 2,500 police and National Guard troops lined the streets near the tomb of slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. on Saturday as four white supremacists, led by Richard Barrett of Mississippi, demonstrated on the national historic site adjacent to the tomb and the King Center. About 75 counterdemonstrators jeered from a distance. Barrett then traveled to Forsyth County, where he and one supporter marched. Civil rights leader Hosea Williams and about 60 supporters also marched in the county Saturday. The two events passed without incident. Barrett said today that ``in an attempt to be reasonable,'' he would consider heeding the governor's request if he could meet with Harris. ``We would like to meet with Gov. Harris _ and President Bush,'' Barrett said, ``to discuss reforms that would help bring about more democracy and greater majority rule. ... Something constructive might come from it.'' Ms. Morgan said today that the governor's office had not heard from Barrett and would have no immediate response to his statements. Harry Heath, spokesman for the Georgia Department of Defense, estimated it cost the department $500,000 for its weekend security work in Atlanta, in addition to costs for National Park Service personnel. A Ku Klux Klan rally at the state Capitol on Jan. 6, which drew about 50 Klan members and supporters and 100 counterdemonstrators, also cost taxpayers $500,000. ``When people put in for a permit, we know how large the nucleus is going to be, but we have no idea how large the counterdemonstration will be because they don't have to have a permit,'' Heath said. ``We have to prepare for the absolute worst.'' Ms. Morgan said the security staff for such demonstrations wouldn't be cut back as a rule. She said such determinations are made by the state's security experts on a case-by-case basis. ``It's not just to provide protection for the demonstrators,'' she said. ``We have to consider the potential for violence outside the demonstration as well.'' Cumming Police Chief Wayne Lindsey estimated that security costs to his city were $2,500. Forsyth County Sheriff Wesley Walraven said county security costs may have ranged from $50,000 to $100,000.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Envoy Winds Up Talks on Higgins
DOC.TEXT: A U.N. envoy left the country today after talking with Lebanese militia officials about the fate of U.S. Marine Lt. Col. William Higgins, who was reported hanged by kidnappers last year. Marrack Goulding, a U.N. assistant secretary-general, arrived in Beirut on Thursday and conferred earlier with President Elias Hrawi and Prime Minister Salim Hoss. He met today with Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, the spiritual leader of the pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem Hezbollah, or Party of God, and with Nabih Berri, justice minister and leader of the secular Shiite Amal militia. A source close to the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon said Goulding's meeting with Fadlallah was to ``try to ascertain Higgins' fate.'' Higgins, who led a U.N. observer team in southern Lebanon, was kidnapped near the port of Tyre on Feb. 17, 1988. The pro-Iranian group called the Organization of the Oppressed on Earth said it killed him in July after Israel kidnapped a Hezbollah sheik. U.S. intelligence officials believe Higgins actually was killed a year earlier in retaliation for a U.S. warship accidentally shooting down an Iranian civilian airliner over the Persian Gulf. All 290 people on board the plane were killed. Hezbollah is an umbrella organization for several pro-Iranian Shiite factions holding most of the 18 western hostages seized in Lebanon since March 1985. The hostage held longest is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. The main goal of Goulding's Middle East tour is obtaining a renewal of the U.N. observer force's mandate. The force of 5,800 troops drawn from nine nations has been deployed in southern Lebanon since Israel invaded part of the region in 1978. Goulding was to travel to Syria after he left Lebanon today.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Let New Mexico Officials Break Prison Pact
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to let New Mexico officials break part of a 1980 pact they say put the state's four prisons under ``day-to-day federal court control.'' The court, without comment, let stand rulings that upheld the 10-year-old court consent decree. The dispute dates back to a 1977 lawsuit by inmates of the state's penitentiary, at the time New Mexico's only prison. The suit challenged prison conditions and practices as unconstitutional. A partial settlement was agreed to in 1979. A broader agreement between prison authorities and inmates was reached several months after 33 inmates were killed a February 1980 riot at the penitentiary. The 1980 court-approved pact, which covered all future prisons and inmates as well, set standards for numerous aspects of prison life. Some of the standards, such as those governing food services and medical care, were not challenged by state officials. But others were attacked in a 1987 request seeking to modify the 1980 agreement. Specifically, state officials objected to these requirements: _Inmate security classifications must be made by a three-member committee representing a prison's psychological, program and security staffs with participation by the individual inmate. _Maximum security may be used only for inmates who have committed or been linked to particular acts involving prison security. The state's appeal said the requirement makes maximum security ``unavailable for known gang leaders who have not themselves engaged in recent misconduct.'' _Inmates may be punished only for certain designated offenses and only for specified lengths of time, never exceeding 30 days. _All inmates except those in maximum security must receive ``eight hours a day of meaningful activity,'' to include vocational training, education and work. _No prison may use ``double-celling,'' or putting more than one inmate in any cell, except in the face of dire emergencies such as riots or fires, regardless of the cell's size. Dormitories must provide 60 square feet for each inmate. _Liberal visitation policies must be used, including allowing kissing and embracing when feasible. U.S. District Judge Juan G. Burciaga in 1988 turned down the state's request to modify the consent decree, and the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld his ruling last Sept. 15. In the appeal acted on today, New Mexico Attorney General Hal Stratton argued, ``The issues in this case vitally affect the ability of the states to administer their ... prisons free from long-term, day-to-day federal court control over matters not governed by federal law.'' The state's appeal called the 1980 consent decree ``outmoded'' because more recent high court rulings make clear that the decree's standards ``go far beyond any federal law requirements.'' The appeal was supported in a ``friend-of-the-court'' brief filed by 39 states and Puerto Rico. The case is Carruthers vs. Duran, 89-786.

DOC.HEAD: Exports Rise, But Economic Sanctions Hurt
DOC.TEXT: China's trade figures improved in 1989, but economic sanctions imposed after the crackdown on the pro-democracy movement severely limited access to foreign loans and technology, a trade official said today. Liu Xiangdong, spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations and Trade, said exports reached $43.27 billion, up 6.5 percent from 1988, while imports declined by 3.9 percent to $38.27 billion. But he said economic sanctions imposed by Western nations after the military crushed the student-led pro-democracy movement in June caused foreign loan agreements to drop by 51 percent, to $4.8 billion. He said the number of technology import contracts, 328, was down 25 percent due to tougher restrictions on technology transfers to China following the crackdown. The value of those contracts dropped 18 percent to $2.9 billion. Liu noted that some developed countries recently indicated they will lift sanctions. But he said no action had been taken and ``we do not have any unrealistic fantasies.'' China must stress self-reliance in its modernization drive, he said. The nation's chief economic planning official echoed Liu's sentiments in a speech to businessmen in Tokyo today. ``The population of China is large, and the issues the Chinese people face are serious and tough,'' said Zou Jiahua, head of China's State Planning Commission. ``We need a stable and united government, and a stable environment, to carry through construction of socialism,'' he told the Japan Association for the Promotion of International Trade. Zou, who arrived in Japan last week at the invitation of the trade group, is the first high-level Chinese official to visit since the crackdown. He said China's lifting of martial law in Beijing on Jan. 11 was evidence of stability. The move was widely seen as a gesture aimed at bringing foreign investors back to China and persuading Western governments to drop sanctions imposed after the June crackdown. The United States reacted by dropping opposition to World Bank loans for ``basic human needs,'' and Japan has indicated it will renew talks on a credit package for development projects. Liu said China had not signed one foreign assistance contract since last spring's political turmoil. He said imports were down because of the drop in technology purchases and austerity policies that have sharply reduced demand and economic growth. As a consequence, trade with Japan fell 5 percent to about $14 billion, Liu said. U.S.-Chinese trade was up 13.7 percent, to $9.4 billion, however. Liu said not one of the 899 Beijing-based foreign firms registered with the trade ministry left after the military crackdown, and that 71 more firms had registered since June. He said there were 5,784 new projects involving foreign investment nationwide last year, down by 2.7 percent.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Looks Into Agreement With Rivals; Experts Say Pact Can Be Legal
DOC.TEXT: The nation's fiercely competitive long-distance carriers may reach a detente if AT&T asks for a mutual-aid pact to ease the effects of a network failure like last week's massive shutdown. Already, the company has told its operators to give out the access codes of its two rivals, MCI and US Sprint, and other carriers in case of a similar problem. Harry Baumgartner, a spokesman for the American Telephone & Telegraph Co., said the company is studying the idea of a backup system involving all three companies, and a proposal could be ready this week. ``We're still looking at the feasibility, and this may never come to pass,'' said Baumgartner. ``The point is, what we are interested in at AT&T is that our customers don't experience anything like this ever again. Whatever it takes to do that, we'll do it.'' US Sprint and MCI appeared to be receptive to the idea. Spokesman for all three major carriers said that the prospect of a mutual-aid agreement raises some technological questions but none that can't be overcome. Legal experts said it also could be challenged on anti-trust grounds. ``It's remarkable because they've been battling so bitterly, with the industry so competitive,'' said Audrey Stevoff, an analyst with Duff & Phelpps Inc. in Chicago. ``It would definately be a major change for the industry.'' The system failure, which hampered long distance calling nationwide for nine hours a week ago, was a blow that may go deeper than merely bruising the prestige of the No. 1 carrier, analysts said. But it will help AT&T's competitors more than it will hurt AT&T, they predict. ``I think AT&T has been very intelligent about how they're handling this and is minimizing its effects,'' said Paul Aran, an analyst with Bear Stearns in New York. ``They've taken this very, very seriously so that it doesn't happen again, and they're working to make it up to their customers.'' AT&T has proposed, pending Federal Communications Commission approval, giving its 80 million customers nine hours of discount service on Valentine's Day to compensate for the outage. Aran said No. 2 MCI Communications Corp. and No. 3 US Sprint stand to gain, but the public relations windfall will be short-lived. ``AT&T has been seen as something like America's most invincible company, but nothing, no company, is perfect,'' Aran said. ``OK, now the shock wears off, people say, `So they're not perfect.''' He added that AT&T's handling of the incident has shown that it is a strong company with high standards, and that signing on with its rivals in a backup agreement would be a bold move. US Sprint has pounced on the shutdown to try to increase its 8 percent of the market. The company immediately began running full-page ads in major newspapers with instructions on how to use Sprint ``the next time you experience difficulties dialing long distance.'' But Sprint doesn't rule out cooperating with AT&T, either. ``We'd welcome anything in the industry that will give people better service,'' said Sprint spokesman Sid Courson. ``If we can help make sure everybody who wants to call long distance can, and the logistics are there, we'd welcome talking to AT&T.'' The sentiments were echoed at MCI, which controls about 12 percent of the long-distance market. ``I think it would be nice to have plans like that in place,'' said MCI spokesman Dave Thompson. ``We are a service industry and should do everything we can to see that that service is not interrupted.''

DOC.HEAD: President Replaces Reagan Rug
DOC.TEXT: A $49,625 rug installed in the Oval Office a year and a half ago has been replaced by President Bush as part of an overall redecoration program, the White House said today. The old rug, which took two years to design and make and was paid for by an anonymous donor, was removed last Friday. It was replaced by an oval rug measuring 30 feet, 10 inches long by 23 feet, 5 inches wide. Larry Hokanson, president of a Houston company that made the new rug, said it cost $28,550, plus freight and installation charges. ``Normally, the designing process takes a couple months and the normal manufacturing time is about 16 to 18 weeks, but because of the prestige of this, we cut all that back to two weeks on designing and 2{ months on production, Hokanson said. He said every stitch of the new rug was hand-guided. It was unclear what would happen to the old rug, which was installed June 6, 1988. ``It was not terribly attractive. The president did not like it,'' Hokanson said. The new rug has a gray-blue field that centers the coat-of-arms from the presidential seal, delineated in shades of gold on an ivory ground. When the old rug was installed, press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, ``wanted to leave an asset to the White House and they felt this would be an attractive asset.'' A White House statement said that in addition to the new rug, the Oval Office had new draperies, a new coffee table and reupholstered armchairs. The entire redecoration cost $62,470 and was paid for with funds contributed by private donors, the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Newspapers, Leaders, Blast China's Restrictions on Hong Kong Government
DOC.TEXT: Newspapers and local leaders today blasted a decision by China to limit the number of lawmakers freely elected by voters, and one editorial called it an ``inglorious'' victory for Beijing. Politicians burned a copy of China's decision in front of the headquarters of the Xinhua News Agency, Beijing's de facto embassy to the British colony. In London, a senior member of Hong Kong's legislative council, Alan Lee, arrived today to lobby the British government to speed democratic reforms in the colony before it reverts to Chinese rule in 1997. Conservative business leaders took the unusual step of joining with pro-democracy activists in criticizing the plan. ``Beijing has insisted on a political scheme that has been publicly dismissed by virtually every organization and every community leader in Hong Kong,'' said Martin C.M. Lee, a leading voice for democratic change. At a news conference, Lee called on Britain to continue its push for democracy in Hong Kong. The reaction indicated the lack of faith many in this territory of 5.7 million have in Communist China. Beijing has promised to maintain Hong Kong's free-wheeling capitalist system for 50 years after it resumes control in 1997. Confidence in that promise has evaporated since the June 3-4 military crackdown on pro-democracy protesters in Beijing. Further blows have been struck as China's stance has become increasingly hard-line due to upheavals in Eastern Europe. On Saturday, in the southern Chinese city of Canton, a Chinese-appointed committee decided to limit to 18 the number of directly elected seats in Hong Kong's 60-member legislature, rising to 30 in 2003. The committee is writing the Basic Law, the blueprint for Hong Kong's government after 1997. The committee also voted to divide the legislature into two houses and further restrict who could hold high office in the territory after Beijing resumes sovereignty. None of the six committee delegates from Hong Kong voted for Beijing's plan, which passed because all 10 of China's delegates supported it. Raymond Wu, the leader of the Hong Kong delegation, called Beijing's move dictatorial and vowed to leave politics. Wu broke down in tears during sessions in Canton because, he said, ``I became sad when I thought about the future of Hong Kong.'' Hong Kong politicians have called for at least 20 seats to be directly elected in 1991 with substantial increases after that. About 1,000 Hong Kong residents leave the territory each week and the number is expected to rise. Analysts fear that if the trend continues Hong Kong's economy will suffer. Critics said China's decision to split Hong Kong's legislature revealed Beijing's desire to control political developments in the territory. Under the plan, laws will have to gain a majority of two groups - those directly elected and those chosen by special interest groups. The Daily Express said such a model would weaken the legislature and benefit the executive branch, which Beijing is expected to easily influence.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Fair-Trial Rights Not Violated When Blacks Excluded from Juries
DOC.TEXT: A sharply divided Supreme Court ruled today in the case of a convicted white rapist that fair-trial rights are not violated when blacks are excluded from serving as jurors. But the 5-4 ruling in an Illinois case did not leave white defendants powerless to challenge the exclusion of blacks from their juries. The court left unanswered whether race-based exclusions ever discriminate unlawfully against white defendants. The dissenters said the decision condones racial bias in jury selection. The court in 1986 ruled that when prosecutors disqualify potential jurors based on their race it violates the 14th Amendment's ban on discrimination. The amendment guarantees equal protection under the law. The 1986 case involved a black defendant and black jurors, and was not based on the Sixth Amendment's guarantee to be tried by a fair cross-section of the community. That ruling dramatically curtailed the traditionally broad power of prosecutors to eliminate prospective jurors from trials by using peremptory, or automatic, challenges. Justice Antonin Scalia, writing for the court in today's case, said, ``Race as such has nothing to do with the legal issue in this case.'' Scalia said the Constitution's Sixth Amendment right to be tried by a jury representing a fair cross-section of the community was not violated by excluding blacks from the trial of Daniel Holland, a Chicago-area white man sentenced to 85 years in prison for rape, kidnaping and armed robbery. Holland's ``Sixth Amendment claim would be just as strong if the object of the exclusion had been, not blacks, but postmen, or lawyers, or clergymen, or any number of other identifiable groups,'' Scalia said. The Sixth Amendment ``no more forbids the prosecutor to strike jurors on the basis of race than it forbids him to strike them on the basis of innumerable other generalized characteristics,'' he said. Justice Thurgood Marshall, in a dissenting opinion, said, ``The majority today insulates an especially invidious form of racial discrimination in the selection of juries. The elimination of racial discrimination in our system of criminal justice is not a constitutional goal that should lightly be set aside.'' He was joined by Justices William J. Brennan and Harry A. Blackmun. Justice John Paul Stevens, in a separate dissent, said, ``A jury that is the product of such a racially discriminatory selection process cannot possibly be an impartial jury within the meaning of the Sixth Amendment.`` Joining Scalia were Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Byron R. White and Anthony M. Kennedy. In Holland's case, the only two blacks among the more than 30 prospective jurors were excluded by the prosecution from serving on the all-white panel that convicted him. Prosecutors said they were not motivated by racial considerations when they used their peremptory challenges to exclude the two blacks, a man and a woman, from the jury. Holland was convicted of raping and kidnaping a Des Plaines, Ill., teen-age girl on May 4, 1980. The Illinois Supreme Court ruled that because Holland is white he lacked legal standing to raise the issue of whether race played a part in the exclusion of the blacks. The U.S. Supreme Court ruled otherwise today. Scalia said a white criminal defendant has as much legal standing as a black to claim a Sixth Amendment violation in such a case. But Scalia said Holland's claim fails because eliminating a distinctive group from a jury does not deprive the defendant of a representative jury in violation of the Constitution. The court has never held that ``representativeness cannot be diminished by allowing both the accused and the state to eliminate persons thought to be inclined against their interests,'' Scalia said. The case is Holland vs. Illinois, 88-5050.

DOC.HEAD: Court Scuttles Suit Stemming from Collapse of Maryland S&L
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today scuttled a federal lawsuit stemming from the collapse of the Old Court Savings & Loan Association in Maryland, saying state courts may handle suits based on a federal anti-racketeering law. The justices unanimously ruled that lower federal courts rightly dismissed the suit because similar suits were being handled by state courts in Maryland. Old Court's collapse helped trigger a savings and loan crisis in Maryland in 1985, and led to criminal convictions for former owners Jeffrey Levitt, Jerome Cardin and Allan Pearlstein. Levitt was sentenced to 30 years in prison for stealing $14.7 million from the thrift institution; Cardin 15 years for stealing $385,000; and Pearlstein eight years for stealing $640,786. Civil suits seeking hundreds of millions of dollars were filed against the owners in federal and state courts. Some of those claims have been settled out of court. Old Court owners and others, including a law firm and an accounting firm that worked for the savings and loan, were accused in the suits of the largest financial fraud in Maryland's history. A group of 30 Maryland non-residents _ Old Court investors who live in seven other states _ sued in federal court. They alleged, among other things, that the defendants violated the federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO). The law, although primarily aimed at fighting organized crime, has been used increasingly in lawsuits against businesses. The investors' federal suit was dismissed by a federal judge because other suits alleging RICO violations were then pending in Maryland state courts. The 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the dismissal, and today's decision said the appeals court was right. The ruling resolves conflicting rulings on the issue among the nation's federal appeals courts. ``We hold that state courts have concurrent jurisdiction to consider civil claims arising under RICO,'' Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote for the court. ``Nothing in the language, structure, legislative history or underlying policies of RICO suggests that Congress intended otherwise,'' she said. The case is Tafflin vs. Levitt, 88-1650.

DOC.HEAD: Three Guerrillas Killed by Israelis in South Lebanon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with military now saying two sted three guerrillas were killed today, details; picks up 5th pvs, `From the...' DELETES 9th pvs, `An army...' as outdated. Minor editing to CONFORM.
DOC.TEXT: Israeli troops killed two Arab guerrillas today after a firefight in southern Lebanon left an Israeli army colonel dead, the army said. In the southern Lebanese city of Sidon, the radical Abu Nidal Palestinian group today claimed responsibility for the border attack Sunday, in which the colonel and an Arab guerrilla were killed. After Sunday's exchange, troops backed by tanks launched an overnight search for two other guerrillas who the soldiers believed had fled the house, the army said. ``A chase has been going on since the early morning hours, and in the end they were discovered and in a short battle they were eliminated,'' said Israel's chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, on Israel army radio. He gave no further details of today's action. The army initially said three guerrillas were killed today, but it later said a search of the area found only two bodies. The exchange of fire began Sunday after the guerrillas barricaded themselves in an isolated house just north of the Israeli-Lebanese border. From the building, they ambushed a group of Israeli-backed Lebanese militiamen of the South Lebanon Army. The unit was led by Israeli Col. Yitzhak Rahimov, who was fatally wounded. Troops stormed the three-story house, where they found the body of one guerrilla, Shomron said. He said it was not certain whether the guerrilla was killed by Israeli troops or by cover fire from his squad members. Rahimov was the highest-ranking Israeli officer to be killed in southern Lebanon since the army withdraw the bulk of its troops in June 1985, ending a three-year occupation. Sunday's gunbattle occurred north of the Lebanese village of Yaroun, about one mile north of Israel's border. Rahimov had led a unit of the South Lebanon Army to Yaroun on Sunday after a villager reported seeing three guerrillas, Israel radio said. The guerrillas were reportedly armed with rocket-propelled grenade launchers and Soviet-designed Kalashnikov assault rifles. As the militiamen surrounded the house, the guerrillas opened fire and hurled grenades at them. South Lebanon Army fighters called in tanks, and the 39-year-old Rahimov was hit in the head by automatic gunfire as he approached one of the tanks, the radio said. Militia tanks opened fire, heavily damaging the house, the report added. In Sidon, a spokesman for Fatah-Revolutionary Council, the group led by terrorist Abu Nidal, told reporters his group had mounted the attack. However, he refused to provide other details. A separate statement by the group said the guerrilla squad was retaliating for Israeli air raids Friday on Palestinian bases and positions of the pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem Hezbollah, or Party of God. Seven people were killed and 18 wounded in those attacks. The weekend clashes on the ground occurred in Israel's self-declared security zone, a strip up to 10 miles deep in southern Lebanon. It is designed as a buffer against attacks by Palestinian and Shiite Moslem guerrillas. The security zone is patrolled jointly by Israeli troops and about 3,000 militiamen from the predominantly Christian South Lebanon Army.

DOC.HEAD: Detained Palestinian Activist Released
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Shamir threatening to resign if he loses vote of confidence, fixes typo in lead; picks up 3rd pvs: Also today ...
DOC.TEXT: Authorities today released a leading Palestinian activist after he was arrested last week on suspicion of financing Palestinian militants. The pro-PLO activist, Faisal Husseini, has been mentioned as a likely negotiator in proposed Israeli-Palestinian peace talks. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, meanwhile, threatened to resign if he loses a vote of confidence in his Middle East peace plan when his right-wing Likud bloc convenes next month to consider motions by hard-liners that the plan be dropped. ``It is very clear that if the (party) Central Committee doesn't support me I cannot stand at the head of Likud and not at the head of the country,'' Shamir said in an interview on Israel army radio. Also today, Attorney General Yosef Harish ordered police to investigate suspicions that Science Minister Ezer Weizman of the left-of-center Labor Party held illegal contacts with Palestine Liberation Organization figures, Israel radio reported. Husseini, unshaven and wearing a leather coat after leaving a police lockup, told reporters, ``Nothing will stop the peace process.'' He was released without bail while the investigation against him continues. About a dozen supporters of the anti-Arab Kach movement tried to attack Husseini as he left the jail. His supporters blocked them, and the two groups exchanged blows with fists and clubs. Women from the organization ``Victims of Arab Terror'' also scuffled nearby with Palestinian women. No one was reported injured in the melees, and Husseini managed to push his way into a waiting car. His arrest Friday brought international criticism. U.S. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said in Washington that ``such actions discourage Palestinian confidence in the peace process and contribute to the prevailing atmosphere of distrust.'' Israeli leaders have rejected charges by Israeli liberals and Palestinians that Husseini was arrested to placate right-wing pressure groups. Authorities have said Husseini belonged to a ``hostile organization'' and paid $450 to Palestinian activists to buy uniforms. In a detention hearing Friday, a district court judge ordered Husseini held for four days for questioning. Before his release today, Husseini appeared before a police investigator who said the inquiry against him would continue, but that there was no need to extend his detention. Israel radio said Husseini was questioned during the weekend by Israel's domestic security service and that several Palestinians were arrested as a result. The report did not elaborate. Husseini, 49, has been involved in behind-the-scenes diplomatic efforts to arrange Israeli-Palestinian talks in Egypt on Israel's proposal for elections in the occupied lands. Husseini, who speaks fluent Hebrew, frequently addresses Israeli audiences, calling for a Palestinian state alongside Israel and denouncing violence on both sides. Husseini spent 18 months in prison at the start of the 2-year-old Palestinian uprising without being charged.
