The reports of an inquiry of Weizman comes three weeks after allegations that he had PLO contacts nearly broke up Israel's coalition government. Shamir forced him to resign from the decision-making Inner Cabinet because of the accusations. Justice Ministry officials could not immediately be reached for comment. Despite an investigation, Weizman would be immune from prosecution unless Parliament lifted his immunity as a legislator by a majority vote. Israeli law bars contacts with the PLO as a terrorist organization, allowing a maximum punishment of three years in jail.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Review Former Wrestling Coach's Suit Against Ohio Newspaper
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 3rd graf, The Willoughby-based, to show Diadiun now with Cleveland Plain Dealer.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to review a former high school wrestling coach's 15-year-old libel lawsuit against an Ohio newspaper, a case that reached the high court twice previously. The justices said they will review an Ohio Supreme Court ruling that threw out Michael Milkovich's 1975 suit against the News Herald of Lake County. The Willoughby-based newspaper is published by the Lorain Journal Co. It and onetime sports writer Ted Diadiun, now an editor with The Plain Dealer in Cleveland, were sued over a 1975 column that accused Milkovich and a former school administrator of lying during a court hearing. Milkovich was coaching Maple Heights High School's wrestling team at a 1974 home meet against Mentor High School when a melee involving both teams and spectators erupted. Several wrestlers were hospitalized. Diadiun, who was at the meet, wrote several articles criticizing Milkovich's conduct. In a Jan. 8, 1975, column, Diadiun accused the coach and H. Don Scott, then superintendent of Maple Heights public schools, of lying to a judge who had overturned disciplinary measures against the Maple Heights team. During extensive litigation, Milkovich won two preliminary rounds before the Ohio Supreme Court, and both victories were left intact by the nation's highest court. In a 1984 decision, the Ohio court ruled that Diadiun's statements about Milkovich were reported as facts, not opinion. Expressions of opinion generally are immune from libel lawsuits. But in ruling on Scott's related libel suit two years later, the Ohio Supreme Court reversed its 1984 ruling _ and said Diadiun's statements were expressions of his opinion. In an unusual move, the Ohio court used its Aug. 6, 1986, decision in Scott's case to doom as well Milkovich's suit against the paper and Diadiun. The state court, voting 4-3 and applying a ``totality of the circumstances'' test, said the sued-over column is immune, under the Constitution's free-speech guarantees, from liability. One factor discussed by the Ohio court was the column's placement on the paper's sports page _ what the court called ``a traditional haven for cajoling, invective and hyperbole.'' In the appeal acted on today, lawyers for Milkovich urged the justices to use his case to clarify how courts should determine whether allegedly libelous statements are to be viewed as ``fact'' or ``opinion.'' But lawyers for the newspaper and Diadiun said the appeal should be rejected because the Ohio court had based its decision not only on the federal Constitution but on the Ohio Constitution as well. A state's highest court, not the U.S. Supreme Court, is the ultimate interpreter of that state's constitution. The case is Milkovich vs. Lorain Journal Co., 89-645.

DOC.HEAD: Court Signals It Willing to Allow Random Drug Testing of Some Government ^Eds: Inserts grafs 5-14, In other action, with other cases.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court, giving another signal that it is willing to allow random drug testing of government employees in sensitive positions, today rejected appeals by Justice Department employees and civilian Army counselors. The justices, in their first drug-testing rulings, last March upheld drug and alcohol tests for railway workers involved in accidents and for U.S. Customs Service employees applying for jobs in drug enforcement or jobs that require carrying a gun. Neither of those rulings, however, determined the constitutionality of randomly administered drug tests. Today the court, without comment, rejected appeals by Justice Department employees with top security clearance and civilian Army drug and alcohol counselors who said mandatory random tests violate their privacy rights. In other action, the court: _ Ruled in the case of a convicted white rapist that fair-trial rights are not violated when blacks are excluded from serving as jurors. But the 5-4 ruling in an Illinois case did not leave white defendants powerless to challenge the exclusion of blacks from their juries. The court left unanswered whether such race-based exclusions ever discriminate unlawfully against white defendants. The dissenters said the decision condones racial bias in jury selection. _ Agreed to decide whether nuclear industry ``whistleblowers'' who say they were disciplined for complaining about lax safety may sue under state personal-injury laws. The justices said they will review a North Carolina case in which a federal appeals court said such workers must sue under a special federal law. _ Agreed to use a decade-long dispute over the rights of Haitian refugees to decide when the government must pay legal fees to people who sue it successfully. The court said it will hear a Bush administration appeal aimed at limiting such fees. _ Refused to require arbitration for hundreds of thousands of federal workers when they are fired, demoted or otherwise disciplined. The court, without comment, rejected appeals by a labor union and the Federal Labor Relations Authority seeking broader job protection for federal employees. In one of the drug-testing cases acted on today, the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here upheld random urinalysis for several hundred civilian drug counselors in the Army. The appeals court said requiring them to submit to the tests is reasonable because counselors who use illicit drugs are bound to be ``unsympathetic to their mission'' of helping others overcome drug addiction. ``The Army maintains a legitimate interest in ensuring that its employees are allegiant to their essential mission,'' the appeals court said. Random testing for thousands of other civilian Army workers who fly and service planes and helicopters and hold law enforcement jobs was upheld by the appeals court also. Those employees did not appeal. The drug counselors' appeal was made by their union, the National Federation of Federal Employees. In the case involving top-ranked Justice Department employees, the appeals court said the government's interest in protecting top-security information outweighs individual privacy interests. But the appeals court barred the government from imposing random tests for other department employees, such as federal prosecutors and workers with access to grand jury information. Bush administration lawyers did not ask the Supreme Court to permit more widespread drug testing by overturning that portion of the appeals court ruling. But administration lawyers urged the court not to disturb the rulings that permit testing of the Army drug counselors and Justice Department employees with top security clearance. The counselors ``occupy a critical place in the Army's comprehensive drug program,'' the government lawyers said. As for Justice Department employees with top security clearance, the government said it is reasonable to require those ``entrusted with the government's most closely held secrets'' to be drug free. The testing of federal employees stems from a 1986 order issued by then-President Ronald Reagan calling for a drug-free federal workplace. The Supreme Court's 1989 drug-testing rulings and the cases acted on today do not bear directly on workers in private employment. Congress is reviewing proposed legislation that would set federal standards for testing by private businesses. A number of states already have drug-testing laws. Some of them give more privacy protection to workers than the federal proposal. Army counselors and Justice Department employees whose tests show they have used drugs are subject to disciplinary action or even firing, but do not face criminal prosecution as a result of the tests. The cases are National Federation of Federal Employees vs. Cheney, 89-635, and Bell vs. Thornburgh, 89-679.

DOC.HEAD: Baku-Born Chess Champ Slams Soviet Attack, Warns of Possible Bloodbath
DOC.TEXT: World chess champion Garri Kasparov today criticized the Soviet military crackdown in his hometown of Baku, saying it came too late to help his fellow Armenians in the embattled republic of Azerbaijan. Kasparov, a Jewish-Armenian, said he rescued 60 of his friends and relatives from the violence Wednesday night and that he had lost two relatives in the ethnic fighting between Azerbaijanis and Armenians. He said he used his money to charter a plane _ virtually impossible in the Soviet Union _ with the help of the Chess Union, and managed to get the people past vigilante squads to the airport on a back road. Kasparov said there were plenty of Soviet Interior Ministry troops and police in Baku before soldiers stormed the capital of Azerbaijan on Saturday to put down a nationalist uprising. Yet they took no armed action against Azerbaijanis who roved the city in bands and killed Armenians in a campaign of terror against the minority population, Kasparov claimed at a news conference. Kasparov said Azerbaijanis angry with Soviet troops could turn on the 100,000 Russians of Baku, expanding the ethnic conflict beyond the Caucasus. ``I fear that what is now happening in Azerbaijan may lead to a terrible bloodbath in the whole country,'' he said. The mainly Moslem republic Azerbaijan and the neighboring republic of Armenia, which is predominately Christian, are locked in a decades-old dispute over Nagorno-Karabakh, a region of Azerbaijan that is populated mainly by Armenians. At least 167 people have been killed since the violence began 10 days ago, including 83 since Soviet troops entered the city Saturday morning and were met by firebombs and machine-gun fire. Azerbaijani estimates of the death toll are far higher. Kasparov said Moscow either was unwilling or unable to solve ethnic disputes involving Azerbaijan and Armenia, and he called for individuals to begin direct negotiations between the republics. He volunteered to act as a mediator himself. Officials have evacuated the Armenians, and Kasparov contended virtually all had left by the time Soviet troops assaulted on Saturday. Therefore, he said, he believed the military action was intended to crush the Azerbaijani independence movement, not stop the killing, as Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said. Kasparov blamed much of the violence on the desperation of homeless Azerbaijanis, many of whom seized Armenians' apartments. ``You do not have to be a politician or a particularly farsighted person to see the political danger that lies in homeless people who have nothing to look forward to,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Zhivkov Could Face 30 Years in Jail
DOC.TEXT: Ousted leader Todor Zhivkov, who was arrested last week, faces up to 30 years in jail if convicted of misuse of state property, a newspaper reported today. Zhivkov also faces charges of inciting ethnic hostility and abusing his power during his nearly 35-year rule. Also today, a 12-party opposition coalition today resumed its discussion with the Communist leadership on reforms. The talks were suspended for several days last week after the Communists rejected an opposition demand for access to state television and radio. According to the Panorama weekend television program, Zhivkov was at his Boyana residence south of Sofia until Friday, when he was taken into custody. The report quoted the Interior Ministry as saying that Zhivkov was being held ``in a place specially adjusted for the purpose'' of investigative custody. There was no elaboration. According to the newspaper Pogled, Zhivkov could serve from 10 years to 30 years in jail if convicted of illegally ``receiving an especially large amount of public property.'' He has been accused of having about 30 hunting or holiday retreats. Another charge against him, ``inciting ethnic hostility and hatred,'' carries a maximum of three years, it said. The third charge, abuse of power, is punishable by imprisonment of between three and 10 years, it said. Zhivkov was replaced Nov. 10 by his former foreign minister, Petar Mladenov, who promised free elections and struck down guarantees of Communist Party supremacy in society. However, the pro-democracy opposition and some members within the party contend party leaders are not moving fast enough. Koprinka Chervenkova, the spokeswoman for a reform-minded faction within the ruling Communist Party, said if the party ignores the various ideological trends, platforms and associations inside it, the Alternative Socialist Society will leave the party.

DOC.HEAD: Roman Catholic Archdiocese Announces Church and School Closings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 4 grafs on end with Detroit cardinal appointed to Vatican post, his comment on the Chicago situation. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Roman Catholics reacted with sorrow, shock and at least one protest to the proposed closing of about 30 churches and 10 religious-run schools in the nation's second largest archdiocese. ``I feel like I'm losing my faith,'' said Ray Rean, who said he was born and baptized 69 years ago in St. Cyril and St. Methodius parish, which is scheduled to be closed. Cardinal Joseph Bernardin announced the closings and mergers Sunday to ease a budget defict that has forced the archdiocese to borrow from commercial banks for the first time in its 110-year history. The financial rescue plan also includes asking for greater donations and higher school fees. Though some schools and congregations knew in advance, some parish priests broke the news in announcements at services Saturday night and Sunday morning. ``For some people this is their whole life,'' Anna De Santo said after learning that her church, St. John Nepomucene, may be among those that are shuttered. ``My grandson was christened here, my children educated here, my father buried from here. I'm very sad.'' Parishioner Howard Holubetz said he was shocked to learn St. Dionysius Church in suburban Cicero would close. ``We were pretty well told if we could keep our nose above water, and we have, that it would not close,'' he said. Bernardin said shifts in demographics have left some churches and schools with too few people to meet costs. Officials say 27 percent of churches in the archdiocese sit less than half a mile from a neighboring one, reflecting the practice in the late 19th and early 20th centuries of providing ethnic-oriented parishes to serve various immigrant groups. The archdiocese has experienced several years of deficit spending, much of it to prop up individual parishes. It has borrowed $15 million since July 1988, and officials think they'll need to borrow at least $5 million more before the end of June. Without measures to stem the red ink, archdiocese debt could balloon to $142 million in 1993, officials have said. In the past five years, 27 parishes and 20 elementary schools have closed or consolidated, while five new or consolidated parishes and six new or consolidated schools have been created. Declines in numbers of priests and nuns forced the church to hire lay employees at higher costs. Insurance costs have risen, as has the cost of maintaining church buildings, Bernardin said. Officials said Sunday that the precise number of closings is not yet known, but they estimated the number at about 30 churches and six to 11 schools in the city and several suburbs. The majority are to close by the end of June and the rest by the end of June 1991. About 200 people demonstrated at the cardinal's residence later in the day to protest the announcement last week that the 604-student Quigley South prep seminary will be closed at the end of the school year. The closings and a planned 10 percent cut in administrative costs will save more than $13 million, officials said in a news release. The Chicago Archdiocese has 416 parishes in Cook and Lake Counties, an area where 2.35 million of the 5.7 million population is Catholic. It has the largest number of parishes and Catholic institutions in the nation and is second in parishioners to Los Angeles, according to officials. It runs the largest Catholic school system in the country, with 343 elementary schools, 52 secondary schools, eight colleges or universities, and five seminaries. In Detroit last year, Cardinal Edmund Szoka ordered 30 city parishes to either close or merge, citing a shortage of priests, declining membership and the increasing costs of maintaining church facilities. Today, Szoka was named by Pope John Paul II to a top financial post at the Vatican. He will head the Prefecture for Economic Affairs of the Holy See, which draws up the Vatican's budget. At a news conference called to discuss his appointment, he reacted to the Chicago announcement, saying other American cities that no longer have the flood of immigrants they did decades ago may face the same cutbacks. ``As painful as it is, we must face the reality,'' Szoka said. ``We simply can't hang onto the past. We have to change. We did that in Detroit. ``I was the first to do so on such a grand scale. Chicago now faces a similar situation. Other cities, like Philadelphia, New York and Cleveland and cities of that type, will face the same problem, and possibly the same solution.''

DOC.HEAD: Landmark Plea Raises Questions About Money-Laundering Prosecutions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after the 6th, ``I don't...,'' to UPDATE with Justice Dept. comment today. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `The subsidiaries...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SPB1
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government's acceptance of a plea bargain by subsidiaries of the world's seventh-largest private bank for laundering millions in drug money is being called a joke by some critics. But other observers say the deal with the Bank of Commerce and Credit International may be justified if it helps win a conviction against deposed Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. ``It seems like a light hit, but it depends on what the government is going to get out of them. It could be they are sitting on a wealth of information,'' said Robert Powis, a former U.S. treasury official. The divisions of the Luxembourg-based bank pleaded guilty Tuesday to about 30 charges, including tax fraud, money laundering and failing to report currency transactions of more than $10,000. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, said he was seeking an explanation about the arrangement from the Justice Department and may initiate a congressional investigation. ``I don't believe that the entire criminal justice system in America, nor all of our efforts to eliminate drugs in America, revolves just around Noriega,'' Metzenbaum said. At the Justice Department today, spokesman David Runkel defended the plea agreement, saying it guarantees the banks' cooperation in continuing investigations of international money laundering. Runkel also noted it resulted in ``the largest forfeiture ever in a case like this from a financial institution.'' ``We're satisfied this is a good deal,'' Runkel said, adding that the agreement contains further penalties if the banks fail to fulfill their obligations to the U.S. government. The subsidiaries of BCCI, which has assets of about $20 billion, admitted in Tampa federal court to laundering $14 million in drug profits for traffickers tied to Noriega. Originally charged with laundering $32 million in cocaine profits, the bank agreed to forfeit only the $14 million that the U.S. government was able to freeze during its ``Operation C-Chase'' investigation that began in 1986. Fines, which could have reached $45 million, were suspended. The bank also was placed on five years of government-supervised probation, and promised to cooperate with prosecutors in what's left of the money-laundering trial. The top remaining defendant is Amjad Awan, a bank officer who told a U.S. Senate panel in 1988 he had acted as Noriega's personal banker, managing up to $23 million in the dictator's secret accounts at the bank's Panama branch. Jury selection resumed this morning at the trial. U.S. District Judge W. Terrell Hodges has imposed a gag order to prevent parties in the case from commenting. The Bush administration has backed new initiatives against money laundering during the past year amid mounting evidence that interdiction efforts have failed to keep drugs from flooding the nation's borders. The bank's forfeiture is the largest in a money-laundering case against a financial institution in the United States. Mark Schnapp, a former assistant U.S. attorney who advises banks on how to prevent criminals from gaining access to their accounts, said financial penalties against BCCI are less significant than the fact that an entire bank has pleaded guilty to money laundering. ``I think it's a substantial price to pay,'' said Schnapp. ``No bank or banker would want to step up to the podium and say they're guilty. That smell sticks with them a long time.'' But Florida's comptroller, Gerald Lewis, said: ``We've declared unconditional war on drug traffickers. That's been the rhetoric in Washington and elsewhere. ... Was it all just a joke?'' Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., who chairs the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on narcotics, said the penalty was too lenient. ``I think it's a very, very light sentence, it's that simple,'' Kerry said. ``I think it undercuts the war on drugs.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Says D.C. Lawyers' `Strike' Against City Was Illegal
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court ruled today that lawyers in the nation's capital violated antitrust law when they went ``on strike'' to demand higher pay from the city for representing poor criminal defendants. By a 6-3 vote, the court said the boycott was ``a plain violation of antitrust laws.'' The case now goes back to a lower court to consider reinstating an order by the Federal Trade Commission that prohibits the lawyers from engaging in similar conduct in the future. Justice John Paul Stevens, writing for the court, rejected arguments that the attorneys' boycott is protected by the Constitution. ``The undenied objective of their boycott was an economic advantage for those who agreed to participate ... no matter how altruistic the motives may have been,'' he said. Stevens said the case is different from a boycott by blacks in Mississippi who refused to buy from white merchants. The court in 1982 ruled that the First Amendement protected those boycotters against antitrust damages. In a dissenting opinion joined by Justice Thurgood Marshall, Justice William J. Brennan said today's ruling goes too far in limiting free-expression rights. Brennan said the lawyers may have violated antitrust law. But he said the FTC must first prove the attorneys exerted ``market power'' _ that they were capable of exercising economic control through concerted action to determine how much the city paid them. Justice Harry Blackmun also dissented. The lawyers are members of the Superior Court Trial Lawyers Association. The group organized a boycott in 1983 to pressure the District of Columbia government to increase the hourly compensation paid to attorneys who represent indigent criminal defendants. The attorneys, some 100 lawyers who represent most of the city's poor criminal defendants, had been receiving $30 an hour for time in court and $20 an hour for out-of-court work. They won a $25 per hour increase after a two-week boycott in which nearly all of them refused to accept new cases. The boycott created a crisis for the city, swamping the city public defender's office with criminal cases. The city government agreed to the higher hourly rate at an annual cost to taxpayers of more than $4 million. The private lawyers who boycotted represent 85 percent of the poor defendants. The remaining defendants are represented by the public defender service, third-year law students or, in a small number of cases, lawyers volunteering to work free. The FTC ruled after the so-called strike that the lawyers had engaged in price fixing and an illegal boycott and ordered them not to engage in similar conduct again. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here set aside the FTC decision and ordered the agency to conduct further study to determine whether the lawyers exerted market power. The case is FTC vs. Superior Court Trial Lawyers Association, 88-1198.

DOC.HEAD: Street Erupts, 10 Injured; Blame Pressurized Tunnel
DOC.TEXT: A section of a Tokyo street erupted Monday, spewing water, stones and mud before collapsing into a hole 17 feet deep, authorities said. Ten people were injured, including three who were jostled by hundreds of spectators trying to get a closer look. The 3:05 p.m. incident in the Ueno district was believed to have been caused by a pressurized tunnel beneath the street, and it opened up a hole about 42 feet long and 32 feet wide, said Kenichiro Sumi of the Metropolitan Fire Board. No one fell into the hole. Most of the injured were hurt by stones and other debris sent flying by the erupting street, which is beneath the tracks of two major commuter lines near a Japan Railways station. A 18-year-old suffered a head injury when the front wheels of the station wagon he was driving slipped over the edge of the hole, police said. All trains on the tracks overhead were stopped for about an hour while the rails were inspected, Japan Railways officials said. A pressurized tunnel was suspected of causing the eruption, police said, but added they still were investigating. The tunnel, still under construction, reportedly had been pressurized to prevent a cave-in. The spectacular eruption, which spattered nearby buildings with mud and debris up to the third story, attracted a huge crowd, estimated by Kyodo News Service at 5,000, within minutes. Kenichiro Sumi of Tokyo's Metropolitan Fire Board said three of the injuries occurred as spectators jostled for a better view.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Says Bhopal Settlement Will Be Scrapped
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD comment from Union Carbide, SUB grafs 9-10 with 4 grafs; pickup 11th graf pvs, `When Union...'
DOC.TEXT: Declaring India will make no deals ``over human corpses,'' Prime Minister V.P. Singh rejected a $470 million settlement with Union Carbide in the Bhopal gas disaster and vowed to pursue $3 billion instead. The new prime minister also said Sunday that his government would press criminal charges in the case. The 1984 gas leak, the world's deadliest industrial disaster, killed more than 3,500 people. The $470 million settlement was accepted last year by the Indian Supreme Court and by Singh's predecessor, Rajiv Gandhi. Singh was greeted Sunday by surging crowds when he arrived at the Jaiprakash Nagar shantytown, where many of the victims had lived. Some people draped garlands of flowers around Singh's neck or knelt to touch his feet as he walked through the narrow lanes of huts just across the street from the now-closed Union Carbide plant. At a public rally attended by an estimated 100,000 people, one-tenth of Bhopal's population, Singh declared: ``We have decided to do away with the settlement and pursue the $3 billion suit against the company and also the criminal suit against UCC (Union Carbide Corp.) officials.'' He promised that his government would provide interim relief to all people living in affected areas. The amount of money to be paid will be determined within one month, he said. The prime minister, who took office Dec. 2, did not spell out how his government would revive the legal case. Union Carbide said today from its headquarters in Danbury, Conn., that it would have no comment beyond a statement made last week by Joseph E. Geoghan, the company's vice president and general counsel. ``The settlement was extremely fair and is a binding agreement of the union of India,'' Geoghan said at the time. India's Supreme Court on Feb. 15 accepted the $470 million deal as ``full and final settlement'' of the government's suit, which had been dragging through a maze of Indian court procedures for about four years. The Gandhi government originally sought $3 billion in damages and later filed criminal negligence charges against top officials of Union Carbide and dissolved its local subsidiary. When Union Carbide and the Gandhi government agreed on the $470 million, the Supreme Court absolved the company of further civil or criminal liability. However, under Indian law, the decision is subject to review if challenged. Gas victims and activist groups filed petitions with the court challenging the settlement on two grounds: that the Gandhi government had no right to declare itself the sole representative of all claims arising from the Bhopal gas disaster; and that the compensation of $470 million was inadequate. The Supreme Court declared Dec. 22 that the Gandhi government did, indeed, have the right to be the claimants' only representative. The second challenge is still pending, and the Singh government announced Jan. 12 it would support the challengers. Union Carbide has maintained the gas leak was the result of sabotage by a disgruntled employee at the Bhopal plant. The government maintained the disaster was caused by company negligence. Methyl isocyanate, a liquid used in making pesticides, leaked from a tank and turned into a deadly vapor when it hit the air Dec. 3, 1984, while most people were asleep. According to figures compiled by the government of Madhya Pradesh state, which includes Bhopal, the death toll has reached 3,598. About half the victims died immediately or within a few days of exposure to the gas. The others died later of respiratory and other problems caused by the gas, according to government records.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Military Plane Crashes, Pilot Injured
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet MiG-27 fighter plane crashed into a forest during a training flight Monday, and the pilot was injured when he ejected, the official news agency ADN said. The fighter plane crashed between the villages of Petkus and Wahlsdorf, in the district of Potsdam near Berlin. No one was injured on the ground in the crash, which was under investigation, ADN said.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Killed in Bus Crash to be Cremated in Katmandu
DOC.TEXT: Two Americans killed in the head-on collision of two buses in west Nepal will be cremated Wednesday on the banks of the Bagmati River, officials said. Adam Zakir of Richmond, Calif., and his wife, Karen Lee Duthie, were among 25 people killed in the crash Friday at Adhuwa Mandrebhir, about 95 miles west of Katmandu. U.S. Embassy officials said Monday they had received authorization from the families for the cremation.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Assures Marchers He Opposes Roe v. Wade
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs files; trims throughout to remove outdated material and shorten
DOC.TEXT: President Bush assured anti-abortion marchers today of his ``deep conviction'' against the Supreme Court ruling 17 years ago today that legalized abortion and his steadfast opposition to abortion on demand. Bush, speaking by telephone to marchers gathered outside the White House before their annual march past the Capitol and the Supreme Court, said the anti-abortion movement reminds Americans ``of the self-evident moral superiority of adoption over abortion.'' Bush also addressed the March for Life last year on his third day as president, continuing the tradition of his predecessor, Ronald Reagan. Even as he spoke, pro-choice forces led by the Planned Parenthood Federation were urging Americans to call the White House switchboard to register their support for legal abortions. Bush, in remarks that lasted just 90 seconds, said, ``Before you begin the march, I want to take a minute to share my deep personal concern about abortion on demand, which I oppose. ``For 17 years the March for Life has served as a poignant reminder to all Americans that human life in all its forms must be respected. And I think all of you know my deep conviction on Roe vs. Wade,'' he added. The protest movement ``also reminds Americans, especially young Americans, of the self-evident moral superiority of adoption over abortion. We should all be grateful to the families that adopt babies, giving them care and love and a chance for a wonderful life,'' said Bush, two of whose 12 grandchildren are adopted. After hearing Bush and a handful of congressmen and other speakers, the crowd planned to march up Pennsylvania Avenue to the U.S. Capitol and the Supreme Court. Leaders of the National Right to Life Committee praised the president and said they had no differences with Republican National Chairman Lee Atwater's statements that the party can support candidates on both sides of the abortion debate. ``We don't believe he's signaled any change in the Republican Party's position,'' said David O'Steen, executive director of the anti-abortion group. ``Of course the Republican Party contains and is big enough to contain people with both points of view, as is the Democratic Party.'' Earlier, backers of legal abortion raised the specter of Romania's former communist repression in warning against a rollback of abortion rights. The head of the National Abortion Rights Action League told a gathering on Capitol Hill that legalizing abortions was one of the first steps Romania took after overthrowing its hated dictator last month. ``Romanians know firsthand what most Americans can only imagine _ the deadly impact of government bans on abortion,'' said Kate Michelman, executive director of the abortion-rights lobbying group. ``It would be a travesty if the United States, the beacon of democracy in the world, applauded Romania's reforms while adopting repressive anti-choice laws here at home,'' she said. Activists on both sides of the issue _ sensing 1990 will be a pivotal year in the political debate on abortion _ held competing events marking the anniversary of the high court decision that legalized abortions. Abortion foes expected tens of thousands of marchers in Washington, and more at smaller events around the country. Abortion-rights advocates also gathered on the Mall outside the Capitol where a temporary memorial was erected in tribute to all women who have died from illegal, botched abortions _ including Becky Bell, a 17-year-old Indianapolis girl who died in September 1988 after a self-induced abortion. Bill Bell, her father, said his daughter died because Indiana law requires minors to obtain parental consent before they can get a legal abortion. ``Our daughter was punished,'' he said. ``She was denied a reasonable and safe choice because she loved her parents and died not wanting to disappoint them. ... How many more young women will share Becky's fate if we allow our government to deny them a safe choice?'' Sen. Bob Packwood of Oregon, a leading Republican supporter of abortion rights, said his party is being damaged by the strongly anti-abortion platform and position of Bush, who vetoed abortion-rights bills passed by Congress last fall. He predicted the anti-abortion plank in the Republican Party platform will be removed in 1992. Activists on both sides of the abortion issue rallied Sunday in cities across the country, from Albany, N.Y., to Sacramento, Calif. Leaders of the anti-abortion movement planned to meet with Bush's chief of staff, John Sununu, and other administration officials, but there were no plans for the president to see them, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Friday. Sununu is a strong opponent of abortion. Others planning to speak to the anti-abortion rally included Republican Sens. Jesse Helms of North Carolina and Gordon Humphrey of New Hampshire. Abortion opponents have held their ``March for Life'' every year since the court's decision. But this year's events had a new significance: it was the first since the high court's Webster decision in July 1989, which opened the door for states to impose some restrictions on abortion. ``Most of the time this is a sad occasion,'' said Nancy Myers, spokeswoman for the National Right to Life Committee. ``But there's a sense of hope this year because for the first time since 1973 the Supreme Court has said it will allow some reasonable limits on abortion.'' The march came as political debate on abortion has intensified. Abortion opponents have said they intend to push for new restrictions on abortions in many state legislatures. But candidates who supported abortion rights won key elections last fall, and pro-choice leaders claim public opinion has shifted to their side.

Here is the text of President Bush's remarks from the Oval Office on Monday to the March for Life. I want to welcome all of you gathered in Washington from around the country for this year's March for life. Before you begin the march, I want to take a minute to share my deep personal concern about abortion on demand, which I oppose. For 17 years the March for Life has served as a poignant reminder to all Americans that human life in all its forms must be respected. And I think all of you know my deep conviction on Roe vs. Wade. The continuing strong presence of the March for Life reminds those of us in decision-making capacities in the White House and in the Congress and on the Court that millions of Americans care fundamentally about this issue and are committed to preserving the sanctity of life. Your movement also reminds Americans, especially young Americans, of the self-evident moral superiority of adoption over abortion. We should all be grateful to the families that adopt babies, giving them care and love and a chance for a wonderful life. So ladies and gentlemen, let me assure that this president stands with you on this issue of life. And that my prayers go out to all of you for your faith and courage. God bless you and God bless life. Thank you very much.

DOC.HEAD: Quarterback Controversy Sparks Racism Discussion in Small Town
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `The demonstrations...', to CORRECT player's name to Mickey Wilson sted Leland.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NU1
DOC.TEXT: Five months after a high school football coach replaced a black quarterback with a less-experienced white player, a chain of recriminations has embittered race relations in this small town. Racial problems generally had stayed hidden in this bucolic town of 14,000 residents. But the largely black protesters say the boycott of the team, picketing of the school and weekly marches that began in August are partly the result of longstanding grievances. ``Conway very definitely has a problem with racism. America has a problem with racism,'' said the Rev. H.H. Singleton, a former science teacher who was fired by the all-white school board after becoming a spokesman for boycotting black players. Conway's population is 41 percent black. ``While these kinds of incidents have been happening all along, the white community thinks it's nothing to get excited about,'' said Dr. William Gibson, a Greenville dentist and chairman of the NAACP national board of directors. ``Yes, it angers them because they're not used to it. They blame the person who is the victim every time.'' Said Mayor Ike Long, who is white: ``I don't think that Conway had a racial problem as such until this thing came up. I don't know that we have so much of a racial problem now.'' The demonstrations began after Conway High's white football coach, Chuck Jordan, switched quarterback Carlos Hunt, who is black, to defensive back. Jordan replaced Hunt with Mickey Wilson Jr., a less-experienced player and the son of an assistant coach. Jordan later said he made the change because Hunt refused to follow his instructions on the field. Hunt wasn't happy with the switch, and neither were many of his teammates. On Aug. 22, Singleton announced that 31 of the 37 black players were boycotting the team to protest the quarterback change. All but 10 of the striking players stayed out the entire season and the team ended up with a 1-11 record. Less than a week after the walkout began, the parents of 61 white students enrolled in Singleton's science class at Conway Middle School requested their children be assigned another teacher. The following day, Horry County School Superintendent John Dawsey suspended Singleton on the grounds he was disrupting school. The school board fired Singleton, who also is pastor of Cherry Hill Baptist Church, three months later. What followed were protest marches through town that drew hundreds of marchers on several Saturdays; regular picketing outside the high school; a two-day boycott of classes by black students; and a promise by the NAACP to stage a political and economic boycott in Horry County. An investigation by state Human Affairs Commissioner James Clyburn determined the Hunt incident was not racially motivated. Long appointed a bi-racial task force to study the issue. In general, Clyburn's findings were supported by the white community and decried by blacks. Leaders of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People say they will continue their protest until Singleton is reinstated in his teaching job, and will press for other changes. For one thing, they want a change in hiring practices for schools in the town, which is 15 miles northwest of Myrtle Beach. A lengthy investigation by the state Human Affairs Commission concluded last month that for the last decade, white job applicants in Horry County schools have had a distinct advantage over blacks. The investigation was begun before the dispute over the football team arose. On Saturday, 1,000 people turned out for a protest march in Myrtle Beach. ``It's a process that has to evolve,'' Gibson said. ``Horry County is moving in that direction, but it hasn't arrived yet. We're going to march in Conway a long time, a lot of times.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Invites Incoming Presidents of Brazil, Uruguay
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has invited the presidents-elect of Brazil and Uruguay to meet with him at the White House, his spokesman said today. He will meet Jan. 26 with Brazilian president-elect Fernando Collor de Mello, then on Feb. 5 with the president-elect of Uruguay, Luis Alberto LaCalle, press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. Fitzwater suggested the meetings are partly in response to Bush's desire to reach out to Latin American leaders to ease resentments from last month's invasion of Panama. The spokesman cited a ``continuing dialogue with Latin America on political and economic issues.'' ``Democracy in the region'' will be high on the agenda of both meetings, Fitzwater said. At Bush's behest, Vice President Dan Quayle leaves Saturday on a goodwill mission to Honduras, Jamaica and Panama. He plans to visit several other Latin American nations in March.

DOC.HEAD: Romanian Leader Says 120 Bullets Taken from Ceausescus' Bodies
With AM-Romania
DOC.TEXT: Only five volunteers were asked to execute deposed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife last month, but the entire 80-man firing squad insisted on shooting, a member of Romania's interim government told a newspaper. Silviu Brucan, a member of the 11-member executive council of the National Salvation Front, told the daily newspaper Le Figaro that the enthusiasm of the firing squad reflected the popular support for the Dec. 25 execution. ``I can tell you that when the firing squad was formed, the officer in command asked for five soldiers to step forward and prepare to fire. The squad was made up of 80 men. All fired at the same moment. They found 120 bullet holes in the bodies of Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu,'' Brucan said in the interview, published Monday. Some Western nations criticized the new Romanian leaders for conducting the trial of the Ceausescus in secret. Parts of the trial later were shown on state television. Brucan said the leaders of Romania's revolution would have prefered to hold a public trial, ``but in the context of Dec. 24, that was utopic.'' ``That Sunday was the most dangerous for the Romanian revolution,'' he said, recalling in the interview that the state Securitate was on the offensive and had attacked the TV station. ``We thought there was a risk of the Securitate attacking the barracks where Ceausescu and his wife were being detained. If they had been freed and retaken by their men, it would have been a bloodbath in Romania,'' Brucan told the newspaper. He added that after it was announced that Ceausescu was dead and state TV showed pictures of his body, ``the unity of the Securitate began to fall apart.'' Brucan said about 10,000 people died during the violence in December, but that life has begun to return to normal. But, he added, it could be many years before the country achieved democracy and the kind of open political system hoped for by his countrymen. ``Our people should learn democracy, and us as well, we should learn to govern democratically,'' he told the newspaper. ``In 10 years, social life will achieve an equalibrium. But for democracy, it will take 20 years. In any case, that is my opinion.''

Here, at a glance, are highlights of actions taken Monday by the Supreme Court.
DRUG TESTS
The court, giving another signal that it is willing to allow random drug testing of government employees in sensitive positions, rejected appeals by Justice Department employees and civilian Army counselors. The justices, in their first drug-testing rulings, last March upheld drug and alcohol tests for railway workers involved in accidents and for U.S. Customs Service employees applying for jobs in drug enforcement or jobs that require carrying a gun. Neither of those rulings, however, determined the constitutionality of randomly administered drug tests. Today the court, without comment, rejected appeals by Justice Department employees with top security clearance and civilian Army drug and alcohol counselors who said mandatory random tests violate their privacy rights. The cases are National Federation of Federal Employees vs. Cheney, 89-635, and Bell vs. Thornburgh, 89-679.
JURORS
The court ruled in the case of a convicted white rapist that fair-trial rights are not violated when blacks are excluded from serving as jurors. But the 5-4 ruling in an Illinois case did not leave white defendants powerless to challenge the exclusion of blacks from their juries. The court left unanswered whether such race-based exclusions ever discriminate unlawfully against white defendants. The dissenters said the decision condones racial bias in jury selection. The case is Holland vs. Illinois, 88-5050.
NUCLEAR SAFETY
The court agreed to decide whether nuclear industry ``whistleblowers'' who say they were disciplined for complaining about lax safety may sue under state personal-injury laws. The justices said they will review a North Carolina case in which a federal appeals court said such workers must sue under a special federal law. The case is English vs. General Electric, 89-152.
LEGAL FEES
The court agreed to use a decade-long dispute over the rights of Haitian refugees to decide when the government must pay legal fees to people who sue it successfully. The court said it will hear a Bush administration appeal aimed at limiting such fees. The case is Commissioner of INS vs. Jean, 89-601.
ARBITRATION
The court refused to require arbitration for hundreds of thousands of federal workers when they are fired, demoted or otherwise disciplined. The court, without comment, rejected appeals by a labor union and the Federal Labor Relations Authority seeking broader job protection for federal employees. The cases are National Treasury Employees Union vs. Treasury Department, 89-610, and Federal Labor Relations Authority vs. Treasury Department, 89-758.
LAWYERS
The court ruled that lawyers in the nation's capital violated antitrust law when they went ``on strike'' to demand higher pay from the city for representing poor criminal defendants. By a 6-3 vote, the court said the boycott was ``a plain violation of antitrust laws.'' The case now goes back to a lower court to consider reinstating an order by the Federal Trade Commission that prohibits the lawyers in Washington from engaging in similar conduct in the future. The case is FTC vs. Superior Court Trial Lawyers Association, 88-1198.
FARMERS
The court turned away a challenge to a bank's foreclosure on an Oregon couple seeking to hold onto a farm in their family since 1853. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the federal law Myron and Jane Harper relied on in their legal fight gives only the government, not farmers, the right to sue. A federal appeals court ruling in the Harpers' case set binding law in nine western states, and involves a farm-loan program totaling over $50 billion nationwide. The case is Harper vs. Federal Land Bank of Spokane, 89-863.
VOTING RIGHTS ACT
The court ruled that a Bibb County, Ga., school bond referendum attacked by blacks as a violation of the federal Voting Rights Act was legal. The court, without waiting to hear arguments in the case, upheld a ruling that permitted the county's voters to approve $29 million to air-condition existing schools and build a new high school. The justices' decision was not accompanied by any written opinion. There was no recorded dissenting vote. The case is Lucas vs. Townsend, 89-400.
ABORTION PICKETS
The court refused to revive a federal civil rights lawsuit by five people prosecuted for anti-abortion picketing outside a San Diego medical clinic. The justices, without comment, let stand a decision dismissing allegations that the clinic's operators violated the pickets' free-speech rights. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last June 23 threw out $11,800 awards each of the five pickets had won in a federal trial. The case is Collins vs. Womancare, 89-819.
HOME ADDRESSES
The court refused to let public employee labor unions get from the government the home addresses of federal workers. The court, without comment, left intact a ruling that the workers' privacy would be violated if government agencies are forced to divulge the information to the unions. The cases are American Federation of Government Employees vs. Department of Health and Human Services, 89-444; National Treasury Employees Union vs. Treasury Department, 89-566; and Federal Labor Relations Authority vs. Treasury Department, 89-853.
LIBEL SUIT
The court today agreed to review a former high school wrestling coach's 15-year-old libel lawsuit against an Ohio newspaper, a case that reached the high court twice previously. The justices said they will review an Ohio Supreme Court ruling that threw out Michael Milkovich's 1975 suit against the News Herald of Lake County. The case is Milkovich vs. Lorain Journal Co., 89-645.
SAVINGS AND LOAN
The court scuttled a federal lawsuit stemming from the collapse of the Old Court Savings & Loan Association in Maryland, saying state courts may handle suits based on a federal anti-racketeering law. The justices unanimously ruled that lower federal courts rightly dismissed the suit because similar suits were being handled by state courts in Maryland. The case is Tafflin vs. Levitt, 88-1650.

DOC.HEAD: Armenian, Azerbaijani Leaders Agree to Try to End Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to ADD details on agreement between Armenian-Azerbaijani officials; picks up 10th pvs, `If the...'
DOC.TEXT: Armenian and Azerbaijani leaders agreed today to remove armed groups from the border between the new republics in an attempt to end clashes that have led to at least 167 deaths, Tass said. The Soviet news agency said the agreement came during a meeting of Armenian and Azerbaijani government officials in the border town of Yeraskh. But it would need the approval of armed militants on both sides. In the Azerbaijani capital of Baku, hundreds of thousands of Azerbaijanis massed today to bury scores of countrymen killed by Soviet troops dispatched to end the ethnic violence, witnesses said. The official Tass news agency said 83 people were killed Saturday in an assault by Soviet troops in Baku or in skirmishes the previous day. The ethnic violence flared Jan. 13 with anti-Armenian riots in Baku, a oil-producing center of 1.7 million people on the Caspian Sea, and spread throughout Azerbaijan and Armenia. The neighboring republics are locked in a decades-old dispute over Nagorno-Karabakh, a region of Azerbaijan that is populated mainly by Armenians. Armenians are predominately Christians said the night had been peaceful. A political scientist who teaches at the Azerbaijan Academy of Sciences, Jahun Mulazade, reported scattered gunfire early today but said Soviet military forces generally appeared in control of the city. Azerbaijani activists claimed the death toll in the military assault was much higher than the official figure. Yusif Bagirov, an attorney and member of an independent investigatory commission created by Baku lawyers, asserted that 1,000 civilians were killed in the district that encompasses Baku. He said at least 94 bodies were in coffins borne through Baku's streets for burial today. An emergency overnight session of the Azerbaijani legislature demanded the withdrawal of Soviet army and Interior Ministry troops from the republic, with the exception of border districts with Armenia, said another Baku lawyer, Viliyad Mamedov, who attended the 11{-hour meeting. Lawmakers also demanded the lifting of the curfew in Baku and the state of emergency Gorbachev declared in much of Azerbaijan one week ago, Mamedov said by telephone. If those demands are not met, Mamedov said, the legislature will consider voting to secede from the Soviet Union. In Baku, radio, television and means of public transport except the city's metro were not working today due to the general strike, Mula-Zade said. It was not clear who called the strike, but Radio Moscow blamed the grass-roots Azerbaijani People's Front, which it said was trying to ``fan hostility and breed popular resentment toward the Soviet army.' Foreign reporters were barred from Armenia and Azerbaijan so it was difficult to determine the exact death toll. About 29,000 Soviet troops, police, cadets and interior ministry forces are reported combating the violence in the southern region. The number of militants has been reported to be in the thousands. Sheikh Ul Islam, the spiritual leader of Azerbaijani Moslems, condemned the Saturday assault on Baku in an address to world and religious leaders sent to Azerinform today. In Moscow, world chess champion Garri Kasparov today said the Soviet assault on his native Baku was too late to save the terrorized Armenian population. ``I fear that what is now happening in Azerbaijan may lead to a terrible bloodbath in the whole country,'' said Kasparov, of Jewish and Armenian parentage, who fled Baku with 60 relatives and friends.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor: Computer `Worm' Was No Juvenile Prank By Grad Student
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to CORRECT prosecutor's first name to Ellen sted Elizabeth and UPDATE with defense closing argument. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `There is...'.
DOC.TEXT: A graduate student was engaged in no juvenile prank when he created a ``worm'' program that paralyzed thousands of computers throughout the nation in 1988, a prosecutor contended this morning. Robert T. Morris, 25, of Arnold, Md., is the first person brought to trial under a section of the 1986 Computer Fraud and Abuse Act that makes it a felony to break into a federal computer network and prevent authorized use of the system. Closing arguments in his federal trial began this morning. Ellen Meltzer, a trial lawyer for the U.S. Justice Department, said Morris deliberately stole computer passwords from hundreds of people so the worm could break into as many computers as possible. And she said Morris, who had testified that he never intended for the worm program to cause such harm, took deliberate and conscious steps to make the rogue program difficult to detect and eradicate. ``This was not a mistake,'' she said. ``Robert Morris worked diligently at creating this worm ... at trying to make it better.'' But Morris' lawyer, Thomas Guidoboni, contended in his closing arguments that didn't intend to cause, and did not cause, permanent damage to any computer files when he unleased the worm. ``There was no work lost; work was delayed. That's the bottom line,'' Guidoboni said. He said that once Morris realized the worm had gone berserk, he took steps to try to stop it. When that failed, Guidoboni said Morris had friends send out a message on an electronic bulletin board with instructions how to defeat the worm. ``Does a person who intends unauthoritized use or to cause a system to crash send out a message to stop it? Of course not,'' Guidoboni said. Following this morning's closing arguments, U.S. District Court Judge Howard Munson sent the jury to lunch. He was expected to instruct jurors and give them the case this afternoon. There is mixed feeling among those who testified over whether the suspended Cornell University graduate student should be severely punished for what he said was an experiment that ran out of control. ``I don't think he did anything wrong,'' said Paul Graham, a government witness who became friends with Morris at Harvard and knew of Morris' work on the worm. Graham said Morris should not be punished because the worm was ``an intellectual experiment'' common among computer security students and the only practical way to test whether security holes they find really exist. ``A lot of computer security people, while in graduate school, spend time breaking into systems. The government has decided it doesn't want them to do this anymore,'' Graham said. ``They want them to learn about computer security from reading books.'' But Eugene Spafford, a Purdue University computer ethics professor who has written about the worm and testified as a government witness, said Morris committed vandalism and should be punished accordingly. He said Morris' defense that he didn't mean to paralyze the Internet network, which links computers at major universities, NASA and several military facilities, is like an arsonist saying he didn't mean for the fire he started to cause any damage. Most of the nearly dozen computer systems managers from facilities attacked by the worm said Morris should be convicted but should not be dealt a harsh sentence. ``I'd like to see an uncontested conviction and a light sentence,'' said Michael Muuss, leader of the Advanced Computer Systems team at the U.S. Army Ballistics Research Laboratory in Aberdeen, Md. ``I think the conviction would be a deterrent enough for others thinking about something like this,'' he said. Morris admitted last Thursday on the witness stand that he designed the worm specifically to infect Internet. He said the worm was an experiment that turned into a ``dismal failure'' because of a programming error he made that caused it to replicate wildly once it entered a computer. It took several days to eliminate the worm. The rogue program was originally termed a computer ``virus,'' but unlike viruses it did not require a ``host'' program to reproduce. Although the indictment charged the worm did about $1,000 in damage, computer experts estimated that the time computers were down and the labor needed to combat the worm cost $5 million to $12 million. The worm was only supposed to break into a handful of the 180,000 computers on Internet and then just leave a single copy of itself in all but a few machines, Morris said. ``It was a mistake and I'm sorry,'' were Morris' last words as he stepped off the witness stand.

DOC.HEAD: Navigation Satellite Scheduled for Launch Wednesday
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force announced Monday it plans to launch the fifth in a new series of military navigation satellites on Wednesday. Liftoff of the Delta 2 rocket was scheduled for a 21-minute period that starts at 5:55 p.m. The $65 million Navstar satellite is to join a network of navigation spacecraft that can tell U.S. and allied military forces where they are to within 50 feet anywhere in the world, in any weather. The Air Force plans to have 21 of the satellites orbiting the Earth by 1992 to form a global network.

DOC.HEAD: Criminologists See Little Lasting Impact from Barry Arrest
With AM-Barry Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry's arrest on a drug charge could do some good as a cautionary tale for white collar drug users, especially government officials who might believe they'll never get caught, criminologists suggest. Indeed, private queries at some drug treatment centers increased sharply after the arrest. But people well-versed on the subject say such concern by possible users usually doesn't last. And no one is predicting much, if any, impact on the drug trade in general. Most drug distributors and sellers ``are very cynical about the way the world operates,'' said criminologist Richard R. Bennett of American University. ``They're going to say, `Mayor Barry got caught. It's the price you pay for playing the game.' ... They expect their leaders to be cunning and deviant and deceptive, because that's how they operate on their day-to-day basis.'' At the same time, Geoffrey P. Alpert, University of South Carolina criminal justice professor, said the arrest's impact on drug users ``is a very important one, that you cannot be above the law.'' ``It gives a message to the white collar user,'' he said. ``It also gives a message to government officials, and that is that no matter how hard you try to hide your use of narcotics, and particularly cocaine, you can get caught, you can get arrested.'' Barry, who was arrested Thursday night, has not commented directly on the charge of cocaine possession, but his lawyer has said he will plead not guilty. The mayor left the city Monday for a treatment center. Dr. Errol Segall, director of chemical dependence services at Dominion Hospital in Falls Church, Va., reported that phone calls to the hospital have ``increased three- to four-fold since the story broke.'' ``During a crisis time, people come forth with questions, with concerns,'' Segall said. ``It's a breakthrough of their denial systems, and so they reach out. Unfortunately, once a crisis like this episode is past, the denial level sort of goes back up. And that's what keeps drug problems going, is a sense of denial.'' Roger Chapin, president of the 300,000-member Citizens for a Drug Free America, said he doubts Barry's arrest will have much impact because ``an awful lot of people have suspected for a long time that he was a user.'' If another prominent mayor turned out to be a drug user, that would ``shake a lot of people,'' Chapin said. Bennett said District of Columbia children are likely to be rattled by the arrest. ``The idea of this guy getting up before us two days before saying, `We're doing something, we're winning the war on drugs,' ... I think it sends a very confusing message to a lot of inner city black kids who look up to Marion Barry as an idol. I think that is going to hurt us.'' Dr. Alfred Blumstein, dean of the School of Urban and Public Affairs at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, said the arrest's impact is ``going to depend critically on how the mayor plays it.'' ``If he plays the sympathy angle, and I gather that's where he's going, I think he can use that as an opportunity to dedicate himself not only to his own salvation, but as part of the message to the larger community, to say, `Look at the evil that can befall one when one gets messed up with drugs,''' Blumstein said in an interview Monday. The arrest demonstrates that, ``The war on drugs ultimately is going to have to get at demand issues,'' Blumstein said. ``It's clear that as long as the demand is maintained, the supply side will find a way to meet it, whether through new sources of supply, new ports of entry, or new drugs.''

DOC.HEAD: Six Missing, One Dead as Charter Boat Capsizes off Washington Coast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with search resuming, weather still a problem, picking up at 4th graf pvs, `None of...'.
DOC.TEXT: High seas and wind hampered a search today for six people missing after a charter fishing boat smashed against a jetty at the mouth of a river, and officials said rescue hopes were dwindling. One woman died and two other people aboard the Gambler were rescued after the 45-foot boat capsized Sunday in 15-foot swells while crossing a bar at the mouth of the Quillayute River about 110 miles west of Seattle. A helicopter, a lifeboat and beach crews searched for the missing men today. Visibility was good but seas ran 16 to 18 feet with wind blowing at 25 to 30 mph. During the night, the search was hampered by 20-foot seas, wind of 15 mph to 25 mph and fog that frequently reduced visibility to near zero, the Coast Guard said. Six people patrolled the Pacific beach overnight, said Coast Guard Quartermaster 1st Class Robert Goodrich. ``None of the (missing) people were wearing any life jackets,'' Goodrich said. ``I'm sure you can read between the lines, but we're just hoping for the best.'' Paula Becker was pronounced dead on arrival at the hospital after she, Jerry Nelson and Ron Wilson, both believed to be in their 20s, were plucked from the water by a Coast Guard helicopter from Port Angeles, officials said. Nelson and Wilson were listed in stable condition at Forks Community Hospital. The charter boat owner and operator, Jeffrey Andersen, was among the missing. Ernie McGill, a worker at a nearby resort who witnessed the capsizing about 3 p.m. PST, said the tide had just turned as the boat headed for land. ``The water started boiling ... and the boat was pushed into the jetty,'' McGill said. ``The boat is in a million pieces.''

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrations Across Country on Eve of Roe vs. Wade Anniversary
With PM-Abortion Rally, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with more demonstrations today, Nebraska legislature adjourning without taking action. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `In Dallas...'.
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators carried the battle for the hearts and minds of Americans on the abortion issue to state capitals today to commemorate the 17th anniversary of the Supreme Court's Roe vs. Wade ruling. The demonstrations began Sunday, when an estimated 25,000 to 30,000 people joined dueling rallies in Phoenix, while supporters of legalized abortion sang and chanted in Albany, N.Y., and opponents held ``baby showers'' for poor women who choose to have children in Provo, Utah. Demonstrations also were held in Boston, Raleigh, N.C., and Spokane, Wash. Today, there were rallies by both sides in Washington, D.C., by anti-abortion groups in Trenton, N.J., and Salt Lake City, and by a pro-choice group in Baton Rouge, La. In Indianapolis, bells tolled at a a dozen churches to mark the day, rung 25 times ``one time for every million babies killed since 1973,'' said Right to Life spokeswoman Kathleen Porter In Baton Rouge, the newly formed Coalition for Reproductive Freedom wound a 200-foot ribbon around the state Capitol steps as a symbol of their support for Roe vs. Wade. In Trenton, about 150 protesters marched in front of the New Jersey Statehouse, the site of recent debates over a bill to require notification of parents whose minor daughters seek abortions. A similar protest at the Utah Capitol also drew about 150 abortion opponents. Debate began today on a parental notification bill pending before the Nebraska Legislature, but the legislators got bogged down on time-consuming amendments proposed by a critic of the bill and adjourned without taking action. In Dallas, the attorney who argued the case that legalized abortion 17 years ago spoke to pro-choice advocates at a commemorative breakfast today. ``We are here to say we won 17 years ago today, and we will win again,'' Sarah Weddington said. In Sunday's rallies, speakers called for renewed action by state legislatures following a recent U.S. Supreme Court decision modifying Roe vs. Wade, which legalized abortion in this country. The summer decision, Webster vs. Reproductive Health Services, allowed states to regulate abortion in some cases. ``Some political candidates have slid down the slippery slope of accommodation, changing their positions from pro-life to pro-abortion in order to gain votes,'' Mary Ellen Bork, the wife of rejected Supreme Court nominee Robert Bork, told a rally in Boston. But, she told opponents of legalized abortion, ``this is not a time to wallow in discouragement.'' Other rallies were held Saturday. For abortion opponents, the weekend of activity was to culminate today with a march on the U.S. Capitol and other demonstrations around the country. President Bush was scheduled to address the Washington ``March for Life.'' Demonstrators Sunday were peaceful. In Phoenix, both sides displayed hundreds of American flags and invoked the spirit of the late civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. Shouts were exchanged, but police and rally marshals from both groups kept the peace. In Southern California, 5,000 people linked arms to line the sides of Beach Boulevard along parts of a five-mile stretch through the cities of Anaheim and Westminster to dramatize their opposition to abortion. Bagpipes played in Little Rock, Ark., where an estimated 10,000 to 17,000 demonstrators marched in opposition to abortion. In Provo, Utah, a right-to-life group sponsored several ``baby showers'' to gather donated maternity clothes and baby gifts for needy women who spurned abortion. Several thousand demonstrators opposed to abortion gathered for a day of speeches and song at the state Capitol in Oklahoma City. About 600 oppoents of legalized abortion in Concord, N.H., placed wreaths outside the city dump to mourn discarded fetuses, while 75 women and a few men held a candlelight vigil in St. Paul, Minn., to remember women who have died in illegal abortions. In Albany, N.Y., abortion-rights activists, some of whom arrived on cross-country skis in a heavy snowstorm, chanted, sang and shouted a pledge to lobby their view in the statehouse. As they met in the legislative office building, about 60 people demonstrated against abortion. ``I pledge not to vote for or support with my money or my time any candidate for any office who does not fully support and work for women's equality and the right to safe, legal and accessible abortion,'' the crowd shouted out in response to Marilyn Fitterman, president of the New York State chapter of the National Organization for Women.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Official Doubts Wisdom Of Children's AIDS Study
DOC.TEXT: A leading government researcher expressed concern about the continuation of a study in which more than 300 children with AIDS are not getting the drug AZT, now widely believed to be effective in children. Half the children in the study are getting an unproven drug called intravenous immunoglobulin, or IVIG. Half are getting only a placebo, lacking any beneficial ingredients. In October, Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan acted to make AZT widely available to children, saying there was enough preliminary evidence the drug was effective and safe. AZT is the only anti-AIDS drug so far approved for routine use. Dr. Anthony Fauci, the director of the national program to test and evaluate potential anti-AIDS drugs, said he believes the time has come to give all patients access to AZT, and said he has expressed his doubts about the children's study. ``I questioned that many, many months ago,'' Fauci said in an interview Sunday during the New York-Italy Medical Symposium. Fauci also has set up a trial to test intravenous immunoglobulin, but in his trial the children receiving IVIG and those receiving a placebo are all receiving AZT as well. ``I made sure in our own institute that a trial was done which included an AZT arm,'' said Fauci. ``I don't feel comfortable with a placebo-controlled trial at this stage,'' he said. Fauci is the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in Bethesda, Md., which operates the national AIDS drug-testing program. The director of the experiment he questioned _ Dr. Anne Willoughby of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development in Bethesda _ has emphasized that children in her trial were not being denied AZT. In fact, however, few are receiving it. Of the 347 children in the trial, 31 are getting AZT. That leaves 316 who are either receiving IVIG alone or are receiving nothing. The children are being treated at more than two dozen centers across the country, Willoughby said. ``There is a legitimate difference of opinion about the status of this study,'' Willoughby said. She said she would like to see more data on the trials of AZT in children before she was convinced of its effectiveness. Several researchers interviewed by The Associated Press were critical of Willoughby's study, agreeing with Fauci that children should be given AZT. The most vocal of them was Dr. Philip Pizzo, chief of the pediatrics branch at the National Cancer Institute. Willoughby said he has more experience than anyone else on the use of AZT in children. ``The issue of immunoglobulin alone might have been timely three or four years ago,'' Pizzo has said. ``But in 1989, not having AZT ... means that the potential benefit of the drug, particularly to children's nervous systems, is being lost.'' Pizzo's studies have shown that AZT can stop or even reverse damage to the brain and central nervous system in children. As a result, some children who had lost the ability to speak or walk have recovered those abilities, Pizzo has reported. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome is caused by a virus that damages the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to infections and cancer. As of Nov. 30, the latest date for which figures are available, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control had received reports of 1,947 cases of children with AIDS and 1,059 deaths. Dr. Keith Krasinski, a pediatrician at New York University Medical Center who is helping to conduct Willoughby's experiment, disagrees with Pizzo. ``It would be premature to say that AZT is the standard of therapy,'' Krasinski has said. Willoughby said the study's data safety and monitoring board, an independent group that could halt the trial if it were considered unethical, has repeatedly approved its continuation. Researchers disagree over the potential usefulness of immunoglobulin. Some have found that it can help reduce the frequency of bacterial infections in children with AIDS. Others say the studies so far are too preliminary to be conclusive.

DOC.HEAD: NAACP Chief Suggests Possible Racism in D.C. Mayor's Cocaine Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts graf 11, Hooks did not.
DOC.TEXT: The head of the NAACP today questioned whether the cocaine arrest of District of Columbia Mayor Marion Barry was part of a pattern of harassment of elected black officials and ``the rising tide of racism in this nation.'' NAACP Executive Director Benjamin L. Hooks commented to reporters after meeting for the second time in two weeks with President Bush on the recent wave of bombings and threats against civil rights targets in the South. Hooks, who led a delegation of 17 NAACP leaders to the White House, said afterward he was ``fairly satisfied'' with the administration's actions in the case. Hooks said the delegation and Bush did not discuss Barry's arrest at a Washington hotel last Thursday night. The president has had no comment on it, except to say Sunday that it was ``very sad.'' ``I'm not trying to justify any wrongdoing'' or condone use of cocaine, Hooks said, but ``I am opposed to selective enforcement of the law.'' The NAACP leader said newspaper accounts of Barry's arrest in an FBI sting operation made it sound like ``the search had finally paid off. We spent all of these years trying to find him with a grain of cocaine, and by God we did it, didn't we? ``We haven't found all the people who've stolen all the money from the savings and loan associations and are driving Rolls Royces and Jaguars, so obviously many of us in the black community will have some peculiar feelings as we go further,'' said Hooks. A reporter then asked: ``You're not saying it's wrong to bring somebody to justice for violating the law, are you, Dr. Hooks?'' ``No, I think you ought to bring everybody to justice for violating the law,'' he eplied. ``That would have meant most of us here would be arrested for speeding, spitting on the sidewalk or something. If we can afford to do it, let's do it.'' ``I simply said that there will be in the minds of many blacks the continued feeling that there has been undue harassment of black elected officials. To the extent that that fits into this conference, the rising tide of racism in this nation, it is something we want to examine,'' Hooks said. Hooks did not give any other examples of harassment of black elected officials. Bush also met today with actor-strongman Arnold Schwarzenegger, the new chairman of the President's Council on Physical Fitness. He also planned a midday address by telephone from the Oval Office to support anti-abortion activists' ``March for Life,'' rallying at a park behind the White House. Hooks also visited the White House on Jan. 9 to discuss the wave of bombings and threats against civil rights targets in the South. He came this time with 16 other officials, including Dr. William F. Gibson, a Greenville, S.C., dentist and chairman of the NAACP board. Also attending the meeting were Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and FBI Director William Sessions. Gibson said the administration officials told them there was ``some movement'' in finding those who mailed bombs that killed a federal judge in Birmingham, Ala., and a civil rights lawyer in Savannah, Ga., as well as others mailed to the federal courthouse in Atlanta and the NAACP office in Jacksonville, Fla. Hooks said he had asked Bush for another meeting to discuss other concerns of the 600,000-member civil rights group. Today's ``March for Life'' came on the 17th anniversary of the Supreme Court's Roe vs. Wade ruling that struck down state laws against abortion. During a similar march in January 1989, Bush called abortion on demand ``our American tragedy.'' He said, ``I think the Supreme Court's decision in Roe vs. Wade was wrong and should be overturned. I think America needs a human life amendment.'' ``When it comes to abortion, there's a better way: the way of adoption, the way of life,'' he said then. Bush once took a more permissive view of abortion, but changed his position by the time he became Ronald Reagan's running mate in 1980. Now he opposes abortion except to save the mother's life or in cases of rape or incest, and he favors federal funding of abortion only to save the mother's life. Newsweek magazine reported Sunday that the president and his family are deeply divided on the issue, with all the women pro-choice and all the men anti-abortion. The magazine said it had learned that Bush and his wife Barbara discussed the issue at a recent family gathering with their children and spouses. ``The family split down the middle,'' the magazine said, without identifying its source. ``All the women were pro-choice; all the men anti-abortion.'' It added that some of the women, including the first lady, said abortion should not be without controls, but they believed in a woman's right to choose in certain circumstances. Mrs. Bush has refused to answer reporters' questions about her personal views on abortion.

DOC.HEAD: District of Columbia Government Promises Smooth Transition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 5 grafs new with news conference; picks up at pvs 4th graf, There will
