DOC.TEXT: City Administrator Carol Thompson, who will be in charge of the District of Columbia government while Mayor Marion Barry receives treatment, said today that there was no ``management vaccuum.'' ``The day-to-day management of this government has been and continues to be a team effort,'' Ms. Thompson said at a news conference. The top managers are ``competent professionals'' who have acted in Barry's absence before, she added. Barry turned over his administrative role to Ms. Thompson on Friday, the day after he was arrested on a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge. She asked the media and critics to give her time to ``fine-tune'' the operations. Top officials will be in contact with Barry to provide him with information and recommendations on the decisions which could not be turned over to her, Ms. Thompson said. Those include the signing and vetoing of legislation and signing contracts. ``There will be no loss in the quality of existing programs and services provided by the government,'' Madelyn Andrews, spokeswoman for Ms. Thompson said. ``(Ms. Thompson) will also underscore the strong commitment of the government to maintain stability and continuity.'' Several City Council members, including Chairman David A. Clarke, also stressed that governmental services will continue unhindered. ``The leaders of the council met with the city administrator and the corporation counsel,'' said Clarke. ``We pledged to the city administrator and she pledged to us cooperation.'' Another council member, Charlene Drew Jarvis, said, ``What we need to do now is to assure some stability and continuity in the government.'' Clarke, Mrs. Jarvis and councilman John Ray are announced candidates for the Democratic mayoral nomination. A Thompson aide, who asked not to be identified, said the city administrator was sensitive to the awkward moments Barry's departure could create. ``She does not see herself as acting mayor but more as a city administrator with a few extra duties,'' said the aide. ``For instance, I would be very surprised if she (moved from) her office and started working behind the mayor's desk.'' One key department head, Corrections Director Walter Ridley, said Barry's departure from the daily routine will ``make a lot of difference on a feeling level.'' ``He's is going to be missed,'' Ridley told The Washington Post. ``You can't lose a Marion Barry and not expect for there to be some trauma.'' One of Ms. Thompson's major tasks will be balancing the current budget and finalizing the budget for the upcoming fiscal year which must be submitted to the council in early February. Barry has estimated the shortfall for the current year at between $70 million and $80 million. Ms. Thompson likely will leave her imprint on the budgets, the aide said. ``She tends to be more conservative (than Barry),'' said the aide. ``She is not going to jump out and say `We're going to fund this program' unless she first knows where the money is coming from.'' Aides said she also is scheduled to make a decisio soon on how to improve the city's ambulance service, which has been plagued by reports of slow service and poor medical training for paramedics. Under the city charter, Ms. Thompson has all the powers of the mayor except the ability to sign or veto legislation and approve contracts. Barry has said he will remain in daily contact with her. It was not known, however, how much his activities would be restricted if he enters a treatment program, as expected. Another councilman, John Wilson, who is running for council chairman, said he was concerned that Congress could use the opportunity to change the city's ``home rule'' powers or deny an extension of powers in the future. One cabinet member suggested that many of the mayor's appointees will now find themselves in limbo until Barry decides what to do. ``It will be Carol's challenge to motivate those people, get them to do something productive, instead of sitting around waiting for the other shoe to drop,'' said the Barry aide, who asked not to be identified. ``Some of the more politically oriented offices, ones that are there primarily to give the mayor good exposure on issues, are going to have less to do for a while.''

DOC.HEAD: Parents of Teen Who Died During Abortion Oppose Parental Consent
With AM-Abortion Rally, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The parents of an Indianapolis teen-ager who died from complications of an illegal abortion said Monday that their daughter's case was a tragic consequence of a parental consent law. ``Our daughter was punished,'' said Bill Bell, father of Becky Bell, who was 17 when she died Sept. 16, 1988. ``She was denied a reasonable and safe choice because she loved her parents and died not wanting to disappoint them.'' Bill and his wife, Karen, spoke to reporters at a pro-choice gathering on the Mall near the Capitol where a temporary memorial was erected in tribute to girls and women who have died from illegal abortions. Indiana law requires a minor to obtain parental consent or have the provision waived by a court before she can have an abortion. Twenty-six states have parental consent laws, said Eleanor Smeal, president of the Fund for the Feminist Majority. Bell said that his daughter did not tell her parents she was pregnant and that her best friend told them after Becky died that their daughter had told her she didn't want to disappoint her parents because she loved them. At home, the teen-ager became ill and when she began hemorrhaging her parents took her to a hospital, where she died a short time later. Doctors told the Bells that Becky had had an illegal abortion. The Bells said that had their daughter told them she was pregnant, they would have let her decide whether to have an abortion. ``Our daughter's fate was decided by others. Parental consent laws clearly denied her a safe option,'' said Bell, his voice breaking. ``How many more young women will share Becky's fate if we allow our government to deny them a safe choice?'' Karen Bell said other parents will face the same kind of tragedy unless parental consent laws are changed. ``If you think it can't happen to you, God help you,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: A lonesome moose that wandered south into the Berkshires where there are no other moose has been smitten by a herd of dairy cows. ``He's there every day,'' said Frank Montague, who has been running Bridgmont Farm while his son is on vacation. The moose has been hanging around the farm since Jan. 10, he said, and at one point even broke down a fence to get closer to the cows. Ralph Taylor, a state wildlife official, said the moose should be out of rut by now, but perhaps is being kept sexually active by the proximity of heifers in heat. ``If they scare him away and keep him away from the cows for a couple of days it should be OK,'' Taylor said. But Montague said that is easier said than done. ``They said to make a racket, throw something at him, whatever,'' he said. ``But there's not much you can really do.''

Nebraskans are learning that some of the things commonly believed about China _ especially concerning its food _ are just not true, thanks to 18 Chinese students attending Dana College. For example, they never heard of Chinese fortune cookies until they arrived in America. The graduate students attending Dana's English Language Institute also said they found it difficult to adjust to much of what passes for Chinese cooking in this country because the vegetables are cooked too much. ``But we are glad to be at Dana. We like it very much,'' said Liu Ping. Sybille Bartels, program director of the college's department of languages, said: ``It's a delight when they invite us to a Chinese dinner they cook. It's excellent, especially their dumplings.'' Zhang Xian, 35, a high school teacher and mother from Shanghai, laughed at the informality of American college life. ``In China you can't be as friendly with the school president,'' she said. ``Here teachers sit on their desks and drink coffee. People say `excuse me' to almost anything but teachers don't say excuse me when they sit on their table while teaching.''

Unlike most Eastern Washington University students who hop aboard a cross-town bus to attend classes, Yvonne Jones boards a commuter airline for a 45-minute trip across the entire state. Three days a week, Mrs. Jones takes an Alaska Airlines 737 from Seattle-Tacoma International Airport to Spokane, about a 15-mile drive from the EWU campus at Cheney. It's a long way to travel for a degree in Spanish, but Mrs. Jones, a former stewardess whose husband works as a mechanic for the airline, said she prefers soaring above the clouds for the 280-mile trip to riding through Seattle's rush hour traffic. And her husband's job gets her a discount fare. ``From my first visit, I liked the helpful people and the small town atmosphere,'' she said. ``When I drive to Cheney, I have the road to myself. I'm not used to that.'' She keeps one car in Seattle and one at Spokane. Her husband, Robert, said he agrees with his wife's decision, although he was reluctant at first. ``I told her I thought she could spend about the same and get those classes here,'' he said. ``But she is strong-willed.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Two months after being released from a hospital and one month after turning 92, former U.S. Sen. Margaret Chase Smith felt so good she went out for a snowmobile ride. ``I feel fine,'' she said. ``I wouldn't be going snowmobiling if I didn't.'' Mrs. Smith rode Saturday on the back of a snowmobile driven by a niece, Anne Herrin of Canaan, with Smokey's Angels Snowmobile Club. Mrs. Smith, who celebrated her 92nd birthday on Dec. 14, spent about a week at hospitals in Illinois and Maine in November after she became ill on an airplane flight from Bangor to Chicago.

Judy Woodruff, who has anchored PBS' ``Frontline'' for six years, is leaving the Boston-based documentary series in June in order to spend more time with her family and the ``MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour.'' Woodruff lives in Washington, D.C., where she is chief Washington correspondent for ``NewsHour.'' Her decision to leave ``Frontline'' was announced by the program last weekend. David Fanning, the program's executive producer, issued a statement saying no decision had been made on whether Woodruff will be succeeded by another anchor.

Hats off to radiation treatment, Sammy Davis Jr. says, but it was really the kindness of friends and strangers that pulled him through. ``A hundred letters a day is a lot of mail, you know, for somebody who ain't got a hit series or hit records,'' Davis, 64, said in the Jan. 29 issue of People magazine. ``It was such an outpouring, it was unbelievable.'' He said Frank Sinatra and Bill Cosby offered their planes to fly him to Paris and New York for treatment for throat cancer. Liza Minnelli showed up at his home, bags in hand, and stayed for four days. Jerry Lewis scoured the medical community for the right doctor. Steve Lawrence said he ``tried to cheer him up, kinda like a wife.'' For inspiration, Davis turned to his friend Jill Ireland, who has been fighting cancer for years _ and a seven-year-old boy he met in a hospital. ``He had no hair, he had no legs, and here I am complaining about what by comparison was nothing but a minor inconvenience,'' he said. ``From that day on, I think, I stopped feeling sorry for myself.''

Steven Spielberg has done big-budget films about aliens in ``E.T.'' and ``Close Encounters,'' World War II prison camps in ``Empire of the Sun'' and comic book adventure with ``Indiana Jones.'' What's next? A movie about himself, in a script written by childhood chum and sibling Anne Spielberg. ``Annie just wrote a small, wonderful story about the two of us and my mother,'' he says in the Jan. 29 issue of People magazine. ``We're shooting the whole thing in Cincinnati, where it takes place.'' It's budgeted for only $5 million, peanuts compared to his usual productions. ``I realized when Annie wrote the script that there was no (big budget) value in my childhood, none whatsoever,'' he said. ``It's basically based on experiences we had, friends of ours. It's more a comedy than an intimate portrait of our growing up.''

Country rock musician Charlie Daniels says he isn't the hidebound, simplistic person whose views are presented in the song ``Simple Man.'' But Daniels has sympathy for him. The song's lyrics advocate the lynching of anybody involved in drugs and call for a slow death for child abusers by leaving them for alligators and rattlesnakes. ``When I say I'm a simple man, it's simple attitudes,'' Daniels said. ``Obviously, I'm being facetious with the song. I certainly don't think we should string anybody up from a tree or leave people out in the swamp.'' During a recent interview at his ranch, Daniels expressed some of the same frustration voiced in the song. ``This country is inundated with violent crime and we're not dealing with it,'' Daniels said. ``Most things are a lot simpler than people want them to be. If you got a fire, you put it out.''

DOC.HEAD: Chess Champion's Gambit: Kasparov Offers to Mediate Dispute
LaserPhoto NY11
DOC.TEXT: World chess champion Garri Kasparov on Monday condemned the storming of his native city of Baku by Soviet troops, saying too much force was used and it came too late to save the Armenians. Kasparov, who is of Armenian and Jewish descent and once wrote that his roots were in Moslem capital of Azerbaijan, volunteered to mediate the ethnic dispute, which he said could spread and lead to a ``bloodbath'' across the Soviet Union. At a Moscow news conference marked by an even-handedness seldom seen in the two-year Armenian-Azerbaijani conflict, Kasparov said there were plenty of Interior Ministry troops and police in Baku before Saturday's attack. Yet they took no armed action against the roving squads who reportedly killed at least 67 Armenians and ravaged 1,200 apartments in a six-day campaign of terror. Instead of halting the murderers, officials evacuated the Armenians, and Kasparov contended virtually all had left by the time Soviet troops attacked on Saturday. ``That is why I cannot accept the official explanation'' that the troops attacked Baku to stop the ethnic violence, he said. Kasparov said he thought the attack was meant to crush the pro-independence movement in Azerbaijan and warn similar groups in other republics. ``I fear that what is now happening in Azerbaijan may lead to a terrible bloodbath in the whole country,'' said Kasparov, 26. He added that he fears angry Azerbaijanis could turn on the 100,000 Russian residents of Baku, expanding the ethnic conflict. ``If clashes are provoked between Russians and Azerbaijanis, and if there are victims or refugees among the Russian population, just think what might happen if they show up in Moscow,'' he said. Baku, like many Soviet cities, is home to a variety of ethnic groups. In his autobiography ``Child of Change,'' Kasparov wrote about his boyhood experiences in the Azerbaijani capital. ``My roots are in Baku. That knowledge gives me strength when I go off to conquer other worlds and gives me solace when I return.'' Kasparov spends most of his time now in Moscow, where he has a Russian wife. At least 167 people have been killed since the wave of violence began 10 days ago, including 95 since Soviet troops poured into the city Saturday morning and were met by firebombs and machine-gun fire. Azerbaijanis estimate the death toll is far higher, and Kasparov put it at 500 to 600. Kasparov, who rescued 60 of his friends and relatives Wednesday night, said the government has shown it is either unwilling or unable to solve the Armenia-Azerbaijan dispute and called for individuals to begin direct negotiations between the neighboring republics. He offered to act as a mediator. He declined to lay blame exclusively on President Mikhail S. Gorbachev during the news conference. But in an interview with the Spanish newspaper El Pais, he said the violence was cultivated by conservatives to undermine Gorbachev, and he blamed the Soviet leader for not taking decisive action. Kasparov, who became the youngest world chess champion in November 1985 and earlier this month became the highest rated player in history, has spoken out frequently on domestic problems in the Soviet Union. He said he used his own money to charter a plane _ virtually impossible in the Soviet Union _ with the help of the Chess Union. He managed to get his refugees past Azerbaijani mobs to the Baku airport on a back road, and 40 of them are staying with him in Moscow. In a telephone interview with The Associated Press, Kasparov's wife, Maria, said the passengers included two of his mother's brothers, other relatives, several of his chess friends and eight to 10 strangers who happened to be at the Baku airport. Azerbaijani friends helped his group escape, Kasparov said, and he expressed sympathy for innocent Azerbaijanis killed when the troops attacked. Kasparov also blamed the troops themselves for arming both the Armenian and Azerbaijani extremists. Tass reported that militants obtained helicopters, tanks and even ground-to-ground missiles. Armenian activists carried one of their fallen leaders to his grave Sunday in an armored personnel carrier. ``My impression is the population of Baku would have favored a radical and strong-handed curtailment of the repressions'' against the Armenian population, he said. ``Nonetheless, the pogroms and repressions went on in full view and silent consent of the militia and interior troops.'' Kasparov also criticized authorities for ignoring the ``explosive'' problem of 160,000 homeless and jobless Azerbaijani refugees from Armenia, who have been waiting in Baku for resettlement for as long as two years. He specifically blamed the killings on the desperation of the refugees, who terorized the Armenian population of Baku to grab their apartments when they fled. A program to find them jobs and apartments failed in August, 1988, he said. ``You do not have to be a politician or a particularly far-sighted person to see the political danger that lies in homeless people who have nothing to look forward to,'' he said. ``I lost two relatives in Baku, so I have serious reasons to cry and to shout, he said. ``But I don't think it will help. I don't want to see another 100,000 killed. It's suicide to continue.'' ``No matter what happens, the two republics will forever border one another. No matter how long the war may last, sooner or later they will have to start negotiations for peace,'' he said. He suggested that Armenians abroad, especially in the United States and France, should work with Moslem groups in Saudi Arabia and Turkey, ``which must naturally be interested in a peaceful solution to this conflict.''

DOC.HEAD: Meeting Set Today On Port Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to CORRECT that Bentley is Republican, sted Democrat, recast. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `A union...'.
DOC.TEXT: A congresswoman says she hopes a meeting she set up today between the International Longshoremen's Association and management would cool tempers in the three-day walkout that has disrupted the Port of Baltimore. Rep. Helen Delich Bentley, R-Md., who has been acting as a mediator, said the two sides would meet this afternoon in New York. She said the meeting is not expected to end the strike but may create a better atmosphere that will help bring about a resolution later. A union official says the governor may be to blame for the strike. The walkout has already caused at least a dozen Baltimore-bound ships to use other ports during the weekend, port officials said. A management proposal to cut the jobs of about 150 clerks, also known as checkers, led to the strike. National ILA president John Bowers canceled a contract vote scheduled for Friday after Local 953 president Richard P. Hughes complained about the job cuts. After management refused the terms Bowers had set for resolution through arbitration, Bowers ordered dockworkers not to report for work, beginning at midnight Friday. Hughes has suggested that the threat of a state takeover of the terminals now run by private companies is what drove management to demand deep cuts in the clerical jobs filled by Local 953's 430 members. Hughes has submitted a sweeping request for notes, documents or other records of all conversations or meetings Gov. William D. Schaefer may have had in the last two years concerning labor issues in the port. ``We want to find out as much as we can under the Freedom of Information Act,'' Hughes said. ``We want to know who our friends are, who are enemies. We want to find out if the state acted in good faith.'' ``The governor's at fault for this entire situation,'' said Rich Krueger Jr., a member of Local 953 and a delegate to the Baltimore District Council, an assembly of top International Longshoremen's Association officials in Baltimore. Schaefer prompted the work action by putting pressure on the Steamship Trade Association, the management negotiating group, and threatening to put them out of business by taking over some or all of the port operations, Krueger said. Schaefer has said he is making such threats because the labor problems at the port are so disruptive. Maryland Transportation Secretary Richard H. Trainor said the governor bears no responsibility for the stoppage. The blame, he said, lies with Local 953's leaders. ``I don't know where else you're going to put it,'' Trainor said.

DOC.HEAD: Schwarzenegger Heads Presidential Fitness Council
DOC.TEXT: Actor-strongman Arnold Schwarzenegger came to the White House on Monday and emerged in a new role: chairman of the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports. The broad-shouldered Austrian-born performer, after getting marching orders from President Bush in the Oval Office, said his aim is to get all Americans, from the very young to the very old, to exercise regularly. ``President Bush is very much committed not only to have this a kinder and gentler nation, but also a very fit nation,'' said Schwarzenegger. The onetime Mr. Universe said of the 65-year-old president: ``He's 100 percent behind physical fitness. ... He's in tremendous shape himself.'' Bush said in a statement that ``I have asked Arnold to chair the council because I believe he is uniquely qualified to address and influence national health and fitness issues, especially among our youth.'' Schwarzenegger, 42, who parlayed his body-building skills into a Hollywood career, has starred in such films as ``The Terminator'' and ``Conan the Barbarian.'' He made numerous appearances for Bush in 1988 at campaign rallies, where Bush delighted in introducing him as ``Conan the Republican.'' Schwarzenegger promised, ``I will give this charge by the president the fullest dimension of energy and commitment. Fitness for the '90s is what we will emblazon on our banner and we will wave this banner very high.'' He said Bush ``believes in physical fitness for the young, for the adults and also for the senior citizens. He stressed that he really wants to cover the whole thing, the whole range. ``He believes and I believe that everyone in the United States has the right to be physically fit,'' said Schwarzenegger. The actor said his first objective will be ``to get physical education classes back into schools.'' Illinois is the only state where phys ed is a daily requirement, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Prefabricated Town Packing Its Bags
DOC.TEXT: A prefabricated company town that arrived on flatbed trucks 23 years ago is leaving the same way, Ray Huseby says. Huseby bought the fire hall, the community center and 22 houses in Taconite Harbor as an investment, and plans to sell the buildings, which cost $210 to $4,000, as homes once he decides where to put them. ``He moves houses like other people move cars,'' said his daughter Cindy Lubich, who is in on the deal. The ghost town, a relic from the booming 1950s that had become a headache for LTV Steel Mining Co., will be moved away house by house on Huseby's rig. He has until July 1 to finish. LTV Steel inherited the town from Erie Mining Co. in 1987 and is happy to be rid of it after local laws stopped it from literally giving away the homes. Huseby and Lubich plan to fix up and resell most of their holdings, which have been appraised at $11,000 to $15,000. Taconite's two other houses were sold to other bidders. Huseby says how much he invests in the 15-ton buildings depends on how much money they will command, whether he buys lots and builds foundations and where they end up. Toivo Maki, superintendent of operations at LTV Steel, said in in a large city such as Minneapolis-St. Paul the bungalows might fetch $60,000 apiece. Dead towns are nothing new in hard-pressed northeastern Minnesota. Erected in 1957 by Eire Mining 50 miles south of Canada on the shores of Lake Superior, the town wasn't incorporated and never had its own mailing address or school. Taconite Harbor was on the map, but not on the census rolls. ``It was never a town, exactly,'' said Maki. ``I'm not sure what it was.'' A line of houses facing each other on a street squeezed between the highway and the lake, the town was built to house the workers needed to run the docks that handled the taconite pellets bound for the steel mills. It was a cog in the system that fed the nation's appetite for automobiles from Detroit. For $400 down and $110 a month, a couple could buy its first house from the company and start a family in a three- or four-bedroom bungalow. Company docks and the now-defunct power plant were a few hundred yards away. Later, the auto and steel industries sagged and the demand for taconite, a low-grade iron ore, plummeted. Today, only a few workers are needed to work the dock; the last family left Taconite Harbor about 19 months ago.

DOC.HEAD: Moslems Defy Curfew, Fight Troops
DOC.TEXT: Moslem militants defied curfews Monday and fought soldiers for a second day in an outburst of secessionist violence police say has killed 48 people and injured 400. Trouble began late Saturday when Moslems protested a police crackdown. Moslem militants want to secede from predominantly Hindu India and either make Kashmir independent or unite the northwestern state with adjacent Pakistan, an Islamic nation. Only a brief lull during heavy rain Sunday has interrupted the violence. Police said militants and two policemen were killed Monday in Srinagar and four protesters were shot to death in neighboring Anantnag. ``The whole city is up in revolt,'' said Mohammad Nomani, inspector-general of police in Srinagar. He estimated the number of protesters at 1,500 and said they had at least 1,000 automatic rifles and other weapons. A senior official in Srinagar said privately the local authorities had asked for more troops ``to back up the security forces.'' Hundreds of soldiers have been sent to Srinagar, a city of 1 million that is the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir state on the Pakistan border. At least 38 people, most of them protesters, were killed late Saturday night and Sunday. Police said troopers opened fire on curfew violators in at least six places Monday. Doctors at the Soora Medical Institute said at least 300 people were wounded Monday when soldiers fired on a group of about 5,000. ``Most of them had injuries in the upper part of the body,'' one doctor said, asking that his name not be used. Other doctors said all beds in the hospital were occupied and the cafeteria was converted to provide more space. Thousands of Moslems, defying the curfew, camped inside the hospital to donate blood. Troops with shoot-on-sight orders patrolled streets in Srinigar. The roa of army trucks and wailing of ambulance sirens could be heard through the city. A near-mutiny of part of the state police force, which Moslems dominate, occurred after a member was killed by gunfire from other security forces. About 500 armed policemen stayed inside a police complex Monday, refusing to join the crackdown, but an officer said they were ``pacified some hours later.'' Mohammad Aslam, a state policeman, said the dead comrade was hit by army fire and soldiers refused to deliver his body. The officer of state police, who spoke on condition of anonymity, confirmed the death and said the matter ``has apparently been sorted out.'' An around-the-clock curfew applies in Srinigar. Only soldiers and military vehicles are permitted on the streets. Bands of 50 to 100 men formed throughout the day, however. Teen-age boys shredded an Indian flag in front of soldiers while people in a crowd screamed: ``You Indians go back!'' Heavily armed soldiers guarded government buildings and bridges over streams feeding Dal Lake, once a major tourist attraction. Jammu-Kashmir is the only Indian state with a Moslem majority. Moslem followers of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front have attacked government buildings and patrols in their quest for independence or union with Pakistan. Attacks increased after five jailed militants were freed last month in exchange for the the kidnapped daughter of a Cabinet minister. The old princely state of Kashmir was divided between India and Pakistan when the subcontinent was partitioned in 1947 and became independent of Britain. They do not agree on the border and have fought three wars, the last in 1971. Pakistan controls the western part of Kashmir and the eastern section was incorporated into Jammu-Kashmir. About 64 percent of the Jammu-Kashmir's 5 million people are Moslems, who make up only 12 percent of the Indian population of 880 million.

DOC.HEAD: Diaphragms Should Be Promoted To Stop Heterosexual AIDS Spread
DOC.TEXT: Health officials trying to block the heterosexual spread of AIDS should promote research on the use of diaphragms, which could be as effective as condoms and are likely to be more widely used, a researcher says. Zena Stein, an epidemiologist at Columbia University in New York, said Sunday that diaphragms can prevent the spread of other sexually transmitted diseases and have important advantages over condoms, which are now the most widely promoted means of preventing the spread of AIDS. The use of diaphragms and anti-viral creams or gels ``could and should be promoted among women,'' Stein said at the New York-Italy Medical Symposium. ``It's not going to do everything, but it will do something.'' Stein said studies of gonorrhea and family planning programs suggest that research on diaphragms as an AIDS preventive is warranted. For example, she said, diaphragms and spermicides are as effective as condoms in preventing the spread of gonorrhea and might, therefore, be as effective in preventing the spread of the AIDS virus. Research is needed to settle that question. ``We need a research program that tests these barriers we have,'' she said. The so-called ``barrier'' contraceptives include the diaphragm, the contraceptive sponge and the ``pouch,'' a female condom. Research should also be done to determine which spermicide best kills the AIDS virus, and whether it should be provided as a cream, foam or gel, Stein said. ``We don't know what women want and what they'll use,'' she said. Stein said that while condoms can prevent the spread of AIDS, they are not used nearly as often as they should be. Most heterosexual transmission occurs from men to women, she said, and therefore it is women, not men, who have the incentive to use condoms. ``Women can offer them, can urge the man to use them, can persuade, but it's up to the man. We know that that's often not acceptable,'' Stein said. In practice, condoms are not being widely used, she said. ``Compliance is very far from 100 percent. Very far from where we want it.''

DOC.HEAD: Rural Poor Still Suffer Months After Hurricane
DOC.TEXT: The forgotten victims of Hurricane Hugo are still struggling to survive in roofless trailers along gravel back roads in coastal Williamsburg County, or in modest cinderblock homes on the outskirts of tobacco towns. Life for hundreds _ some say thousands _ of South Carolina's rural poor is not much better than the day after the killer hurricane struck. The storm, which crashed ashore last Sept. 21 at Charleston, claimed 29 lives and caused an estimated $5.9 billion damage when it cut a swath hundreds of miles wide through the state. After Hugo, 24 of the state's 46 counties were declared federal disaster areas. While relief immediately flowed to coastal areas, counties dozens of miles inland _ many of them rural and populated by poor blacks _ were ignored in some cases. Four months after the hurricane, there are few offers of help, even though workers and building supplies are still needed, said Edna Hampton, the Hugo outreach coordinator for Williamsburg County. Officials estimate as many as 4,000 structures were destroyed or heavily damaged in that county, one of the poorest in the state. ``Before the storm came, some of the homes were half liveable,'' she said. ``Now they're not liveable. People are a little bit discouraged. We feel forgotten in a sense.'' She has been trying to locate people who may not have applied for disaster assistance yet. Illiteracy, lack of communication and transportation and suspicion of government have kept many rural residents from seeking aid, she said. In her small cinderblock house on the outskirts of Kingstree, Audrey Epps fights back tears as she remembers how the storm smashed the windows and tore the roof off her home. Ms. Epps and her 78-year-old invalid mother, Zeal, had to seek shelter in the only room of the five-room house that didn't leak. She lost clothing and other personal effects. Ms. Epps lost her job because the pharmaceutical company where she worked third shift was shut down by storm damage. She can't find another third-shift job and can't afford to pay someone to look after her mother during the day. When she worked nights, a relative stayed with her mother. ``The only thing I can do is stay here and take care of her,'' Ms. Epps said. Nor does she have the funds to adequately repair and refurnish her home. She received $2,750 from the Federal Emergency Management Agency, but supplies to fix the roof alone came to $1,800. The ceilings and walls are waterlogged and still need repair. Plastic sheeting covers broken windows, keeping in heat from a wood-burning stove. ``I didn't want a beautiful home. I only wanted a house I could live in,'' Ms. Epps said recently. ``I thought once I would snap, I still think I might,'' Ms. Epps said, sobbing. A few miles south, down a gravel road near the community of Lane, George Bradshaw and his two mentally handicapped sons live in a trailer roofed by a plastic tarp, without electricity, drawing water from a pump up the road. ``We've been here ever since the storm,'' said Bradshaw, who is retired. Bradshaw's insurance company settled by paying off the mortgage on the trailer, leaving the family with only a few hundred dollars, not enough to make repairs. A handful of out-of-state volunteers are at work in the county, such as John Nienhuis, who arrived with a group from the Christian Reformed Church of Grand Rapids, Mich. He said workers many times are trying to repair homes that really should be leveled and rebuilt from scratch. ``We're putting so many good hours into jobs and when they're done, they're (homes) not worth 5 cents,'' he said. Recovery from the storm won't be measured by how well the state's beaches are restored or how many tourists return, but by how all of the state's people recover, says J.T. McLawhorn Jr., president of the Columbia Urban League. ``We, individually and collectively, are going to be held responsible for this recovery,'' he said.
Editors: The Hugo Relief Fund, operated through the South Carolina governor's office in Columbia, may be reached at (803) 734-9818.

DOC.HEAD: Army Says It Kills Two More Guerrillas
With AM-Israel, Bjt
LaserPhoto TLV1, 2
DOC.TEXT: Israeli forces on Monday tracked and shot to death two Palestinian guerrillas who killed an army colonel while trying to infiltrate Israel from southern Lebanon, army officials said. The body of a third guerrilla was found Sunday, when the confrontation began. In the southern Lebanese port city of Sidon, the radical Abu Nidal Palestinian group claimed responsibility for the border attack. Abu Nidal's group, Fatah-Revolutionary Council, said the guerrilla squad was retaliating for Israeli air raids Friday on Palestinian bases and positions of the pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem Hezbollah, or Party of God. Seven people were killed and 18 wounded in those attacks. Brig. Gen. Zeev Zaharin, who is in charge of Israel's ties with the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militia, praised the militiamen and Israeli troops for ``stopping the killers who tried to attack our citizens from the other side of the border.'' ``The only reason for a Palestinian group to reach the border is to attack Israeli settlements,'' Maj. Gen. Yossi Peled, chief of the army's northern command, said on Israel Television. The statements came shortly after Salah Khalaf, a top aide to PLO leader Yasser Arafat, declared the Middle East peace process deadlocked and called for military operations against Israel outside the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Khalaf, second in command in Arafat's mainstream Fatah branch of the PLO, said in Kuwait that ``the PLO now has no alternative but to escalate armed struggle'' to support the Palestinian uprising in the territories. The fighting began Sunday after Col. Yitzhak Rahimov led a unit of the Israeli-trained South Lebanon Army to Yaroun when a villager reported seeing three guerrillas in olive-colored uniforms, Israel radio said. Yaroun is about a mile north of Israel's border and two miles north of Avivim, an Israeli frontier communual farm. The guerrillas were armed with grenade launchers and Soviet-designed assault rifles, the radio said, and had barricaded themselves in a house on the edge of Yaroun. As the militiamen surrounded the house, the guerrillas opened fire and hurled grenades, the radio said. It said South Lebanon Army fighters called in tanks, and Rahimov, 39, was killed by gunfire as he approached one of the vehicles, the radio said. Israel's chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, said the body of one guerrilla was found in the house. He said it was uncertain whether he was killed by Israeli troops or by cover fire from his squad members. Soldiers backed by tanks searched overnight for two other guerrillas who were believed to have fled the house, the army said. ``A chase has been going on since the early morning hours, and in the end they were discovered and in a short battle they were eliminated,'' Shomron said on Israel's army radio. Army officials said both guerrillas were killed within a mile of the house. Rahimov was the highest-ranking Israeli officer to be killed in southern Lebanon since the army withdrew the bulk of its troops in June 1985, ending a three-year occupation. The clashes occurred in Israel's self-declared security zone, a 2{- to 12-mile-wide strip the Israeli's view as a buffer against attacks by Palestinian and Shiite Moslem guerrillas. Israeli troops and about 3,000 militiamen from the predominantly Christian South Lebanon Army patrol the zone. Last year, two Israeli soldiers and 12 militiamen were killed in clashes in the zone; 75 guerrillas were killed and 12 captured.

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Advocates Snub Census
DOC.TEXT: A leading advocate for the homeless said Monday that he will urge those who live on the streets not to cooperate with an upcoming census. ``You can't count all the people in the streets,'' said Mitch Snyder of Washington's Community for Creative Non-Violence. ``Experience quickly teaches the homeless that to be identified as such is to risk harassment ... and abuse.'' David Hayden of the Justice House Community, a shelter in Roanoke, Va., said he, too, would decline to cooperate. ``The key to survival for homeless people is invisibility,'' Hayden said. ``If you are a homeless woman with children you deny being homeless because you don't want to lose the children.'' Peter A. Bounpane, assistant census director, said he hoped the agency could persuade Snyder and other homeless advocates to change their minds. Major federal programs are targeted and funds distributed based on census figures. Snyder contends that both the Reagan and Bush administrations have sought to minimize the problem of homelessness and that, because many homeless would be missed, the census results will lead to less money and attention for the needy. ``If we were dealing with an honest government and an honest administration, we would cooperate,'' Snyder said. Homelessness has received increasing attention in recent years, but no accurate figures of the number of people affected are available. The National Alliance to End Homelessness, a private research and assistance group, estimates that as many as 2 million people are homeless for at least a portion of the year and that the number has been growing. The Partnership for the Homeless in New York issued a similar estimate after a national survey of 46 cities. However, a 1984 study by the Department of Housing and Urban Development estimated the number of homeless at 250,000 to 350,000; a Harvard study put the total at 350,000 in 1986; and an Urban Institute report in 1988 estimated the total at about 600,000. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, has estimated the total at 3 million. The Census Bureau plans a special count of the homeless March 20, about 10 days before the survey of the rest of the nation. Census takers across the country will spend the night visiting shelters, flophouses, hospitals, missions and counting people on the streets. Advocates for the homeless, as well as the homeless themselves, are being recruited to participate. Snyder burned census envelopes that had been used to send him materials concerning the effort. He said, however, that other groups are cooperating and that opinion is divided in the National Coalition for the Homeless. Some cities have made special efforts to get their homeless counted. New York, for example, compiled an extensive list of places where homeless people spend their nights to guide the census takers.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Leaves for Treatment Center
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf, However, a, to CORRECT location from Delray Beach to West Palm Beach, Fla.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry, facing a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge, left the nation's capital today to check into a residential treatment facility in Florida, a city official said. ``At this point the mayor is not considering resignation,'' City Administrator Carol Thompson told a news conference. ``There will be no management vacuum'' in the mayor's absence. Barry, who has turned over the daily control of the local government to Ms. Thompson, did not speak to reporters before leaving his home. ``The mayor has left the city ... he has left for treatment,'' said Ms. Thompson. She said it was ``not appropriate'' for her to disclose details of the mayor's treatment. She said Barry would be doing that. However, a top politial aide to the mayor said Barry left for the Hanley-Hazelden Treatment Center in West Palm Beach, Fla. Clinic spokeswoman Patricia McRae said confidentiality rules forbid the clinic from revealing the names of patients. Meanwhile, NAACP Executive Director Benjamin Hooks questioned whether Barry's arrest was part of a pattern of harassment of elected black officials and ``the rising tide of racism in this nation.'' ``I'm not trying to justify any wrongdoing'' or condone use of cocaine, but ``I am opposed to selective enforcement of the law,'' the civil rights leader told reporters after meeting with President Bush about recent racial bombings in the South. Barry, his political career in shambles following his drug arrest, said in an emotional 15-minute speech Sunday he will take steps ``to heal my body, mind and soul.'' Barry offered no clue during his speech as to what kind of assistance he is seeking, except to say that social activist and self-described nutrition expert Dick Gregory was helping him explore his options. The Washington Post today quoted unnamed sources as saying that while Barry had initially decided to seek treatment at the Betty Ford Clinic in Rancho Mirage, Calif., he was leaning toward an alternative program with Gregory. The Post also said some of Barry's longtime political allies are beginning behind-the-scenes moves to shift their allegiance to Jesse Jackson rather than lose their own influence in city government if Barry's political career is over. The Washington Times, meanwhile, said an agreement was reached Friday for Barry to throw his support to Jackson in this fall's mayoral election. ``You are going to see politicians, preachers, businessmen come out in public in the next few days, if not weeks, calling for Jackson to get off the fence for the good of this city,'' the Times quoted an unidentified source as saying. A Jackson spokesman, Eric Easter, told the newspaper, however: ``That kind of discussion is inappropriate at this time. His (Jackson's) concern right now is very personal, for the mayor, his family and the city. Our focus continues to be statehood for the city.'' Barry said Sunday that the events of the past several days had been ``more difficult than fighting my way out of poverty'' or struggling in the civil rights movement, because ``I spent so much time doing for others that I have not worried enough about ... caring for myself.'' U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens has hinted in interviews that he might look favorably on a resignation by Barry when deciding whether to pursue other phases in an ongoing probe of the mayor's activities. After refusing to comment directly on whether Barry's resignation would lead to a dismissal of the misdemeanor charge against the mayor, Stephens said: ``I'm very sensitive to the concerns of this community, to the people in this community and the need to have an effective government in place...'' ``There are a broad range of considerations as United States attorney that I would consider beyond the simple issue of holding Mr. Barry accountable for his criminal conduct,'' Stephens said. However, the prosecutor said on NBC's ``Today'' show this morning, ``In a system that requires fairness, I think it is appropriate that we go forward with the charge that has been lodged here.'' While Barry did not say in his Sunday speech that he is suffering from drug or alcohol abuse, others indicated he was. Herbert O. Reid Sr., one of the mayor's closest personal advisers, said he hoped that from Barry's travails ``we can all learn something about drug addiction.'' ``The most serious problem is alcoholism,'' Barry spokeswoman Lurma Rackley said. ``The mayor has acknowledged that he has a health concern, and the details are his private matter.'' The mayor's wife, Effi, said in remarks that followed her husband's, ``For you to admit that you have a problem ... that you need to make yourself whole again is truly a burden lifted from our souls. For our family it is just the beginning.'' Barry, surrounded by clergy in a broadcast appearance in St. Timothy's Episcopal Church near his home, clasped his wife's hand and said he has come ``face to face with my deepest human failures.'' Barry said, ``these ministers have helped me to keep the strength I need ... I'm going to find a way to heal my body, mind and soul.'' Barry, 53, faces a cocaine possession charge after testing positive for cocaine in blood and urine tests administered following his arrest. Barry had been poised to announce his bid for a fourth term as mayor on Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Searches For New Approaches to Counter Government Reforms
DOC.TEXT: Reforms by the South African government and upheaval in Eastern Europe have caught the exiled African National Congress groping for new strategies to wage a political rather than military struggle. The ANC, the main guerrilla movement fighting white rule in South Africa, recently held a policy review conference in Lusaka but announced no new proposals to counter reforms by President F.W. de Klerk that have eased pressure on his government. The ANC continues to focus on hard-line strategies such as its largely ineffectual bombing campaign and efforts to increase sanctions against South Africa. But these policies are generating little enthusiasm at a time when de Klerk has been advocating negotiations with blacks and raising the possibility that he might lift the 30-year ban on the ANC. ``Looking at our situation realistically, we must admit that we do not have the capacity within our country to intensify the (armed) struggle in any meaningful way,'' said ANC secretary-general Alfred Nzo. He urged the guerrilla group not to ``trail behind events with our feet shackled by old perceptions and a fear to confront a new reality.'' The ANC's support among millions of black South Africans is probably as strong as its been in its 78-year history, including the last three decades in exile. Most observers believe the ANC would win elections if South Africa's 28 million blacks were allowed to vote. The group also has good relations with most leading powers in the East and West, and solid backing from black African states. However, the ANC must readjust to changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, traditionally their biggest backers and main weapons suppliers but now moving away from active involvement in far-away conflicts. South African academic Philip Nel, a Soviet expert, said officials in Moscow have conveyed to the ANC the Soviets would maintain support for the movement ``only on condition that the ANC commit itself clearly to a political program which could lead to a negotiated stabilization in South Africa.'' The ANC conference highlighted generational and tactical differences among its members and uncertainty about how to approach potential negotiations after so many years of rejecting all proposals by the government. Many senior ANC leaders are in their 60s and 70s, and its president, Oliver Tambo, 71, is recovering from a stroke. Members of the older generation are reserved in demeanor, wear suits at public events, stress the importance of dialogue and stress that the armed struggle came about only as a last resort after the ANC was outlawed in 1960. Most of the 1,000 rank-and-file members at the conference were in their 20s, 30s and early 40s, and belong to a generation of ``young lions'' whose political education came during times of frequent street clashes between activists and police in South Africa. They wear jeans and T-shirts with anti-apartheid slogans, give clenched-fist salutes and are quick to burst into militant freedom songs. Steve Tshwete, a high-ranking ANC member in his 40s, said, ``We must continue to intensify the struggle. We are fighting for liberation. It is a war that's going on. It's not a game of cricket.'' But in South Africa, the battle is being fought less with bombs and more along traditional political lines. Sisulu and five other ANC leaders freed last year after more than 25 years in prison campaign freely on behalf of the organization in South Africa, although it remains outlawed. The South African government says it is reviewing the status of banned organizations, including the ANC, which authorities previously depicted as a communist-led terrorist group. De Klerk also has eased the government's long-standing requirement that the ANC renounce violence before it can participate in negotiations. He now says the group need only commit itself to ``peaceful solutions.'' The ANC is demanding de Klerk legalize the movement and institute other reforms before they enter negotiations. But they have been caught off-guard by several of de Klerk's announcements, sometimes taking days to respond. The ANC says it has no plans to announce major policy or leadership changes until another conference in June. By that time Nelson Mandela, the ANC's best known leader, is widely expected to be out of prison. Mandela, along with Sisulu and other recently freed colleagues, should give the organization a high-profile, authoritative voice inside the country. The government considers the older ANC leaders more moderate and would prefer to negotiate with them rather than the ``young lions.'' Should the two sides end up at the same conference table, there appears to be little chance of a quick breakthrough. The ANC seeks a one-person, one-vote democracy, which de Klerk opposes, saying it will lead to black domination of the nation's 5 million whites. He envisions power-sharing with blacks, but with whites having some sort of veto power on major policy issues.

DOC.HEAD: Mofford Decision Throws Race Open
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Gov. Rose Mofford's decision not to run for office this fall, announced after weeks of conflicting signals, has thrown Arizona politics and government for a loop. Mrs. Mofford said she had ``no idea'' who might run in her place and would not say who she favored. But with four Republicans, including impeached Gov. Evan Mecham, already in the race and control of the statehouse during a redistricting year at stake, the names of a half-dozen Democrats were being mentioned as possible candidates before Mrs. Mofford had finished speaking Thursday. Mrs. Mofford, who is recovering from gallbladder surgery, said health was not a factor in her decision and that she intended to be ``a full-time governor'' for the remainder of the term to which she was elevated in 1988, from secretary of state, when Mecham was ousted. Lawmakers and lobbyists said it wasn't clear if Mrs. Mofford's agenda would suffer because she was now a lame duck or would prosper because the Republican-controlled Legislature no longer would worry that adopting her program might help her campaign. House Speaker Jane Hull, a Republican, said she thought Mrs. Mofford's announcement would allow her to ``hold the politicking down'' during this year's legislative session. But Republican lobbyist Michael Smith said that while Mrs. Mofford's decision could help her with her program, it also could mean that ``now no one has to listen to her'' because she is a lame duck. Democratic Rep. Peter Goudinoff, a political science teacher, took a completely different tack, saying Mrs. Mofford's status could make her stronger politically by allowing her to veto bills without worrying about the political consequences. The electoral front was equally confused. Mrs. Mofford and her aides had sent several signals that she would, including massive fundraising and a State of the State message that could have doubled as a campaign platform. Thursday's announcement caught potential Democratic candidates off guard, and three of the likeliest _ Phoenix Mayor Terry Goddard, former state education czar Carolyn Warner and Chief Justice Frank Gordon Jr. of the Arizona Supreme Court _ said it would take time to test the waters. Goddard and Gordon would have to give up their current posts in order to run for governor. Goddard, son of state Democratic Party chairman and former Gov. Sam Goddard, said he was taking ``a hard look'' at running but that it might take him three weeks to decide. Gordon said Friday that he did not know how much time it would take him to make a decision. Mrs. Warner, an ally of organized labor and the party's candidate in the 1986 election that Mecham won, said she was consulting friends and associates and hoped to have a decision within days or weeks. Goddard gets along well with the Republican establishment, is popular statewide and can raise money quickly if he is perceived as the likely winner, said Democrat Alan Stephens, the Senate's minority leader. Gordon presided over the Senate trial that resulted in Mecham's ouster as governor. Others mentioned as potential Democratic candidates include Tempe Mayor Harry Mitchell, grocery magnate Eddie Basha, and former congressman and Mecham aide Sam Steiger. Republican candidates said they believed Mrs. Mofford's departure and the likelihood of a Democratic primary fight would alter the whole dynamics of the election and could bring more candidates into the GOP race as well. Mrs. Mofford's decision ``creates a level playing field,'' said developer J. Fife Symington, a GOP establishment candidate. ``It's always difficult to run against an incumbent.'' Mrs. Mofford was criticized for lacking leadership and for a hands-off approach to government, but she fared well in popularity polls until recently. ``I believe that if she had chosen to run in 1990 she would have been a formidable candidate,'' Symington said. Mecham agreed: ``I don't believe the Democrats will be able to field anybody that will be more difficult to beat than her.'' In addition to Symington and Mecham, those who have announced for the GOP nomination are former Maricopa County supervisor Fred Koory and maverick school teacher Bob Barnes. Attorney General Bob Corbin, another Republican, also has been approached about running but has not announced his plans and said that he expected to hold off until the end of the month. Mrs. Mofford said she would support whoever wins the Democratic primary and that the roughly $375,000 that she has collected in campaign funds will be returned to contributors where possible.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Says Soviet Troops on Border Barred People From Crossing
With AM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: N) _ Iranian TV reported Soviet troops stationed along Iran's border with strife-torn Soviet Azerbaijan on Monday barred people from crossing into Iran. Tass, however, said crossings were continuing. The Tehran broadcast, monitored in Cyprus, said the guards also carefully screened anyone wishing to enter from Iran and allowed through only Soviet Azerbaijanis returning home. In Moscow, the official news agency Tass said, ``The situation remains complicated on the state border. Azerbaijanis and Iranians continue to cross the border en masse in both directions.'' Thousands of Soviet Azerbaijanis, who are bound by a common language, culture and religion with their Iranian kin, had poured across the 400-mile border into Iran following the outbreak of violence in their home republic Jan. 13. The television reported that 20,000 Soviet Moslems had fled to Iran since Thursday and that arrangements were being made to house them. Turkey, which has a large ethnic Azerbaijani minority, on Monday said it wanted an end to the bloodletting in Azerbaijan and has asked Moscow to allow a medical team to enter the republic to help the wounded. Thousands of Azerbaijani Turks rallied in the eastern town of Aralik, near the point where the Iranian, Turkish and Soviet borders converge. Official Soviet reports have said more than 160 people have died since ethnic violence erupted earlier this month between the republic's predominantly Moslem Azerbaijanis and Christian Armenians living there. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev blames Moslem fanatics for the violence. The Soviets have long feared that Iran's revolutionary zealots who seized power in 1979 would seek to inflame the 70 million Moslems who live in the Soviet Union's southern republics. Soviet media accused Iran of supplying arms to the Moslems in Azerbaijan, but Iranian media denied the allegation. Nationalists in Soviet Azerbaijan have been agitating for the establishment of a ``Greater Azerbaijan,'' an independent, oil-rich homeland for 20 million Azerbaijanis on both sides of the border. The top Moslem religious leader of Soviet Azerbaijan, in an interview published Monday, predicted grave repercussions from the Soviet military intervention. ``This mistaken decision will have dire consequences,'' Sheikh-ul-Islam Allahshukur Pasha-Zade was quoted as saying. The Kuwaiti daily Al-Anbaa said it conducted the interview by telephone from Moscow. Iranian leaders, fearful that any forceful crushing of the rebellion in Azerbaijan would escalate the crisis and endanger its own stability, have cautioned Moscow to use peaceful means to stem the fighting. The Iranian Foreign Ministry Sunday called on the Soviet Union to halt ``violent clashes'' with Moslems in its Caucasus republics, and warned that the widening crackdown on the nationalists could jeopordize Moscow's reformist policies. In Monday's interview, Pasha-Zadeh also said Gorbachev was giving false information about the situation in Azerbaijan. ``This prompted him to take a precipitous and costly decision as the Soviet troops did when they occupied Afghanistan, and when they intervened in Czechoslovakia in 1968,'' he added. But, he went on, ``the imposition of a state of emergency and the intervention of troops have exacerbated the situation.'' ``I say it frankly, I am unable to control the sentiments of angry people outraged over the shedding of blood in Baku's streets.''

DOC.HEAD: Mazowiecki Seeks Closer Polish-Czechoslovak Ties
DOC.TEXT: Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki paid homage Monday to Czechoslovakia's drive for freedom and pressed for closer ties between the two emerging democracies. Mazowiecki met with Premier Marian Calfa and later had an 80-minute meeting with President Vaclav Havel. He also conferred with Parliament Speaker Alexander Dubcek and Roman Catholic primate Cardinal Frantisek Tomasek. ``I come here as the first prime minister to visit a Czechoslovakia returning itself to the road of full democracy,'' Mazowiecki told Polish and Czechoslovak journalists after his meeting with Calfa. ``I come ... prepared to discuss all matters and controversies ... to bring a new quality to our relations.'' He said he hoped for good and close relations between the ``two sovereign nations'' of Poland and Czechoslovakia. ``I am convinced that such good cooperation could have an essential effect for the launching of the new Europe at a time when central-eastern Europe is undergoing such great changes,'' he said. Popular citizens movements in both Poland and Czechoslovakia succeeded in 1989 in breaking the monopoly of power held for four decades by the Communists. Mazowiecki, a longtime Solidarity activist, became Eastern Europe's first non-Communist government leader in August. Calfa, a reform Communist who assumed the premiership in December, resigned from the party this month. Czechoslovakia has scheduled fully democratic elections for June. ``I welcome Prime Minister Mazowiecki as a representative of a state that supported the democratization process in Czechoslovakia and openly expressed it,'' Calfa said. The visit comes amid intense diplomatic activity between Warsaw and Prague. Czechoslovak Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier visited Poland Jan. 10-11, and Havel is due to visit Polish President Wojciech Jaruzelski on Thursday. On Mazowieka's agenda Monday were talks on easing border restrictions for Poles visiting Czechoslovakia, increased cooperation to reduce air and water pollution along their border, closer cultural ties, and rights for the Polish minority in Czechoslovakia. There have been recent suggestions of reviving a 50-year-old proposal to create a Polish-Czechoslovak federation, positioned between Germany and the Soviet Union, that would be strong enough not to be dominated by either. The proposal, voiced last month by former U.S. National Security Adviser Zbigniew Brzezinski, was met with interest by Poles concerned about a reunified Germany. The response from Czechoslovak officials, however, has been tepid. Calfa told a Polish newspaper last week that Czechoslovakia may want ``closer cooperation. ... But now we are not ready, due to economic reasons, to establish any formal unions or confederations.'' Mazowiecki's day in Czechoslovakia began with a trip to the grave of student Jan Palach, who immolated himself 21 years ago to protest the 1968 Warsaw Pact invasion that restored hard-line Communist rule. It was the first time a government leader had gone to the grave during a state visit. ``It is not an accident that I begin my trip at the grave of Jan Palach,'' Mazowiecki said at the small village cemetery in Vsetaty, about 15 miles north of Prague. ``His sacrifice has remained in our minds all these years, this tragic sacrifice. This is why, when things are better now, we should return our thoughts to those who could not see these days. ... ``This is why when I come to a free and democratic Czechoslovakia, I start in this place.'' Side by side, Mazowiecki and Calfa bowed their heads and lighted candles as a small crowd watched in the birch-shaded graveyard nestled on a hillside looking out over rolling farmland.

DOC.HEAD: Governing Party, Two Opposition Groups Will Form Alliance
DOC.TEXT: President Roh Tae-woo said Monday his governing party and two moderate opposition groups will create a new party, a serious setback for the nation's most radical leaders. ``We agreed to establish a new political order based on political stability and create a new popular party of moderate democratic forces to meet the needs of the times,'' Roh said in a televised address after a 10-hour meeting with opposition leaders Kim Young-sam and Kim Jong-pil. The alignment boosted the chances of Kim Young-sam coming to power after Roh steps down in Feburary 1993 at the end of a single five-year term. The two were bitter rivals in the presidential elections in December 1987, and Kim Young-sam accused Roh of vote fraud. The new party will be assured of a two-thirds majority in the 299-member National Assembly. It also will dwarf the largest opposition group, Party for Peace and Democracy, and limit its chances of coming to power. The party's charismatic leader, Kim Dae-jung, denounced the alliance as a power grab, and radical students called it an attempt to prolong what they view as a pro-U.S. military dictatorship. Students battled riot police with firebombs and rocks at five universities in Seoul and two other cities, and police arrested hundreds of demonstrators. Roh said the new party, tentatively named the Democratic Liberal Party, will be inaugurated within six months. Until then, Roh said he and Kim Young-sam and Kim Jong-pil will lead a working committee. He said Korea needed a new political order ``to overcome an economic crisis and effectively solve pending problems facing the nation.'' It will be the first time in Korea's history that a new political party is formed by ruling and opposition parties. Kim Youn-sam said the three leaders talked about changing the country's current presidential government system to a Cabinet structure. Roh and Kim did not elaborate, however, apparently in order to avoid friction with Kim Dae-jung. Kim Dae-jung called the new party a ``a political coup d'etat aimed at holding onto power.'' He said new elections should be held as a referendum on the issue. Governing party officials rejected the criticism, saying the opposition leader had been asked to form an alliance. Party officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the new party will adopt a collective leadership, with Roh serving as a ceremonial head and Kim Young-sam likely to be selected chairman. Kim Jong-pil, who once served as prime minister under the assassinated autocratic president, Park Chung-hee, called the change ``revolutionary'' and said he hoped other political ``heavyweights'' would join the alliance. Roh defeated the three Kims by a narrow margin in the 1987 presidential election, the first democratic balloting in 16 years. Many Koreans blamed Kim Young-sam and Kim Dae-jung for losing the presidential election by splitting the opposition vote.

DOC.HEAD: Superpower Talks Enter Final Phase; Confidence Expressed
With AM-Yugoslavia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S.-Soviet arms talks resumed Monday and negotiators expressed confidence they could meet the Malta summit goal of completing a treaty on long-range nuclear weapons this year. Round 13 of the 5-year-old negotiations on strategic nuclear arms and space weapons began with a meeting of delegation chiefs Richard Burt of the United States and Yuri Nazarkin of the Soviet Union. A joint statement said both hope ``it will be possible during this round to make substantial progress on those issues where differences remain.'' Burt and Nazarkin signed an agreement allowing trial inspections of each other's nuclear warheads, with the goal of finding ways to make sure the number of warheads on each missile does not exceed the limit. ``It's a good way to start,'' Burt said after the 35-minute meeting. Nazarkin nodded and noted the inspection agreement was the fourth ``trial measure'' agreed upon by the negotiators. The three others covered notification of maneuvers, procedures to identify bombers carrying air-launched cruise missiles and reciprocal demonstration of missile identification techniques. The treaty resulting from the negotiations, called START, is intended to reduce the number of long-range missiles on each side by 30 to 50 percent. Negotiators have agreed on limits of 1,600 delivery vehicles _ missiles and bombers _ and 6,000 nuclear warheads. Presidents Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev agreed at the Malta summit in December that all major outstanding issues should be resolved by their next meeting in June and a START treaty should be signed by year's end. ``It's constructive pressure,'' Burt said, and added later that he was ``very optimistic'' the summit goals could be achieved this year. He and Nazarkin plan to return home in a few days to help prepare for the meeting Feb. 6-7 in Moscow of Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Negotiations in Geneva will continue in their absence. Burt said he hoped for progress in Moscow on the most difficult remaining START issues: the permitted range of air-launched cruise missiles, how to count them and how what to do about bombers that carry such missiles equipped with conventional rather than nuclear warheads.

DOC.HEAD: Midsummer Nights' Dreams at Dior, Balmain
DOC.TEXT: Haute couture was a midsummer night's dream at Monday's shows. Very short, often flirty styles for summer never looked more expensive and yet feathery-light. The clothes, costing many thousands of dollars per outfit, are mainly for show. Only about 2,000 women regularly buy couture, which is meant to power the houses' other activities, from accessories to perfumes. Dior's show by Gianfranco Ferre was a suite of expensive clothes that ended up with mounds of gold, ochre and saffron iridescent taffetas, satin and sparkling sequins on lace. The Italian designer, hired last year by financier Bernard Arnault to bring the celebrated couture house out of the doldrums, reworked some of his strong themes. These included huge organza bows and bold silk-flower corsage effects. The clothes were pretty, but whether their impact will make Dior top money-earning couture house in the world is still debatable. Ferre's mood was romantic but low-key. The day clothes worn with amusing high-crowned smokestack or boater hats turned up in black and white or shades of silvery gray in fitted pinstriped suits with deep decolletes, insets and tucked-in swaths of white organza, a Ferre signature touch. He is still using organza prodigiously and has already been copied all over the place in the cloud-like puffy blouses and enormous bows at waist or neck. Lots of trousers here should please high-styled dressers who can actually afford a couture outfit. Impeccable cuffed gray charcoal lean pants topped by a fabulous white organza jacket and strapless bustier would look at home anywhere from Palm Beach to Paris. The wicker-chair sparkly embroidery on white jackets over simple black skirts are also great choices for the moneyed set. Except for violet, lilac, a flash of red and all that gold, Ferre hardly varied his color palette. But the cuts were right on target, especially when he draped a sexy sheath with a gold satin-lined long stole. Erik Mortensen at Balmain proved once again that he's a great couturier. He produced a teaser of a sexy collection that offered plenty of choice besides bare skin in skirts slashed to the hip or mere slips of handkerchief chiffons adorning nearly nude bodies. His day clothes were striking in belted ivory white suits with sleeveless jackets in contrasting coral, saffron or green soft wool. The clothes looked both contemporary and clever, some of the false cutaway suits turning into short shifts in back. Other daytime ideas included split paneled skirts, crepe chiffons with giant polka dots under enormous halo circle hats. But from silky bias-cut paneled dresses to jeweled chiffons and strapless dresses topped with clouds of gazar as stoles, Mortensen won on all fronts day to evening in a beautifully edited show that was exciting from start to finish. Cardin still knows how to cut and give a fillip to modern styles. But the impact was watered down by too much of a good thing. Among the memorable newer looks were his billowy-skirted and egg-shaped dressy short models in the softest pastel hues _ lots of violet, aqua and linden or sea green. Many of the pretty new outfits were presented by two of his favorite new mannequins brought in from the Soviet Union, where he has been manufacturing for two years to pep up the fashion scene. All of Cardin's favorite ideas were present and sparkling: huge collars, enormous flower effects _ the dress becomes a flower _ zig-zag diagonal or swirly asymmetrical coat fastenings, batwing-sleeve shifts galore. An intriguing new suit here was cut with ``step'' effects on the sharply geometrical jackets. Cardin used big floppy bows in profusion, draping a whole dress from a bow at the neck, or ending up a hemline with a bow. With lots of navy and white or a raft of pretty pastels, the palette in luxury fabrics was extended to please anyone. He brought out circular hoop stiffening and Chinese-lantern effects in skirts and sleeves, a rather extravagant way to use some of these lovely flowered fabarics. Jean-Louis Scherrer took another of his exotic trips to India, a favorite theme he uses over and over again. The outfits fit for a maharanee included some sensational draped dresses with iridescent sari-style scarves, lots of mirror sequins, the lightest of silvery paisley patterns on silks. Tulip-draped skirts were beautifully done as were some all-over pleated and tucked blouses and dresses that were a tour de force. Scherrer kept to the softest palette possible in creams, khakis, light golds, sand tones with echoes of pink. But he sometimes opted for interesting mixes of hot cyclamen and ochre, shocking pink and Indian rose in his silk crepes, chiffons and taffetas. While several of his trouser suits were topped with Nehru-collared lean jackets, others were lean midcalf styles with tunic or jacket toppers. Nobody could miss Scherrer's incredible gray and gold cobra-patterned silk taffeta pants suits with an ample jacket tightly belted at the waist.

DOC.HEAD: Former Houston Chief Sworn in as Big Apple Police Commissioner
DOC.TEXT: Former Houston Police Chief Lee Brown was sworn in Monday as New York's 36th police commissioner, acknowledging the city's fiscal problems but promising ``clear vision and firm resolve'' against drugs. The audience gave a standing ovation when newly elected Mayor David Dinkins said: ``Lee, the people of this city are aching. We hate drugs and what they're doing to our communities and our children.'' ``We despise the despair caused by crime, and we are ready to join together to take back our streets and our parks, by night as well as by day,'' Dinkins added. ``In all candor, I do not come here with a quick and easy solution to this terrible problem'' of drugs, Brown said. ``No one does. I will pledge my most earnest and most diligent effort in lessening the impact of drugs on all the city's neighborhoods.'' Brown acknowledged the city's budget crisis, saying it may not be possible to expand the force for some time. But he said he looked forward to ``bringing about a safer, toward bringing about a more secure, toward bringing about a more liveable city for all New Yorkers.''

DOC.HEAD: Ransacked Headquarters To Become Memorial, With Files Open
With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The central files of the former secret police are to become an archive open to scholars, delegates from the government and opposition agreed Monday. Negotiators called for the East Berlin headquarters of the state security agency, symbolizing four decades of iron-fisted Communist control, to become a memorial to the victims of Stalinism. The proposed steps were adopted at the latest session of talks on reform between the Communist-led government and opposition groups. The motion was introduced by the fledgling Greens, an environmentalist opposition group. Greens delegate Carlo Jordan called for preserving the central files of the secret police, known popularly as ``Stasi,'' after thousands of demonstrators ransacked the headquarters Jan. 15 and destroyed records. Researchers at the future archives would help citizens who were police targets to prepare legal action against the state, Jordan said. Communist Premier Hans Modrow has ordered the dismantling of the Stasi, but opposition groups and street demonstrators have remained wary of government assurances the agency is being dissolved. On Monday, the delegates appointed a three-member panel including East Berlin Lutheran Bishop Gottfried Forck as civilian watchdogs over the Stasi's abolition.

DOC.HEAD: Interim Government Switches Gears, May Take Part in Election
DOC.TEXT: The provisional government that replaced the toppled dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu may field candidates in the April elections, a government spokesman said Monday. A decision to take part in the elections would be a reversal of the government's earlier insistence that it was only a caretaker coalition formed to escort Romania to democracy after Ceausescu's 24 years of harsh rule. Aurel Dragos Munteanu, state radio and television chief, said no final decision has been made on whether the governing National Salvation Front will field candidates. ``The country as a whole feels the National Salvation Front should turn into a movement independent from other political parties, and nominate its candidates for the forthcoming elections,'' Munteanu told a news conference, according to the state news agency Rompres. He sought to qualify earlier comments by interim President Ion Iliescu, who had seemed to indicate the government definitely would participate in elections. ``Mr. Iliescu said we don't know yet. We might go that way or that way ... It was not a commitment by Mr. Iliescu,'' said Munteanu, referring to the comments by the acting president in a meeting with students Sunday. The National Salvation Front, a group about 150 members, gained popular support amid the post-revolutionary chaos by disavowing electoral ambitions and representing itself as purely an interim force until parliamentary elections could be held. They are tentatively scheduled for April, although some opposition groups not participating in the interim government have said they need more time to mount effective campaigns. The National Salvation Front is made up of dissidents, military leaders, intellectuals, technocrats and disgruntled Communists. It is led by an 11-man council headed by Iliescu, a former Communist Party secretary who ran afoul of Ceausescu in 1971 and was ultimately demoted to the job of editor of a technical publishing house. Munteanu noted that the leaders said after Ceausescu was overthrown Dec. 22 that they did not consider the National Salvation Front to be a political party. But then he told the news conference that ``It is a feeling in the country by many people .. . that is calling for the front in one way or another to take part.''
