Asked a question about Romania's economy, Munteanu noted that the front's governing council may still be running the country after elections. He did not elaborate. The National Salvation Front, which has taken enormous powers into its own hands, governs this nation of 23 million people by decree. Acting as an ad hoc legislature, the front has repealed the regime's most hated laws, opened borders for Romanians, appointed ministers and taken over the media. Iliescu and his defense minister, Gen. Nicolae Militaru command the 180,000 army troops whose switch of sides turned December's street demonstrations into a successful revolution. Iliescu fired all Ceausescu ministers, but retained midlevel administrators. Critics of the government have complained that some of its members were too closely associated with Ceausescu's government and may have plans to continue some form of Communist rule. Commenting on Romania's future economy, Munteanu said he favored privatization ``to some extent'' but added it would be difficult to have an economy as privatized as in Western countries. Munteaunu also said the first trials of Ceausescu aides probably would begin next week, adding the defendants would include former Communist Party secretary Emil Bobu, third in the Ceausescu hierarchy after the dictator and his wife, Elena; and former Interior Minister Tudor Postelnicu, who supervised Ceausescu's dreaded special police. Also likely to be tried next week are former Premier Manea Manescu and Ion Dinca, a former high-ranking Politburo member. Prosecutor-General Gheorghe Robu said the four have been indicted on charges of genocide for their role in violently suppressing demonstrations during the December revolution, Rompres reported. Ceausescu and his wife were executed by firing squad Dec. 25.

DOC.HEAD: Drive Announced to Recruit U.S. Capital to Rebuild Panama
DOC.TEXT: The White House said Monday the Overseas Private Investment Corp. is recuiting U.S. businesses for an investment mission to Panama, which is struggling to rebuild its economy following the toppling of the Noriega regime. The announcement touted Panama's ``excellent potential'' for U.S. investors interested in farming, light industry and tourism. OPIC, a federal agency, will arrange a Feb. 23-28 trip to Panama to familiarize U.S. investors with the economic and political climate in Panama and to meet with that nation's new government and business leaders, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. The purpose ``is to help rebuild the Panamanian economy,'' he said. Panama's economy was under heavy strain from U.S. sanctions before the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion, which dethroned strongman Manuel Antonio Noriega. Several hundred Panamanians, as well as 23 U.S. soldiers, died in the fighting, which devastated sections of Panama City. Estimates of how much it will cost to repair the damage in Panama have ranged from several hundred million dollars to as high as $2 billion. Fitzwater, in a written statement, said, ``Panama's business infrastructure retains attractive features such as transportation, communications and financial services. It has excellent potential in agriculture, aquaculture, light industy and tourism.'' OPIC is the federal agency responsible for encouraging investment in developing countries. In the last year, it has led investment missions to sub-Saharan Africa, Poland, Hungary, Bolivia and other nations.

DOC.HEAD: Interest Rates Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities were mixed in Monday's auction. The Treasury Department sold $7.6 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.66 percent, down from 7.68 percent last week. Another $7.6 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.58 percent, up from 7.54 percent last week. The rates were the lowest since three-month bills sold for 7.57 percent on Jan. 8, and the highest since six-month bills averaged 7.64 percent on Dec. 26. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 7.92 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,806.40 and 7.99 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,616.80. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, rose to 7.97 percent last week, up from 7.78 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Students Demonstrate For Broader Education
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: More than 3,000 high school students demonstrated Monday for a broader education than the narrow curriculum enforced by the regime of deposed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The demonstration was also aimed at the abolition of special exams at the end of the second year of high school, which students must pass in their major field of study or face expulsion. ``If Elena Ceausescu can fall down, our exam must fall down, too!'' the students chanted as they marched from the Ministry of Education to the provisional government headquarters. Student leaders said they had given the provisional government one month from Dec. 22, when the Ceausescus were forced to flee the city, to do away with the special exam. Ceausescu reportedly intended to drop the exam this year. ``Until now, they have told us nothing. That's why we're here,'' said Rodica Guja, 16. ``We want to study the real history because the history they taught us before was a wrong history,'' she said. ``We want to obtain culture and we want more subjects. We want to study the history of art, science, foreign languages.'' There was a sense of exhiliaration as the students wound their way along the icy streets of old Bucharest behind a Romanian flag with the Communist emblem torn out. ``The police just look at us. Before, if we did something like this, we would be arrested and beaten,'' Miss Guja said. The students from about 15 schools walked out of classes Monday. Romania has specialized high schools in industrial fields and academic subjects such as mathematics and physics, language and history, chemistry and biology. Rosu Costin, who is studying math and physics, said the exams were so difficult that students needed private tutoring to pass. ``This isn't fair because poor students don't have money to pay professors at home,'' said Costih, 16, adding that the $4,450 needed for a year of tutoring was enough to buy a small car. Engineering student Bogdan Popescu said he was demonstrating because the exam meant students learned only two subjects and didn't have ``a general culture.'' Ozana Ninosu, studying at the German high school, said: ``I don't learn anything in school, just a little German.'' She said she wanted to study art, music, and learn the true history of her country and the rest of the world. All the students complained that they had to wear gloves and coats in their classrooms because the schools were so cold. Costin said many youngsters were unable to attend sports classes because they didn't have enough to eat and had no energy. At the former Foreign Ministry building, now headquarters of the National Salvation Front provisional government, a delegation of students was chosen to meet Education Minister Mihai Sora. Zosim Basir, a member of the Front, told the students that Romania's economic plight had top priority. ``The young people are in revolution,'' he said, ``and in a revolutionary situation, everything comes mixed up.''

DOC.HEAD: Company Recalls Whistle That Could Choke Children
DOC.TEXT: More than 170,000 toy whistles were recalled on Monday by their manufacturer because they present a potentially fatal choking hazard to young children, the government said. Approximately 174,000 ``Siren Whistle'' toys, manufactured by the Kansas-based Mitchell Import Co., Inc. were recalled because they easily break apart into small pieces that can be swallowed by a child, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said in a statement. The toys consist of a set of six solid-color, 1}-inch whistles. Consumers who have the toys, which were sold nationwide from 1988 to 1989, should take them away from children and return them to the store where they were purchased for a full refund, the agency said. The CPSC said there have been no reports of injuries involving the toy but the voluntary recall was done as a preventive action.

DOC.HEAD: Law Would Allow Seizure of Johns' Cars
DOC.TEXT: A legislator has introduced a bill that would allow police to seize and sell vehicles of people engaged in prostitution in an effort to bring more pressure on johns. ``We believe the crucial point of attack on this issue is the john _ the guy who's waiting in the car looking for a prostitute,'' said the legislator, Rep. Peter Bock. ``We want to embarrass that guy and make things harder for him,'' he said. Bock said he decided to act after residents had complained of finding condoms and needles in their yards. He drove through one neighborhood in his Milwaukee district and found women soliciting men on street corners. ``At that point I realized there was a problem,'' said Bock, 41, who was propositioned before dusk on that evening last summer. Bock's bill would enable police to seize and sell the vehicles of people convicted of engaging in prostitution if the vehicle is used in the act. Besides reducing prostitution, the bill would help prevent the spread of AIDS. Milwaukee's West End Community Association, a community group, has long urged stiffer penalties for crimes involving prostitution, especially punishment that focuses on the customer. ``Unless the fines and penalties are stiffer, how can we expect to stop this problem,'' said Lora Gooden, director of the non-profit group, who said prostitutes have ``no problem finding business in this city.'' ``They (customers) have been slapped on the hand with these mediocre fines and they can get home before anyone knows they were arrested,'' she said. The solution is in targeting the customer, not the prostitute, proponents of the bill say. ``As long as the demand is out there, those women will be out there,'' Ms. Gooden said. ``If the prostitutes get fined, they'll just be out there working harder to pay it. We have to take away the demand.'' Under the proposed law, a car that has been confiscated can not be sold until a person had been found guilty of having performed a sexual act in the car, Bock said. A resolution to the bill will urge newspapers to print the names of people found guilty of engaging in prostitution. ``It's a common thing for these men to drive by, pick up a prostitute, drive around the corner, have sex and then drop her off,'' Ms. Gooden said. ``A lot of the activity has been going on in the cars.'' Ms. Gooden said she doesn't believe the bill will stop prostitution, but it ``would cause them (the johns) to have to explain why their cars aren't there.'' A similar bill in Portland, Ore., drew criticism from the Oregon American Civil Liberties Union. ``The seizure takes place at the sole discretion of the police officer,'' said Stevie Remington, executive director of the Oregon ACLU. ``That's a violation of due process.'' Portland Police Department spokesman David Simpson said the department has seized six vehicles since the bill became law in December and hasn't had any problems. Public nuisance laws in Wisconsin allow the court to seize and sell any personal property involved with prostitution, creating the possibility an entire family could be left homeless if one person engaged in sex for pay, said Eunice Edgar, executive director of the Wisconsin ACLU. ``Obviously, we see some problems with that,'' Ms. Edgar said. ``I'm not sure how the seizure of vehicles would apply. I think there's a double-whammy for women who are married to philanderers. ``First, they're subjected to humiliation and then they lose the family car and can't go to work,'' she said. Ms. Edgar said the Wisconsin ACLU lawyers would review the bill.

DOC.HEAD: East Germans Begin Dismantling Berlin Wall
With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: East German border guards began tearing down a 330-yard section of the Berlin Wall on Monday night to begin replacing the barrier with a metal fence, a West German official announced. The dismantling work began along the Kreuzberg district that borders the wall in the southeastern sector of the divided city, said Werner Kolhoff, spokesman for the West Berlin city government. Kolhoff said an East German border official told him other sections of the wall would be torn down shortly as well, but he was not specific about when that would occur. East Germany's interim president, Manfred Gerlach of the Liberal Democratic Party, disclosed on Jan. 2 that the wall built in 1961 would be replaced with ``normal border markings.'' There had been no public announcement by the East German government on the dismantling. Kolhoff said he was informed that the stretch of wall being torn down now would be replaced by a six-foot metal fence by Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Lords Release Son of President's General Secretary
DOC.TEXT: Drug lords released the kidnapped son of a presidential adviser Monday, apparently in another bid to persuade the government to end its 5-month-old war on cocaine trafficking. Alvaro Diego Montoya had been abducted at gunpoint from his office Dec. 20 in Bogota. He is the son of German Montoya, President Virgilio Barco's general secretary. A statement issued by his family said Montoya was freed on a Bogota street early Monday. Montoya was the fifth person released by the drug traffickers since Thursday. Another 16, including prominent businessmen or their relatives, still were being held, apparently for use in bargaining to get the government to negotiate a truce in the nation's bloody drug war. A newspaper reported Monday that only some of the nation's traffickers are willing to negotiate. A communique issued last week with the release of two kidnap victims said the drug lords would dismantle their cocaine-smuggling empire and release all hostages in exchange for amnesty. Interior Minister Carlos Lemos Simmonds said that under no circumstances would the government negotiate with the traffickers, and that they must surrender and face the judicial system. However, the government since has said it is waiting for clarification on what the drug lords want, and Barco has made seemingly conflicting statements on his position. He has said on the one hand that his hard-line position of fighting the traffickers has not changed, but also that the government will not be inflexible in looking for a way to end the war. In a letter published in the Bogota daily El Tiempo on Saturday, he said it would be ``simplistic to believe that the only two alternatives are blind and stubborn repression or wide-open talks with the criminals.'' The traffickers' communique has been widely interpreted by the press in Colombia, but it appears the drug lords want assurances that they will not be extradited to the United States. The government began its crackdown after the cocaine lords assassinated a leading presidential candidate on Aug. 18. Since then, the government has extradited to the United States 13 Colombians facing charges of drug smuggling, trafficking and money laundering. Authorities also killed Rodrigo Gonzalo Gacha, a founding member of the Medellin cocaine cartel. The traffickers responded with a terror campaign that has killed 209 people, including 106 who died when a bomb blew a Colombian airliner out of the sky. Authorities blamed them for 262 acts, including bombings and arson. El Tiempo said Monday there was disagreement among the traffickers about whether to surrender or continue fighting. The traffickers' offer Wednesday to abandon cocaine smuggling came only from the Medellin cartel's two top men, Pablo Escobar and Luis Ochoa, El Tiempo said, quoting military intelligence sources. The daily said the army had intercepted a message indicating that the Cali cartel, another big band of traffickers, would not surrender or negotiate a truce in the war. The Medellin and Cali cartels, named after two Colombian cities, fought a gang war last year that killed more than 200 people.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Canon Law Not Sufficient To Seal Bishop's Deposition
DOC.TEXT: A judge ruled Monday that a bishop's right to confidentiality under religious law is not sufficient to keep the court from releasing pretrial testimony in a case involving a priest who molested boys. ``I feel that good cause has never been established for the sealing of a deposition based upon an argument that it is to protect a canonized right alleged to be a First Amendment guarantee,'' said Superior Court Judge Thomas Needham. Lawyers for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Providence had argued that under a theological doctrine called ``internal forum,'' priests must keep secret anything told to them in confidence by church members. The depositions had not been filed by Monday afternoon. The depositions were taken for a lawsuit filed in 1986 by a Narragansett woman and her son, who was one of three boys the Rev. William C. O'Connell was convicted, after pleading no contest, of sexually abusing while pastor of St. Mary's Church. The $14 million lawsuit contends Bishop Louis E. Gelineau and Auxiliary Bishop Kenneth A. Angell were negligent in failing to remove the priest from his Bristol parish after they knew, or should have known, of his activities. The plaintiffs contend Gelineau knew of concerns involving O'Connell's relationship with young boys as early as November 1983. The diocese did not remove O'Connell from his position until after his arrest in 1985. Gelineau cited internal forum in refusing to answer 128 questions at his deposition last June. Superior Judge John P. Bourcier in September ordered 75 of those questions answered. Lawyer William A. Curran, an attorney for the diocese, then tried to seal the testimony. He argued that ``it's our right under the First Amendment, to free exercise of religion'' to follow the theological rules of internal forum. The diocese also said the depositions would be ``used as fuel for the fire'' of publicity surrounding the case. Rhode Island is considered by the church to be the most Catholic state in the country on a per capita basis, with 64 percent of its population Catholic, said William Halpin, a spokesman for the diocese. Needham referred to a 1983 U.S. Supreme Court case involving The Seattle Times Co. and Keith M. Rhinehart, a spiritual leader, in making his decision. In that instance, however, the court ordered depositions sealed because ``the affidavits of the respondents and those members of the (religious) foundation supported the danger that release of their names would bring reprisals or fear of reprisals,'' Needham said. Needham said there was no indication that people not involved in the Rhode Island lawsuit would be harmed if the bishops' depositions were made public. He also said depositions given by two priests, Monsignor Salvatore Matano and the Rev. Robert Evans, should be filed with the court. Curran had asked those answers be sealed because the priests were asked to assess the truthfulness of other priests _ material he said would not be admissible at trial and therefore should not be open to the public. ``I didn't have anything to give other than my own thinking,'' said Curran. ``I don't fault the court.'' R. Daniel Prentiss, a lawyer for the plaintiffs, said he had no comment. O'Connell pleaded no contest to 26 counts of sexual contact with three boys, who were 12, 14 and 17 at the time in June 1986. He was given a one-year sentence in a work release program and ordered to take two years of therapy in a church-run program.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Promoting Rural Development
DOC.BYLINE: AP Farm network of councils will coordinate federal rural
DOC.TEXT: development programs in each state. Members will include representatives of governors and all federal departments administering rural development programs locally. Yeutter later told a news conference that the thrust of Bush's rural development includes farming as the mainstay of rural economies. ``Clearly, production agriculture is still by far the most important source of earnings for rural America,'' he said. And that is ``likely to continue for as long as we can visualize.'' Thus, Yeutter added, it is most important for rural development ``to make sure that we have a very healthy farm economy.'' But Yeutter said there was a need to go beyond the farm economy in matters of economic development for the small towns and communities where about 60 million Americans live, including only about 5 million farmers and their families. It is not enough to ask rural America to be dependent entirely on production agriculture, Yeutter said. That became evident in the early 1980s as hard times hit the nation's agriculture, oil and gas areas and energy-based industries. One of the objectives will be to determine which programs and how much money are available for rural people from dozens of offices scattered among federal agencies. Yeutter and Undersecretary Roland R. Vatour, who directly oversees small community and rural development programs, said they had no solid estimate on how much federal money might be available. However, Vatour said that in USDA alone, programs operated by the Farmers Home Administration, Rural Electrification Administration and Extension Service have budgets totaling $8 billion to $8.5 billion. ``There is ample potential here to get a great deal more bang for the buck in rural development,'' Yeutter said. ``We certainly could devote additional financial resources to this issue, just as we could devote additional resources to a lot of other things.'' Other steps ordered by Bush included: _A series of rural development demonstration programs to help identify regional needs, develop action plans, bring together available resources,and evaluate the process for possible use on a larger scale. Yeutter said that project had not been formally set up. _The Agriculture Department will set up a rural development technical assistance center and hot line to provide detailed information on federal programs that serve rural communities. The center also will link callers with federal, state and regional program officials. _Targeting of ``limited federal budget resources'' on activities that generate maximum economic benefits. _The Economic Policy Council's working group on rural development will become a permanent fixture at the White House to ``implement any rural development initiatives'' developed by the new council and approved by the administration.

DOC.HEAD: Military Government to Begin Registering Political Party Members
DOC.TEXT: The military government of Gen. Ibrahim Babangida announced Monday it will begin registering members of the two political parties it has created to return Africa's most populous nation to civilian rule. The statement said the registration will begin in March and will be conducted by administrative secretaries appointed by the military. Also Monday, Babangida defended the soldiers who have seized power several times in Nigeria, saying they acted against ``the monopolistic interest of our civilian leadership that transformed political parties into war machines of the electoral process.'' Babangida's six-year-old government faces increasing criticism from civilians following a December leadership reshuffle that also has increased tensions between Moslems and Christians, who accuse the military leader of favoring fellow followers of Islam. All former politicians and leading members of Babangida's government are banned from seeking office. Parties also are banned from creating women's and youth groups because, the government says, those groups were used to break up rallies of opponents, harass followers of rival parties and, in some cases, beat up rival candidates and their supporters. Public denunciations of the military here have grown since Babangida's Armed Forces Ruling Council in October rejected nominations of 13 organizations seeking to register as political parties. Babangida said all were tainted by the corruption and ethnic and religious factionalism that he blames for the failure of previous civilian governments. Instead, the military government itself created two political parties, one center-right and one left-leaning, and is writing their platforms. Babangida told an annual conference Monday of senior military officers that they don't need to be defensive when responding to criticisms leveled by civilians of the military's intervention in politics. ``Those who quarrel about how to share the rooms of a house, the foundation of which is collapsing, can only with extreme charity be condemned for lack of wisdom,'' he said. Soldiers have governed Nigeria by force for all but nine years of the country's 29 years of independence from Britain. Babangida dismissed as simplistic criticisms by the media, which has condemned the military as an overzealous, power-hungry organization. Military men are patriots ``largely responsible for preserving the country,'' Babangida said. The public criticism has been compounded by religious animosities aroused after the government on Dec. 29 dismissed Gen. Domkat Bali as defense minister. Bali, a Christian, was demoted after he called Babangida a dictator. He subsequently resigned.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Premier Agrees to Give Opposition Role in Gov't
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to include dismantling of wall; picks up 4th pvs `Modrow bowed' with minor editing thereafter
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BER9,14
DOC.TEXT: Premier Hans Modrow said Monday he would open the Cabinet to the pro-democracy opposition, and former Communist Party leader Egon Krenz apologized for his role in secret police operations. They spoke during negotiations on East Germany's future between the party and opposition groups, which immediately accepted Modrow's offer. Pro-democracy activists demonstrated in at least eight cities after nightfall, including more than 100,000 in Leipzig. The official news agency ADN also reported rallies in Berlin, Cottbus, Dresden, Halle, Potsdam, Schwerin and Suhl. East German border guards began tearing down a 330-yard section of the Berlin Wall in the Kreuzberg district, to be replaced by a metal fence, said Werner Kolhoff, a West Berlin government spokesman. He said an East German official told him other sections would be dismantled soon. Manfred Gerlach of the Liberal Democratic Party, interim president of East Germany, said Jan. 2 the wall would be replaced with ``normal border markings.'' The Berlin Wall was built in 1961. Modrow bowed to pressure to revise his 27-member Cabinet, which previously excluded all but Communists and traditional allies. The leadership, which replaced Communist hard-liners last year during a peaceful popular revolt, has been trying to appease an opposition upset with the pace of promised reform. Modrow's declaration came one day after the No. 2 figure in the Communist Party quit and joined the Social Democrats. Until Monday, reformist groups such as New Forum, Democratic Awakening and the Social Democracts had resisted joining Modrow's government, partly from fear voters would hold them responsible by for the economic mess left by four decades of Communist rule. The Social Democratic leader, Ibrahim Boehme, said a coalition was possible ``if all parties and groups are prepared to enter the government on an emergency basis, without weeks-long negotiations.'' Modrow proposed political groups meet Wednesday to consider a new Cabinet, but did not make clear which or how many ministries might be offered the opposition. Communists hold 16 of the 27 seats and the remainder are divided among four parties once allied with them: the Liberal Democrats with four, Christian Democrats with three and two each for the National Democrats and farmers' party. East Germany's first free elections are to be held May 6, but broad differences between the Communist-dominated government and opposition groups have delayed economic reform measures and hindered the transition to democracy. Krenz, who was ousted from the leadership Dec. 3 and expelled by his party Sunday, apologized for the ``old security doctrine'' he imposed on the country. He appeared before the political forum to answer allegations that he helped falsify previous election results and misused the secret police service for political aims. The 52-year-old career politician conceded there had never been free elections in East Germany, ``only ballot-folding,'' and said he believed some votes failed to reach the central counting facility after elections in May. But he denied the results were falsified, and cast himself as one who had fought for change from within. Krenz apologized for his role in leading East Germany to its crisis and said he hoped the people would forgive him. ``As a citizen and Christian I accept your apology,'' responded Wolfgang Ullmann of the Democracy Now reform movement. In a rare display of unity, the opposition groups joined Modrow in denouncing a West German newspaper report Monday alleging that soldiers and secret police agents were planning a coup. The Hamburg newspaper Bild contended the renegades had held joint exercises and said a general strike could be used as the pretext for an armed takeover. ``I must decisively reject as provocation a report in today's Bild newspaper,'' Modrow said. He said he had checked with the interior and defense ministers, who assured him no signs of such preparation had been detected. Wolfgang Schnur, a leader in the Democratic Awakening movement, called the Bild report a ``horror story.'' Modrow also announced the resignation of Communist Finance Minister Uta Nickel, the target of a criminal inquiry into alleged financial irregularities. Ms. Nickel has denied wrongdoing. On Sunday, the Communists lost one of their most popular members when Dresden Mayor Wolfgang Berghofer, a party deputy chairman, defected to the Social Democrats. The moves were expected to cause mass defections from the party. Its membership in the country of 16.3 million people has plunged to 1.2 million from nearly 2.3 million in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: US Accuses Sandinistas of Anti-Semitic Remarks
DOC.TEXT: The State Department accused the Nicaraguan government Monday of using anti-Semitic remarks to try to discredit what the Sandinistas contend is a bungled U.S. effort to help finance the Nicaraguan electoral process. At issue is an editorial in last Thursday's edition of the government-controlled newspaper ``Barricada'' which tried to explain why the ``Yankee bureaucracy'' has had difficulty in disbursing the money. The editorial said there has been an ``excessive distrust'' by the ``Yankees'' toward the leading opposition coalition in Nicaragua and attributes this to the ``traditional `Jew-style' with which the U.S. Congress manages the taxes of the taxpayers.'' Congress, with the stated aim of promoting fair elections, has approved funds for such politically neutral projects as verifying voter registration lists and training poll watchers. Other funds were earmarked for the opposition coalition led by presidential candidate Violeta Chamorro. With the election just five weeks away, however, only a small fraction of the money has been delivered to the designated recipients. Partly as a result, the opposition campaign has been far less visible than the Sandinistas'. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler blamed the Sandinista government for the logjam in the disbursement of the U.S. funds and ridiculed the Barricada's comments. ``The Nicaraguan government is doing everything in its power to block moneys designed by Congress to help level the playing field for the opposition,'' she said. ``To resort to anti-Semitism in its attempt to explain to Nicaraguans why it has failed to live up to the promises it made ... to the national opposition is contemptible and does a profound disservice to the Nicaraguan people, to Congress and to all who want open, free and fair elections in February.'' The funds earmarked for Nicaragua are channeled through the National Endowment for Democracy, which uses international affiliates of the U.S. Democratic and Republican parties as conduits. The Barricada editorial makes references to two officials of the National Democratic Institite, Ken Wollack and Barry Feierstein. It claimed that the funds earmarked for the election campaign are being diverted by Nicaraguan opposition leaders for ``renovating their homes and purchasing new cars.'' Wollack, the executive vice president of the institute, refused comment on the editorial. Feierstein was not available for comment. The Reagan administration frequently charged the Sandinista government with anti-Semitic activities but was hard-pressed to back up its allegations. President Reagan's allegations were undercut by his own ambassador to Managua, Anthony Quainton, who said in a secret July 1983 memo that ``the evidence fails to demonstrate that the Sandinistas have followed a policy of anti-Semitism or have persecuted Jews solely because of their religion. ``Although most members of Nicaragua's tiny Jewish community have left the country and some have had their properties confiscated, there is no direct correlation between their Jewish religion and the treatment they received from the ( Sandinistas),'' Quainton's memo said.

DOC.HEAD: Automaker Asked to Pull Ad
DOC.TEXT: Safety, insurance, medical and police experts Monday asked Nissan not to show a television fantasy commercial for its 300ZX Turbo sports car on grounds it promotes ``excessive and unsafe speed.'' ``This is hitting a new low in automobile advertising,'' said Brian O'Neill, president of the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. ``This is the worst example of an out-and-out speed ad we've ever seen.'' The company declined, saying it believed the ad would never be taken for real. In the dream-like commercial, set on an automotive speedway, the 300ZX Turbo outpaces a motorcycle, race car and jet plane as its driver murmurs: ``Some have to dream. I'm in a Turbo 300 and these guys are after me _ and they can't catch me.'' In the final shot of the commercial, scheduled to be shown during next Sunday's Superbowl football championship, the car leaps from the ground, all four wheels in the air. ``The message in the ad is simple and straight forward: Look at how fast this car can go,'' O'Meill told a news conference. O'Neill said the commercial ``irresponsibly promotes excessive speed and exhibits a blatant disregard for public safety.'' He was joined in denouncing the ad by Dr. Howard Champion, director of the Medstar shock-trauma unit at the Washington Hospital Center, Lt. Col. C.M. Robinson of the Virginia State Police and retired Air Force Brig. Gen. Robert McDermott, chairman of USAA Insurance Group of San Antonio. ``When you're promoting speed and killing young people, you're going too far,'' McDermott said, who pronounced himself ``surprised, outraged and disgusted'' with the commercial. Asked if his company would continue to insure the 300ZX, McDermott replied: ``We may not.'' But later he told a reporter: ``I don't want to threaten them. I want to wait and see if they pull the ad.'' Dan Spetner, a Nissan spokesman in Los Angeles, dismissed the criticism. ``We believe that the Turbo 300 ad is so futuristic and far-fetched that it would never be interpreted as representing a real-life driving situation,'' Spetner said. ``It should be up to the American public to decide what can or cannot be shown on our airwaves,'' he said. ``Nissan claims this ad is a fantasy,'' O'Neill said. ``But what isn't a fantasy at ll ... is that people are dying in high-speed crashes involving this car.'' He displayed photographs of two demolished 300ZX models taken after recent crashes in which three people were killed. O'Neill also complained that Nissan's 1990 300ZX is not equipped with safety airbags but instead features what he said are ``vastly inferior detachable automatic belt systems.'' ``Nissan's contention that the ad is a fantasy is a transparent farce,'' McDermott said. ``It has only one, unmistakable, overpowering message _ speed, period.'' O'Neill said his institute estimates that the 300ZX in the commercial was exceeding 150 mph. ``If there was a crash at that speed there would be nothing left of that car _ little pieces,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Szoka Accepts Pope's Appointment to Join Vatican Staff
DOC.TEXT: Cardinal Edmund Szoka, known for his cost-cutting and fund-raising success as archbishop in the nation's fifth-largest diocese, on Monday accepted a papal appointment to a post at the Vatican. A Vatican announcement said Szoka will head the Prefecture for Economic Affairs of the Holy See, which draws up the Vatican's budget. Szoka announced his acceptance of the position in a news conference. Pope John Paul II and Szoka discussed the Vatican post in December during one of the archbishop's visits to Rome. The 62-year-old prelate has been serving on a special commission studying ways to overcome the Vatican's chronic budget deficit. ``In that conversation, (the pope) said he realized that it would be difficult for me to leave Detroit and for that reason he made it very clear that he was only asking me to consider accepting this appointment,'' Szoka said. He said the pope offered to let him both jobs, but Szoka, who has undergone angioplasty for a narrowed artery, said serving in both posts would stretch him too thin, and both the Prefecture and the Detroit Archdiocese would suffer. Some time in June, Szoka will succeed Cardinal Giuseppe Caprio, a 75-year-old Italian who resigned because of his age. Szoka's fiscal skills have brought him praise and criticism _ the latter stemming from the closings of 30 inner-city parishes of the 1.5-million member archdiocese last year. He cited a shortage of priests, declining membership and the increasing costs of maintaining the church buildings. Earlier this month, five other inner-city parishes were ordered to close after failing to show their viability during a one-year reprieve. The Vatican itself has ordered austerity measures. In 1988, the Vatican reported it was $57 million in the red. It since has cut the deficit by $9 million. Szoka said he hopes to be able to cut the deficit further. ``I have some ideas, but the question is how do I implement them? The bureaucracy has been in place for 2,000 years.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Raid Illegal Opium Fields
DOC.TEXT: Five hundred policemen raided Nile River islands south of Luxor and seized 400 acres of poppies being grown for illegal opium, the state-run daily Al-Akhbar reported Tuesday. Al-Akhbar said police arrested six men found hiding behind thick reeds that protected the poppy fields. The operation was planned for a week and occurred Sunday, the newspaper reported. It called the raid ``The Fall of Colombia,'' a reference to the cocaine industry in that South American country. Photographs published by Al-Akhbar showed officers stepping from rubber dinghies onto a small island 65 miles south of Luxor. It said the raiders seize 6.36 million poppy plants on 400 acres. Sunday's raid was the first major operation reported under Maj. Gen. Abdel-Halim Moussa, who replaced Zaki Badr as interior minister earlier this month. Al-Akhbar quoted Moussa as saying he would give special attention to fighting drugs, a problem that has grown steadily the past five years. It said police raided the islands last year but the poppy growers were heavily armed and drove them off. ``The area was a fortress ... because of natural factors and because of the ferocity of its inhabitants,'' the paper reported.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Agents Search Warehouse, Source Says Connected With Mail Bombings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with second warehouse, bomb squad. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `But federal...'
DOC.TEXT: FBI agents and an Army bomb squad searched two downtown warehouses Monday in a sweep federal law enforcement sources said was linked to the mail bomb slayings of a judge in Birmingham and a civil rights lawyer in Georgia. FBI agents were seen executing a search warrant at one warehouse, and a bomb squad from nearby Fort Rucker Army base went to a second warehouse. Coffee County sheriff's officers referred all inquiries to the FBI in Washington. Asked if the search was connected with the mail bomb killings, FBI spokeswoman Kelley Cibulas replied, ``It could very well.'' She said details could not be released now, but a statement likely would be issued later by the FBI. But federal law enforcement sources in Washington who spoke on the condition they not be identified by name said the search was one of several connected with the mail bomb slayings. Package bombs sent through the mail exploded and killed U.S. Circuit Judge Robert Vance at his Mountain Brook home near Birmingham on Dec. 16 and a black lawyer, Robert Robinson of Savannah, on Dec. 18. Other mailed bombs were found and defused at the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta, the court Vance served, and the NAACP office in Jacksonville, Fla. The FBI has said one or more white racists appear behind the mail bomb attacks. The warehouse search was one of several being conducted by FBI agents in the area around Dothan in an attempt to find bombing paraphernalia or other evidence, the federal sources said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says No Sign Israel Selling Cluster Bombs to Ethiopia
DOC.TEXT: The State Department, disputing a published report, said Monday it had no evidence that Israel was providing Ethiopia with cluster bombs. The report, in Sunday's New York Times, quoted unnamed State Department and Pentagon officials. It followed a statement by former President Jimmy Carter a month ago that ``one of our Middle East allies'' had provided cluster bombs to the Ethiopian air force. Carter, who has been trying to mediate an end to a long civil war between the Marxist government in Addis Ababa and Eritrean rebels, did not identify Israel specifically. Asked about the Times report, Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said: ``We have no clear physical evidence that Israel has provided such weapons to the government of Ethiopia.'' She said Secretary of State James A. Baker III raised the issue with Israeli Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin at a meeting here last Thursday and was told that ``Israel has not provided cluster bombs to Ethiopia and would not do so.'' Ethiopia re-established relations with Israel last October after a 16-year break. Its friendship with the Jewish state goes back to the Old Testament. In recent years, however, Israel has been unable to arrange with the Marxist government for the emigration of thousands of impoverished black Jews. Others were smuggled out before the ``Operation Moses'' exodus was halted. Last week, without elaboration, Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir voiced confidence that all those remaining in Ethiopia would be allowed to go to Israel. The United States suspended sale of cluster bombs to Israel in 1982 after they were used during an incursion into Lebanon. In 1988, the ban was lifted, but Ms. Tutwiler said no American cluster bombs had been sent to Israel since. The Times story quoted officials as saying they did not know whether the cluster bombs reportedly provided to Ethiopia were American-made or Israeli-made. A cluster bomb, dropped from an airplane, explodes and releases scores of small bombs contained in the canister. It can have severe tactical and psychological effect because of the series of explosions that are set off.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Slide Again On Interest Rate, Profit Worries
DOC.TEXT: The stock market took another drubbing Monday, with the Dow Jones industrial average suffering its 10th-biggest daily drop ever amid worries about the outlook for corporate profits and interest rates. The widely watched Dow average of 30 blue-chip stocks finished down 77.45 points at 2,600.45, its largest one-day point loss since a 190-point drop last Oct. 13. Broader market indicators also fell sharply and more than five stocks declined in price for each one that rose on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts said traders remained uneasy about weak corporate earnings reports for the fourth quarter of 1988, as well as the recent upturn in open-market interest rates. The Federal Reserve Board is seen as facing an increasingly difficult set of choices in setting monetary policy to stave off a recession while trying to keep inflation at bay. If the Fed decides to boost interest rates to quell inflation, that could hurt profits. Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, will be making several appearances before congressional committees in the near future. Wall Streeters will be watching closely to see what positions Greenspan might take on such matters as the risk that rising worldwide interest rates might pose for the U.S. business outlook.

DOC.HEAD: Eritrean Rebels Free Polish Ship Crew
DOC.TEXT: Rebels fighting the Ethiopian government on Monday released the crew of a Polish cargo ship attacked in the Red Sea on Jan. 3 and the Poles were flown home within hours, the official Sudan News Agency said. The rebels believed the vessel was carrying arms for government forces. SUNA quoted Ali Shummo, minister of information and culture, as saying rebels of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front handed over 30 Poles to a Sudanese military team at the border with Ethiopia shortly after midnight. Three hours later, the Poles arrived at Port Sudan, the country's major port on the Red Sea. SUNA said they were flown home in the afternoon by a special plane provided by the Polish government. In Cairo, a Polish Embassy spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Poles included 29 crew members and the wife of one of them. Rebels in northern Eritrea province, a former Italian colony on the Red Sea, have fought for secession since Eritrea was incorporated by Ethiopia in 1962. The rebels said they attacked the 8,137-ton Polish freighter Boleslaw Krzywousty on Jan. 3 as it steamed from Port Sudan to Massawa, a port in Eritrea. A rebel spokesman contacted from Bahrain on Jan. 7 said the freighter was one of two ships the rebels attacked on suspicion they carried arms to Ethiopia's Marxist government. The attacks, apparently from shore gun batteries, were in the first week of January, he said. ``We were sure one of the two Polish ships was carrying arms to Ethiopia,'' the spokesman said. He identified the other target as the motor vessel Adam Asnyk. He gave no details, but shipping sources in the Persian Gulf said they received information the Boleslaw Krzywousty was left stranded and ablaze 50 miles from Massawa. The Boleslaw Krzywousty, a general cargo ship owned by the Polish Shipping Association, had its home port at Gdynia on the Baltic Sea. Peter Vanau headed a Polish government team that negotiated the release with rebel representatives.

DOC.HEAD: Vice President Says GOP Should Lead In Civil Rights
DOC.TEXT: The Republican Party must correct its past mistakes and become a leader in civil rights, Vice President Dan Quayle said Monday in the city where racial tensions were heightened by the Stuart murder case. Quayle toured a Catholic school in the Mission Hill neighborhood where a white couple, Charles and Carol Stuart, were shot Oct. 23. Later Quayle attended a GOP fundraiser where he noted how recent events in Boston have brought racial issues to the forefront. Stuart was wounded and his pregnant wife was killed, and he led police and the public to believe their assailant was a black mugger. When Stuart committed suicide this month, knowing he had been implicated in his wife's murder, black leaders criticized the city and police for the way the black community was treated. Quayle said there was no need to comment on specific aspects of the case, but he told fellow Republicans that the GOP must commit itself to fighting racial injustice. ``We must acknowledge our party failed to provide the leadership it should have in the civil rights movement of the '60s,'' Quayle said. ``We are the party of Lincoln. We are the party of equality.'' Quayle also delved into Massachusetts politics and said Republicans have a chance to end a one-party system. He noted that in his home state of Indiana, Republicans lost the governor's seat in 1988 after holding the office for 20 years. ``If the Democrats can do that in the state of Indiana, the Republicans can do it to the Democrats in the state of Massachusetts,'' Quayle said. Gov. Michael Dukakis is not seeking re-election this year, and the race for his seat has attracted a number of conservative Democrats, as well as several GOP candidates. Among Repubublicans, former U.S. Attorney William Weld, state House Minority Leader Steven Pierce and former Rep. Paul Cronin are vying for the governor's seat. Boston University President John Silber, Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy and former state Attorney General Francis Bellotti are seeking the Democratic nomination. Earlier in the day when he visited the Our Lady of Perpetual Help grammar school, Quayle told students to think of the recent space shuttle mission and urged them to commit themselves to furthering America's role in space exploration. Quayle also congratulated a first-grade class for showing how to pronounce and spell his name. ``You are way ahead of the majority of the people in this country,'' he said. The students asked Quayle if he had a favorite book when he was a student and he said he read a lot of Hardy Boys mysteries. When asked if his job was difficult, he said ``I wouldn't call it a hard job.'' He said that while his job has many responsibilities, ``it's easy in one aspect, it's very easy to work with President Bush.''

DOC.HEAD: Atlantic City Mayor Seeks Re-Election
DOC.TEXT: Mayor James L. Usry, who faces arraignment next week on charges he accepted $6,500 in bribes, announced Monday he will seek a third term. Usry, who has spoken little in public since his July 27 arrest, said he is confident of victory in the May 8 non-partisan election, despite the bribery charges. ``There is an urgent need for the most qualified person to act in the interests _ the best interests _ of Atlantic City,'' said Usry, flanked by his wife and supporters at a crowded City Hall news conference. ``I am that person.'' He pointed to redevelopment in the blighted Inlet section of the city and his role on the state Casino Reinvestment Development Authority as reasons why he should win re-election. Levies placed on casino hotels are allocated by the authority toward city and state projects. But Usry said he would not allow the state to control his government, a reference to what some critics believe is the need for the city, long suffering the taint of corruption, to come under greater state supervision. ``We will not be subjected to a second-class position,'' he said. ``We will share, but we will not be taken over.'' One supporter at the news conference said the charges lodged against the mayor may actually help him marshal support in black neighborhoods. ``He's made a great effort to turn this city around,'' said community activist Omar Salahuddin. ``These charges are the same kind of charges that black mayors across the country are facing. Usry was indicted Jan. 3 on charges of conspiracy, official misconduct, bribery, gifts to public servants and violating the state campaign contribution law. The mayor, who will turn 68 Feb. 2, reiterated Monday he is innocent until proven guilty. Usry is accused of accepting $6,000 in cash and a $500 check to back an ordinance change that would allow a motorized business on the Boardwalk. Usry has said the money was for a charitable fund-raiser. Scheduled along with three others for arraignment Jan. 29, Usry faces up to 36 years in prison and $315,000 in fines if convicted of all charges. Eleven others, including the city council president and two city councilmen, were arraigned two weeks ago in a probe of alleged municipal corruption. Usry, president of the National Conference of Black Mayors, became mayor in 1984 after he defeated incubant Michael Matthews in a recall election. Matthews is now serving a 15-year sentence for extortion. Usry was re-elected in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Pressure Building to Speed Sales
DOC.TEXT: Officials in charge of the 5-month-old savings and loan bailout are coming under increasing pressure to act more quickly on what amounts to the largest thrift institution and real estate sale in history. The Resolution Trust Corp., created Aug. 9 when President Bush signed the bailout legislation, hit the ground running with an initial flurry of action. Within two months, it had disposed of 33 failed S&Ls out of the 262 it inherited. But, in the three months since then, it's disposed of only seven and its portfolio of failed S&Ls is growing faster than its list of resolutions. At the end of last week, it had sold a total of 40 institutions, but still held 302 institutions with assets totaling $113 billion. And, in coming months, it expects to take control of an additional 200 bankrupt thrifts. The House Banking Committee on Tuesday opens three days of hearings into the administration's conduct of the bailout. The Senate Banking Committee is following with a fourth session next Monday. Legislators and analysts are criticizing the administration for not doing more, a marked contrast from the generally favorable reception bailout officials received during the last big round of congressional oversight hearings in October. ``Speed is crucial,'' said Professor Paul Horvitz of the University of Houston. ``These insolvent institutions are losing money. ... But, much more important than that ... is they're also affecting the market and imposing losses on solvent institutions.'' Democrats on the banking panel are faulting Resolution Trust Corp. officials for being too afraid of the kind of withering criticism that hamstrung and ultimately forced the resignation of M. Danny Wall, who as chairman of the now defunct Federal Home Loan Bank Board handled the disposal of 223 institutions in 1988. ``It's a politically charged area and they're being extremely, perhaps overly, cautious,'' said Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., a member of the banking committee. ``They're very troubled and worried about doing anything and often the bureaucratic response to that is: Don't just stand there, do nothing.'' ``The message we have to get across is: inaction is not an alternative,'' said Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., who heads a House task force overseeing the bailout. ``We didn't appoint them to be in a popularity contest. We appointed them to do a job.'' Critics also cite the cumbersome administrative structure created by the S&L bill. Policy and purse strings are controlled by a board chaired by the secretary of the treasury. However, the corporation's work is supervised by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., an independent agency that insures bank and S&L deposits. ``There's a fundamental structural problem,'' said Bert Ely, a financial institutions analyst in Alexandria, Va. ``Ultimately, who's in charge?'' L. William Seidman, who is chairman of both the FDIC and Resolution Trust Corp., conceded that the administrative structure has slowed the cleanup process, but he stressed the enormity of the agency's task. ``You're setting up a new organization that had zero employees five months ago. Already it's the equivalent of the second-largest financial institution (after Citicorp) in the country,'' he said. This month, the corporation put 51 of its institutions on the auction block, bringing the total for sale up to 70. It also released a 3,000-page inventory of 30,000 pieces of real estate available in 45 states. ``We want to do things rapidly, but we also want to do things right,'' Seidman said. ``Overall ... I think our crew has accomplished quite a bit.'' The corporation hopes to complete the sales in the second quarter, but after that says it will face a cash crunch if the administration and Congress cannot resolve the politically sticky question of how to raise working capital for the agency. The S&L bill provided $50 billion to cover losses in insolvent, but still open, thrifts. But, the corporation needs an additional $40 billion to $100 billion in working capital. It would be repaid as the government sells assets from the failed S&Ls and would not increase the ultimate cost of the bailout. ``They need more money and they need it sooner rather than later,'' said Robert Litan of the Brookings Institution, a policy research group in Washington that sometimes advocates liberal positions. ``The problem is the uncertainty over the budget treatment.'' The administration wants to avoid inflating the budget deficit. But, congressional Democrats argue that it's is cheapest to borrow the money through the Treasury, which would count toward the deficit. So far, no one has come up with a compromise that will satisfy both sides.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Spokesman Says Views on Abortion a Matter of `Personal Choice'
With AM-Abortion Rally, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's spokesman said Monday that Americans are entitled to differing views on abortion based on their ``personal choice of conscience.'' At the same time, Bush was telling anti-abortion marchers he stands with them. White House aides sought to play down the significance of the emotion-charged subject as an election-year issue, as well as reports of divisions on the subject within the Bush family itself. ``We all feel there is room within the (Republican) party for varying points of view on this issue,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, the president's spokesman. He said that Bush's own anti-abortion view was ``a personal choice of conscience he has made'' and that the president ``urges others to consider their conscience and principles in making their own personal judgments.'' As to a report in this week's Newsweek magazine that the Bush family discovered at a recent family gathering that it was split on the abortion issue, with Bush and his wife disagreeing, Fitzwater said such a meeting never took place. Despite longstanding speculation that Barbara Bush retains the pro-choice position Bush himself once espoused, Fitzwater said, ``The president said no such meeting ever took place.'' Mrs. Bush repeatedly has refused to answer interviewers' questions about her views on the abortion issue. In a year in which many analysts see a rigid anti-abortion stance as a political liability, Bush limited his contact with the marchers to a 90-second speech by remote telephone hookup. He spoke to the marchers as they prepared for their annual march past the Capitol and the Supreme Court. ``Let me assure you that this president stands with you on this issue of life,'' Bush told the marchers on the 17th annivesary of the court's Roe vs. Wade decision, which legalized abortion. ``For 17 years, the March for Life has served as a poignant reminder to all Americans that human life in all its forms must be respected. And I think all of you know my deep conviction on Roe vs. Wade,'' Bush said. Although Bush said in 1980 that he believed the Roe vs. Wade decison was ``right,'' he now supports a constitutional amendment to overturn the ruling. He opposes abortion except to save the mother's life or in cases of rape or incest. Bush opposes federal financing of abortions for poor women except to save the mother's life. Fitzwater, asked at his daily news briefing whether Bush shares Republican National Chairman Lee Atwater's view that there is enough room in the GOP for both those who oppose and those who favor abortion rights, Fitzwater said: ``Yes, he does.'' ``We welcome Republicans being Republicans. And they're free. We have people of independent belief and thought here,'' he said. Newsweek reported that Bush and his wife discussed abortion at a recent get-together with their children and their children's spouses and found all the men were anti-abortion but all the women were pro-choice, said the magazine. It did name its source. Mrs. Bush's press secretary, Anna Perez, echoed Fitzwater's denial that any such meeting took place. ``It did not happen as reported,'' she said. Furthermore, Ms. Perez said that Mrs. Bush ``has a longstanding policy of not commenting on controversial issues. She does not want to defuse the ability she has to focus public opinion on those areas where she can make a difference: literacy, teen pregnancy, hunger. ...''

DOC.HEAD: More Price Rises Likely for Milk, U.S. Economist Says
DOC.TEXT: Consumer prices of milk and other dairy products may well rise again this year but not at the pace of 1989, an Agriculture Department economist said Monday. Ralph Parlett of the department's Economic Research Service said 1990 retail prices of dairy products could rise as much as 3 percent, compared with an average gain of 6.6 percent in 1989. A few weeks ago, Parlett figured dairy product prices might go up in a range of 1 percent to 2 percent this year. But now, he said in a telephone interview, the increase could be more volatile, ranging from zero to 3 percent. Consumer food prices generally are expected to rise 3 percent to 5 percent in 1990, according to a forecast announced by USDA last fall. The 1989 average was up almost 6 percent, the sharpest gain since 1981. Parlett said he is sticking by the 3 percent to 5 percent forecast, at least for the present. In an outlook report by the USDA agency, economists said dairy markets ``are adjusting after the record prices and chaotic conditions of last autumn.'' The report said dairy prices at the farm and wholesale will drop in the first half of 1990 because of cutbacks in non-fat dry milk exports, likely increases in milk production, and consumer reaction to higher prices. Another factor will be seasonal increases in milk output, the ``flush'' season of spring when production is at a peak. By then, the report said, most wholesale prices are likely to be below a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection for Child Mutilation Case Begins
DOC.TEXT: The sexual mutilation of a 7-year-old boy so inflamed Tacoma residents that a judge went more than 100 miles north Monday to pick a jury that hasn't formed opinions from pretrial publicity. Between 80 and 90 people showed up Monday in the start of jury selection for the trial in Tacoma of Earl Kenneth Shriner, a 40-year-old ex-convict with a 24-year history of attacks on young people. Shriner has pleaded innocent to charges he raped and choked the boy and cut off his penis on May 20. The boy, now 8 and back in school, will testify. The crime is one of several violent sex crimes recently in Washington state which have sparked proposed legislation to snare more sex predators and keep them in jail longer. In addition to pretrial publicity, Pierce County Superior Court Judge Tom Sauriol also cited a number of death threats against Shriner in moving jury selection. He initially refused to tell the news media about the move until ordered to by the state Supreme Court. When asked Monday if there had been a lot of threats, Sauriol said, ``I don't know what you'd call an awful lot. There has been an awful lot that's scary.'' Barbara Corey-Boulet, Pierce County deputy prosecuting attorney, said there had been more death threats in this case than in any case she'd every been associated with. When potential jurors were asked how many had heard of the Shriner case, almost everyone raised their hands. A few raised their hands when asked if they or someone they talked to had expressed an opinion about the case. Shriner sat expressionless during the proceedings. No one was to be excused from possible jury duty until lawyers for both sides study the results of a 12-page, 55-question questionnaire potential jurors were asked to fill out after orientation Monday. Jury selection was expected to take about a week and the trial, set to start in Tacoma on Jan. 29, about three weeks. Jurors will be sequestered, Sauriol said. Prosecutors have said they would seek a life sentence for Shriner, who completed a 10-year prison term shortly before the attack on the boy for kidnap and assault of two teen-age girls. Shriner has been held in lieu of $1 million bail. No Washington county has been immune from the sex crimes fallout. A governor's task force held hearings throughout the state before drafting a $17 million package of proposed legislation to toughen sex-offender sentences and create a civil procedure to indefinitely commit highly violent offenders after they have served their criminal sentences.

DOC.HEAD: Former Justice Buried at Arlington National Cemetery
DOC.TEXT: With the late afternoon sun casting long shadows at Arlington National Cemetery, former Justice Arthur J. Goldberg was buried Monday beside his wife and near the grave of Chief Justice Earl Warren, under whom he served on the Supreme Court. Retired Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and six of the eight associate justices were among mourners at private Jewish services in the Fort Myer Memorial Chapel, but did not come to the gravesite. Lt. Cmdr. Eric S. Renne, an Air Force chaplain, presented the flag from the casket to Goldberg's son, Robert Goldberg of Anchorage, Alaska. By Robert Goldberg's side was his sister, Barbara Goldberg Cramer of Chicago. Goldberg's wife, Dorothy, died in February 1988. Their gravesite lies between that of Warren and that of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles in a hilltop area of the cemetery across the Potomac River from Washington. Goldberg and his wife were entitled to burial in Arlington because of his service as an Air Force colonel. Rabbi Stanley Rabinowitz conducted the graveside service, an Air Force firing party fired three volleys and Staff Sgt. Joel C. Guyton of Bolling Air Force Base, Wash., played ``Taps.'' Justices John Paul Stevens and Anthony Kennedy did not attend. Retired Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. was also absent. Powell and Burger are the only surviving retired members of the court. Goldberg, who served on the high court from 1962 until his resignation in 1965 to become U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, died of coronary artery disease Friday at his home in Washington. He was 81. He came to Washington as President John F. Kennedy's first secretary of labor in 1961 after a career as a union lawyer. Kennedy named him to the Supreme Court on the retirement of the ailing Justice Felix Frankfurter. He left the court when President Lyndon B. Johnson persuaded him to accept the United Nations post left vacant by the death of Adlai E. Stevenson. Johnson appointed Abe Fortas to succeed him on the court. Goldberg resigned from the U.N. position in 1968, and was the unsuccessful Democratic nominee for governor of New York against incumbent Republican Nelson Rockefeller in 1970. He practiced law in Washington and served on public commissions and as an arbitrator until shortly before his death.

DOC.HEAD: Rain And Snow In Northeast And Northwest
DOC.TEXT: A cold front brought rain to the Northwest on Monday, with snow at higher elevations, and light rain and light snow lingered over parts of the Northeast. Showers extended from the northern Pacific Coast to western Montana, with freezing rain reported around Missoula, Mont. A snow advisory was posted for the Cascade mountains of Washington state. Rain amounts during the six hours up to 1 p.m. EST were all one half-inch or less. Quillayute, Wash., got 1.05 inches during the 24 hours up to 7 a.m. EST. Light rain and light snow lingered in the Northeast. Light rain and snow extended from the upper Ohio Valley to New England, with freezing drizzle reported in western Pennsylvania. Elsewhere, a few showers developed ahead of a cold front over southern Florida. Fog lingered late into the morning in some California valleys. Dense fog developed overnight in the Gulf Coast region and along the Atlantic Coast. Strong, gusty wind developed over the eastern slopes of the Rockies in Wyoming and Colorado. Subzero temperatures were reported in northern Maine and in the central Rockies. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was 16 degrees below zero at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Will Nominate Kolstad as NTSB Chairman
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday that he will nominate James Kolstad as chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, ending a 17-month stalemate over leadership of the agency that investigates air, sea and land transportation accidents. Kolstad, 50, a former airline executive, has been a member of the safety board since 1987 and its acting chairman since August 1988 when Jim Burnett failed to win Senate approval for a fourth two-year term as chairman. White House action on the nomination had been delayed while Kolstad underwent an extended background check, including scrutiny of his interim stewardship of the agency. The board has been beset with bickering and other difficulties, exacerbated by a tight budget and shrinking investigative staff. Board member Joseph Tribbe Nall was killed Nov. 28 in a plane crash in Caracas, Venezuela, where he had gone to give a speech. ``This long interim has been destabilizing and it's good that the issue has been resolved,'' said Stephen Hayes, vice president of the Air Transport Association, which represents the major airlines. ``We think he's certainly well-qualified and will be a very effective chairman of the board.'' On Capitol Hill, Sen. Wendell Ford, D-Ky., the chairman of the Senate aviation subcommittee, said he was pleased with Bush's move. ``I believe Mr. Kolstad has the necessary background, qualifications and temperament to serve in this capacity. Mr. Kolstad will continue to promote the smooth operation of the board and I look forward to working with him as chairman,'' Ford said. An aide to Ford said the panel will schedule confirmation hearings on both Kolstad and Susan Coughlin, a Bush nominee whose appointment to the board languished last year without a hearing. Kolstad was a White House aide and presidential advance man during the Nixon administration. He was director of congressional relations for the old Civil Aeronautics Board from 1973-78 and later served as public affairs director for Frontier Airlines.

DOC.HEAD: Safety Panel Wants Sleepwear Labels Should Indicate Burn Danger
DOC.TEXT: Consumer Product Safety Commission staff members say adult sleepwear should be labeled according to its degree of flammability to help prevent fire deaths among the elderly. Manufacturers argue that a simple warning would do the job. The commission will soon consider staff and industry recommendations for adult sleepwear labeling after postponing a vote on the issue Monday. ``We want to provide the consumer with information on relative flammability to build safety into making a choice,'' said James Hoebel, head of the CPSC fire hazard and burn prevention division. Hoebel's staff has recommended the commission require labeling that would classify adult pajamas, nightgowns and robes by degree of fabric flammability. ``I don't quarrel with their intent,'' said Larry K. Martin, government relations director for the American Apparel Manufacturers Association. ``They want to provide some added safety to elderly people but you can't segregate nightwear for elderly people from what you and I wear,'' added Martin. According to the CPSC, there were 179 clothing fire deaths in 1986, the last year for which figures are available. Adults aged 65 and older were victims in all but 40 of those incidents and the clothing most frequently involved was sleepwear, said Hoebel. ``We're very concerned about trying to prevent those deaths,'' said CPSC spokesman Ken Giles. But Martin said a simple flammability warning would accomplish the same goal as a complex system of fabric testing and rating. ``We've recommended to the commission that they require a warning label that has a logo with a strike through it and a flame and language that says `Warning: Keep away from flame and other ignition source,''' Martin said. Labels are not required for children's sleepwear but garments must meet a flammability performance standard that measures how quickly a garment stops burning. CPSC testing includes burning with an open flame at least five 10-by-3-inch swatches from a garment. No sample can burn more than seven inches before it stops burning and no one swatch can burn its full length for a garment to satisfy the government standard. The American Association of Retired Persons, a lobbying group for the elderly, prefers a performance standard but would back a classification system and a mandatory labeling program, AARP volunteer James Ryan told the commission last week.

DOC.HEAD: Cult Leader's Wife Pleads Innocent in Murder Case
DOC.TEXT: The wife of a cult leader pleaded innocent Monday to 15 counts of helping him and some of his followers kill a family of five last spring. Alice Lundgren, wearing handcuffs and shackled at the ankles, appeared somber at her arraignment, other than to smile faintly at another jail inmate brought to court. A judge set bond at $250,000 after a prosecutor expressed concern Mrs. Lundgren might flee if released from the Lake County Jail. She and her husband, Jeffrey Lundgren, were arrested with their 19-year-old son, Damon, earlier this month in Southern California. ``The state has information and believes that had this defendant been successful in delivering her minor children to relatives, she and her husband would have fled into Mexico,'' Lake County prosecutor Steven C. LaTourette told Common Pleas Judge James W. Jackson. Mrs. Lundgren, 39, pleaded innocent to five counts of complicity to aggravated murder, five counts of conspiracy to commit aggravated murder and five counts of kidnapping in the shooting deaths last April of Dennis Avery, his wife, Cheryl, and their three daughters, aged 15, 13 and 7. The bodies of the family were found Jan. 3-4 buried under a barn on a farm near Cleveland where Lundgren and his small band of followers lived for a time. Authorities have speculated the deaths may have been a religious sacrifice. The Averys were among Lundgren's followers. Lundgren is a former lay minister for the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints in Kirtland. In January 1988, he was defrocked after church leaders said he espoused radical beliefs and used his position as a tour guide at a church temple to recruit believers. Lundgren and his son each are charged with five counts of aggravated murder and five counts of kidnapping. They are fighting extradition from California to Ohio. Eight other cult members were arrested this month in the case. Charges against them range from aggravated murder to kidnapping. Kay Sunday, lawyer for Mrs. Lundgren in San Diego, said last week the couple's three younger children were staying with Mrs. Lundgren's mother in Missouri.

DOC.HEAD: Security Forces Disperse Demonstrators
DOC.TEXT: Police spraying foam from water cannons dispersed a rally Monday night of people demanding the parliament of this Persian Gulf emirate be reinstated, witnesses reported. An Interior Ministry spokesman said five people were arrested ``after trying to resist security men and prevent them from carrying out their duty'' and that one tried to attack police with a knife. No estimate was available of the size of the crowd at Farnawaniya, 10 miles south of Kuwait city. The official Kuwaiti News Agency said the crowd gathered without permission at the home of Abbas Munawer, a member of the parliament dissolved in 1986. ``Despite several warnings ... to disperse, they went ahead with their plan, prompting security men to disperse them,'' it said. Activists said police sprayed foam on the crowd and cordoned off the area. It was the fourth such meeting in two months to be declared illegal and dispersed by force. It occurred less than 48 hours after the emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, said he favored a functioning parliament but urged activists to stop protesting. He dismissed the 50-member parliament, the only elected legislature in the Arab states around the Persian Gulf, because of harsh criticism of the government by members. Iran was at war with Iraq in 1986 and was threatening military action against Kuwait. Iran and Iraq agreed to a truce in August 1988 and supporters of greater democracy in Kuwait want the parliament reconvened. Pro-democracy activists collected 25,000 signatures on a petition, but the emir has refused to accept it.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Considering Making EPA Cabinet Post
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is weighing a plan to elevate the Environmental Protection Agency to Cabinet status after the idea won the backing of several key White House staffers, his spokesman said Monday. Presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said a bipartisan congressional proposal to make the EPA the 15th Cabinet agency is under serious consideration for White House backing. ``One of the selling points is that it could have managerial advantages for the agency. The EPA's in kind of a unique situation where it's part regulatory, part policy,'' Fitzwater said. ``Several members of the staff are receptive to the idea, but there has been no final decison yet.'' A bipartisan bill to make the EPA a Cabinet agency is expected to be introduced when Congress returns this week from its winter recess. Fitzwater said that White House aides have had discussions with congressional sponsors of the measure, but no commitment was given. The New York Times reported in Monday editions that Bush had reversed his previous opposition to expanding the Cabinet, and was ready to accept the outcome of a congressional vote on the proposal _ although would not initiate the plan himself. Fitzwater disputed that, however, saying Bush ``doesn't have a personal position at this time. No decision has been made.'' Previously, Bush has said he did not support any increases in the size of the Cabinet. ``We'd like not to expand the Cabinet, but occasionally we may come up with reasons why we'd want to change our mind,'' said Fitzwater, who worked in the EPA office of public affairs from 1972 to 1981. The Cabinet was last expanded in 1988, before Bush took office, with the addition of the Department of Veterans Affairs, formerly the Veterans Administration. The president has emphasized environmental issues in his first year in office, including calling for tough new clean-air legislation. He also is expected to propose an increase in funds for environmental programs in the fiscal 1991 budget he submits to Congress next Monday. The EPA was created in 1970 in an executive order by President Nixon. Bills were introduced last year to add the EPA to the Cabinet, but did not make it to the floor of either the House or Senate. Among legislators backing the idea are Sens. David Durenberger, R-Minn., John Chafee, R-R.I., and Bill Bradley and Frank Lautenberg, both New Jersey Democrats.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Meets With Reform Communist Before Party Congress in Poland
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa met Monday with a potential leader of the reformed communist party as Polish communists begged the Solidarity-led government for protection from ``revenge'' before holding their last congress. Walesa, a founder and leader of Solidarity, conferred with communist Tadeusz Fiszbach, a deputy speaker of parliament who was ousted as Gdansk party leader after the 1981 martial-law crackdown here for his Solidarity sympathies. Fiszbach has not said if he will bid to head the new party expected to emerge when the Polish United Workers Party _ the communist party _ is dissolved during its 11th national congress opening Saturday . The only announced candidate is Mieczyslaw F.
