Rakowski, the current first secretary who seeks to bolster the party's dwindling role in Polish politics with a new name and program. ``If the slogans and ideas that Mr. Fiszbach represents were valid during the last 10 years, we would surely be further in reforming Poland,'' Walesa said after the meeting. He called Fiszbach ``a man of reconciliation,'' and the communist said, ``There are common issues that do not divide us but unite us.'' The two men did not indicate any agreement, however, on a major issue: whether the buildings, industries and other property accumulated by the communist party during 45 years of total power should be reclaimed for the public treasury. Walesa said the party's assets are ``public property.'' ``One should not have an emotional approach,'' Fiszbach said. ``I think the government should take up the issue and should consider the needs of newly created parties and the newly elected local governments.'' Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and his Solidarity-dominated Cabinet have stopped government subsidies to political parities without moving to regain the property. But there is considerable public demand to go further. Up for consideration Thursday is a draft law submitted by 93 parliament members who want to take back party property. The party congress' coordinating committee protested Monday, and asked the government ``to guarantee us the elementary right to hold our congress.'' ``An attempt to confiscate communist party property on the eve of its ending its life impedes the shaping of a rational arrangement of political forces in the country,'' delegates said in a statement carried by the party daily Trybuna Ludu. ``At the decisive moment, we are becoming the focus of a propaganda and political attack. ``In a climate of aggression, there are attempts at revenge in a style that we assess as a relic of the past. Recently, the slogan of nationalizing communist party property became the pretext for the attacks.'' A commentary in Trybuna Ludu said parliament's adoption of the measure would be ``a revengeful abuse of freshly won power'' and ``end the short period of democracy in Poland.'' It said nationalizing party property would reinforce the arguments of the hard-liners and be a ``political blow at the reform-oriented current in the party.'' Over the weekend, Parliament began dismantling Poland's vast cooperative system, attacked as a monopolistic, bureaucratic vestige of communist power that must be pared down and opened to competition. The lawmakers, backed by the government, voted to dissolve the Central Cooperative Unions, the top tier of a system that funneled small producers' wares into a network of distributers ultimately regulated by supreme councils. ``Does a shoemaker in the countryside really need a chief manager in Warsaw?'' Deputy Urszula Jarosz asked during the debate, the official news agency PAP reported. The new law will remove regulations and restrictions imposed on producers by the Central Cooperative Unions as part of radical economic reforms that aim to turn Poland's staggering socialist economy into one driven by market forces. ``Adoption of the draft law will break up the old structures .. . and will encourage grass-roots initiative,'' PAP quoted Deputy Marian Kowal as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Woman to Test Dress Code Requiring Slacks
DOC.TEXT: A woman who says she stopped wearing slacks to work due to her religious beliefs will challenge her dismissal by her employer, who says trousers are safer on the job. The lawsuit, filed by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission on Bonnie Mai Owen's behalf, goes before U.S. District Judge Thomas Wiseman Jr. on Wednesday. ``I am a member of the Apostolic Pentecostal Church,'' Ms. Owen, of Culleoka, said in a statement filed with the court. ``My church teaches, and I believe for religious reasons, that it is wrong for women to wear slacks.'' Heil-Quaker officials say they have an unwritten dress code requiring all employees to wear trousers for safety reasons, and that Ms. Owen was informed of this policy during orientation. The company, whose Lewisburg plant makes sheet metal components for residential heating and cooling systems, claims dresses might get caught in machinery. Lee Fortier, a safety inspector hired by the EEOC, said the slow-moving assembly line on which Ms. Owen worked poses little danger. He said loose shirttails and carpenter-type aprons worn by many male employees pose as much hazard as a dress. Ms. Owen wore slacks to work for nearly three years before reporting for work Feb. 19, 1986, in a skirt. She said she was told to go home and change clothes and was fired the next day after she refused.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Cautions Soviets on Azerbaijan
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration cautioned the Soviet Union on Monday against suppressing peaceful political expression while quelling violence in Azerbaijan. It also urged Moscow to undertake ``a political dialogue'' with all peoples in the embattled republic. ``We hope for an early end to all bloodshed,'' the State Department said. ``We hope that reason and restraint will mark the actions of all parties to the dispute.'' Strife between Azeris and Armenians prompted Moscow to dispatch troops to the region last week. Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said 83 people were killed in Baku, the capital of the republic, over the past two days and that this toll ``is sure to rise.'' She said she could not confirm reports from Moscow that the troops had managed to take control of the city. Again, the U.S. spokeswoman deplored the ethnic violence that has plagued the region. Last week, the State Department supported Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's use of troops to try to restore order and criticized feuding Azeris and Armenians for ``revisiting old ethnic hatreds.'' Shifting gears slightly, Tuesday's statement stressed that U.S. support for Moscow in using force was limited. ``There is a fundamental difference between the short-term use of force to restore order and the use of force to suppress peaceful and legitimate political expression,'' Ms. Tutwiler said, reading from a prepared statement. ``We hope to see the early creation of conditions in which a political dialogue can be undertaken,'' it said. ``Such a dialogue must accommodate the aspirations of all the peoples in the republics.'' Asked if the Soviet Union was using force to suppress dissent, Ms. Tutwiler replied: ``No, we are not saying that.'' The spokeswoman said Soviet troops along the border with Iran had been augmented to prevent ``unauthorized access.'' Ms. Tutwiler said she had nothing to say about reports that Iran was aiding the Azeris with equipment. Most Azeris and Iranians are Moslems while Armenians are predominantly Christians. ``We deplore the ethnic violence that has plagued the region,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. ``We deeply regret the loss of life in Baku.''

DOC.HEAD: Envoy Resigns in Protest Over Crackdown
With AM-Haiti
DOC.TEXT: Haiti's ambassador to the United States resigned on Monday in protest against the ``repeated violations of human rights'' by his country's military government. Ambassador Pierre Francois Benoit told a news conference that the Haitian government has described itself as provisional but ``in my view is becoming permanent.'' In a etter to the nation's military leader, Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, Benoit said, ``In view of repeated violations of human rights in our country, which culimated in the events which transpired this weekend, I cannot continue to serve as your administration's ambassador to the United States and to the Organization of American States.'' He said his decision was triggered primarily by the government's decision to send several political leaders into exile. He plans to return to his former employer, General Motors, where he worked before assuming his duties as ambassador a year ago. Meanwhile, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler also criticized the crackdown in Haiti. ``By suspending four articles of the constitution, declaring state of siege, and arresting a number of political leaders, the government has put at risk the democratic transition in Haiti,'' she said. ``Especially disturbing is the deportation without charges, evidence or due process of responsible democratic opposition leaders. Such actions undermine the confidence that candidates and voters must have in order to participate in a credible electoral process.'' She called on the government to move quickly to rescind the measures taken over the weekend and to restore faith in the democratic process.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Cautions Against Quick-Fix Solutions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Embargoed for release at 7:40 p.m. EST; time set by source
DOC.TEXT: President Bush cautioned Monday against ``quick-fix solutions'' to problems such as homelessness, drug abuse, crime and education. More government spending is not the answer, Bush said in remarks prepared for a dinner sponsored by the conservative American Spectator magazine. He called for a renewal of dedication to the institutions of church, family and community and ``to the fundamental ideals of free government.'' ``With all the flash and fluff in the world today, there's something we can't afford to lose sight of _ something deceptively simple: It's who we are that makes this nation what it is,'' Bush said. ``We need to look beyond superficial, quick-fix solutions.'' The president said the 1990s would be an ``ideal time to renew our vows and our values, time to look beyond the next paycheck and the next personal problem. ... We simply have to remember that the American adventure isn't over; it's just begun.'' He praised the magazine, saying ``our nation's intellectual life would be more than a little poorer without the American Spectator surveying the scene.'' ``Your critical eye helps helps us see beneath the surface _ beyond the intellectual fads and fashions of the day _ to the ideas and the enduring values that really matter in our society.''

DOC.HEAD: Cincinnati Joins in Anti-Drug Program
LaserPhoto CS1
DOC.TEXT: Police and education officials kicked off Monday an anti-drug program sponsored by Kiwanis International that teaches school children the dangers of drug use. ``We teach them the reasons to say no _ that it can kill you _ with questions like `What is an alcoholic?' and `Are cigarettes dope?'' said Kiwanian Bob Galloway, a leader of the project. ``Operation KNOW'' has been started in 12 cities as a follow-up on Nancy Reagan's ``Just Say No'' campaign. The program costs the Kiwanis about $3 per child and provides them with such materials as a ``Know to Say No'' board game, T-shirts, headbands and pledges that youngsters sign promising to be drug- and alcohol-free. The pledges go to first lady Barbara Bush, and the children are to receive response cards from the White House. Other cities taking part in the program are New York, St. Louis, Los Angeles, Chicago, Boston, Detroit, Atlanta, Houston, Indianapolis, Harrisburg, Pa., and Washington, D.C.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Demand End to Communist Rule, Probe of Secret Police
DOC.TEXT: Opposition leaders meeting with ruling communist officials demanded quicker reforms to eliminate Communist Party influence in the government and workplace, and called for an investigation of the secret police. Also Monday, the newspaper Pogled reported that ousted Stalinist leader Todor Zhivkov, 78, arrested last week, faces a maximum of 30 years in jail if convicted on a single count _ misappropriation of state property. ``Todor Zhivkov's repressive system has not ceased to exist; we are its hostages,'' said Zhelyu Zhelev, chairman of the 12-party opposition Union of Democratic Forces, quoted by the state news agency BTA. Zhelev called for a speedup of democratization because of a ``possible adverse turn of events in the Soviet Union'' where unrest is wracking several of its republics and because of the need for Western economic aid, BTA said. The opposition says reform has been slow in coming since Zhivkov was deposed Nov. 10 in a wave of pro-democracy uprisings that swept Eastern Europe last year. Communist leader and President Petar Mladenov, who replaced Zhivkov, has pledged widespread reform and free elections by May. Politburo member Andrei Lukanov, leader of the Communist Party delegation, said, ``I deeply trust the Communist Party of the Soviet Union's ability to take the country out of the difficult stage,'' he said, apparently referring to the separatist movements that Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev is facing. Without the Soviet Union's cooperation Bulgaria would be unable to find its way out of its economic difficulties, BTA quoted Lukanov as saying. Opposition spokesmen at the negotiating table demanded that the Communist Party cells be removed from the workplace and urged that activities of the Committee for State Security be examined at a public inquiry, BTA said. The opposition also wants the army, the Interior Ministry, the law courts and the prosecutor's office to be ``depoliticized,'' meaning freed of influence by the ruling Communist Party and other parties. Opposition representatives also demanded disclosure of property of the Communist and Agrarian parties and of high-ranking officials in Bulgaria's ``nomenklatura,'' BTA said. They demanded the lifting of customs controls on the import of literature, the news agency said. The leadership was scheduled to answer the opposition demands on Tuesday. The opposition has received the green light to issue an independent newspaper, which will be titled Democracy, but the government has so far rejected a demand for opposition access to the media. The disagreement held up the talks last week. According to the Panorama weekend television program, Zhivkov was at his Boyana residence on the slopes of Mt. Vitosha south of Sofia until Jan. 19 when he was taken into custody. The report quoted the Interior Ministry as saying Zhivkov was being held ``in a place specially adjusted for the purpose'' of investigative custody. There was no elaboration. Conviction of the crime of illegally ``receiving an especially large amount of public property'' could draw a sentence of 10 to 30 years in jail, said Pogled. The other charge _ ``inciting ethnic hostility and hatred'' _ carries a maximum of three years. The third charge _ ``an especially grave case of abuse of power'' _ is punishable by imprisonment of three to 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: Movement Seen in Bombing Investigation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf new material after 15th graf pvs, But Hooks
DOC.TEXT: NAACP leaders said Monday after a meeting with President Bush there may be ``some movements'' in the effort to find the terrorists responsible for mail bombings in the South. Their assessment came as FBI agents searched a warehouse in Enterprise, Ala., in an action a spokesman said ``could very well'' be linked to the bombing investigation. Dr. William F. Gibson, a Greenville, S.C., dentist and chairman of the NAACP board of directors, said after meeting with Bush, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and FBI Director William Sessions: ``We got indications that there are some movements in the cases. I can't say anything further.'' NAACP Executive Director Benjamin L. Hooks said, ``We were fairly well satisfied that the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Justice Department were doing their best.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Thornburgh ``simply said that we were making progress, that he was hopeful, but he could not give any specifics at that point.'' Mail bombs claimed the lives of a federal appeals judge in Alabama and a Savannah, Ga., civil rights lawyers in November. Other bombs were mailed to the federal courthouse in Atlanta and the NAACP branch office in Jacksonville, Fla., but were intercepted before exploding. Among the 17 NAACP officials at the White House meeting were Willye Dennis, head of the Jacksonville office, and Erl Shinhoster, director of its Atlanta regional office, where a tear gas bomb exploded last Aug. 21. Hooks, who also met with Bush on Jan. 9 to discuss the attacks, said, ``We are concerned about the climate ... that has caused race relations to deteriorate, and increased acts of violence.'' He suggested that last week's arrest of District of Columbia Mayor Marion Barry on cocaine charges _ not discussed at the White House meeting _ may be part of a pattern of `undue harassment'' of black elected officials, and part of ``the rising tide of racism in this nation.'' Hooks said the Ku Klux Klan and Skinheads have picketed the NAACP's national headquarters in Baltimore twice in recent weeks. ``We're concerned about the mood, the kind of relationships that are developing schisms between blacks and whites in America,'' said Gibson. ``We encouraged the president to use (his) office ... to get the word over that we feel that there needs to be more relations and negotiations and discussions between black America and white America,'' said Gibson. They said they asked Bush and Thornburgh to use the Justice Department's Community Relations Service and a revised U.S. Commission on Civil Rights to promote such a dialogue. Bush was ``amicable'' toward those steps, Gibson said. Hooks said they did not discuss with the president the widely publicized Barry arrest in a FBI sting operation in a Washington hotel last Thursday. But Hooks said: ``There is no question about the fact that we at the NAACP across the past few years have felt that there has been undue emphasis on harassing black elected officials.'' Thornburgh, asked later about the harassment charge, said, ``If that were the case, it would be intolerable. It is not the case.'' Hooks said newspaper accounts made it sound like ``the search had finally paid off. We spent all of these years trying to find him with a grain of cocaine, and by God we did it, didn't we? ``We haven't found all the people who've stolen all the money from the savings and loan associations and are driving Rolls Royces and Jaguars, so obviously many of us in the black community will have some peculiar feelings as we go further.'' Hooks was asked if he objected to bringing law-breakers to justice. ``No, I think you ought to bring everybody to justice for violating the law. That would have meant most of us here would be arrested for speeding, spitting on the sidewalk or something. If we can afford to do it, let's do it. Bush has said nothing of the Barry arrest, except that it was ``very sad.''

DOC.HEAD: Italian Leaders Meet with Former King of Afghanistan
DOC.TEXT: Italian leaders met Monday with the former king of Afghanistan for talks on the political situation in the war-torn nation. Italian President Francesco Cossiga invited Mohammed Zaher Shah for a new year's lunch, the president's office said in a statement. Cossiga's spokesman, Ludovico Ortona, said Italian Premier Giulio Andreotti and Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis also attended but he refused to say what was discussed. However, a spokesman for the former king, Gen. Abdul Wali, said there was an ``analysis of the situation in our country.'' He described the atmosphere as ``cordial.'' Wali refused to comment directly on reports that President Najib of Afghanistan had agreed to turn over power to an interim government led by the former king. ``Sharing power with the ... (Communist) party in Kabul has always been something which is not acceptable,'' he said, adding that the former king would ``accept any role or mission that the Afghan people ... would bestow upon him.'' The Soviet Union withdrew the last of its troops from Afghanistan nearly a year after a decade-long effort to sustain Marxist rule. There have been suggestions the former king could play a role in a transitional government that would lead the country out of civil war between the government and Moslem guerrillas. Zaher Shah, who suffers from rheumatism, was enjoying the thermal spring waters of the Italian island of Ischia when his cousin and former prime minister, Mohammed Daud, seized power in July 1973. He has lived in Italy since then. Monday's lunch marked one of the rare occasions on which the former king has appeared in public.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Anniversary Marked As States Debate New Rules
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with comment from Norma McCorvey, her lawyer in Roe Vs. Wade, Gloria Steinem, other demonstrations. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators marched with renewed fervor at state capitols and cities around the nation Monday to commemorate the 17th anniversary of the Supreme Court's Roe vs. Wade ruling, which legalized abortion. At least 9,000 people marched against abortion at the Georgia Capitol in Atlanta, while Washington's annual March for Life carried a similar message to the White House, the nation's Capitol and the U.S. Supreme Court. ``It may be a long fight,'' the Rev. Pat Robertson told demonstrators in Atlanta, ``(but) we will come back this year, we will come back next year, we will come back the year after ... until sooner or later we have victory.'' Norma McCorvey, the woman who was the ``Jane Roe'' in Roe vs. Wade, was keynote speaker at a pro-choice rally that drew about 1,000 people to the steps of the California Capitol in Sacramento. ``We're still fighting and will continue to fight as long as the fight must go on,'' she said. ``The movement didn't start with me. I was just the straw that broke the camel's back.'' Sarah Weddington, the Texas lawyer who argued Ms. McCorvey's case before the Supreme Court, told a breakfast in Dallas: ``We are here to say we won 17 years ago today, and we will win again.'' The Roe vs. Wade anniversary has become an increasingly important day to those debating the future of abortion in the United States. This year's commemoration carried special weight because of last summer's Supreme Court ruling in Missouri's Webster case. That ruling, which opened the door for states to impose some restrictions on abortion, was the biggest legal victory in decades for anti-abortion forces and led to speculation that the high court would overturn Roe vs. Wade. It also pumped new life into organizations on both sides of the abortion debate, and led to a flurry of legislative proposals to both restrict and guarantee access to abortions. Those bills helped give added significance to this year's demonstrations. Tens of thousands of people marched at rallies around the nation on Sunday. The Webster case also provided a backdrop for one of the stranger incidents in the abortion observances. On Sunday night, police in San Francisco cited Ms. McCorvey for illegally posting stickers bearing the name ``Roe'' on city street signs. The signs were on Webster Street. ``It was just a prank,'' Ms. McCorvey told reporters Monday. ``We were plastering Webster signs, making them Roe signs.'' In another unusual twist, about a dozen pro-choice demonstrators wrapped 200 feet of purple ribbon around the Louisiana statehouse in Baton Rouge to draw attention to their new Coalition for Reproductive Freedom. The ribbon, they said, symbolized the purple sashes worn by suffragettes who marched for women's rights earlier in the century. In Charlotte, N.C., a Planned Parenthood chapter set up three mobile telephones downtown for pro-choice supporters on their lunch breaks to pay $3 to call Gov. Jim Martin and President Bush. Many people stopped to take leaflets, but a few placed calls. ``I'm pro-choice and I vote,'' Lyla Bendsen shouted into one of the cellular phones as she called Martin's office over the sounds of traffic. In Trenton, N.J., about 150 protesters marched in front of the New Jersey statehouse in support of anti-abortion bills, including one that would require minors seeking abortions to notify their parents. The demonstrators included a group of schoolgirls from Incarnation School in nearby Ewing, N.J., one of whom carried a sign that read: ``Real Women Don't Kill Babies.'' ``All of our parents gave us a chance, so why don't we give them a chance,'' said another student, eighth-grader Theresa Thoma. A parental notification bill is also pending in Nebraska, where the Legislature chose Monday's anniversary to begin its debate on the issue. State lawmakers in Lincoln adjourned for the day without voting. In Maine, about three-dozen anti-abortion demonstrators marched on the federal courthouse in Portland, while their opposites lobbied legislators in Augusta ``to keep Maine a pro-choice state,'' in the words of pro-choice leader Betsy Sweet. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo appeared with Gloria Steinem, a founder of the modern women's movement, at a conference of family planning advocates in Albany. ``There is an uprising on the streets and in the voting booths on this issue in this country, just as there was for democracy in Eastern Europe,'' Ms. Steinem said.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Claims Contras Planned Ambush Against Him
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to RECAST lead, ADD protest note. Pickup 6th, `Ortega addressed...'; INSERTS 1 graf after 11th `Therefore it's...' with Ortega speculation on why Contras did not attack him. Pickup 12th, `On Nov. 1...'
DOC.TEXT: President Daniel Ortega said U.S.-backed rebels had planned to ambush him in a remote northern area where he campaigned for elections. No attack took place, and his claim could not be independently confirmed. Ortega spoke at a political rally Sunday in San Juan de Rio Coco, a small town in the northern province of Madriz, which borders Honduras. A tape of his speech was provided to The Associated Press. Ortega is running for re-election against Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the candidate of the U.S.-backed United National Opposition. General elections are scheduled for Feb. 25. The leftist government has said the number of clashes with the Contra rebels increased sharply this month. Ortega said in an annual economic speech Monday that he would send a note protesting the attacks to the U.S. government, the U.N. Security Council and the Organization of American States. Ortega addressed a rally in Quilali, then left for San Juan de Rio Coco. ``Now that we were coming from Quilali, they (Contras) tried to stage an ambush on the road,'' Ortega said. ``And the comrades (military commanders) were telling me, `It's not convenient to go to San Juan de Rio Coco because the ambush could be waiting for you.' ``But I told them, `Let's go.' '' There were no journalists with the president's caravan as it traveled from Quilali to San Juan de Rio Coco. Journalists were shuttled in a helicopter. ``Those Contras are lurking around there, threatening ... and in some way they are threatening the president of Nicaragua and the candidate of the Sandinista Front,'' Ortega said. ``Therefore it's the Yankees, I accuse the Yankees, I give responsibility to the Yankees, of any criminal action against me or against the comrades who are traveling with me,'' he added. Ortega said Monday the Contras desisted from their ambush plan because it was daylight and their retreat would have been more difficult. On Nov. 1, Ortega broke a cease-fire that technically had been in place since March 1988. He said thousands of Contras had begun infiltrating from Honduras, where most of them have been based since the cease-fire was signed. The Contras took up arms in 1981, claiming the Sandininstas had betrayed the goals of the 1979 popular revolution that toppled dictator Anastasio Somoza. The United States now supplies them only non-lethal aid. Under an agreement between Central American presidents in August, the Contras were to return to their homeland or be relocated. Thousands of Contras remain in Honduras, and they have refused to surrender.

DOC.HEAD: North, South Yemen End Border Restrictions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to CLARIFY nationalities of the prime ministers, MOVES up that South Yemen is Communist. Pickup 3rd, `They also...'
DOC.TEXT: SAN`A, North Yemen (AP) _ North Yemen and South Yemen on Monday began allowing citizens to move freely between the two countries, their latest step toward eventual unification. At the conclusion of a three-day meeting in San`a, prime ministers Abdul-Aziz Abdul-Ghani of the capitalist north and Yassin Saeed No`man of the Communist south declared that citizens could cross without hindrance. They also said all political prisoners would be freed immediately but gave no numbers. The human rights organization Amnesty International has reported that each nation holds dozens of people as political prisoners. The statement from the three-day meeting, which was held to outline steps to merging the countries, also said the two governments foresaw a joint body of 33 ministries for the unified state. The two Red Sea countries have been working for unity for more than a decade despite the difference in ideology between conservative North Yemen and Marxist South Yemen. But the unity drive gained impetus last year as the Soviet-backed government in South Yemen, following the lead of other countries, began leaning toward reform. President Ali Abdullah Saleh of North Yemen and South Yemeni Socialist Party Secretary-General Ali Salem al-Beidh have decided that a joint constitution for the full merger should be prepared by their parliaments and put to a referendum in both countries no later than Nov. 30. The North Yemeni capital of San`a has been designated as capital of the united country. The border regions are rugged, mountainous and mainly inhabited by tribes. Yemeni citizens in recent weeks have gained automatic telephone access to each other's countries, and there are reports of plans for a joint television program. Representatives of the nations today also requested that a financial and economic committee speed the drafting of single laws for customs, currency, banking, taxes and other areas. Similar instructions were issued to ministries dealing with education, judiciary, information, legislation, foreign affairs and diplomatic representation and the interior. Asked about adjusting differences in economic systems between a relatively free North Yemen and a socialist South, No`man said ``we shall be bound by the economic principles that will emerge in the constitution and political will.''

DOC.HEAD: Princess Anne Denies Reports She's to Divorce
DOC.TEXT: Princess Anne, separated from her husband since August, on Monday denied reports in British newspapers that she is to divorce Capt. Mark Phillips. ``Divorce? It's not been mentioned,'' Queen Elizabeth II's only daughter told reporters outside her Gatcombe Park home, British Broadcasting Corp. television reported. Buckingham Palace refused to comment on the Monday reports in the Daily Express, Daily Mail and Daily Mirror newspapers. Anne, 39, and Phillips, 41, separated last August after 15 years of marriage. They have two children. A spokesman at Buckingham Palace, who was not identified in keeping with British custom, said: ``I have nothing to add to what was said at the time of the separation.'' The palace issued a statement on Aug. 31 that said: ``Her Royal Highness, the Princess Royal, and Captain Mark Phillips have decided to separate on terms agreed between them. There are no plans for divorce proceedings.'' At the time, royal sources said the queen was ``obviously saddened'' but understood the couple's decision. Princess Margaret, Queen Elizabeth II's younger sister, was divorced from her husband, Lord Snowdon, in 1978.

DOC.HEAD: Boston Lawyer for Commerce Post
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS sex of nominee from male to female
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday he will nominate L. Joyce Hampers, a Boston lawyer, to be assistant secretary of commerce for economic development. If confirmed, she would succeed Orson G. Swindle III. Hampers, 51, of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was the Republican candidate for Massachusetts state treasurer in 1986; he lost. She was a commissioner at the Massachusetts Department of Revenue in 1979-83.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Halts Repairs to Iowa Turret
DOC.TEXT: The Navy has halted repairs to the battleship USS Iowa's No. 2 turret amid speculation that the World War II ship would be mothballed. Navy Secretary H.L. Garrett III ordered the work suspended this weekend after consultations with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. ``This action was agreed upon in view of the uncertainty surrounding the battleship's future service life,'' a Navy statement said. Fourty-seven sailors were killed when the No. 2 turret exploded last April. The Iowa entered the Norfolk Naval Shipyard in Portsmouth on Jan. 13 for a 14-week, $26 million overhaul. Repair to the 16-inch gun turret was expected to cost about $13 million. Pentagon officials have said two of the nation's four battleships probably would be mothballed to help with cuts in the defense budget.

DOC.HEAD: Azerbaijanis March to Mourn Those Slain by Soviets, Threaten to Secede
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with location of new deaths; Armenian, Baltic, Azerbaijani comment, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB1,5,6,7,10,12, MOS30,33,37,39,42,43,44,57
DOC.TEXT: Up to 2 million wailing, black-clad Azerbaijanis marched through Baku on Monday to mourn those killed when Soviet troops put down a nationalist revolt, and the republic's legislature threatened secession if Moscow did not pull out its soldiers. In further defiance of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, local legislators declared Moscow's state of emergency void. Militants vowed to keep up crippling strikes in Baku, an oil center of 1.8 million people on the Caspian Sea, until troops leave. Communist leaders from Soviet Armenia and Azerbaijan took a tentative step Monday toward ending 10 days of ethnic warfare, agreeing to withdraw armed groups from areas along their border, Tass said. But activists in Armenia and Azerbaijan said they doubted the truce would be kept. The official Soviet news agency reported 12 more people killed in ethnic clashes Monday on the border of the two republics, raising the toll since Jan. 13 to 167. Soviet officials said 83 of those were from the Soviet assault on the Azerbaijani capital Saturday, including 14 soldiers and members of their families. More than 500 have been wounded in the conflicts. Tass said the 12 new deaths occurred when Armenian militants fired on an Azerbaijani village in the Volchy Vorota border area. Azerbaijani activists told a Moscow news conference Monday that 3,700 died when Soviet troops entered Baku, Tass said, but it emphasized this was an unconfirmed figure. An emergency overnight session of the Azerbaijani Supreme Soviet legislature demanded full withdrawal of Soviet troops from the republic, with the exception of border districts with Armenia, said Baku lawyer Viliyad Mamedov, who attended the 11{-hour overnight session. Lawmakers also demanded lifting of the curfew and state of emergency in Baku and other areas of Azerbaijan, which Moscow imposed without the approval of Azerbaijani authorities, Mamedov said in a telephone interview. If those demands are not met, Mamedov said, the legislature will consider voting to secede from the Soviet Union. At Monday's mass rally in Baku, demonstrators carried posters reading, ``Gorbachev is the butcher of the Azerbaijani people,'' and ``Azerbaijanis will not succumb to tanks,'' said Shain Gajiyev, a Baku journalist. Witnesses said throngs of mourners numbering as many as 2 million bore coffins of Azerbaijanis killed in the weekend assault down the narrow streets and major thoroughfares to Lenin Square, now renamed Freedom Square in honor of the Azerbaijani nationalist cause. The mourners, wearing black and carrying black-bordered portraits of some of the victims, then buried the victims at Kirov Park, overlooking the Caspian Sea. ``All the people of Azerbaijan and Baku are in tears and mourning,'' official Baku Radio said in a broadcast monitored by the BBC in London. Soviet troops and police did not interfere in the funeral, said Leila Yunusov, a spokeswoman for the Social Democratic Group, an informal Azerbaijani political organization. Foreign reporters were barred from the region, so it was difficult to determine the exact death toll or reconcile conflicting information. Military officials said no one had been killed in Baku the last two days, and residents said the Soviet troops seemed to have the city under control. No armed clashes with troops were reported Monday, Gajiyev said, although scattered gunfire was heard. Conflicting reports came from the Soviet-Iranian border, where Azerbaijanis have torn down many barriers. The government newspaper Izvestia said 40,000 Azerbaijanis crossed into Iran on Sunday evening alone, but Iranian media said Soviet troops clamped down on the border and were not letting Azerbaijanis out. Interfax, an affiliate of Radio Moscow, said unidentified extremists threatened Russian residents of Baku with violence unless they left and threatened to blow up oil tankers in Baku's harbor unless troops were withdrawn. Soviet TV on Monday evening suggested the government launch negotiations with the Azerbaijani People's Front, the nationalist organization behind much of the unrest. The evening news program said since the People's Front controls some areas of Azerbaijan, it is the logical partner for peace talks. It was not clear whether the People's Front and Armenian activists participated in the negotiations in the Armenian town of Yeraskh. High-ranking Armenian and Azerbaijani Communist Party and government officials also agreed to repair disrupted communications lines. In a statement issued Monday, people's fronts from the Soviet Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia commiserated with the Azerbaijanis and said Moscow, with its centralized policies, was to blame for provoking the conflict. They offered Riga, the Latvian capital, as a site for peace talks. Armenia's popular movements condemned Moscow for the Baku deaths. When Armenians demanded protection for themselves and punishment for Azerbaijani extremists who victimized them, they ``did not mean a deployment of the Soviet army in a large-scale, bloody action, but the use of civilized methods proper to a law-based state,'' the Armenian Board of National Movements said. The statement, read over the phone by activist Rafael Popayan from Yerevan, the Armenian capital, said ``innocent blood is being shed, and that cannot leave the Armenian people indifferent.'' At a protest march by 2,000 Azerbaijanis in Moscow on Monday, one demonstrator carried a sign reading ``Comrades! In Baku more than 9,000 people were killed.'' A gathering Monday in the Azerbaijani town of Pushkino to mourn those slain ended in mass rioting, Tass said. The explosion into violence of the longstanding hostility between Armenia and Azerbaijan is considered one of the worst crises Gorbachev has faced in his nearly five-year tenure as Soviet leader. Moscow sent thousands of troops and other forces to Baku after fighting flared between the Moslem Azerbaijanis and mainly Christian Armenians this month. The neighboring republics are locked in a decades-old dispute over the region of Nagorno-Karabakh, which is inside Azerbaijan but populated mainly by Armenians. The total number of Soviet forces combating the violence in Armenia and Azerbaijan is reported to be 29,000, including troops, police, cadets and Interior Ministry forces. The number of militants is reported in the thousands. Violence began Jan. 13 with anti-Armenian rioting in Baku that killed 67 people by official count and sent thousands of Armenians fleeing from their homes in panic. It escalated into open warfare elsewhere in Azerbaijan. Sheikh Ul Islam, spiritual leader of Azerbaijani Moslems, condemned the assault on Baku by Soviet troops in an address to world and religious leaders sent to Azerinform, Azerbaijan's official news agency, on Monday. The Shiite cleric said evil deeds were committed in Baku over the weekend, beyond reason. No people are to be talked to with the language of guns, he said. He did not mention the Armenian deaths in Baku the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Haughey Would Welcome Unionist Talks on Anglo-Irish Accord
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Charles Haughey said Monday he is willing to talk with Protestants about replacing the Anglo-Irish accord, a 1985 pact giving the Irish Republic a say in the affairs of Northern Ireland. But Haughey reiterated his government's commitment to the accord, which is aimed at protecting interests of the 40 percent Roman Catholic minority in the strife-torn British colony. Haughey's carefully worded statement came after weekend overtures from two leading figures in the Ulster Unionist Party, the largest party in Northern Ireland that is adamantly against the 1985 agreement. ``I would welcome hearing unionist concerns at first hand,'' Haughey said. ``I place no restriction on the agenda. ``I would be quite prepared to consider any agreed alternative arrangements which would replace the existing agreement'' if Britain also agreed, he added. Britain's Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Brooke, found the developments ``encouraging.'' ``There does seem to be signs of movement,'' he told the British Broadcasting Corp. TV in an interview in Washington, ``and what happened over the weekend seems to me to be further evidence of that fluidity.'' Most Protestants favor some form of power-sharing with Catholics, but the more vehement loyalists see the Anglo-Irish agreement as a prelude to being drawn into a united and Catholic-dominated Ireland. The Protestant parties' anger about the agreement has been an obstacle to ending sectarian fighting in the province that has left 2,777 people dead. In an interview with Dublin's Sunday Press, Jim Nicholson, deputy chief of the Ulster Unionists, and party chairman Jack Allen were quoted as saying they were ``prepared to put everything on the table'' if Haughey publicly indicated he would consider a new framework to replace the Anglo-Irish Agreement. Haughey reiterated Dublin's continuing commitment to the accord ``unless and until it is transcended by a new and more comprehensive arrangement,'' but said it had never been regarded as immutable. ``The start of a new decade reinforces our sense of urgency about bringing to an end the violence that the people of Northern Ireland have endured for the past 20 years,'' Haughey said. Haughey, who has previously issued invitations to unionist leaders to meet him for discussions, has come under growing domestic political pressure to achieve this during his six-month presidency of the European Community. In Belfast, Peter Robinson, a leading member of the smaller Democratic Unionist Party, said, ``His remarks express fine sentiments but very little substance.'' The Irish Republic, although it has not relinquished its long-held claim to the north, is in consensus with the British government that nothing can change in Northern Ireland without Protestant consent.

DOC.HEAD: Former Armored Car Driver Waives Extradition in $651,000 Heist
DOC.TEXT: A former armored car guard who gambled away $651,000 stolen from his truck during two years on the lam agreed Monday to return to Philadelphia for trial. Edward Leigh Hunt Jr. told reporters he had spent his two years as a fugitive living in Hollywood _ ``a block from the Chinese theater'' _ and consumed much of the time studying Spanish because ``I love languages.'' ``I'm very glad the whole thing is over,'' he said. The 26-year-old Hunt, handcuffed and wearing blue jail coveralls, waived extradition on interstate theft charges. Hunt wouldn't explain details of a gambling system he has said he devised in an effort to make a profit on the money taken Jan. 20, 1988, from a truck belonging to the Brooks Armored Car Co. in Philadelphia. ``I stole the money because I thought I could quadruple it through gambling, and then I would give half to the company I stole it from,'' Hunt said in a Dec. 20 letter to his hometown newspaper, the Wilmington (Del.) News Journal. ``But I lost it all. ... I screwed up. ... I'm sorry,'' the letter said. Hunt said in the letter that he would give himself up in Los Angeles on the second anniversary of the heist. He kept his promise. Asked Monday if all his gambling was in Las Vegas, Hunt shook his head and declined explanation. Hunt made a brief appearance before U.S. Magistrate Ralph Geffen, who accepted his waiver and ordered him held without bail until he is transferred to Philadelphia. The FBI and U.S. Marshal's office said it could take several days to assemble the paperwork for transfer. On Jan. 20, 1988, Hunt was one of three guards working on the armored truck in Philadelphia. Two other guards returned from a bank to the truck to find that Hunt and two bags of cash had disappeared. Millions of dollars in cash, Hunt's gun and a uniform jacket were left behind. An arrest warrant was issued for Hunt two days later and he was indicted on April 26, 1988, on interstate theft charges by a Philadelphia grand jury.

DOC.HEAD: Argentina Gets Fourth Central Bank President in Six Months
DOC.TEXT: For the fourth time in six months, Argentina has a new Central Bank president. Enrique Folcini was appointed to the post Monday following the resignation of Rodolfo Rossi, who lasted five weeks. Analysts said Rossi was forced out by private banks troubled by the government's decision Jan. 1 to convert several billion dollars of short-term certificates of deposits to 10-year bonds in a bid to stabilize the economy. That move curtailed currency speculation that was devaluing the austral daily and reduced sky-high 600-percent-a-month interest rates by abruptly restricting the money supply. However, private banks said their reserves held by the Central Bank were not enough to cover the new bonds, and wrangled with Economy Ministry officials to expand use of the bonds, something Rossi opposed. Rossi's resignation, rumored for days, occurred Friday when he met with Economy Minister Antonio Gonzalez, a Central Bank official said. Gonzalez officially accepted it Monday and named Folcini successor. Rossi also reportedly lost favor with his own Union of the Democratic Center political party when the Central Bank this month printed 1 trillion australs _ $500 million _ an amount that almost doubled the money supply. That monetary expansion, which Rossi had pledged to quell, almost certainly will fuel inflation that was 40 percent in December and is projected at at least that this month. Folcini, 53, is an economist and former university professor. He was director of the Central Bank from 1976-81 during the military dictatorship, and previously served in high-level posts in the economy and treasury ministries. ``He's a banker's kind of guy,'' an economic consultant said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``His strength is he knows the Central Bank and Treasury inside out.'' Since Carlos Menem of the Peronist party took office last July, he has sworn in three economy ministers during a time of hyperinflation, record interest rates and the threat of social unrest. Argentina's foreign debt too remains onerous _ at $62 billion the third highest in Latin America after Brazil and Mexico. Menem, 59, has pledged to address Argentina's chronic economic stagnation by curtailing the budget deficit that is seen as a prime cause of inflation, selling state-owned money-losing companies and attracting foreign investment. Felipe de la Balze, a banking consultant, said Rossi was a victim _ like his predecessors Javier Gonzalez Fraga and Egidio Iannella _ of the general crisis rather than a specific cause. ``It's like the Titanic: when it's about to go down, is it relevant the hundred things that happened just before it did?'' de la Balze said. ``I think Rossi was swallowed by the crisis,'' he added. ``A specific cause is not relevant. The financial and economic crisis is so big it swallows people every 30 to 60 days.''

DOC.HEAD: Population Surpasses 29.1 million, State Reports
DOC.TEXT: Some 29.1 million people now live in California, about 11.7 percent of the population of the United States, as the state's growth expands at its greatest rate in more than 25 years, the state reported Monday. As of July 1, 1989, the most recent date for which figures are available, California had 29,063,000 inhabitants, 2.6 percent more than the year before and the greatest rate of increase since 1963-64, the state Finance Department said. The current population is 11.1 million more than New York, the nation's second-most populous state. As of July 1, California's population had swelled by 23 percent since the beginning of the decade, climbing from 23,668,049. The start-of-the-decade figure is the actual count of the 1980 census. All of the later figures are estimates. The next official census will be this coming April 1. The department also said that net migration for 1988-89 was the highest since 1942-43, when the state lured hundreds of thousands of people to military bases or to toil in World War II industries. Amid the general expansion, one county _ San Francisco _ lost population to 727,400. The fastest growing county in California was Riverside, which grew by 7.8 percent to 1.06 million. Los Angeles County remained the most populous of the state's 58 counties, at 8.7 million, follwed by San Diego County with 2.45 million and Orange County with 2.3 million. During the past decade, California's share of the country's total population has risen from 10.4 percent in 1980 to the current 11.7 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Freed; Shamir Threatens to Resign on Peace Issue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 4 grafs SUB for grafs 18-21, Industry Minister ... UPDATING with economics minister pooh-poohs resignation threat. Picks up 22nd, Etti Eshed ...
DOC.TEXT: Faisal Husseini, a leading Palestinian activist and potential peace negotiator with Israel, was freed from jail Monday. The United States had called his detention an obstacle to Middle East diplomacy. In a related matter, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir threatened to resign if he loses a vote of confidence in his right-wing Likud bloc. Likud leaders will meet next month on motions by hard-liners that Shamir's peace plan be dropped. Attorney General Yosef Harish ordered an investigation of allegations that Science Minister Ezer Weizman met illegally with high officials of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Shamir made similar accusations three weeks ago and forced Weizman out of the powerful Inner Cabinet. Weizman represents the center-left Labor Party, which is in a tenuous ``national unity'' coalition with Likud. He cannot be tried unless Parliament lifts his legislative immunity. Husseini was freed after three days of questioning about suspicions that he belonged to a ``hostile organization'' and gave other Palestinians $450 to buy military uniforms. Husseini, 49, lives in Arab east Jerusalem, which Israeli has annexed. No charges were filed, but police said the investigation would continue. Several dozen Israeli militants scuffled with Palestinian supporters of Husseini as he left the jail. They shouted ``Death to Husseini!'' and ``Death to the terrorists!'' Riot police with clubs pushed reporters away and dragged off several Jewish militants. At a news conference in east Jerusalem later, Husseini said he was arrested because Israel did not want him in a Palestinian delegation expected to hold preliminary peace talks with Israeli officials in Cairo. Shamir has said he does not want Palestinians from east Jerusalem included because that would undermine Israel's claim to the city. ``Mr. Shamir ... thinks maybe to put Faisal Husseini in jail so he cannot be part of the delegation,'' Husseini said. ``The Israelis know I will continue to work for peace. ... I hope we are near the stage'' of opening peace talks. It was Husseini's first public confirmation that he wants to join the Palestinian delegation. The Cairo meeting is supposed to deal with Shamir's plan for elections among the 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip for representatives to negotiate limited Palestinian autonomy. A central question in peace efforts is whether Jerusalem should be on the agenda. Shamir refuses to negotiate its status. Husseini said Palestinians were willing to accept Jerusalem ``as one city, with two capitals, west Jerusalem for Israelis and east Jerusalem for the Palestinians.'' He made the remark in Hebrew. At a meeting of the Likud Central Committee scheduled for Feb. 7, hard-liners plan to urge Shamir to drop the election idea. On army radio, Shamir said: ``It is very clear that, if the Central Committee doesn't support me, I cannot stand at the head of Likud and not at the head of the country.'' Economics Minister Yitzhak Modai, a prominent Likud hard-liner, dimissed Shamir's resignation threat, saying on radio: ``Nobody doubts his position ... as the head of the movement and as our prime minister. But privileges also entail responsibilities, and I don't think the Central Committee would be impressed by this dramatic announcement. We are talking about the essence, and he is talking about personal status.'' Etti Eshed, spokeswoman for the Justice Ministry, confirmed an investigation of Weizman had begun but would not give details. Israeli media have said Weizman was suspected of meeting with PLO official Nabi Ramlawi in Geneva in mid-December and of having telephone conversations with PLO figures in Tunis. Israel forbids contacts with the PLO, which it regards as a terrorist organization, and violators of the law can be imprisoned for up to three years. In the occupied West Bank, the body of a 35-year-old Palestinian was found in Talouza village. He apparently was slain on suspicion of collaborating with Israeli authorities, Arab reports said. Farhan Salah's death raised to 172 the number of people killed by other Palestinians during the 25-month-old uprising, most on suspicion of collaborating. Israeli soldiers or civilians have killed 648 Palestinians and 43 Israelis have died. Soldiers in the Gaza Strip shot and wounded seven youths aged 12 to 17 on Monday, Arab hospital officials reported. Reports in the West Bank said a 3-year-old boy from Turah was hit in the head by a plastic bullet and was in serious condition in Ramallah Hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Alaska Town Divided Over Plans to Test Submarines in Fishing Area
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `It's going...' to CORRECT that Jack Lee not a member of the Ketchikan Gateway Borough Assembly; SUBS 7th graf, `The activists...' to conform. Picks up 8th graf, `Concerns over...'
DOC.TEXT: The Navy's search for a quieter nuclear submarine is causing a ruckus in this port town. Residents are divided over Pentagon plans to measure the noise of Seawolf-class attack submarines in the rich fishing grounds that support the town's economy. On one side are those who support the project as a contribution to national defense. On the other are those who say it would threaten the region's lucrative sport fishing industry and make Ketchikan a potential target for nuclear attack. The opponents also complain that the Navy has no plan to deal with a nuclear accident in the isolated area. ``It's going to seriously hurt our economy as far as tourism, sport and commercial fishing industry goes,'' said resident Jack Lee, one of the project's most outspoken critics. Lee added that the community ``also has some very valid concerns about safety, about our inability to evacuate in light of the Navy's pathetic safety record.'' Supporters say those are the unfounded fears of a small but vocal minority in a town that has long welcomed visiting Navy vessels with its fishing fleet and tourist-filled cruise ships. ``The activists are the kind you normally see on these anti-nuke things _ these bearded, long-haired artists,'' said Ralph Bartholomew, a member of the Ketchikan Gateway Borough Assembly. ``They're the kind that aren't producing much in the community. They're living off it.'' Concerns over the project have been raised far beyond the mountainous, spruce-carpeted islands of southeastern Alaska. A lawsuit to halt the project is pending in federal court in Washington, D.C., and objections have been heard in the Canadian Parliament. Although the state has not officially approved the project, the Navy began clearing a site for a $12.7 million facility on tiny Back Island last fall. Beginning next year, the Navy plans to use a stretch of Behm Canal near Back Island for tests aimed at making U.S. submarines the quietest in the world. The site, about 25 miles north of Ketchikan and 688 miles north of Seattle, is within one of the most popular sport fishing grounds in Alaska. King salmon up to 40 pounds and halibut over 100 pounds are frequently caught in the sheltered waters of Behm Canal. Charter and resort operators fear the movement of submarines will scare away the fish and the fishermen. Gene Romano, a Navy spokesman in Seattle, said the sub tests would be conducted periodically. In one, submarines would move between underwater microphones; in another, a barge-mounted crane would suspend a submarine under water with its engines off while on-board equipment is turned on and off to test its contribution to the vessel's noise level. ``The acoustical testing of submarines is a critical factor in maintaining superiority in the submarine force,'' Romano said. The Navy argues that the task can best be done in the quiet, island-protected waters of Behm Canal. A sound-testing range in Puget Sound near Tacoma, Wash., has become too noisy to be effective, officials say. Development of the Alaska site coincides with construction of the first Seawolf submarine by General Dynamics Corp. in Groton, Conn. Its estimated cost is $1.7 billion. Romano would not say if Back Island was designed specifically with the Seawolf in mind. ``The site will be designed to test all types of Navy submarines,'' he said. A lawsuit opposing the testing was filed by the Foundation on Economic Trends, a Washington, D.C.-based technology and military watchdog group. Ketchikan groups representing environmentalists, sport fishermen, natives and a wilderness resort joined the lawsuit. U.S. District Judge Joyce Hens Green declined to issue a preliminary injunction two months ago, but said it appeared the Navy had violated the National Environmental Policy Act in planning the project. Her ruling on a request for a permanent injunction is expected soon. Romano said the Navy has modified its plans to meet community concerns. In response to fishing interests, the Navy has changed its proposed testing times and created a corridor in which fishing boats can move at slow speed and not have to wait for the tests. ``Obviously in today's age it's almost impossible to have a major construction project that's not going to upset someone,'' he said. ``But we feel the majority of the people are in support of the project.''

DOC.HEAD: Bill Presented Calling for Extension on Removal Deadline
DOC.TEXT: The government presented a bill to Parliament Monday calling for a six-month extension on the May deadline for the United States to dismantle its military installations in Greece. Under terms of a defense accord that expired in December 1988, the United States has until May 21 to remove personnel and property from four major bases and several smaller installations unless a new agreement is reached. The bill would extend to Nov. 21 the deadline for dismantling the bases, which were established in the mid-1950s. The bill, signed by Foreign Minister Antonis Samaras and Defense Minister Tzannis Tzannetakis, is to be debated by a parliamentary committee on Tuesday. It will then be presented to a full parliamentary session for debate and a vote. The conservative and socialist parties that support Premier Xenophon Zolotas' three-party administration decided last month to grant the six-month extension requested by the United States so that negotiations on a new defense pact could continue. The two parties hold 276 seats in the 300-member Parliament. The Communist-led Coalition of the Left and Progress is opposed to the bases remaining in Greece but has said it will not withdraw from the government in the event of a law postponing their removal. General elections in November were inconclusive, and the Zolotas administration was appointed to deal with pressing economic and foreign policy issues. New elections are slated for April, leaving the next government to work toward an agreement with the United States. The previous five-year Defense and Economic Cooperation Accord negotiated by the former Socialist government and Washington expired in December 1988. It gave the United States 17 months to dismantle the bases if no new accord was reached. After 17 rounds of fruitless negotiations, Athens and Washington suspended talks before national elections last June. A short-lived coalition formed by the conservative and Communist parties after those elections put the issue on hold. The Socialist government headed by former Premier Andreas Papandreou had demanded that any new defense accord include guarantees of help in case of aggression by NATO ally Turkey, which the United States has been wary of providing. Greece and Turkey almost went to war in March 1987 over disputed territorial waters in the Aegean Sea.

DOC.HEAD: General Motors Plans Massive Fiero Recall
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. will recall 244,000 four-cylinder Pontiac Fieros _ every one ever made _ because of a nagging engine-fire problem that contributed to the company's decision to scuttle the two-seater. The Fiero was an immediate sales success in September 1983, but its demise at the end of the 1988 model year came nearly as quickly, partly after consumer advocate Ralph Nader alleged engine problems led to fires. General Motors hasn't determined when the recall will take effect or what kind of repair work will be performed, company spokesman Tom Pyden said Monday. ``We've notified NHTSA (the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration) of our intent to conduct a recall,'' Pyden said. He said GM was working on the procedure for a recall ``and until that point it is premature to come out and notify owners and dealers.'' Tim Hurd, a spokesman for the national highway safety agency, said Monday the agency received a letter dated Dec. 28, 1989, from GM saying the company would recall the cars. Hurd would not say if it was unusual that a month pass between the time the agency was notified and the time a recall is issued. It is the second time the four-cylinder Fiero has been recalled because of possible engine fires. Pontiac made about 100,000 six-cylinder Fieros, which will not be subject to the recall. ``It is my understanding that the previous fix has not solved the problem of fires in Fieros,'' Hurd said from his Washington office. ``I'm sure that GM is working as hard as it can in good faith to get this problem solved.'' In 1987, GM recalled 125,000 four-cylinder versions produced in the 1984 model year after engine fires occurred in one of every 400 cars. The company said engine connecting rods, which link pistons to the crankshaft, could blast through the side of the engine, causing an oil leak which could cause a fire. During that recall, GM made some alterations, including boosting oil capacity to four quarts from three and urging motorists to check the engine oil every time they got gasoline. Word of the recall was published Friday in the national highway safety agency's monthly defect report. GM was caught unaware that the notice would be published, said spokesman Reggie Harris. ``This is unusual. Normally, we would make our own announcement when we have a program in place,'' Harris said. GM began making the Fiero at a plant in Pontiac in January 1983 for the 1984 model year. The first car was rolled off the assembly line in July 1983, with a base price of $7,999. On March 1, 1988, Pontiac announced that Fiero production would end with the 1988 model year, when 24,621 Fieros were sold.

DOC.HEAD: Photographer Who Documented Pre-Holocaust Jewish Life Dies
DOC.TEXT: Roman Vishniac, a photographer who spent much of the 1930s photographing pre-Holocaust Jewish life in Eastern Europe, died on Monday at his home here. He was 92. ``He used to say he took (Adolph) Hitler (threats) seriously and therefore he took the pictures,'' said a relative, Jesse Cherry. ``Everything he photographed was subsequently destroyed.'' Born in Pavlovsk, Russia, on Aug. 18, 1897, Vishniac came to the United States in 1940. He was a medical science photographer in Berlin from 1920 to 1939 and had documented Jewish life in Germany with photographs from 1935 to 1939. His works are included in the permanent collections of the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Smithsonian Institute and the Library of Congress in Washington and the Jewish Museum in New York. His works are published in several books, including ``A Vanished World,'' which he wrote in 1983. Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Developments in Eastern Europe at a Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief look at Monday's latest developments in Eastern Europe:
DOC.HEAD: SOVIET UNION
DOC.TEXT: As many as 2 million Azerbaijani mourners marched through Baku Monday lamenting those killed when Soviet troops put down a nationalist revolt. The republic's legislature threatened secession if Moscow did not pull out its soldiers. Local legislators declared Moscow's state of emergency void, and militants vowed to keep up crippling strikes in Baku until troops leave. Communist leaders from Soviet Armenia and Azerbaijan agreed to withdraw armed groups from border areas. Activists doubted the truce would be kept. Tass reported 12 more people killed, raising the toll since Jan. 13 to 167.
DOC.HEAD: YUGOSLAVIA
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party voted Monday to give up its 45-year-old guarantee of power, and liberals said they would set their own ideological course, which could lead to a split in the ranks.
DOC.HEAD: EAST GERMANY
DOC.TEXT: Communist Premier Hans Modrow said Monday he will open the Cabinet to the pro-democracy opposition, and opposition groups immediately accepted the offer. East German border guards began tearing down a 330-yard section of the Berlin Wall, to be replaced by a metal fence, a West Berlin spokesman said.
DOC.HEAD: ROMANIA
DOC.TEXT: The provisional government that replaced the toppled dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu may field candidates in the April elections, a government spokesman said Monday. That would reverse a government stand it was only a caretaker coalition formed to escort Romania to democracy.
DOC.HEAD: POLAND
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity's Lech Walesa met Monday with parliamentarian Tadeusz Fiszbach, a potential leader of the reformed communist party. Communists asked Poland's Solidarity-led government for protection from ``revenge'' before holding their last congress. They said a bill ``to confiscate communist party property ... impedes shaping of a rational arrangement of political forces in the country.''
DOC.HEAD: BULGARIA
DOC.TEXT: Opposition leaders meeting on Monday with ruling communist officials demanded quicker reforms to eliminate Communist Party influence in the government and workplace, and called for an investigation of the secret police. The newspaper Pogled said ousted Stalinist leader Todor Zhivkov, 78, faces a maximum of 30 years in jail if convicted of misappropriation of state property.

DOC.HEAD: Anonymous Donor Offers Rewards
DOC.TEXT: An anonymous donor on Monday offered two $25,000 rewards for information leading to the arrest and indictment of those responsible for a series of attacks on children in two Dallas neighborhoods, police said. Deputy Police Chief Lowell Cannaday said at a news conference that the reward was posted anonymously Monday morning. In Oak Cliff last week, two children were abducted as they walked to school and driven elsewhere, where they were raped. In each case, the assailant drove them back and let them off in the vicinity where they had been picked up. In far north Dallas, someone broke into homes late at night and abducted four young girls. In three of the cases, the victims were sexually assaulted. Police believe the north Dallas and Oak Cliff attacks are unrelated. Cannaday said the Oak Cliff assailant apparently has been driving a white pickup. He said the girls have given investigators a partial license plate of ``776.'' Cannaday said the victims in the north Dallas attacks were all white, ages 7 to 10, and the victims in the Oak Cliff attacks in far south Dallas were all black, ages 10 to 15. The most recent attack occurred Jan. 19. Police said the north Dallas attacker has broken into homes since September through fences and security systems to take the girls from their bedrooms. He usually assaults them outside the home and leaves. The most recent incident was Jan. 10, when the girl screamed and escaped when the assailant dropped her.

DOC.HEAD: Fruit Exports to U.S. Resume after Mediterranean Fly Scare
DOC.TEXT: Fruit exports to the United States from the central Aconcagua Valley resumed Monday, five days after the discovery of Mediterranean fruit flies in the area prompted a regional quarantine. Authorities said the problem is now considered under control, and no new findings of flies were reported after fruit was fumigated and trees were sprayed with pesticide in the valley 50 miles northeast of the capital Santiago. Monday's shipment from the Aconcagua Valley was the first since authorities reported Wednesday that at least 12 Mediterranean fruit flies _ the first since 1978 _ were found in a residential neighborhood of Los Andes. Ronald Bown, president of the Fruit Exporters Association, said 47,000 crates of grapes and other fruit from the valley were loaded Monday in the neighboring port of Valparaiso for shipment to the United States. The Aconcagua area fruit was fumigated and stored in cold chambers in the boat, separated from 300,000 crates of fruit from other regions in the country. The low-temperature storage for periods of three to four days is a common procedure to fight the fly and its larvae, which are harmless to humans. Experts from the United States Department of Agriculture supervised the shipment, Bown said. Jorge Prado, president of the National Agriculture Society, an organization of Chile's largest private farmers, said the main problem in the Aconcagua Valley now is the lack of enough fumigation capacity and cold storage facilities. Grapes, peaches, nectarines and kiwis are grown in the Aconcagua area. About 16 million crates are expected to be harvested this year in the valley, virtually all for export to the United States, Japan and western Europe. Last year, Chile's fruit exporters suffered a major blow when two grapes laced with cyanide were found in a Chilean shipment in Philadelphia. The finding prompted the U.S Food and Drug Administration to temporarily ban the sale of Chilean fruit in the United States. Resulting losses were estimated at $300 million. Fruit exports have boomed in recent years, earning about $900 million annually for Chile, which as Latin America's fourth largest foreign debt.

DOC.HEAD: White Gang Member: Black Teen Attacked Without Provocation
DOC.TEXT: A member of a white gang charged in the fatal shooting of a black teen-ager said in a videotaped statement to police that the victim and his friends were attacked without provocation. ``They were young and they were small and did not say one word to us,'' Charles Stressler said in the tape made the day after the shooting last August in the Brooklyn neighborhood fo Bensonhurst. The videotape was presented Monday during a pretrial hearing before Judge Thaddeus Owens of Brooklyn state Supreme Court. The hearing was continued until Tuesday with no decision on whether the tape will be used as evidence. Owens scheduled a trial in the case for March 5 and ordered one of the seven defendants, Keith Mondello, 20, to be tried separately. Prosecutors want the videotape and other police statements of the defendants submitted as evidence, but defense attorneys contend investigators failed to notify the youths they had the right to remain silent. Yusuf Hawkins, 16, was shot to death Aug. 23, 1989, when he and three friends were surrounded by a gang of about 30 white youths in mostly white Bensonhurst. The black teen-agers had gone to the neighborhood to look at a used car. On the night of the shooting, white youths in the neighborhood said they believed a gang of blacks were coming to their turf looking for a fight. Stressler said 20 or 30 youths, many armed with baseball bats and other weapons, gathered on the street. Stressler, 21, said in the videotape made several hours before he was arrested that the white gang saw Hawkins and his friends walking down the street. ``Someone turned the corner and said: Are these the kids? Are these the kids?'' Stressler said. Hawkins and his companions ``didn't say anything. They didn't get in our way,'' he said. ``You just knew they weren't looking for trouble. ... They were minding their own business.'' Stressler, Mondello and four other young whites were charged with second-degree murder. A seventh defendant, Steven Curreri, 19, was charged with first-degree assault. All of the defendants except the alleged triggerman have been released on bail.

DOC.HEAD: Rock's Frank Zappa Meets Czech President
LaserPhoto PRG4
DOC.TEXT: Rock musician Frank Zappa on Monday met a fellow maverick, new Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel. Zappa, who has a cult-following in Czechoslovakia, arrived in Prague Sunday, and was welcomed by hundreds of fans at Ruzyne airport. ``Never in my 25 years in rock'n'roll have experienced anything like this, and I don't have the slightest idea of why this is happening,'' Zappa told journalists on arrival. Asked by Czechoslovak television what he thought of Communism after the dramatic democratic changes that have occurred in much of Eastern Europe, Zappa replied with acid brevity _ ``The same.'' Zappa met Monday with Havel, a banned playwright of international renown who became president last month, outlining his ideas of cultural and economic cooperation between the two countries, the official news agency CTK said. ``Havel told Zappa he would support holding a giant rock concert of Western and Czechoslovak musicians this summer in Prague,'' sources present at the meeting said. Zappa, known for his cynical comments about American political life on records such as ``Freak Out'' and ``Joe's Garage,'' visited Czechoslovakia at the invitation of Michael Kocab, a Czechoslovak rock musician and member of parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker's Grounding Was Second Incident in Alaska Waterway
DOC.TEXT: A tanker that ran aground and spilled 57,600 gallons of gasoline in Alaska's Inside Passage over the weekend struck a submerged boulder and leaked fuel in the same channel in 1988, officials said Monday. The tanker Frank H. Brown resumed its trip north to Skagway with a Coast Guard escort and a relief captain Monday, less than two days after it struck a charted reef in Wrangell Narrows, 15 miles south of Petersburg. The tanker hit a boulder in the channel on Jan. 26, 1988, and the Coast Guard fined the ship's Canadian owner $500 for leaking 4,094 gallons of gasoline, said Petty Officer Bud Stevenson at the Coast Guard's Marine Safety Office in Juneau. The slow leak was not discovered until the tanker docked at Skagway and the tanks were unloaded, said Marvin Taylor, president of White Pass Transportation Inc. in Whitehorse, Yukon. The boulder left a 2-3 inch crack in the tanker's hull, he said. The boulder since has been removed by the Army Corps of Engineers, Coast Guard spokesman Greg Robinson said. Saturday's spill remained under investigation by the Coast Guard and White Pass. Blood and urine samples taken from the crew were being tested for alcohol and drugs Monday in Petersburg, Robinson said. Such tests are conducted routinely after ship accidents. The 400-foot ship ran into Burnt Island Reef on Saturday night. The reef is marked by a lighted buoy, Coast Guard spokesman Ed Moreth said. The ship's captain, John Kininmont of Vancouver, British Columbia, told the Coast Guard that the grounding resulted from ``a judgment error,'' Coast Guard spokesman Ed Moreth said. Taylor said he no indication of what went wrong and had not talked to Kininmont. ``Mr. Kininmont has been employed with us about 25 years and he's got an unblemished record. He's a very fine employee,'' Taylor said. The channel where the grounding occurred is one of the more difficult in the Inside Passage, he said. The Coast Guard said it decided not to clean up the gasoline because it dissipated and evaporated quickly. State officials said the spill caused minimal damage to the marine environment. No dead fish or birds were found. ``It appeared the strong tidal action and the fact that the tide was running out into more open waters did the most to protect the resources,'' said William Bergmann, area management biologist in Petersburg for the state Department of Fish and Game. After the ship unloads its 1.8 million gallon cargo of diesel fuel, gasoline and heating oil in Skagway, it will return to its home port of Vancouver for repair of a 2-foot hole in its hull, Taylor said.

DOC.HEAD: Network Says Alleged Spy Won't Be Prosecuted
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department has decided not to try to prosecute Felix Bloch, the American diplomat suspected of spying for the Soviet Union, ABC News said Monday night. The department declined to confirm the report. Bloch was the subject of a massive and highly visible FBI surveillance last year after it was learned that he had been videotaped passing a suitcase to a Soviet agent in Paris. Bloch had been the No. 2 official of the U.S. Embassy in Vienna for much of the Reagan administration before taking up an assignment in Washington. Though he was placed on administrative leave in June, he continued to draw his $80,000 annual salary. The visible agents were withdrawn in December and there were reports at the time that the Department had all but given up hope of prosecuting Bloch on an espionage charge. What has not been reported is what if any secrets Bloch is supposed to have given to the Soviet union _ the necessary ingredient for an espionage prosecution. Bloch is said to have been wiretapped telling his wife that he accepted payments from the Soviets. But such a wiretap might not be admissible in an American court, analysts have noted. David Runkel, spokesman for the Justice Department, said Monday night he understood that the investigation of Bloch was still continuing. He also said, ``It is my understanding'' that no decision had been made one way or another on whether to prosecute Bloch. Bloch was quoted as telling the network he does not know what the government is doing with his case. ``The situation hasn't changed,'' he said. His lawyer, John Bray, declined to comment. Though the State Department has not acted against Bloch, he will have to leave in April if he has not won promotion by then. As a 30-year veteran, he would be entitled to a pension.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Military Officers, Top Civilian Supporter Taken to Prison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with attorney comments, information about other prisoner, Endara-Arias talks. No Pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen military officers under ousted dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega have been charged with crimes and a top civilian supporter is under arrest for investigation of homicide, officials said Monday. Attorneys for the detained men tried to file writs to obtain their release.
