DOC.TEXT: Boots, boots, boots, marching up and down again. But don't take them for granted. Here's a man who makes his living making cowboy boots, and if you have a thousand bucks, he'll even make one out of ostrich for you.

His stubby, stained fingers caress the dark leather as Jim Pope slowly forms two pieces together, gluing here and there. Under his careful hands a cowboy boot begins to take shape. ``You can't get rich doing this,'' he says. ``I do it because I enjoy doing it, and the satisfaction of seeing some old boy who says he can't get boots to fit slip on a pair I've made and walk out of here with a smile on his face.'' But not just anyone can afford a visit to Pope's shop. Prices start at about $400, half up front. But, as Pope says, ``for the exotic leathers, you better get out your big checkbook.'' The customer has a choice of leathers, from calf at the low end to shark and snake at around $550, full-quill ostrich at about $1,000 and alligator at $1,500 to $1,600. ``I made one pair out of armadillo and another out of bullfrog,'' he says. ``I have enough elephant to make one more pair of boots, and then that's gone.'' Pope says he demands a 50 percent deposit ``because I have to buy the leather. A full-quill ostrich hide costs about $700 and I can't afford to just keep it around.'' The amount of stitching on the uppers, and whether there's any inlay, also can run up the cost. He just delivered a pair of boots to a Texas banker that has the outline of that state inset in the uppers. ``I give the customer four rows of stitching,'' Pope says. ``If they want more, it's $25 a row.'' Pope says that besides looking pretty, the stitching helps keep the uppers standing straight. ``It takes about 40 hours to make a pair of boots,'' he says. ``It depends on how fancy they are, some more, some less, but it averages out to about 40 hours.'' ``I've had them ask me to include a little hidden place for money,'' Pope says. ``Others want a place to carry a gun.'' Rows of leather are stacked on an overhead shelf and virtually every inch of the portable building that serves as office and workshop is filled with some sort of shoe-making machine. A window-style air conditioner at the rear fights a standstill battle with the humid, 90 degrees-plus heat. Pope says he is one of only two custom bootmakers still in business in Oklahoma City. ``The young people coming along, they don't want to work this hard for no more money than they get,'' he says. Pope says he did some work for movie actors who were in the area recently making the film ``Homegrown.'' ``I redid some boots for Scott Glenn, the star,'' Pope says. ``He had those pointy-toed boots and I rounded them off.'' Pope got into the boot-making business in a roundabout way. He worked with leather, making belts and wallets and repairing saddles, when he was a ranch hand. ``But if anybody had told me then I'd be making boots today, I would have said they're crazy,'' he says. Pope takes about a half-dozen measurements of a customer's foot and draws an outline on a piece of paper. He uses wooden lasts ``as close to the man's size as possible'' and either builds up with leather or shaves the wood off until he has as near a perfect match for the foot as is possible. The foot part of the boot is formed over that. ``I don't give a money-back guarantee, but I do guarantee that you'll have a boot to fit,'' he says. There was a time when the boot-making business was almost as good as most people think owning an oil well is. That was back in the early 1980s when everyone believed there was no top to the spiraling cost of oil. ``You commonly ran 75 to 100 orders behind, several month's worth,'' the 47-year-old Pope says. But with the oil bust, the flamboyant ``oilies'' and the bankers who backed them faded away, along with the wild parties where beer toasts were drunk from the fancy boots. Now, he says, he makes five or six pairs a month, sometimes seven. ``The bust has hurt all the custom-made leather work,'' says Pope, who learned the trade at the Oklahoma State Technical Institute. ``Leggings, saddles, all that sort of thing, they're all hurting. ``But the repair business has stayed pretty good.''

From AP Newsfeatures

DOC.TEXT: Choosing the right thermal underwear today requires some careful study. Long johns are no longer just long johns. A variety of synthetic fabrics has largely replaced the cotton and wool garments, and what you should buy depends on what you plan to do.

Long johns just ain't what they used to be. And that's good news for the consumer. Today there is a wide variety of high-tech replacements for the old scratchy, bulky, shrunken underwear. Choices range from silk to polypropylene, from trademarked synthetic fabrics like Lifa, Thermax and Capilene to cotton, wool and synthetic blends. ``Underwear is a specialized product today, vs. what it used to be,'' says Jim Jennings, product manager for Lands' End, a direct mail retailer based in Dodgeville, Wis. ``You really have to determine the activity before you buy.'' Kevin Sweeney of Patagonia, a sportwear manufacturer in Ventura, Calif., agrees. ``People used to say, underwear is underwear. But then we said, why don't we make it perform? And then we said, why don't we make it fun?'' Sweeney defines fun as thermals in such untraditional colors as neon orange with navy trim, or emerald with purple trim. Thermal underwear used to be made of 100 percent cotton, with a small amount made of 100 percent wool, says Tom Armstrong, product research and testing manager for L.L. Bean in Freeport, Maine. But an explosion of synthetic fabrics changed that situation for the better about 10 years ago, he says. ``There has been a trend toward more man-made fibers,'' says Bob Blanchard, president of National Knitwear Manufacturers Association in Morristown, N.J., which tracks national wholesale thermal sales. ``It is now well over half the market, where 10 years ago it would have been at least 80 percent all cotton.'' ``Cotton alone is useless in a really cold environment,'' says Armstrong, who oversees a textile lab as well as 400 field testers around the world. ``Its high absorbency is its downfall. In essence, it freezes if you stop in winter. ``Wool is great. The old expeditions to the Arctic or the Himilayas relied on wool. But some people find them itchy, and they don't dry out very well.'' What thermal underwear a person chooses today depends on what they do and how cold it's going to get around them. For cross-country skiers, lumberjacks and backpackers _ or anyone who will work up a sweat in the cold _ Armstrong recommends polypropylene, because of its ability to wick moisture away from the body, keeping wearers warm and dry. But ice fishers, stadium fans, vendors and some hunters _ or anyone who spends several hours still in the cold _ should get heavier, double-ply cotton-wool-synthetic blended thermals, Armstrong says. Even sports names like Nike and Patagonia have entered the previously unglamorous field. People who want to wear the same thermals as space shuttle astronauts can choose Capilene underwear by Patagonia, in three different weights. Nike also offers three different weights of thermals in its All Conditions Gear line. But what weight to choose? ``If you're standing still in the cold _ like a ski race judge _ buy expedition-weight,'' Sweeney says. ``If you're cross-country skiing, buy mid-weight. ``If you're wearing it under your clothes, buy lightweight.'' Those who do a variety of outdoor activities are a retailer's dream. ``If you are both passive and active, you can't use just one set of underwear,`` Jennings says. In the natural fibers, silk is now king, chosen for its soft, light texture. ``Silk is the top-of-the-line,'' Jennings says. ``People use it to sleep in, for layering, anywhere you don't want to be encumbered.'' If the bulk and itch of earlier thermals are gone, what about the tight fit? It seems that shrinkage problems may be a thing of the past as well. ``Normal shrinkage is 5 percent to 7 percent,'' Armstrong says. ``But we build in that size buffer. If you put it on right from the box it would be a little big. Our people fit the garment so it fits correctly after washing.''

From AP Newsfeatures

DOC.TEXT: During the filming of NBC's ``Murder in Mississippi'' in Georgia, Tom Hulce slipped away to get a feel of the real-life locations where three civil rights workers were abducted and killed in 1964. Hulce plays Mickey Schwerner in the two-hour movie, which NBC will televise on Monday. Blair Underwood is James Chaney and Josh Charles is Andrew Goodman. Jennifer Grey also stars as Schwerner's wife, Rita. Schwerner was a social worker who went from New York to join Chaney, Goodman and others in a voter registration drive in Mississippi. Their deaths near Philadelphia, Miss., helped change the course of the civil rights movement. The story tells of the events leading up to the murders during the so-called ``Freedom Summer.'' The FBI investigation of the deaths and its aftermath was told in the feature movie ``Mississippi Burning.'' ``Blair, Jennifer and I went to Meridian, where they were based in Mississippi,'' Hulce says. ``They were having a memorial for the 25th anniversary and it was a wonderful opportunity to see and hear a lot of people in the movement. I wanted to travel the same roads they had traveled the day they died. You just have to look around and it's much easier to climb into the story. ``We shot a good portion of the story in territory that still has an active Ku Klux Klan. We were very low-key about what we were doing, but it got a little real sometimes. We re-created a riot to integrate employment at a department store. Not all of the crowd activities were scripted. It's amazing how people know what to say.'' Hulce, an Oscar nominee for his role as Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart in ``Amadeus,'' most recently was seen in ``Parenthood.'' He has completed a role in the upcoming movie ``Black Rainbow'' and was the brain-damaged garbage collector in ``Dominick & Eugene.'' After doing ``Murder in Mississippi'' he returned to New York where he is now starring on Broadway in Aaron Sorkin's ``A Few Good Men,'' a courtroom drama about a Marine Corps murder. ``I wore a goatee for the role because people in Mississippi called Mickey the `Jew with the beard,''' Hulce says. ``I think they had a specific agenda for his future. He was the one they wanted the most because he was an outsider. Chaney was from Mississippi and Goodman didn't come to Mississippi until the day he was killed. ``Mickey's singular ability was to make everyone feel comfortable with him. He was excellent in making people feel good about themselves. The segregationists felt threatened by his presence.'' The movie begins when Schwerner arrives in Mississippi to help organize the black voter drive. As an outsider, he is immediately confronted by suspicion and bigotry. Schwerner and Chaney take time to forge a good working relationship in the movie, but in reality they were already good friends. ``Segregationists usually tend to be portrayed as morons,'' Hulce says. ``These were intelligent people who believed they are right. There were people in positions of influence who were willing to help them. Mickey had been threatened. A black church they used as a headquarters was burned. He knew the risks, but he believed strongly in what he was doing.'' Hulce grew up in Michigan and studied at the North Carolina School of the Arts. He made his Broadway debut opposite Anthony Perkins in ``Equus.'' He had begun as understudy to Peter Firth, who also played the role in the movie version. The play was written by Peter Shaffer, and when it came time to cast the movie adaptation of his play ``Amadeus,'' Hulce became a contender and was selected over some heavy competition. In ``Parenthood,'' he plays the son of Jason Robards. ``He's a guy who's in pursuit of the deal,'' he says. ``He has a gambling problem. I'm a parent, too, in the picture. I have an illegitimate child.'' He also appears with Jason Robards in ``Black Rainbow,'' as well as Rosanna Arquette. ``I play the hotshot lawyer in `A Few Good Men' who's assigned to defend a Marine accused of murder,'' he says. ``It involves a cover-up involving a Marine on the upper end of the ladder.'' Hulce also has a home in Seattle. ``I have a house with a sidewalk in front of it,'' he says, ``which is a new experience for me. I grew up in the country. I had a place in New York but now I can feel like a part of the community. I'd worked in a play in Seattle and stayed. I found myself in a Realtor's office. Before I knew it I was in a bar being shown the neighborhood.''

From AP Newsfeatures

DOC.TEXT: Leigh Lawson and Dustin Hoffman dreamed up the idea of spitting on each other during their performance of ``The Merchant of Venice.'' It wasn't Shakespeare's idea, nor the director's. Lawson plays the merchant, Antonio, and Hoffman is the moneylender, Shylock, in the Shakespearean play at Broadway's 46th Street Theater. ``Spitting isn't written in the play,'' Lawson says. Before the play opened at London's Phoenix Theater last June, Lawson and Hoffman worked on the scene in which Antonio borrows 3,000 ducats from Shylock and promises to give the Jewish moneylender a pound of flesh if he doesn't pay the money back. ``We were improvising the scene, not doing Shakespeare's words, just finding the chemistry of the scene,'' Lawson says. That's when the spitting started. The director, Sir Peter Hall, bought the idea. Lawson accepted the title role, he says, because Sir Peter is ``brilliant with Shakespeare. This is a very clear production. He makes the story very clear. All of us feel we'd like to do more Shakespeare as a result of this experience.'' Lawson considers Antonio a product of the anti-Semitism of his times in Renaissance Italy. ``But the play is relevant today,'' he says. ``I was talking to Dustin the night before last. He said, `Wasn't it incredible that people started to applaud when I spit on you just before I was going to cut your heart out!' It's amazing that feelings run so strong and heated after 400 years. It would surely give old Bill Shakespeare quite a thrill if he could come back and see it.'' Some find the play anti-Semitic, which surprises Lawson. ``It has anti-Semitic people in it,'' he says. ``But it has that brilliant `Hath not a Jew eyes' speech. To me the people that come out the most obnoxious are the Christians. Asked to give mercy, they take all Shylock's money and say he has to convert. ``Two people end up alone at the end, Shylock and Antonio. They're the ones motivated by money.'' Lawson, a native of Atherstone in Warwickshire, 20 miles from Stratford on Avon, is playing his first major Shakespearean role in some 15 years. It's also his American debut. He hopes that he and his wife, Twiggy, who starred in ``My One and Only'' here, can play Broadway together. They married in 1988 and her billing now is Twiggy Lawson. Lawson is best known to Americans in movies _ as Alec D'urberville, opposite Nastassia Kinski, in ``Tess'' and as Ronnie Blum in ``Madame Sousatzka,'' with Shirley MacLaine. Although he can learn pages of Shakespeare's dialogue in an evening, Lawson hasn't been in a Shakespeare company. After attending the Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts, he decided not to go to the Royal Shakespeare Company, where actors start with tiny parts and work up. ``I decided I couldn't bear to stand around for two years,'' he says. So he went to a repertory company in Coventry, where he'd do larger parts right away. ``I auditioned for Franco Zeffirelli's film `Brother Son Sister Moon,' the story of St. Francis of Assisi,'' he says. ``I had it written in my repertory contract that I could be released at a month's notice for this film. I managed to do two seasons before that film got started. That gave me a year in Italy where I completed my education in wine and food, and started a film career.'' Lawson also spent two years in leading roles at the National Theater. ``There's a mystical thing that happens between audience and actors on the stage,'' he says. When he's in an audience, Lawson wants to hear every word. ``To listen to actors who think they can give TV performances in the theater drives me potty,'' he says. ``The Olivier Theater at the National is a big space to fill. It's not a case of shouting. It's a case of articulating so your consonants zing to the back of the auditorium. ``Dame Edith Evans came to speak to us as students. She said one's voice should be a powder puff shot by a cannon. That image often comes to mind when I'm on stage.'' When he isn't performing or attending plays, Lawson says, ``My favorite nights are sitting around talking about theater with theater people. There is usually somebody funny, somebody intelligent, somebody drunk. It does throw up an eclectic crowd. I find it endlessly fascinating.'' Lawson has a son, Ace, 13, and Twiggy has a daughter, Carly, 11. ``We share them,'' Lawson says. ``They adore each other.'' The Lawsons met at a dinner given by an actor friend in London. ``We were both unattached,'' he says. ``Twigs looked gorgeous. I was a bit shy to ask for her phone number, thinking everybody asks for her number. She says she was a bit miffed that I didn't.'' They next saw each other when he went out for a morning paper and she was delivering Carly to school across the street from his flat. Their courtship was gentle, he says, going to the theater, talking about saving the environment and seeing friends. ``It was like the fates were bringing us together.''

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Social Democrat Back in After 43 Years in the Cold
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: For Petar Dertliev, the changes seeping through Bulgaria have meant a return to battling Communists. The last time he lost. That was more than 40 years ago when the Communists crushed his Social Democratic Party and sent him off to a labor camp and prison for 10 years. The Communists still hold an upper hand in Bulgaria but in one respect the tables have turned for Dertliev: Todor Zhivkov, Bulgaria's longtime Communist Party leader, is under house arrest on charges of incitement of ethnic hostility, misuse of state property and malfeasance in office. After Zhivkov's ouster Nov. 10, Dertliev, now 73, wasted no time calling a dozen former mates of the dark Stalinist days in confinement and reactivating his party, which the Communists, through an unexplained oversight, simply forgot to ban and now was still legal. Membership is already 30,000 nationwide _ 10,000 in this capital _ and Dertliev has a seat at round table talks where 12 opposition groups negotiate with the Communists for more democracy. But Dertliev, like many Bulgarians, is skeptical that the Communists really want to relinquish the power they acquired by ruthless repression after World War II. ``We should not fall into the illusion that they will collapse immediately, even though they are demoralized,'' the trim, retired physician said in an interview. ``The advantages of having real power are keeping them on their toes.'' Unlike their comrades elsewhere in Eastern Europe, Bulgaria's Communists appear confident they can hold on to a good share of power after free elections, which they promise for May but the still weak opposition wants held off until November. Petar Mladenov, the longtime foreign minister who took over as president and party chief from Zhivkov, has not cut a high public profile since losing his temper before an angry crowd of opposition backers outside Parliament in December. But his No. 2 man, Andrey Lukanov, is a skilled political operator and third generation Communist who speaks six foreign languages and was born and educated in Moscow. Lukanov, who heads the Communist team at the round table, has exuded confidence that his party could win a majority in the elections. Dertliev thinks the Communists would get 25 percent to 30 percent of the vote if elections were held now, while some Western diplomats believe they are just as unpopular as those elsewhere in Eastern Europe and would fail miserably at the ballot box. The Communists are trying hard, however. They have so far refused to relinquish their control over newspapers, television and radio, while promising the opposition a daily publication, although limiting its circulation to one-tenth that of their own newspapers. Lukanov has encouraged the formation of liberal, almost social democratic factions inside the Communist Party, apparently hoping these will attract people who might otherwise join Dertliev's party or another opposition group. Dertliev and other activists say they have found, on more than one occasion, that the well-informed Communists skillfully preempted opposition victories by simply making opposition demands their own platform. Recalling one case, he said, ``We decided in the morning to call for the resignations of certain ministers.'' By afternoon, he added, the Communist Party announced the ministers were fired. To some outside the party, such tactics could indicate the divided Communists are following, rather than directing, the drift of Bulgaria's politics, at least at this stage. Dertliev notes, however, that the Bulgarian Communist Party, which predates even the Soviet Communist Party, has strong traditions that go back to the last century and was a well-organized underground body during Fascist rule in World War II. Today the Communists number about 900,000, or 10 percent of the total population, but they have formally relinquished their guaranteed leading role. The words ``socialism'' and ``communism,'' however, still appear throughout the Bulgarian constitution, an intricate 1971 document that outlines strict state controls over everything from foreign trade to authors' copyrights; it even gives a minute description mandating the appearance of the national emblem. Dertliev thus sees his fight as one of the still-weak (the Social Democrats) against the still-strong (the Communists). ``The Communists have at their disposal all the machinery,'' he said. ``What we have is the good will of the people on our side.'' Mindful of the repression that wiped out the popular Social Democratic Party and one anti-Communist faction of the Bulgarian Agrarian Union in the 1940s, Dertliev and other opposition figures now seek legal guarantees that one-party rule will not return. The repression descended on Bulgaria with terrifying force after World War II, with party leader Georgi Dmitrov ruthlessly doing away with opponents before his death in 1949. Some of his victims now are being rehabilitated. But it remains taboo to link the repression directly to Dmitrov, whose embalmed body lies, as Lenin's does in Moscow, in a mausoleum where the Communists hold parades on May Day and other important days. In 1946, Dertliev was 30 years old and one of the 101 Social Democrats sitting in a 400-member Parliament. He recalled the repression. ``Massive persecution'' and rigging elections were already under way by 1945-46, he said. ``The terror then continued and increased,'' with the arrest of Social Democrat Krastyo Pastuhov and other party leaders. Pastuhov ``was sentenced for five years for just two (written) articles,'' Dertliev said. While in prison, he was strangled by a cellmate. Sveta Ivanov, sent to a labor camp for writing just one article urging Bulgaria not to sever all its ties with the West, was another who died. So did Lyudmila Slavova, who was reported to have committed suicide while awaiting trial in 1947, the year other leading Social Democrats were sentenced to terms of 15, 12 and 10 years. Dertliev got 10 years. ``My wife was 21, and my baby 4 months,'' Dertliev recalled with a smile tinged with bitterness. ``When I came back, she was already in the third class at school.'' Although the Social Democratic Party was not formally banned _ Dertliev says this was because ``the Communists thought they would stay in power forever'' _ he and others knew it was impossible to return to politics. Dertliev worked for eight years in the obscurity of a sanatorium for tubercular children in the mountains of central Bulgaria. Little by little, he made his way back to Sofia where he maintained quiet contacts with old cellmates. Now, brimming with humor and energy, he wants to build a democratic Bulgaria, but is sanguine about the chances of outside support and internal willingness to restore the nation's shattered economy and morale. Bulgaria has fewer friends abroad than other East European nations, he said, and it alienated the West through Zhivkov's campaign to assimilate its ethnic Turkish minority. ``We have no false hopes that very soon we will be able to change everything,'' Dertliev said. ``For most people, their own initiative is dead. ... They wait for somebody to command them.''

DOC.HEAD: Consumers, Funeral Industry Split on Future of `Funeral Rule'
DOC.TEXT: Jeanie Karklin says she saved $1,500 on her mother's funeral because a federal rule required the funeral director to give her an itemized price list. She calls the rule ``a godsend.'' The same rule required funeral director Timothy Simms to hand a price list to the parents of a 4-year-old boy killed in a car accident. Simms felt it was ``a tasteless thing to do'' in the emergency room. Six years after it took effect, the so-called ``funeral rule'' is under review by the Federal Trade Commission, and consumers and the funeral industry are split on whether it should be renewed or repealed. The review began in May 1988 and FTC staff recommendations are expected this spring. Consumer groups want the rul strengthened, arguing it gives people important information to help them make one of the biggest purchases of their lives at a time of stress and bereavement. ``It costs next to nothing, provides a great deal of consumer information and may have led to prices going down,'' said Lee Norrgard of the American Association of Retired Persons, which has led the fight to retain and expand the rule. The nation's largest association of funeral directors, meanwhile, says the rule unnecessarily regulates day-to-day business practices, increases costs and hinders funeral directors' ability to serve grieving customers sensitively. ``The rule has placed an undeserved and unwarranted stigma on the nation's funeral directors as unscrupulous and deceptive businessmen,'' the National Funeral Directors Association told the FTC, calling for repeal. The rule took effect in 1984 after more than a decade of debate and investigation into funeral practices, and after the NFDA sued unsuccessfully to block it. But after living with it for more than five years, some funeral directors and smaller trade groups are amenable to retaining it. ``Our membership's living with it very well,'' said Connie Ryan, president of the Wisconsin Funeral Directors Association and director of Ryan Funeral Home in Madison. ``We haven't had any difficulties.'' The rule requires funeral directors to give customers an itemized price list at the start of discussions, an itemized final statement of costs, and to give price information over the phone if asked. It also lets consumers purchase only what they want rather than packages that may include unnecessary extras, and prohibits funeral directors from misrepresenting state requirements for caskets for cremation or the embalming of corpses. Americans each year arrange more than 2 million funerals. With costs averaging $3,000 before burial fees, a funeral may be the third most expensive consumer purchase after a home and a car, according to the FTC. Mrs. Karklin, of Houston, said the price list she got as she arranged her mother's funeral in Granby, Mo., in 1986 helped her insist on reasonably priced items when the funeral director kept saying her ``dear departed loved one'' deserved more. ``Even though I knew beforehand what my rights were, and I knew my mother had always been a strong and thrifty woman who never approved of excess of expense, I felt more and more battered down by what he was saying. I said to him, `Thank God for your price list.' He didn't look very happy.'' When people are aware of their rights under the rule, they are able to be more selective in their funeral purchases, even if they decide to spend as much money as they would otherwise, said Clifford Brownstein, executive director of the Continental Association of Funeral and Memorial Societies. The association, which represents 150 memorial societies nationwide that help people get information and make plans, is calling for better enforcement of the rule and its expansion to businesses such as cemeteries and crematories. ``For people who are aware of it, it has made them more knowledgeable consumers,'' Brownstein said. ``But most people have never heard of it. If you don't know it's there, how can you take advantage of it?'' A 1988 study by the FTC's Bureau of Economics found that while most people got a price list at some point, only about a third of funeral directors gave a price list and final cost statement in the required timely manner and did not make misrepresentations. It found that average funeral spending rose 9 percent between 1981 and 1987, after adjusting for inflation, and concluded that while the rule did not necessarily cause the increase, the data ``strongly suggests that the rule did not contribute to a reduction in funeral expenditures.'' AARP's Norrgard questioned the FTC's analysis and said there is evidence prices may have gone down after adjusting for inflation. In addition, he said, studies show that consumers who get price lists early tend to spend less, even though they may not compare prices between funeral homes. Mary Ponder, of the National Consumers League, said the benefits have been limited because ``there is little to no enforcement'' by the FTC. Robert Hardin, executive director of the NFDA, said the price disclosure requirements have hindered funeral directors, done nothing to benefit consumers and contribute to higher prices by adding paperwork and training demands. The FTC's own study disproved its theory that consumers would spend less and shop around more with the rule, he said, adding that most people select a funeral home because they had a personal experience with the home or because of its reputation, not based on price. ``The whole concept of the FTC back in 1984 was to try to change the social mores of this country and to try to convince the consumer that they're shopping for a car when they're shopping for a funeral,'' Hardin said. ``It's not a consumer product. It's a very professional consumer service.'' Simms, who owns the Wilbur Christensen Funeral Home in Rockford, Ill., said compliance with the rule has kept him from handling difficult cases, such as the 1985 death of the 4-year-old boy, as sensitively as he would like. ``To immediately hand someone a price list really becomes very awkward. The funeral rule lacks the discretion of a judgment call by a professional.'' AARP is pushing to extend the rule to cemeteries and to expand regulation of the booming ``pre-need'' business, in which people buy in advance to finance funeral or cemetery goods and services. Some pre-paid contracts, often sold by telephone, direct mail and door-to-door, aren't covered by the funeral rule. Minimum standards would ensure that consumers know what contracts cover, how the death benefits increase over time, how secure the investments are and whether contracts can be canceled or transferred if people move, Norrgard said. At an FTC hearing last year, William Jones, of Lucerne, Calif., testified that pre-paid plans should be better regulated to keep unscrupulous businesses from preying on the elderly. Jones said his 87-year-old mother was despondent and in early stages of senility when a salesman visited her home in Winnemucca, Nev., and persuaded her to pay $3,105 over two years for a pre-paid funeral. The FTC has shown little inclination to get involved in additional regulation of pre-need contracts, but Norrgard expressed hope these sales might be the subject of a separate rule-making procedure later. The FTC originally faced a November 1989 deadline for a decision on its review of the funeral rule but rescinded that because of the thousands of pages of comments, reports, exhibits and recommendations that have been submitted.

DOC.HEAD: Requirements Under the Funeral Rule
With BC-PRI--Funeral Rule
DOC.TEXT: Here are major requirements of the rule enacted in 1984 by the Federal Trade Commission help consumers obtain information about funeral arrangements. _TELEPHONE DISCLOSURES: When consumers call to ask about terms, conditions or prices, the funeral home must state that price information is available over the telephone and reasonably answer questions. _GENERAL PRICE LIST: If consumers ask in person about arrangements, the home must provide a general price list that people can keep and that contains the cost of each funeral item and service offered. _EMBALMING INFORMATION: Homes must give consumers information about embalming to help them decide whether to buy the service and must disclose in writing that, except in certain cases, embalming is not required by law. _CASH ADVANCE SALES: Funeral homes must disclose in writing if they charge a service fee for buying cash advance items on the consumer's behalf, such as flowers, obituary notices, pallbearers and clergy honoraria. _CASKETS FOR CREMATION: Funeral directors who offer direct cremation without a ceremony may not state that a casket is required and must disclose in writing that consumers have a right to buy an unfinished wood box or an alternative container for direct cremation. _REQUIRED PURCHASE: Consumers do not have to buy unwanted goods or services as a condition to obtain those they do want, unless required to do so by state law. _ITEMIZED STATEMENT: Funeral directors must give consumers an itemized statement listing the costs of goods and services selected. _PRESERVATIVE CLAIMS: Funeral directors may not tell consumers a particular funeral item or service can indefinitely preserve a body in the grave. They also may not state that certain items, such as caskets or vaults, will keep out water, dirt or other gravesite substances when that is not true.

DOC.HEAD: Even Amateurs Can Grow Good Cactuses
DOC.TEXT: James Walters worked for the AP as a reporter and editor from 1947 until he retired in 1984.

Kent Newland, a cactus expert, grows them mainly to enjoy the spectacular flowers, and says he's sure that amateurs _ even city apartment-dwellers _ can do the same by following a few simple basics. ``They are glorious things to see blooming, just gorgeous. The flowers may not live for more than a day or two, but while they last there's nothing quite like it,'' Newland says. ``And if you have enough of them, they bloom so often you can have some in flower every day of the year.'' He has no quarrel with folks who grow cactuses only for their unique shapes, but says many don't realize flowers are possible within a year or so even on the small, inexpensive ones sold at botanical gardens and nurseries. Newland, who ``can't remember when I haven't been in love with'' cactuses, spent 14 years with the Boyce Thompson Southwestern Arboretum in Superior, and now is water resources specialist for Phoenix's Xeriscape programs. For home growers, he says, success with cactus begins with selecting the proper types: ``Globular kinds as opposed, say, to columnar ones like saguaros or cereus, or types like the prickly pears,'' which need a lot of light. ``Better choices are mammillarias, pincushions and similar types. They need good light but not high amounts, so they'll adapt, grow and flower in a south-facing window while the large ones at best will exist.'' Indoors, most people will be happiest with cactus that flourish in no larger than a 6- to 8-inch pot, such as ``hard-bodied'' mammillarias like the old-lady cactus (Mammillaria hahniana) or the mother of hundreds (M. cupressa). ``After plant selection, the trick to growing cactuses is good drainage ... I think more cactus are lost from underwatering than overwatering. To encourage root systems, you need to keep them fairly damp _ not soaking wet, of course. ``Plants don't look very healthy if they haven't been watered for six months, because the root systems die,'' Newland says. So how do you know when to water? ``I'd put a finger on the soil and if it feels moist, it's probably all right. Water when it feels bone dry. When a plant is starting to grow, throwing out new spines or stems, that's the time to encourage it with water and fertilizer to initiate flowers.'' During such growing periods, Newland includes an all-purpose fertilizer every other watering, applying about an eighth to a fourth of the recommended dosage, to ensure ``good, even amounts of growth for flower production.'' While he doesn't use slow-release fertilizers, they would be fine in moderation. ``Growing medium is extremely important,'' he says. ``The big thing is to stay away from pure-organic potting soils, even if the bag is labeled `cactus mix.' They're very hard to wet up and very hard to dry out. However, if you amend that potting soil with some sharp masonry sand and some perlite, the plant should grow well. ``But first make sure the water drains through the mixture. I'd fill a test pot to an inch or so of the top with the mix _ without a plant; tamp the mix as usual and fill it with water. If you don't get water coming out of the drain hole within one or two minutes, a cactus will slowly dry up and die in it. So add more sand and try the new batch until it drains right.'' A good starting point is about half organic matter, 40 percent sand and 10 percent perlite, blended well. Newland repots each new cactus, discarding the former growing medium. ``That way I know the soil mix is identical for all my cactuses and if there are some hidden insects I get rid of them.'' Before transplanting, he also loosens the root ball to encourage the root system to expand. ``Pot size also is important. You don't want to put a 2-inch cactus in a 6-inch pot. Put it in a 3-inch, or maybe a 4-inch, moving it along as it grows.'' Mealybugs have been known to ruin cactus collections almost overnight. Newland will use malathion or diazinon soil drench if necessary, but believes the best way to avoid pests is to grow healthy plants. ``Like a human being, if you're healthy you're less prone to disease.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Jan. 25, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Study May Explain Why Early Alzheimer's Patients Bump Into Things
DOC.TEXT: Patients in the early stages of Alzheimer's disease suffer damage to a specific type of eye cell, explaining why they often bump into things and have trouble reading despite 20-20 vision, researchers say. The incurable, progressive brain disorder, which causes premature dementia or senility, doesn't substantially affect optic cells, called P cells, that are responsible for visual acuity. But it causes degeneration of M cells essential for people to orient themselves in space, according to the study published in the January issue of the journal Ophthalmology. Just as charts of letters test visual acuity produced by P cells, Dr. Alfredo Sadun said his team at the University of Southern California developed a test to check the performance of M cells. Sadun said it might be used to help diagnose early stages of Alzheimer's disease, which is estimated to afflict 8 percent of the U.S. population over age 65. Optic nerves from 10 deceased Alzheimer's patients and the cadavers of 10 people without the disease were examined by Sadun, an associate professor of ophthalmology and neurological surgery. Retinal tissue from three Alzheimer's patients and two normal cadavers also were examined, and 15 Alzheimer's patients with no known eye disease were given complete exams of the eyes and related parts of the nervous system. The postmortems found optic nerve degeneration in eight of the 10 Alzheimer's patients and none of the control cadavers. The degeneration was mainly of M cells and related fibers. The loss of M cells is consistent with the symptoms Sadun found among living Alzheimer's patients: difficulty in reading and spatial orientation despite an ability to see very small objects and colors, and difficulty in detecting movements of objects and differences in shades.
DOC.HEAD: Retirees, Baby Boomers Can Work Together on Health Care
DOC.TEXT: Baby Boomers should help solve problems in health care before they reach retirement, AARP President Louise D. Crooks says. ``The Baby Boomers are seeing what is happening to their parents _ lack of adequate retirement incomes and the high cost of health care _ and don't want the same things to happen to them,'' Crooks said at the American Association of Retired Persons' National Leadership Orientation Conference this month. Retired people and Baby Boomers _ people born in roughly 1946 to 1964 _ are beginning to work together toward achieving a better quality of life, she said. ``This aging of America creates challenges and opportunities we must consider now, not 20 or 30 years from now.'' The population explosion of the Baby Boom produced a third of all living Americans, or about 76 million people, she said. The first of this generation will reach age 50 in 1996 and begin retiring from 2000 to 2010. Quoting Census Bureau statistics, Crooks said there are now 64 million people in the United States 50 or older. That group will increase to 76 million by the end of the century and to 113 million by 2025. The National Institute of Aging predicts that by 2040 life expectancy will be 86 for men and more than 91 for women, she said. ``Will we be able to provide the health care this growing number of older Americans will need?''

Bank of New England Corp. expects to report a $1.05 billion loss for 1989 and said it was ``actively pursuing'' the sale of more than $6 billion in assets. The company, New England's second-largest bank holding company after Bank of Boston Corp., issued a statement Friday that also said it expected to enter a consent order with federal regulators to reshape the company's operations.

Campeau Corp.'s Federated and Allied retail divisions sent suppliers figures showing they have more than $335 million to finance shipments of new merchandise for their stores. Figures released by the companies Friday show Federated Department Stores Inc. has a current cash balance of $220 million and Allied Stores Corp. has $117 million in cash. Federated and Allied filed Monday for U.S. Bankruptcy Court protection from their creditors.

The House Judiciary Committee will investigate the bankruptcy filings by Campeau Corp.'s U.S. retail divisions and look into the consequences of leveraged buyouts, Chairman Jack Brooks announced. The Texas Democrat said Friday the Judiciary subcommittee on economic and commercial law would hold hearings on the court-supervised reorganization of Federated Stores Inc., the renamed holding company of Campeau's U.S. operations. The hearings also will examine the potential for a wave of new bankruptcies resulting from debt-financed takeovers in recent years, Brooks said.

Three former executives were wrongly convicted of murder and other charges in the death of an employee who suffered cyanide poisoning on the job, the Illinois appellate court ruled. The 1985 case, believed to be the first in which corporate officials were convicted of murder in a job-related death, was sent back to Cook County Circuit Court. The appellate court ruling came Friday.

Tele-Communications Inc. stock rose in the wake of the announcement that the nation's lagest cable operator is considering spinning off a new company to handle its programming interests. Industry analysts said the proposal will help the company deal with possible regulatory constraints and to continue to grow. In national over-the-counter trading Friday, TCI rose $2.37{ a share to $17.37{.

A federal appeals court threw out a bid by the Urban Mass Transportation Administration to test local transit system employees for drug use, including random testing. The U.S. District Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia said Friday the agency had exceeded its congressionally mandated authority in trying to impose uniform nationwide rules on local transit authorities. The decison upheld an appeal by transport unions and reversed an earlier decision by the U.S. District Court.

Federal engineers are stepping up their probe of possible automatic torso belt failures in the Ford Escort and Mercury Lynx that consumers have blamed for five deaths and 76 injuries, the government said. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said Friday it was upgrading its investigation from a preliminary evaluation, involving mostly paperwork, to an engineering analysis in which engineers will study the components involved.

Roughly half of the 3.5 million low-income older Americans covered by Medicaid needlessly spend hundreds of dollars for private medical insurance, according to a private study. Between 1.5 million and 2 million people 65 and older are projected to have private insurance such as ``medigap'' policies even though Medicaid covers their medical expenses, the report said Friday. The study was commissioned and released by the American Association of Retired Persons and was based on interviews with a random sample of 1,500 older people contacted by telephone in January and February 1989.

President Bush issued an election-year call for lower taxes and interest rates, saying he's not satisfied with home mortgage rates hovering around 10 percent. Bush spoke Friday at the National Association of Home Builders convention in Atlanta before flying to Miami to campaign for the re-election of Republican Gov. Bob Martinez.

Stock prices finished higher Friday, as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials gained 11.52 to 2,677.90, a loss for the week of 11.31 points. Bond prices gained ground. The dollar was mostly lower against other major currencies. Copper futures prices fell sharply; precious metals were mixed; oil futures rose; grains and soybeans were mostly lower; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Whittle Buys Healthcare Television Network
DOC.TEXT: Whittle Communications, which has been considering making commercially-sponsored television programs for doctor's waiting rooms, said it has acquired a company that was about to launch such a service. The Knoxville, Tenn.-based media company said Sunday it had acquired Healthcare Television Network Inc., a privately-held company based in Tampa, Fla. Healthcare had signed up about 3,500 pediatrician's offices and a dozen advertisers for a television service. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The acquisition increases chances that Whittle will move ahead quickly in developing a closed-circuit TV system of its own, giving advertisers another way to reach a captive audience. Whittle already has magazines and sponsored posters in about 60,000 health care offices, and disclosed in November it was considering developing TV programs for waiting rooms. ``We see the purchase of HTN as a real opportunity to quickly expand our waiting-room television project,'' said Alan Greenberg, Whittle vice chairman. Phil Cohen, the 41-year-old chief executive and founder of Healthcare Television, said in a telephone interview he has been developing the service for about 2{ years and was within a few weeks of launching it. He said his company had ordered 3,500 television sets and videocassette recorders that were to be distributed to participating waiting rooms. He said the first one-hour program, which included several short segments on topics ranging from sleep disturbance to child care safety, was ready. The plan is to have the tapes played continuously in waiting rooms on television sets handsomely displayed in custom-made cabinets. The programming would be changed every three months. Advertisers including consumer products giants such as Procter & Gamble, Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. and Mattell Inc. had signed up, Cohen said. ``We were terribly impressed with what they had accomplished to date,'' Greenberg said in a separate telephone interview. He noted that Whittle does not buy other companies often, preferring instead to develop its own media properties. Greenberg said he is studying how to incorporate Healthcare Television into Whittle's operations. One possibility is to operate Healthcare Television as a separate subsidiary. Whittle also could accelerate plans for its own system and merge it with Healthcare. One difference between the two systems is that Whittle was planning to distribute its programs by satellite. Whittle also had planned to change the programming more frequently, possibly every week. Whittle also was undecided whether its programs would be health-oriented or pure entertainment, while Healthcare's shows were to be health-based. In any case, Whittle said the service it dubbed Waiting Room TV potentially could wind up in 100,000 doctor's waiting rooms nationwide. Whittle's only other TV project to date is the Channel One news service for use in the classroom, scheduled for launch in March in 1,000 schools across the country. Channel One has been barred from public schools in New York and California and has attracted heated opposition from some education groupos because each 12-minute daily news show would include commercials. Cohen, who declined to discuss how much he was paid for Healthcare Television or his future plans, said Whittle has the experience and manpower to expand his company's service more rapidly. ``I know they can take what we started and just multiply it exponentially,'' he said. Cohen said he had several partners in the company, including Grey Advertising, a New York-based ad agency that had invested in the company last spring. Whittle acquired complete control of the company in the deal.

DOC.HEAD: AM General Selling 20,000 Hummers to South Korea ^Eds: Mac Nab is cq in 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: A division of LTV Corp. has announced a joint venture to sell as many as 20,000 all-terrain trucks to South Korea's armed forces. Officials of the AM General Division and Kia Motors Corp. signed a memorandum of understanding Friday giving the Korean company the go-ahead to seek a contract from its government for the vehicle, named the Hummer. AM General officials said the Hummer's performance under fire in Panama recently has bolstered its international reputation. The company will continue to seek more foreign customers, spokesman Craig C. Mac Nab added. Han Sun Kim, president of Kia's Asia Motors Co. Inc. subsidiary, said South Korean armed forces would like to buy as many as 20,000 Hummers over as long as 12 years. The military is eager to buy Hummers because the vehicle is used widely in South Korea by the U.S. 8th Army and has enjoyed a good reputation with troops from both nations, Kim said. AM General President James A. Armour said a Korean deal would bring more jobs to the company's plant in Mishawaka, about 80 miles east of Chicago, and add $15 to $20 million to annual revenues. The plant employs about 1,000 workers currently. Kia is Korea's second-largest automotive manufacturer behind Hyundai. It manufactures the Festiva, a subcompact marketed by Ford in the United States. Under Korean law, any Hummers used by Korean forces would have to be assembled in that country. AM General workers would assemble kits that would be shipped to Korea for final assembly. Over the past 12 years, Asia Motors has assembled about 27,000 heavy-duty military trucks from kits provided by AM General. Armour said AM General's sales to Asia Motors have totaled about $230 million over that period.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Lower at Midday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: will be led after closing
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices declined at midday Monday, after early morning price hikes by market makers attracted little follow-through buying. At about noon local time, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 10 points at 2,325.0, just slightly above its morning low of 2,324.3 and well below an opening peak of 2,346.4. Midday volume totaled 171.2 million, down from 240.3 million Friday. Dealers said genuine buying interest likely wouldn't re-emerge until concerns over domestic and foreign economies subsided. They said any potential advance was hampered by a warning from home products retailer Coloroll Group PLC that it expects a further erosion in profit. The Coloroll news ``was another nail in the coffin as far as sentiment goes,'' said a director at a British brokerage firm.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Stability Has Returned to China, Economic Planner Says
DOC.TEXT: China's chief economic planner said Monday that his country has achieved social and economic stability in the past few months to ensure progress in its economic reforms. But Zou Jiahua, head of China's State Planning Commission, acknowledged that China faces considerable economic headaches. ``The population of China is large, and the issues the Chinese people face are serious and tough. We need a stable and united government, and a stable environment, to carry through construction of socialism,'' Zou said in a speech to the Japan Association for the Promotion of International Trade, the sponsor of his visit. ``Since the turmoil of last year, we have been effective in stabilizing our country's society, government and economy,'' he said. Zou, who arrived in Japan last week, is the first high-level Chinese official to visit since the bloody crackdown on political dissent last June. Japan banned high-level contacts with China until earlier this month to protest the violence in Beijing, which left hundreds of unarmed protesters dead. Zou, a member of the State Council, or Cabinet, said China's lifting of martial law in Beijing Jan. 11 was evidence of stability. The move was widely seen overseas as a gesture aimed at bringing foreign investors back to China and inducing Western governments to drop sanctions imposed after the June crackdown. Zou has met with several leading politicians, including former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita, who pledged a package of $5.6 billion in loans on a visit to China in 1988. Japanese news reports said Takeshita accepted an invitation from Zou to visit China soon. Japan froze discussions on the loans after last June's bloodshed. It urged China to ease its hard-line stance toward dissent, and after martial law was lifted a team of Japanese officials went to China to reopen negotiations on the loans. China's economy has been plagued in recent years by overproduction of some items, scarcities of many resources, widespread construction of unnecessary or unaffordable buildings and facilities, and soaring inflation. ``We have a few economic problems at the moment, but they are problems that go along with progress, and we will overcome them,'' Zou said. ``If you look at the overheated tempo of industrial growth over a few years, it has come down to a more reasonable level.'' Nationwide industrial production was up 6.8 percent last year, and agricultural output was up 4 percent, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Longtime Jobless Turning to Unlisted Numbers
DOC.TEXT: Unlisted telephone numbers are becoming increasingly popular among the longtime unemployed as part of a trend to create barriers for all-too-prying government eyes, a recent study shows. In unemployment-prone districts in the Netherlands' biggest cities, up to 45 percent of those out of a job for more than two years have an unlisted number, according to Godfried Engbersen, a researcher at the Sociology Faculty of Leiden State University. The national unlisted average in this country of 14.6 million is 10 percent of 6.5 million telephones, according to Fred Lemmerink, a spokesman for PTT Telecom, the national phone company. ``Opting for an unlisted number is an act of defiance, of escaping from the ubiquitous eye of the government,'' Engbersen said in a Monday interview. ``People got the feeling that when they are on the dole for a long period of time, their lives are being intolerably intruded by the social security services.'' Engbersen's study covered 270 people who had been jobless for up to 10 years in Amsterdam, Rotterdam, and Enschede, a city in the eastern Netherlands. Nationwide, this category accounts for about 25 percent of the nation's 700,000 unemployed.

The stock market was mixed today, starting a new week on an indecisive note. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 7.18 to 2,670.72 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 9 to 8 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 497 up, 434 down and 488 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 17.56 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said traders remained uneasy about weak corporate earnings reports for the fourth quarter of last year, as well as the recent upturn in open-market interest rates. The Federal Reserve is seen as facing an increasingly difficult set of choices in setting monetary policy to stave off a recession while trying to keep inflation at bay. Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, will be making several appearances before congressional committees in the near future. Wall Streeters will be watching closely to see what positions he might take on such matters as the risk rising worldwide interest rates might pose for the business outlook. First Executive Corp., traded in the over-the-counter market, tumbled 2[ to 4~. The insurance holding company, which has a big investment in ``junk'' bonds, said it expects to post a substantial loss for the past year. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped .22 to 187.34. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .14 at 365.94. On Friday the Dow Jones industrial average rose 11.52 to 2,677.90, reducing its loss for the week to 11.31 points. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 6 to 5 on the NYSE, with 816 up, 651 down and 482 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 185.59 million shares, against 178.59 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Officials File Preliminary Charges In Arms Kickback Probe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, The company ..., with one graf to UPDATE with company declining comment; pickup 5th graf pvs, Rajendra Shekhar ... A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The government today filed preliminary charges against a Swedish arms manufacturer, accusing the company of paying $50 million in kickbacks to seal a 1986 arms deal. Investigators said former Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi would be among those questioned. Gandhi has said repeatedly that he did not gain personally from the deal and that no Indians received kickbacks or commissions in the contract with the company, A.B. Bofors. Bofors spokesman Johnny Ericsson said in Stockholm, Sweden, that the company would have no comment. Rajendra Shekhar, director of the Central Bureau of Investigation, told reporters the preliminary charges would form the ``launching pad'' for an investigation. The charges identify three people as ``the accused'' in the case: Gopichand Hinduja, a London-based Indian industrialist; Martin Ardbo, who was president of Bofors when the deal was signed; and Win Chadha, the Bofors agent in New Delhi. Shekhar said several others, including top Indian officials, also were involved but he refused to identify them. The legal action was the first step by new Prime Minister V.P. Singh toward fulfilling his election campaign promise to root out corruption, which he said flourished under Gandhi. Gandhi's government signed the 1986 contract with Bofors and agreed to pay $1.4 billion for 410 155mm howitzers. But the following year charges surfaced in Swedish and Indian news media of kickbacks in the deal. Shekhar said at least $50 million was paid through Swiss banks to clinch the sale. Newspaper reports have claimed that much of the money was paid to intermediaries, including people close to Gandhi and in the ruling circles of his Congress Party. The corruption charges dogged Gandhi through the rest of his tenure, giving Singh a powerful weapon in last November's national election. Although Gandhi outpolled Singh in the balloting, he could not muster a majority of seats in Parliament, and Singh formed a minority government with support from other parties. The preliminary charges, filed before a district judge in New Delhi, listed these alleged offenses: criminal conspiracy, cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property, forgery, forgery for the purpose of cheating, criminal breach of trust and abuse of official position by public servants. The charges carry penalties that include unspecified fines and prison terms.

DOC.HEAD: Oregon Farm Couple Loses Challenge to Bank's Foreclosure
DOC.TEXT: An Oregon couple seeking to hold onto a farm in their family since 1853 today lost a Supreme Court challenge to a bank's foreclosure. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the federal law Myron and Jane Harper relied on in their legal fight gives only the government, not farmers, the right to sue. A federal appeals court ruling in the Harpers' case set binding law in nine western states, and involves an farm-loan program totaling over $50 billion nationwide. The Harpers raise hogs, corn and small grains on their farm in Oregon's Willamette Valley. In 1984, the Harpers were unable to make all their loan payments on the farm. The Federal Land Bank of Spokane, now the Farm Credit Bank of Spokane, moved to foreclose on the farm in January 1987 and a foreclosure sale was scheduled for Nov. 17 of that year. The Harpers staved off the sale by seeking bankruptcy law protection on Nov. 13. But their bankruptcy petition was dismissed in February 1988, and a sheriff's sale of the farm was held March 18, 1988. In the interim, the Agricultural Credit Act of 1987 had been signed into law by then-President Ronald Reagan. The act, a major rehauling of the federally created Farm Credit Service, requires lenders of distressed loans to let borrowers know, before any foreclosure can take place, that their loans may be suitable for restructuring. Farm Credit System lenders extend about 30 percent of all farms loans nationwide. That percentage totals over $50 billion. The Harpers sued in federal court in April 1988, seeking to postpone final conveyance of their farmland to those who bought it at the foreclosure sale. U.S. District Judge Owen Panner barred the Harpers' eviction from their farm, ruling that the Federal Land Bank of Spokane ``had a duty (under the 1987 law) to weigh the costs of foreclosure against the costs of restructuring.'' But the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals threw out the judge's injunction last June 24, ruling that the 1987 law does not give individual farmers the right to sue lenders who allegedly violate it. In writing the law, Congress did not say explicitly whether such lawsuits were permissible, and the appeals court said, ``We hold there is no implied private right of action.'' In the appeal acted on today, lawyers for the Harpers said the San Francisco-based 9th Circuit court's ruling is at odds with a ruling last Oct. 5 by the St. Louis-based 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. But lawyers for the Federal Land Bank of Spokane noted that the 8th Circuit panel's decision has been set aside pending review by that entire appeals court. The case is Harper vs. Federal Land Bank of Spokane, 89-863.

The stock market declined broadly today, resuming its early-1990 slump. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 23.62 points to 2,654.28 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 341 up, 876 down and 486 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 45.09 million shares at midmorning. Analysts said traders remained uneasy about weak corporate earnings reports for the fourth quarter of last year, as well as the recent upturn in open-market interest rates. The Federal Reserve is seen as facing an increasingly difficult set of choices in setting monetary policy to stave off a recession while trying to keep inflation at bay. Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, will be making several appearances before congressional committees in the near future. Wall Streeters will be watching closely to see what positions he might take on such matters as the risk rising worldwide interest rates might pose for the business outlook. Losers among the blue chips included General Electric, down 1 at 63~; Philip Morris, down } at 38{; American Telephone & Telegraph, down \ at 41~, and USX, down { at 34{. First Executive Corp., traded in the over-the-counter market, tumbled 2{ to 4{. The insurance holding company, which has a big investment in ``junk'' bonds, said it expects to post a substantial loss for the past year. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 1.43 to 186.13. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 1.74 at 364.34.

DOC.HEAD: Monsanto Records Sharply Higher Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Monsanto Co. said Monday that earnings doubled in the fourth-quarter and rose 15 percent for the year, despite volatile raw materials prices, weather-related problems and softness in the U.S. automotive market, a big customer of the chemical giant. Earnings for the fourth quarter of 1989 totaled $90 million, or $1.37 per share, on sales of $2.01 billion, up from earnings of $45 million, or 70 cents per share, on sales of $1.88 billion in the same period a year ago. The company reported earnings for 1989 of $679 million or $10.03 a share, vs. $591 million or $8.68 a share earned in 1988. Sales for the year were $8.68 billion, up 5 percent from the $8.29 billion reported in 1988. ``We expected 1989 to be another strong year for Monsanto and we certainly weren't disappointed,'' said Richard J. Mahoney, chairman and chief executive officer. He said strong demand for Monsanto products around the world, especially in Europe, help offset problems with raw material prices early in the year and the other unfavorable factors. Mahoney said Monsanto Chemical Co. and the NutraSweet Co. had record years and G. D. Searle recorded its first profitable year since the unit was acquired by Monsanto in 1985. He said Monsanto Agricultural Co.'s Crop Chemicals unit recorded another solid year while its Animal Sciences Division experienced narrowed profit margins because of increased competition. Mahoney said Fisher Controls more than doubled annual earnings.

DOC.HEAD: Time-Life Books Acquires Australian, New Zealand Record Clubs
DOC.TEXT: Time-Life Books said Monday it has acquired The Record Clubs of Australia Pty Ltd., making parent Time Warner Inc. one of the largest direct marketers of books and records in Australia and New Zealand. Terms of the purchase weren't disclosed. The Record Clubs, owned by businessman Joseph Schwartz, had revenue last year of about $10 million and has a membership of 125,000. The international division accounted for more than one-third of Time-Life Books' revenue last year, estimated at about $350 million. John Fahey, president an chief executive of Time-Life Books, said the purchase is consistent with his company's strategy for expansion abroad through music and videocassette businesses. Fahey said the deal will generate ``economies of scale and cross-selling opportunities for our continuity book and record business.'' In a telephone interview from Time-Life Books headquarters in Alexandria, Va., Fahey said his company approached Schwartz about the deal. Fahey said he hopes to increase worldwide revenue of his divcision to $400 million this year. The Record Clubs of Australia consists of The Record Club, The Australian Compact Disk Club and a videocassette club. It also owns World Record Club New Zealand, including the Kiwi Compact Disk Club. The Record Clubs of Australia has distribution agreements with all of the major recording studios, and offers a variety of rock, classical, jazz and country music with an artist catalogue of over 6,000 titles. Time-Life Books is the largest direct marketer of books and entertainment products in the United States, shipping over 25 million units of books, records and videocassettes throughout the world.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Turn Mixed After Lower Opening
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade after an opening decline stalled, forcing early sellers to cover risky positions by buying. The turnaround occurred after the March soybean contract reached a life-of-contract low of $5.63 a bushel, an event which often brings more sellers into the market. Fundamental factors remained bearish, with beneficial rains reported over the weekend in the U.S. winter wheat belt and in the key soybean-producing region of southern Brazil. More rain is expected in both regions this week. In early trading, wheat futures were unchanged to 1 cent higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.92 a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 2{ cents lower with March at $2.40{ a bushel; oats were 1 cent lower to \ cent higher with March at $1.38\ a bushel; soybeans were { cent to 3 cents lower with January at $5.57{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .10 cent to .33 cent lower with February at 79.02 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .40 cent higher with January at 84.25 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent lower to .23 cent higher with February at 49.50 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .10 cent lower to .40 cent higher with February at 55.15 cents a pound. Cattle futures ended higher on Friday while pork futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Expanding Interest in Hungary, Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Central Soya Co. is taking advantage of recent political reforms in Eastern Europe to pursue projects in Yugoslavia and the Soviet republic of Estonia, a spokesman said Monday. Central Soya also formed a joint venture earlier this month with a Hungarian feed manufacturer in a deal that evolved from a technical services contract signed 20 years ago. The Fort Wayne-based agribusiness company will be a minority partner in Agrkomplex-Central Soya Feed Producer and Distributor Corp. Agard, Hungary's state-owned agribusiness, will be the majority partner and several other Hungarian companies also will be partners in the venture to produce feed for poultry and livestock. ``In this particular venture, (political reforms) would have had a fairly minimal impact. However, some of the other projects in Eastern Europe, these developments should be accelerated,'' said Central Soya spokesman Barry G. Collingsworth. Last spring the company formed a venture with the Polish cooperative Osnowo to manufacture animal feed concentrates and market livestock. The venture is called Central Soya-Rolpol, Ltd., Collingsworth said. Still in development are a possible technical service contract in Estonia and a soy protein venture in Yugoslavia. ``We're committed to Eastern Europe as a primary growth area,'' said David H. Swanson, Central Soya's president and chief executive officer, ``and we believe that our long-standing business relationships form the basis for that growth. ``We've sown the seeds by offering expert technology and quality products, and that dedication continues to be mutually beneficial,'' Swanson said. Central Soya, a subsidiary of the Italy's Ferruzzi Agro-Industrial Group, has sold feed technology, mixes and concentrates since 1969 to Agrokomplex, the company said. Swanson and other executives traveled to Hungary earlier this month for a celebration marking the 20th anniversary of that deal. ``Agrokomplex holds the second largest single share of the aimal feed market in Hungary,'' Swanson said. ``The manufacturing capabilities and market presence of the Hungarian entity, coupled with the technology of Central Soya, should lay a foundation for the growth and propserity of this new firm.'' Jeno Vancsa, former Hungarian minister of agriculture and food, is chairman of the new venture located near the town of Agard. It will employ about 450 people in producing and marketing premixes, complete feeds and milk replacers to more than 400 ``partners,'' or business associates, throughout Hungary, Soya said. Soya markets products to customers in more than 60 countries. Its major businesses include feed manufacturing, soybean processing, grain merchandising, vegetable oil refining and the manufacture of soy proteins and lecithins. It operates more than 65 plants and facilities worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Plans Joint Minivan Venture In Austria
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. and Austrian automaker Steyr-Daimler-Puch AG said today they would establish a joint venture for producing Chrysler's popular minivans in Austria. The agreement in principle between Chrysler and the Austrian engineering and automotive company provides for establishment of joint production of the Chrysler Voyager in Graz, Austria's second-largest city, for the European market. Under the joint venture, Chrysler and Steyr-Daimler-Puch Fahrzeugtechnick GMBH will develop Voyager spare parts specifically designed for the European market, Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca told a news conference in Vienna. Iacocca said production was scheduled to begin in Spring 1991. Chrysler already has been involved in other joint ventures in Europe, including a venture to build Jeeps in conjunction with French automaker Renault. U.S. automakers increasingly have expanded in the European market as their North American sales have sagged under the weight of a slowing U.S. economy and stepped-up competition from foreign ``transplants'' _ foreign-owned car factories located in the United States. The Voyager has been one of Chrysler's best sellers in the United States since its introduction in 1983, with Chrysler commanding nearly half of the U.S. market for minivans.

DOC.HEAD: Announces Extra Aid For Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Britain on Monday announced a major aid package likely to be worth millions of dollars to help the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe rebuild their economies. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, before flying to East Germany for a three-day visit, said a ``know-how'' fund already in place for Poland and Hungary was to be extended to other countries. No figure was disclosed, but a Foreign Office spokesman, who wasn't identified, in accordance with British custom, said the amount would be substantial. The combined fund for Poland and Hungary, which is separate from British money given in European Community aid, stands at 75 million pounds, or about $123 million.

DOC.HEAD: Court To Resolve Procedural Dispute Over Disability Benefits
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to resolve a procedural dispute over denied Social Security disability benefits. The court said it will review the case of a New Jersey widow whose 1983 application for disability benefits was denied by the Department of Health and Human Services. But the court's decision, expected by July, will not determine whether Marilyn Finkelstein, 59, is entitled to the benefits. Instead, the justices will decide whether a federal trial judge's order that HHS officials reconsider her application may be appealed by HHS to a federal appeals court before any such reconsideration. Mrs. Finkelstein sued, and a federal judge in Newark ruled that HHS had used the wrong standard in determining her eligibility for disability benefits. The 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals dismissed the government's ensuing appeal, saying the trial judge's order was not a ``final decision'' that could be appealed immediately. The government then filed the appeal acted on today. The case is Sullivan vs. Finkelstein, 89-504.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher, Gold Falls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: An AMer expected by 5:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose Monday in trading in Europe, boosted by worries over unrest in the Soviet Union. Gold prices fell. Foreign exchange dealers said worries over the political implications of fighting in Soviet Azerbaijan along with the belief that the Federal Reserve Board was unlikely to ease its monetary policy fortified the dollar. But concern about possible central bank intervention to drive the currency lower or at lerast curb its rise was restraining the dollar, dealers said. ``Sentiment is for a higher dollar, but there's not much to back it up today,'' said one corporate dealer at a U.S. bank in London. The lack of news prompted some light short-covering, or the buying of dollars to fulfill agreements to sell them, dealers said. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.09 yen to a closing 146.42 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 146.45 yen. In London, the British pound fell to $1.6385 from $1.6475 late Friday. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.7230 West German marks, up from 1.7050; 1.5325 Swiss francs, up from 1.5140; 5.8550 French francs, up from 5.6955; 1.9370 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9310; 1,281.50 Italian lire, up from 1,269.25; and 1.1826 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1786. Gold fell in London to a late bid of $405.25 a troy ounce from $410.25 late Friday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $405.75 from $408.65 bid late Friday. Gold fell $1.50 an ounce to close at a bid $407.85 in Hong Kong. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid of $5.20 a troy ounce from Friday's $5.22.
