DOC.HEAD: Delta Reports `Disappointing' Earnings for Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Delta Air Lines Chairman Ronald W. Allen said a 25 percent drop in the company's net income during its second fiscal quarter resulted from higher fuel prices and lower income per mile from fares during the period. Allen said Saturday that weak ``passenger-mile yields'' for Thanksgiving and Christmas, usually two of the busiest times for the airline, also contributed to the decrease. For the three months ended Dec. 31 _ the second quarter in Delta's fiscal year _ Delta's net income was $64.2 million or $1.13 a share. During the same period a year earlier, earnings were $85.2 million or $1.73 a share. Operating revenue for the latest quarter was $2.05 billion, up from $1.86 billion in the same period a year earlier. But fuel costs rose from $220.5 million in the second quarter of 1988 to $314.2 million in the latest three-month period. Increases in fuel costs recently have been cited for fare hikes throughout the U.S. airline industry. ``Fuel expenses rose 43 percent, the result of a 34 percent jump in the average price of aircraft fuel,'' Allen said. He also noted that the passenger-mile yields _ the money taken in per passenger for each mile flown _ were down about 1 percent during the typically busy holiday season. For the recent quarter, the yield was 13.39 cents, down from 13.48 cents in the year-ago report. For the six months ended Dec. 31, Delta said its net income was $197.4 million, or $3.65 a share, compared with $185.1 million, or $3.76 a share, a year earlier. Six-month revenue rose 13 percent to $4.22 billion from $3.74 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Weather, Seasonal Decline Contribute to Decline in Rig Count
DOC.TEXT: Bad weather and a seasonal decline in drilling activity sent the number of working U.S. oil and gas rigs tumbling by 55 this week, Baker Hughes Inc. reported Monday. The rig count totaled 964, compared to 1,019 a week ago. But the tally was higher than the 789 total posted this time last year. Texas and Oklahoma were the big losers this week, accounting for more than half of the decline. Texas lost 23 rigs, while Oklahoma's rig count fell by 12. Baker Hughes rig count _ the widely watched industry index of drilling activity _ reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. Ike Kerridge, a Baker Hughes vice president and economist, said he expected the decline, and he added it will continue. ``This is the time of year when drilling declines,'' Kerridge said, adding that the rig count usually drops by up to 20 percent during the first quarter of each year. Houston-based Hughes Tool Co., an oil toolmaker company that merged with Baker International Corp. of Orange, Calif., has kept track of the rig count since 1940. The rig count peaked at 4,500 in December 1981 _ the height of the oil boom. But oil prices plunged to less than $10 per 42-gallon barrel in the summer of 1986, prompting a collapse in the rig count that bottomed out at 663 _ the lowest since Hughes began compiling figures. Among other major oil producing states, Colorado lost five rigs, Wyoming lost four and Pennsylvania was down by one. North Dakota, New Mexico, Michigan and Kansas each lost two rigs. Louisiana gained one rig.

DOC.HEAD: American Home Products Posts 19 Percent Quarterly Profit Gain
DOC.TEXT: American Home Products Corp. on Monday reported a 19 percent increase in its fourth-quarter income and 10.8 percent profit growth for all of last year. The diversified food, drugs and consumer products company said its sales rose 6.5 percent in the fourth quarter and 5.5 percent in 1989. Income, after taxes, grew to $304 million, or $1.95 a share, in the three months ended Dec. 31 from $254.9 million, or $1.65 a share, a year earlier. Sales totaled $1.64 billion, up from $1.54 billion in 1988's fourth quarter. For 1989, American Home Products earned $1.1 billion, or $7.07 a share, compared to $995 million, or $6.43 a share, in 1988. Last year's sales amounted to $6.75 billion vs. 1988's $6.40 billion. The results for both years were restated to include the operations of A.H. Robins Co. Inc., which was merged into American Home Products on Dec. 15. Last year's net income included tax benefits derived from the use of net operating losses generated by Robins on its funding of the trusts settling lawsuits over the Dalkon Shield birth control device. American Home Products said its 1989 tax provision was reduced by the amount of taxes which would otherwise have been payable on Robins' 1989 U.S. income and by $94 million mainly relating to the refund of prior years' taxes paid by Robins. Robins, faced with thousands of lawsuits involving the Dalkon Shield, had been reorganizing under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act since 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Administration View Sought on Arbitration Contracts
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday asked the Bush administration for its view on whether stockbrokers may be forced to give investors the option of suing rather than resolving fraud disputes in arbitration. The court said it wants to hear from Justice Department lawyers about a ruling that barred Massachusetts from requiring brokers to make arbitration clauses optional, not mandatory, in brokerage contracts. The justices are not expected to take any action in the Massachusetts case until hearing from the government lawyers, which could take months. The Massachusetts appeal is supported by 30 other states, whose officials said a federal appeals court ruling leaves them ``powerless to protect consumers from being coerced to enter arbitration agreements.'' The Boston-based 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled last Aug. 31 that the Massachusetts regulations are pre-empted by federal law. The prevailing practice in the brokerage industry is to require customers to agree to arbitrate all disputes as a condition to opening an account. In other business-related rulings Monday, the court: _Agreed to decide whether nuclear industry ``whistleblowers'' who say they were disciplined for complaining about lax safety may sue under state personal-injury laws. The justices will review a North Carolina case in which a federal appeals court said such workers must sue under a special federal law. _Ruled against an Oregon couple that challenged a bank's foreclosure on a farm in their family since 1853. The court let stand a ruling that the federal law Myron and Jane Harper relied on in their legal fight gives only the government, not farmers, the right to sue. _Refused to require arbitration for hundreds of thousands of federal workers when they are fired, demoted or otherwise disciplined. The court rejected appeals by a labor union and the Federal Labor Relations Authority seeking broader job protection for federal employees. _Refused to let public employee labor unions get from the government the home addresses of federal workers, leaving intact a ruling that the workers' privacy would be violated if government agencies are forced to divulge the information to the unions. _Scuttled a federal lawsuit stemming from the collapse of the Old Court Savings & Loan Association in Maryland, saying state courts may handle suits based on a federal anti-racketeering law. The justices said lower federal courts rightly dismissed the suit because similar ones were being handled by state courts in Maryland. On mandatory arbitration clauses, the justices in 1987 ruled 5-4 that if such clauses are in the contracts signed by investors, disputes over alleged fraud are to be resolved in arbitration, not in lawsuits. Massachusetts' secretary of state in 1988 imposed regulations prohibiting brokers from making arbitration agreements non-negotiable conditions for opening accounts. The regulations also required brokers to tell customers about the legal effects of mandatory arbitration clauses. The state's action immediately was challenged by the Securities Industry Association and 10 brokerage firms affiliated with it. A federal judge ruled for the brokers, and the appeals court upheld that ruling. ``The long and short of it is that we can find no evidence of a clear congressional command to override the unambiguous pro-arbitration mandate of the (Federal Arbitration Act) in the securities field,'' the appeals court said. In the state's appeal, Massachusetts Attorney General James M. Shannon said the August ruling ``has national implications for state regulation of mandatory arbitration agreements in banking, health care, (the) automobile and many other industries.'' Shannon said the Federal Arbitration Act does not pre-empt all state regulation of arbitration. Lawyers for the securities industry urged the justices to reject the state's appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Cranston Says He'll Help Burned Lincoln Bondholders
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Alan Cranston said Monday he would introduce legislation to allow investors to sue the government if they fail in other efforts to recover losses from worthless junk bonds sold at Lincoln Savings & Loan Association. The California Democrat, facing his most serious political crisis because of his involvement with Lincoln, continued an attack that began last week, blaming a former banking regulator for investors' losses. Cranston said his legislation, to be introduced this week, would allow bond holders to file suit against the U.S. government if they are unsuccessful in suits against Lincoln, parent American Continental Corp., and company chief Charles H. Keating Jr. The government is usually immune from such suits, but Cranston said there were precedents allowing lawsuits in cases of government negligence. ``Documents I have received from the Office of Thrift Supervision in Washington and the General Accounting Office are clearly enough evidence on which to bring a case of negligence against the government,'' Cranston said. Cranston spoke at the latest in a series of news conferences intended to deflect blame that had been aimed at him for investor losses stemming from the failure of the Irvine-based Lincoln. Cranston, the Senate majority whip, is one five senators under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee for intervening with regulators on behalf of Lincoln, American Continental of Phoenix and Keating. Keating and his family contributed $1.3 million to the senators and their causes. Three recent polls show Cranston's popularity with California voters has plunged to its lowest level since he came to the Senate in 1969, but he has promised to seek re-election next year nonetheless. By focusing on the bondholders, he hopes to disarm one of the most personally damaging allegations against him _ bondholders' testimony that his intervention for Keating made him partly responsible for their losses. He spent much of last week attacking former chief S&L regulator Edwin J. Gray as the main culprit in the failure of Lincoln and the losses to bondholders, many of them elderly people who lost their life savings. Cranston tried to paint what he called ``a picture of negligence by Gray and his staff'' when Gray headed the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. As ammunition, Cranston released a chronology by federal regulators that showed the bank board permitted American Continental to sell its junk bonds at the thrift's offices even though regulators questioned the firm's ability to repay bondholders. The bonds, unlike bank accounts at Lincoln, were not insured and became worthless when American Continental filed for bankruptcy. Cranston said investors were victims of bait-and-switch tactics that regulators should not have allowed. State and federal officials say the bondholders, mostly Los Angeles-area retirees, were targeted by Lincoln to switch nearly $200 million of federally insured deposits into the uninsured junk bonds after federal examiners first recommended closing the Irvine-based thrift in May 1987. The $2 billion-plus cost for protecting depositors with insured accounts _ not the bondholders _ is likely to be the most expensive thrift takeover in history.

DOC.HEAD: Grain Futures End Mixed

DOC.HEAD: UTC Posts Modest Fourth-Quarter Gains
DOC.TEXT: United Technologies Corp. on Monday credited a strong performance by its jet engine and aeronautics divisions for a modest increase in fourth-quarter earnings despite flat revenues. The defense giant posted net income of $184.4 million, or $1.36 a share, on revenues of $5.3 billion for the quarter ended Dec. 31, compared to net income of $150.6 million, or $1.16 a share, on revenues of $5.3 billion for the same period a year ago. Operating income for the power and flight segments was $249 million vs. $194 million for the same period a year ago, with most of the increase generated by Pratt & Whitney's commercial jet engine business, the company said. The flight systems operating income was $72 million for the quarter, vs. $39 million for the period a year ago, with Hamilton Standard aeronautics division accounting for most of the improvement. Operating income for the building segments, including Carrier air conditioners and Otis elevators, dropped to $73 million from $85 million a year ago, primarily because of lower profits at Carrier, which had benefitted from a one-time gain in the fourth-quarter of 1988. For the year, UTC posted net income of $702.1 million, or $5.20 a share on a fully diluted basis, on revenues of $19.8 billion, vs. net income of $659.1 million, or $5.05 a share, on revenues of $18.5 billion in 1988. For the year, Pratt & Whitney had $11 billion in commercial engine orders, including options, vs. $5 billion in 1988. Revenues from overseas operations and exports increased 18 percent to $9.8 billion and now account for 50 percent of total revenues, said Robert F. Daniell, UTC chairman and chief executive officer.

DOC.HEAD: Universal Foods Agrees to Sell Cheese Division
DOC.TEXT: Universal Foods Corp., which successfully fought a hostile takeover bid last year, announced Monday it has tentatively agreed to sell its cheese division to the division's current management. The company said the proposed sale, which should be completed this spring, is intended to generate capital for other investment opportunites. Terms were not disclosed. In addition to cheese, Universal Foods manufactures yeast products, frozen potato products, food colors and flavors and dehydrated food products. The cheese division, which employs about 400 people, generated $198 million in revenues during fiscal year 1989, or about 24 percent of the company's total revenue of $837 million. Geoff Hibner, vice president of finance for Universal Foods, said the company wanted to focus its attention on developing other parts of its operations. ``The cheese business is tough right now,'' Hibner said. ``The price of milk has skyrocketed and cheese prices just aren't keeping up.'' Hibner said the money from the division's sale will be used for development of the company's frozen food division, which he said is growing fastest, and development of its flavor and color division. ``We made a number of acquisitions last year in the flavor and color business and we anticipate more,'' Hibner said. ``That's really our business _ we want to be in the food ingredient supply business.'' Lee Brinkerhoff and Harry Smith, vice presidents and general managers of the cheese division, have been planning the buyout attempt since the holidays, Brinkerhoff said. ``We already have the initial equity needed for the transaction, but we think we'll need the help of other employees to make the transaction work,'' he said. Brinkerhoff said he and Smith have had talks with several investors but have not yet identified any definite outside sources of capital. He said no immediate changes in the division's operations are planned. ``For the time being, we plan business as usual,'' he said. Hibner said he does not anticipate Universal Foods will sell any other divisions. Guy A. Osborn, president and chief executive officer, said in a prepared statement he anticipates Universal Foods will reach its earnings target of $1.93 per share this year. Universal Foods last year successfully fended off a hostile takeover by Massachusetts-based Amanda Acquisition Corp., which had offered more than $700 million for the company. The takeover was abandoned after courts refused to overturn Universal Foods' poison-pill defense or Wisconsin's anti-takeover law, both of which blocked the takeover.

DOC.HEAD: Earns Fall in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: The Quaker Oats Co. on Monday reported earnings tumbled 42.8 percent for the second quarter of its 1990 fiscal year as its Fisher-Price subsidiary continued a sharp slide through a disappointing year of toy sales. For the second quarter, earnings were $21.4 million, or 27 cents a share, on revenue of $1.34 billion, compared with earnings of $37.4 million, or 47 cents a share, on revenue of $1.35 billion in the same 1989 period. Income for Quaker's U.S. and international grocery products businesses, which account for about 85 percent of sales at the Chicago-based company, were up compared to the same period last year. But Fisher-Price's poor performance was expected to continue through the end of the fiscal year in June, company officials said. The company also was hurt by increased financing costs, $17 million more than the same period last year, due largely to higher interest expense and foreign exchange losses in Brazil. ``The results this quarter are disappointing and reflect Fisher-Price's widely reported deteriorating performance over the last several months,'' said William D. Smithburg, Quaker's chairman and chief executive officer. He said Fisher-Price is likely to be ``only marginally profitable at best in the second half.'' Fisher-Price lost $9.5 million in the second quarter, compared to income of $9.8 million for the same period in 1989. Company spokesman Ronald G. Bottrell said Fisher-Price suffered from sales and production problems with its 1989 toy line, but has received strong early reviews on its 1990 line. Quaker's chief financial officer, Paul E. Price, took over as president of Fisher-Price Jan. 4. He replaced Bruce Sampsell, who left for a Buffalo, N.Y. bank holding company. For the first half of the fiscal year, earnings were $77.1 million, or 97 cents a share, on revenue of $2.8 billion, compared with earnings of $82.4 million, or $1.04 a share, on revenue of $2.8 billion for the same period last year.
