DOC.HEAD: Tandy Earnings Slip On Slow PC Sales
DOC.TEXT: Tandy Corp., parent company of Radio Shack electronics stores and a major personal computer manufacturer, reported a 12.8 percent drop in quarterly earnings as demand faltered for home computers. For the quarter ended Dec. 31, net income was $117.63 million, or $1.43 per share, compared with $135.05 million, or $1.50 per share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter rose to $1.46 billion from $1.4 billion in 1988. Tandy spokesman Philip Bradtmiller said the industry in general had experienced slow sales in the home market for computers. About 70 percent of Tandy's revenues come from retail sales, the bulk of it in Radio Shack stores. For the first half of Tandy's fiscal year, net income was $180.39 million, or $2.14 per share, on revenue of $2.44 billion compared with $199.96 million, or $2.23 per share, on $2.34 billion in the comparable period.

DOC.HEAD: Singh Government Files Bribery Charges in Arms Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to include Hinduja statement; picks up 5th `Rajendra Shekhar... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Swedish company A.B. Bofors and unidentified officials in the government of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi were charged with bribery Monday in connection with a $1.4 million arms deal. Investigators said a full investigation of the 1986 artillery contract would be made and Gandhi, whose Congress Party lost the November elections, would be among those questioned. Bofors is accused of paying $50 million in kickbacks to win the contract. In Sweden, company spokesman Johnny Ericsson said: ``We've had no direct contacts (with Indian officials) over this and have no comments.'' Preliminary charges filed in a special New Delhi court Monday by the government of Prime Minister V.P. Singh named three people: Gopichand Hinduja, an Indian industrialist based in London; Martin Ardbo, president of Bofors when the contract was signed; and Win Chadha, the Bofors agent in New Delhi. Hinduja issued a statement in London saying: ``I totally deny that I am in any way involved in it.'' Rajendra Shekhar, new director of the Central Bureau of Investigation, told reporters that others accused included officials of Bofors and of four companies through which kickbacks allegedly were routed. He did not name the Gandhi government officials suspected of involvement or say how many there were. Shekhar said he needed more evidence before revealing identities. Asked whether Gandhi would be among those questioned, he said: ``He would be, obviously.'' At least 640 million rupees was paid through Swiss banks to clinch the sale of Bofors howitzers to India, the charges say. The sum was worth $50 million in 1986, but now is equivalent to $37 million. Filing preliminary charges would help establish ``the principle of dual criminality,'' enabling the bureau to seek cooperation authorities in Sweden and Switzerland, said Shekhar, whom Singh appointed earlier this month. He said his organization prepared the charges after seeing classified documents related to the arms contract. Access to the documents was granted in December, a few days after Singh took office, Shekhar said. Singh's victory in the Nov. 22-26 general elections capped a vociferous campaign in which he described corruption as flourishing under Gandhi. Some politicians have claimed Gandhi shared in the kickbacks, but lengthy newspaper investigations did not include direct accusations against the former prime minister. Gandhi said in Parliament neither he nor any member of his family received money. The scandal began in April 1987 when Swedish radio said Bofors paid top officials and members of the Gandhi government to win the contract, which French and Austrian companies also sought. These offenses are alleged in the 66 pages of charges filed Monday with a New Delhi district judge: criminal conspiracy, cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property, forgery, forgery for the purpose of cheating, criminal breach of trust and abuse of official position by public servants. Shekhar denied suggestions by some reporters that his news conference was politically motivated, although the Central Bureau of Investigations seldom publicizes its investigations and legal actions.

DOC.HEAD: Kemp Tells Home Builders Current Slump No Cause for Panic
DOC.TEXT: Housing and Urban Development Secretary Jack Kemp told a home builders' convention Monday to avoid alarm over the industry's current slump. ``A lot of the current doom and gloom is contrary to the facts,'' Kemp said. ``I don't believe housing is going to be America's next crisis.'' In a speech to the National Association of Home Builders, Kemp acknowledged that last month's 8 percent decline in housing starts, the recent softening of real estate prices and the crisis in the savings and loan industry are an ``understandable cause for concern.'' But he said efforts by the Bush administration to lower interest rates and the proposed cut in the capital gains tax, themes sounded by President Bush in his speech Friday to the NAHB, could help revive the fortunes of the industry. Both measures appear to have strong support in the industry, as their mention in the speeches by Bush and Kemp drew applause. A capital gains tax cut, he said, ``will reinvigorate the real estate market, the equity market, the bond market and other financial markets.'' Opponents of the cut say it would favor mainly big investors and people making more than $100,000 a year. ``What some on the left forget is that the capital gains tax doesn't just help old wealth, it's an incentive for the creation of new wealth,'' Kemp told the home builders. Kemp's speech came as the NAHB wrapped up its four-day convention in Atlanta, electing Martin Perlman of Houston as its new president. The association also announced Monday, in conjunction with the Federal National Mortgage Association, a new program to assist low-and moderate-income families in buying their own homes. Five cities will be selected for the pilot program, which will build on existing projects already under way, officials said. The program will include designing innovative housing and low-cost approaches to development; encouragement of local governments to be more flexible in zoning, building standards and taxation to make homes more affordable; and special financing programs.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Seeks Permission to Fly Non-Stop to Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines Chairman Frank Lorenzo announced Monday that Continental will ask for government approval to fly four non-stop weekly flights from Houston to Tokyo. The Houston-based airline is among eight U.S. carriers seeking the Department of Transportation's approval to fly non-stop to Tokyo, Continental officials said at a news conference at a Japanese restaurant. Despite the intense competition for 24 weekly non-stop flights to Tokyo, Lorenzo said he believes Continental's chances are excellent. The 24 available flights are the result of an agreement signed by the U.S. and Japan last November. Continental, a subsidiary of Houston-based Texas Air, wants permission to fly four weekly non-stop flights to Tokyo. It already has a request pending with the DOT to offer three weekly one-stop flights to Tokyo. ``Continental is very excited to attempt to provide a very important service for Houston,'' Lorenzo said. ``There are just so many areas from which direct service from Houston to Tokyo will benefit,'' he said. Lorenzo noted there are 125 Japanese companies with Houston offices, and 109 Houston companies that do business in the Pacific Rim. Texas Air spokesman Art Kent said he expected a decision on the one-stop request to be issued sometime in the next few weeks. He did not know when the DOT might decide on the request for non-stop service. Lorenzo said if both requests are approved, Continental could begin one-stop service in August and non-stop flights beginning in early 1991. Last May, Continental began non-stop service between Seattle and Tokyo. Continental has 56 weekly departures from Japan, but only seven of them travel to the U.S. mainland.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Down
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against most major currencies Monday despite a steep slide in stock prices on Wall Street. Gold prices ended lower. In New York, gold for current delivery fell $2.80 to $407.20 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted an ounce of gold bullion at $408.20, down $1.80 from Friday's late bid. The dollar benefited from sales of West German marks. Currency dealers dumped marks as they mulled the implications of fighting in Soviet Azerbaijan and rumors of unrest in Eastern Europe, said John McCarthy, chief dealer at the Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank's office in New York. But the dollar rally met resistance amid speculation about possible central bank intervention to curb its advance, he said. Enthusiasm to buy dollars also was tempered in the afternoon as the stock market piled up losses. ``I'm quite surprised the dollar isn't lower given that the stock market is down a ton,'' McCarthy said. A belief that the Federal Reserve Board is unlikely to ease its monetary policy _ which contributed to Wall Street's selloff _ fortified the dollar. Worries about the outlook for corporate profit growth and impatience for lower interest rates sent stocks tumbling. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 77.45 to 2,600.45, for its largest one-day point loss since it took a 190-point drop last Oct. 13. In 14 sessions since the average began the new year by hitting a record high, it has dropped 209.70 points, or 7.47 percent. The dollar began its trading day in Tokyo with a rise of 0.09 yen to a closing level of 146.42 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 146.45 yen and in New York, the dollar was quoted at 146.505 yen, up from 145.925 yen late Friday. In London, the British pound fell to $1.6385 from $1.6475 late Friday. In later New York trading, a pound cost $1.6370, compared to late Friday's $1.6470. Of the major currencies, only the Canadian dollar strengthed against the U.S. dollar. Selected dollar rates late Monday compared with Friday's late levels included: 1.7242 West German marks, up from 1.7105; 1.5350 Swiss francs, up from 1.5205; 5.859 French francs, up from 5.8130; 1.18015 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1836; and 1,283.00 Italian lire, up from 1,274.12. Late rates for the dollar in Europe, compared with late rates Friday, were: 1.7230 West German marks, up from 1.7050; 1.5325 Swiss francs, up from 1.5140; 5.8550 French francs, up from 5.6955; 1.9370 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9310; 1,281.50 Italian lire, up from 1,269.25; and 1.1826 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1786. Gold prices eased while silver was mixed. The late bid for gold in London was $405.25 a troy ounce, down from $410.25 late Friday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $405.75 from $408.65 bid late Friday. Gold fell $1.50 an ounce to close at a bid $407.85 in Hong Kong. Silver for January delivery rose to $5.268 a troy ounce on New York's Commodity Exchange from Friday's settlement price of $5.202. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid of $5.20 a troy ounce from Friday's $5.22.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices nosedived Monday to their lowest levels since last autum, extending the market's early-1990 slide amid worries about the outlook for corporate profits and interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 77.45 to 2,600.45, for its largest one-day point loss since it took a 190-point drop last Oct. 13. In 14 sessions since the average began the new year by hitting a record high, it has dropped 209.70 points, or 7.47 percent. Declining issues swamped advances by about 5 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 267 up, 1,336 down and 368 unchanged. Analysts said traders remained unsettled by weak corporate earnings reports for the fourth quarter of last year, as well as the recent upturn in open-market interest rates. Many observers believe the Federal Reserve is facing an increasingly difficult set of choices in setting monetary policy to stave off a recession while trying to keep inflation at bay. Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, is scheduled to make several appearances before congressional committees in the near future. Wall Streeters will be watching closely to seewhat positions he might take on such matters as the risk rising worldwide interest rates might pose for the business outlook. Losers among the blue chips included General Electric, down 2 at 62~; Philip Morris, down 1\ at 38; Union Carbide, down 1| at 20~; American Telephone & Telegraph, down 1| at 40{, and International Business Machines, down 2 at 96|. Oil, auto, retailing, pharmaceutical and regional telephone issues all posted broad losses. Helene Curtis fell 3{ to 19\, for the biggest percentage decline among NYSE issues. The company said it expects to report a slightly smaller earnings gain for the fiscal year ending Feb. 28 than had been projected. Delta Air Lines, which reported lower fourth-quarter profits, lost ~ to 65~. First Executive Corp., the most active issue in the over-the-counter market, tumbled 3 to 4. The insurance holding company, which has a big investment in ``junk'' bonds, said it expects to post a substantial loss for the past year. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $74.06 billion, or 2.25 percent, in value. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 148.38 million shares, down from 172.26 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 181.60 million shares. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 4.36 to 183.20. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 10.29 to 379.68, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 8.77 at 330.38. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market lost 8.94 to 431.94. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 360.88, down 5.20.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Decline
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures fell in volatile trading Monday despite wintery weather that swept across the country. The February contract for West Texas Intermediate, the main grade of U.S. crude oil, tumbled $1.12 to close at $22.55 per 42-gallon barrel after trading in a $2 range during the session. Analysts said concern about a possible surplus of crude oil prompted a late selling spree on the final day before the February contract expired at the close of trading. Other contract months posted smaller losses. The March contract fell 31 cents to $21.77 a barrel and April fell 22 cents to $21.15. Among refined products traded on the exchange, No. 2 heating oil for February delivery fell 2.67 cents to 60.99 cents a gallon after trading in a wide range. The contract closed last week with a 0.94-cent gain after five rocky sessions. The March heating oil contract lost 1.68 cents to settle at 58.00 cents a gallon while April ended down 1.32 cents at 55.50 cents. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for February delivery declined 0.98 cent to 60.64 cents a gallon, March lost 1.37 cents to 61.32 cents and April slipped 1.49 cents to 61.94 cents a gallon. ``The focus was on the crude contract expiration,'' said Linda Simard, energy analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ``People heard there were plenty of sweet cargos available and crude fell out.'' Buyers drove crude prices up late last week amid concern about possible tight supplies of light, sweet crude, which is sought by refiners to make gasoline. Heating oil's decline Monday despite the return of wintery weather to many parts of the nation surprised some analysts. Heating oil prices hit record levels in December as cold weather drove up demand. However, industry statistics last week suggested that inventories were climbing faster than many expected as imported oil ordered during the cold weather replaced depleted supplies.

DOC.HEAD: Study Says Protection Out of Reach for Most Elderly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Health Insurance Association comment, inserting 2 grafs after 4th graf, ``The fact ... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The high cost of nursing home insurance places it out of reach for most older Americans and demonstrates the need for a government program to protect people against the staggering costs of long-term care, an advocacy group said Monday. The Families USA Foundation released a study saying that 84 percent of Americans from ages 65 to 79 cannot afford even a basic nursing home insurance policy and most companies do not issue policies to people age 80 and older. Executive Director Ron Pollack called the findings shocking and said they bolster the case for a social insurance solution akin to Social Security, spreading the benefits and costs across the population. Any long-term care proposal keyed to private insurance ``is going to be a failed policy,'' he said. ``The fact is that grandma can't afford long-term care insurance,'' Pollack said. ``Private insurance that claims to protect older Americans from the high cost of nursing homes is itself so expensive that only the very richest elderly can afford the premiums.'' Don White, a spokesman for the Health Insurance Association of America, said the organization hopes to see a public-private solution to the long-term care problem, with private insurers playing a far larger role than that envisioned by Families USA. About 40 percent of elderly people can afford to buy private long-term care insurance, according to HIAA. ``It's clear that the government can't do the job by itself, the private companies can't do the job by themselves, we've got to do it together,'' White said. ``It's the role of the government to provide for those who are poor or near poor, those who need government assistance.'' With the costs of nursing home care averaging more than $2,000 a month, older Americans and their families have been voicing increasing concern about the need for protection against such staggering costs. Private long-term care insurance was virtually non-existent before 1980 but the market has grown rapidly in recent years, with more than 100 companies now offering policies and more than 1.3 million policies having been sold by mid-1989. Families USA studied the average cost of basic policies issued by nine leading insurance companies and found that annual premiums averaged $1,255 when purchased at age 65. At age 79, premiums averaged $3,860. Policies were considered unaffordable when annual premiums pushed total health care costs to more than 10 percent of a person's yearly income and annuitized assets. ``The fact is that nursing home insurance is well beyond the reach of most elderly couples and the situation is even tougher for widows or widowers, who are most in need of long-term care,'' Pollack said. Some older people who fear the high costs of nursing home care purchase insurance that is ``far beyond their means'' and forego meals and medicine to pay for it, he said. Pollack said public opinion surveys indicate most Americans would be willing to pay extra taxes for long-term care protection. He said possible financing mechanisms could include added payroll taxes or changes in the gift and estate tax. The foundation said it was sending copies of its report to the Pepper Commission, made up of members of Congress and White House appointees, which is trying to come up with a solution to the long-term care problem. The commission estimates 9 million Americans currently need long-term care, with the numbers expected to grow as the population ages.

DOC.HEAD: Orange Juice Futures Soar On New Damage Report
DOC.TEXT: Orange juice futures prices soared to record highs Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade following a government report showing far more damage to the Florida orange crop from last month's freeze than traders had expected. On other futures markets, stock-index futures plunged along with the stock market; pork futures surged while livestock futures were mixed; energy futures fell; precious metals were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mixed. Futures prices for frozen concentrated orange juice soared 4.3 cents to 7.55 cents with the spot contract for January delivery settling at $1.9625 a pound and the more heavily traded March contract at $2.0535. The March settlement price was the highest ever for an orange juice futures contract, eclipsing the previous high of $2.0425 set July 18, 1988, after frost damaged the Brazilian orange crop. The rally was largely a reaction to a report released Friday by the Florida state division of the Agriculture Department that said only 32 percent of the orange crop escaped damage from the Christmas freeze, compared with a previous estimate of 44 percent. Buyers were also reacting to an announcement Monday by Brazilian orange juice processors that they were raising their price for orange juice concentrate 20 cents to an effective rate of about $2.08 a pound, said analyst Ernie Thomas of Merrill Lynch Consumer Markets Inc. in Winter Haven, Fla. Brazilian imports are expected to make up for the frost-related shortfall in U.S. supplies. U.S. processors are asking about $2.15 for concentrate, Thomas said. ``We definitely had more damage than we originally thought and it just seems to get worse every day,'' Thomas said. Analyst Judy Ganes of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said the extent of freeze damage is especially disturbing because it occurred in citrus groves located further south than in 1983, when the last freeze of comparable severity hit, and the damage is worse. Stock-index futures prices tumbled on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as the Dow Jones index of 30 industrials plunged 77.45 points amid worries about the outlook for corporate profits and interest rates. The Merc's contract for March delivery of stocks represented by the Standard & Poor's 500 index settled 10.3 points lower at 331.40. The contract is worth $500 a point. Pork futures rose strongly on the Chicago Merc amid rumors that Romania and the Soviet Union were looking to buy U.S. pork products. Similar rumors circulated last week, but so far only sales of beef livers and hearts to Romania have been announced. ``The bottom line is that both the Romanians and the Russians have reasons to buy meat but the real problem is that they don't have much money,'' said Tom Morgan, president of Sterling Research Corp. in Arlington Heights, Ill. Cattle futures finished mixed amid positioning ahead of Wednesday quarterly USDA cattle-on-feed report. Live cattle futures settled unchanged to .10 cent lower with February at 79.25 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent to .45 cent higher with January at 84.30 cents a pound; live hogs were .23 cent to .60 cent higher with February at 50.12 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .15 cent lower to 1.90 cents higher with February at 57.05 cents a pound. Most petroleum futures fell sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange, largely on selling related to the expiration of the February crude oil contract, which went off the board at $22.55 barrel, down $1.12. Other West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures ended 31 cents lower to 8 cents higher with March at $21.77 a barrel; heating oil was .97 cent to 2.67 cents lower with February at 60.99 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .98 cent to 1.51 cents lower with February at 60.64 cents a gallon. Gold futures slipped on New York's Commodity Exchange in reaction to the stronger dollar; silver futures advanced in a technically inspired rebound after last week's sharp decline. Gold futures finished $2.80 to $2.90 lower with February at $408 a troy ounce; silver was 6.3 cents to 6.5 cents higher with March at $5.315 a troy ounce. Wheat futures prices closed higher Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade in a technical correction. Corn was lower and soybeans finished mixed. The January soybean contract expired at noon CST at $5.54{ a bushel, down 3{ cents. Wheat futures were { cent to 3{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.92{ a bushel; corn was 1\ cents to 2} cents lower with March at $2.40{ a bushel; oats were 2 cents to 2} cents lower with March at $1.36} a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents lower to 1\ cents higher with March up { cent at $5.66 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Investment Banker Left Trail of Falsehoods, Newspaper Claims
DOC.TEXT: Investment banker Jeffrey Beck, an adviser on some of the biggest U.S. corporate takeovers ever, lied about his past, fabricating stories about his background and military service and claiming to work for the CIA, according to a published report Monday. Beck, who cultivated a colorful image that included the nickname ``Mad Dog,'' rose to stardom on Wall Street even though one of his tales helped kill a planned billion-dollar buyout of Northwest Industries Inc. in 1985, the Wall Street Journal reported. Beck, 43, a member of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s mergers and acquisitions department, allegedly told friends and colleagues over the years that he was a decorated veteran of the Army's Special Forces in Vietnam, that he did intelligence work for the government and that he would inherit a family fortune of $2 billion, the Journal said. However, the Journal said after interviewing friends, family, colleagues and acquaintances of the investment banker, none of the stories apparently was true. Drexel and Oppenheimer & Co., Beck's previous employer, kept him in their mergers and acquisitions departments although many of his co-workers did not believe his stories, the Journal said. Beck tendered a preliminary resignation to Drexel a couple of weeks ago, Drexel spokesman Steve Anreder told The Associated Press on Monday. The investment firm agreed to discuss the matter further with him but Beck has been unavailable, Anreder said. Beck was said to be out of his office when an AP reporter called for comment on the Journal's story Monday. The Journal said that during an interview, Beck denied that he had told most of the stories that were attributed to him by what the newspaper called business associates, friends and others. ``This is getting wilder and wilder,'' he told the newspaper. ``I am beyond shock.'' Beck, who claimed his troops in Vietnam nicknamed him ``Mad Dog,'' acknowledged there were no official records of his Vietnam service, but said he had made trips to Vietnam, the newspaper reported. Beck also was said to have claimed he had done years of intelligence work, but he denied to the Journal that he told people he worked for the CIA or that he would inherit a $2 billion fortune. Beck is a ``rainmaker,'' one who drums up takeover business for investment firms. He has been highly successful, working as an adviser to the buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. on a number of deals, including its record $24.53 billion purchase of RJR Nabisco Inc. in 1988. Beck in 1986 had helped bring KKR general partner Henry Kravis and investor Donald Kelly together in the $6.2 billion buyout of Beatrice Cos., at the time the biggest non-oil company takeover ever. But when Beck was with Oppenheimer, his story-telling contributed to the collapse of the Northwest Industries deal. In an account confirmed by Oppenheimer, the Journal said the firm was putting together a buyout of Northwest Industries when one investor backed out, leaving Oppenheimer and its partners $75 million short of their needed financing. Beck pledged to make up the shortfall from his own fortune. But after Oppenheimer colleague Stephen McGrath confronted Beck about his claims of wealth, Donald Kelly withdrew from the deal and it foundered. Northwest later merged with Farley Industries in a $1.04 billion transaction. Oppenheimer did not dismiss Beck until six months later, after being given an ultimatum by McGrath, the Journal said. When asked why there was a delay between the incident and Beck's firing, Oppenheimer spokesman John Ryan declined comment. He also refused to say whether any disciplinary action was taken against Beck. Shortly after his dismissal, Beck joined Drexel's mergers and acquisitions department. At Drexel he courted RJR Nabisco President F. Ross Johnson, whobegan the bidding war for the food and tobacco giant. At their second meeting, the Journal said, Johnson brought along a box of Milk Bone dog biscuits as a joke on Beck's nickname _ and Beck at the whole box. Johnson sought the advice of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. and Drexel ended up advising Henry Kravis. Because of his dealmaking abilities, Beck enjoyed great notoriety on Wall Street. The Journal said David Aaron, an Oppenheimer employee-turned-author, used Beck as the model for the main character of his book ``Agent of Influence.'' Beck also served as a technical adviser and had a cameo role in director Oliver Stone's film ``Wall Street.'' He befriended the film's star, Michael Douglas, who was impressed by Beck's war stories and became interested in making a film about them, the Journal said. However, the Journal quoted people familiar with the project as saying Douglas and screenwriter David Black came to believe that Beck's stories were false and dropped the project. Beck also is the subject of a book, ``Rainmaker,'' being written by Business Week reporter Anthony Bianco, the Journal said.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Setting Up 2nd Joint Vehicle Production Venture in Europe
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. said Monday it would form a joint venture with an Austrian company to make a European version of the automakers' popular minivans beginning next year. The move is further recognition by Chrysler of the growing importance of the European market. Trade barriers among the 12 nations belonging to the European Economic Community fall in 1992, and will create a vehicle market larger than North America. General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. have had European manufacturing plants for years. GM makes Opel and Vauxhall cars in Europe and Ford markets European-built Fords. Chrysler exports some cars and minivans to Europe under the Chrysler nameplate, along with its Jeep brand sport-utility vehicles. The deal announced Monday between the No. 3 automaker and Steyr-Daimler-Puch Fahrzeugtechnik is the second joint manufacturing venture between a European vehicle maker and the U.S. automaker, which has no manufacturing plants on its own in Europe. Chrysler and Renault are involved in a joint program to make a sport-utility vehicle, code-named the ``JJ,'' to be built beginning in 1992 at yet-to-be-announced plants in North American and either Spain or Portugal. The Chrysler-Austrian project will use a factory at Graz, and the Austrian company will provide European component engineering in addition to assembly facilities. Details of the agreement, including production targets and marketing plans, will be worked out within two months, Chrysler spokeswoman Karen Stewart said from company headquarters in Highland Park, Mich. ``They had to so something a little different,'' said auto analyst Kathleen Heaney of Nikko Securities Co. International Inc. ``If you wanted to start from scratch, you would go to Spain or Portugal for the labor costs. ``This is an existing facility,'' she said of the Austrian plant, ``so they save a lot of money and it's faster to get it into production.'' Analysts have said the minivan and sport-utility segments are relatively small, and hold good potential for growth within the European market. For years, Volkswagen of West Germany has produced and marketed a passenger van there, but its design is different than U.S. minivans. The French vehicle maker Renault sells the Espace minivan, but in relatively low volumes. Chrysler controls more than half of the U.S. minivan market with its Plymouth Voyager, Dodge Caravan and Chrysler Town & Country vehicles, and sold more than 500,000 of the vehicles last year in North America. It exported about 8,800 minivans to Europe in 1989 from assembly plants in St. Louis, Mo., and Windsor, Ontario. Two years ago, Chrysler exported North American-built Chrysler cars and Jeeps to Europe. Exports reached 50,000 in 1989. In 1983, American Motors Corp. established in China the Beijing Jeep Corp., which Chrysler inherited when it bought AMC in 1987. Chrysler owns about a third of Beijing Jeep, which produces mostly commercial vehicles for the Chinese market.

DOC.HEAD: Merrill Lynch Reports $362 Million Fourth-Quarter Loss
DOC.TEXT: Merrill Lynch & Co. on Monday reported a $362 million fourth-quarter loss, including a one-time charge of $470 million for a drastic restructuring at the nation's largest brokerage. The pretax charge, which analysts called the largest ever for a securities firm, comes during a period of wide retrenchment on Wall Street because of slow business since the October 1987 stock market crash. For all of 1989, Merrill Lynch reported a loss of $213 million, compared to profits of $463 million the previous year. Merrill Chairman William A. Schreyer blamed the decline on Wall Street's hard times characterized by an exodus of small investors, a severe drop in the junk bond market, low return on some products and increased competition. The firm, touted as ``A Breed Apart'' in newspaper and television advertisements, in November began the restructuring, which includes layoffs estimated at more than 4,000. While other firms have reduced staff because of a slowdown in retail brokerage and investment banking, Merrill's cuts have been the most stunning because of the firm's pre-eminence on Wall Street. ``It's scary that the costs could run this high to do what they've done here,'' said analyst Lawrence Eckenfelder of Prudential Bache Securities Corp. in San Francisco. ``What it suggests is there's an awful lot more to come out there, I'm sure at other firms as well.'' Merrill's quarterly loss, which amounted to $3.56 a share, compared with earnings of $276 million, or $2.69 a share, for the same 1988 period. Revenue for the quarter ending Dec. 29 was $2.8 billion, up from $2.67 billion in the 1988 quarter. Merrill reported that quarterly revenue from principal transactions declined nearly 50 percent to $169 million from $321 million the previous year. For the full year, Merrill reported a per share loss of $2.31. In 1988, Merrill reported a profit of $463 million, or $4.29 a share. Revenue for 1989 was $11.3 billion, up 16 percent from $9.75 billion in 1988. But the revenue increase was due mainly to a 35 percent rise in interest and dividends. Revenue sank 18.6 percent for principal transactions and 6.3 percent from investment banking, while commission revenue gained 12.3 percent. Merrill said the two areas of decline reflected markdowns in the firm's inventory of high-yield bonds. The junk bond market was battered in 1989 because of a series of huge defaults and declines in the use of the securities to finance mergers and takeovers. The firm's 1988 full-year and fourth-quarter results included a $255 million after-tax gain from the termination of a Merrill pension plan. Merrill said the restructuring charge resulted from divesting some products lines and business activities; consolidating and relocating some domestic and international retail, institutional and other facilities; and reducing the size of other operations. The bulk of the charge came from paying off office leases, severance payments and asset writeoffs from reduced operations. Merrill officials said they expected the reductions eventually would save the firm $100 million to $200 million a year. Merrill plans to lay off about 3,000 workers by the end of 1990 through layoffs, attrition and selling off businesses. The reductions would drop Merrill's total work force to about 36,800, compared with 40,500 at the end of 1989 and a peak of 47,000 shortly before the October 1987 stock market crash. Merrill recently cut an additional 700 positions by selling its Canadian retail brokerage operation and eliminated 300 more jobs through cuts in its Broadcort Capital Corp. account-clearing business. Since November, Merrill also has abandoned the European commercial paper business, eliminated one equity division at its New York headquarters and reduced trading of British stocks. Merrill's stock price dropped 62{ cents a share to $24.12{ in New York Stock Exchange trading Monday. The earnings were announced after the market closed. Only Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which has slashed its work force by more than 40 percent since resolving securities fraud charges, has engineered a more dramatic cutback. Overall, Wall Street has eliminated more than 23,000 since the crash.

DOC.HEAD: Business Magazine Slates Publishing Plans in Hungary
DOC.TEXT: Business Week magazine announced Monday that it and a Hungarian publishing company have agreed to publish a Hungarian language monthly magazine. The magazine, ``Magyar Kiadas-Business Week,'' will contain editorial selected from Business Week and Business Week International. It will have an initial circulation of 8,000 and be distributed in Hungary and neighboring countries. The first issue of the magazine will be introduced at the Budapest International Spring Fair in May. The company teaming up with Business Week, a division of McGraw-Hill Inc., is Hirlapkiado Vallalet, a Budapest, Hungary-based publisher. ``Business Week International has provided global companies with information and advertising opportunities for years and, now with the opening of new markets, Hungarians will be able to read for the first time in their own language ...'' said John W. Patten, executive vice president and publisher of Business Week. ``As various corporations are moving into Eastern Europe, Business Week Hungary will provide an opportunity for advertisers to deliver their message to an ever growing audience,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Prepares to Tackle Clean-Air Legislation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 19 grafs to UPDATE with Mitchell news conference. Picks up 22nd graf pvs `Saying reduced ... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Congress returning Tuesday from a long holiday recess is all but sure to enact tougher air-pollution controls, but battles remain over how much the legislation should cost and who should pay. ``There will be a long, formidable .... no doubt at times contentious debate,'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, told reporters Monday. ``It is imperative that we act not only for ourselves but for the future generations.'' Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., chairman of the Environmental and Public Works subcommittee that originated the bill and chief sponsor of the legislation, said ``all interested parties know there will be a clean-air bill'' this year. The broad-reaching clean-air bill that will begin to be scrutinized on the Senate floor Tuesday calls for cutting acid-rain pollutants in half, much tighter controls on automobile emissions and greatly reducing toxic chemical releases. The estimated annual cost of the various proposals ranges from $14 billion to $100 billion. Supporters of the legislation argue that some of the costs are being exaggerated and that reduced health-care costs will recoup some of the money. President Bush said last week that he's prepared to veto any legislation that goes substantially beyond the $19 billion proposal he sent to Capitol Hill last summer. ``I want to sign a clean-air bill this year, ... but I will only sign legislation that balances environmental and economic progress,'' Bush said in a letter to the Senate. Mitchell said the Senate legislation would cost slightly more than the bill proposed by the White House, but called the president's cost assessment inflated. He said it was ``extremely unlikely'' that the president would veto a clean-air bill, even the current Senate legislation. ``A cheaper solution is often not the best solution,'' he said. Congress faces other major issues, including reducing the budget deficit, subsidizing child care for working parents, reforming campaign-finance laws, extending farm programs and stepping up the war on drugs. There also will be fights over Bush's proposal to cut the capital gains tax and a proposal by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to cut the Social Security tax. A key to the budget battle will be how deeply defense spending can be cut in light of the recent move toward democracy in Eastern Europe and the lessening of East-West tensions. Some lawmakers say that ``peace dividend'' should be used for domestic programs. With more than 100 million people breathing air the government considers unhealthy and growing concern over the destruction of streams and lakes by acid rain, there is little disagreement over the need for tougher federal air-pollution controls. Lawmakers argue that while new curbs will be expensive, doing nothing may be even more costly. Fran DuMelle of the American Lung Association said the annual health costs associated to air pollution five years ago was estimated at $15 billion to $40 billion. Today, the $40 billion figure ``has become a middle range'' and the health toll continues to rise, she said. The framework of a tougher air-pollution law seems set on Capitol Hill, but major details continue to be the subject of intense behind-the-door maneuvering. Mitchell, a longtime advocate of tougher clean-air legislation, said action is needed this year or the country's determination to deal with environmental problems will questioned worldwide. A House version, not as tough as the Senate bill but closer to what Bush wants, remains in committee. Even after both chambers complete their bills, there will be tough bargaining before final compromise legislation goes to the president. One of the major disagreements over a clean-air bill involves the continuing regional conflict over whether states with the dirtiest utility plants should pay all clean-up costs. Saying reduced acid-rain pollution benefits everyone, senators from a string of states from Pennsylvania to Missouri _ where the dirtiest utility plants are located _ want the costs spread nationwide through an energy tax or fee. Legislators from other states balk at the proposal, and Bush has said he would veto any measure that includes such a cost-sharing tax. ``It's hard to see why consumers in states that have already done their part should be paying a second time for those who have dragged their feet,'' said Minnesota Gov. Rudy Perpich. ``Cost sharing is dead on arrival,'' Baucus said. Nevertheless, an accommodation aimed at easing some of the Midwesterners' concerns is expected. Various proposals are being discussed, including one that would give the dirtiest utility plants extra pollution credits that could be sold to other parts of the country to defer clean-up costs. Meanwhile, industries most affected, including automakers and oil companies, have unleashed lobbying campaigns aimed at blunting the most expensive pollution controls under consideration. One target has been tough proposed auto tailpipe pollution controls that would go into effect in 2003 and for which there is no available technology to bring cars into compliance. Supporters of the so-called ``Stage II'' controls say automakers need to be pushed into developing better technology. The estimated cost of the provision has ranged from $135 a car to, according to auto companies, at least $500 a car.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Decides to Relax Restrictions on Computer Sales
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf with talks with allies after 15th graf pvs, A group ... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said Monday it will move to end controls on overseas sales of computers and other technology readily available to the public. The policy overhaul will have an immediate effect on much of Eastern Europe but no immediate effect on the Soviet Union. Meanwhile, sevral U.S. officials have opened talks in London to prepare for joint steps by 17 nations to accelerate delivery of advanced technology to such countries as Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia. ``The political and military environment is changing ... The situation is different today than it was a year ago,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. For more than 40 years, the United States and its allies have imposed stiff curbs on technology sales to Communist countries on security grounds. But the advent of Mikhail S. Gorbachev as leader of the Soviet Union in 1985 and the spread of reform in the Eastern Bloc spured many Western governments to push for an easing of restrictions. At a National Security Council meeting on Friday, the Bush administration decided to take a softer approach, as well, sources said. Two parallel decisions were made: To work out a joint agreement at a meeting in Paris next month to provide advanced technology to Eastern Europe and to conduct a comprehensive review of U.S. policy. Officials of the State Department, the Pentagon and the Commerce Department participated in the decision. State and Commerce were more willing to permit the technology transfers than the Defense Department. The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said the underlining U.S. principles were: _Support for reform in Eastern Europe. _Strengthening protection for ``truly strategic'' goods and technologies. _More rapid modernization of the current lists of controlled items. _Decontrol of off-the-shelf commodities readily availble to the general public. She said the administration wanted to take advantage of a ``changing enviornment'' in Eastern Europe. In the Soviet Union, she said, ``the situation has not evolved to the same extent.'' Fitzwater called the steps being taken ``a prudent change ... that will not jeopardize strategic interests.'' A group of U.S. officials led by Allan Wendt, of the State Department's office of strategic technology policy, flew to London over the weekend to meet with British officials. The officials will go on to The Netherlands, West Germany and Italy. Meanwhile, delegations from Canada and Japan will come to Washington for talks this week and French and Danish experts are due here next week. The discussions are in preparation for a meeting in Paris in mid-February of Cocom, the Coordination Committee for Multilateral Export Control. There, the United States hopes to work out details of what kind of equipment will be cleared for Eastern Europe and how much of it. Cocom, which includes all 16 NATO countries except Iceland, plus Japan and Australia, attempts to coordinate Western deliveries of technology to Eastern European countries. The United States has been among the most reluctant to provide high technology to allies of the Soviet Union. The countries likely to be assisted include Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia, all of which have shed communist domination nd are adopting capitalistic approaches to their weak economies. The meeting in Paris is designed to adopt uniform rules to guide technology transfers. In this respect, the administration's decision to liberalize restrictions could be balanced against the more eager approaches of some other Cocom members and produce a compromise. The net result, however, would be to deliver better computers and telecommunications equipment to members of the Eastern Bloc provided semi-sensitive technology is not then turned over to the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Phillips Subsidiary Reaches Settlement With Iran
DOC.TEXT: Phillips Petroleum Co. received a $92 million settlement Monday from the government of Iran and the National Iranian Oil Co. for a 1981 claim for the expropriation of Phillips' interest in two offshore oil fields. Phillips filed the claim with the Iran-U.S. Claims Tribunal, which in June awarded Phillips about $110 million for expropriation of the company's one-sixth interest in the oil fields. Iran followed with counterclaims against Phillips, which the Tribunal did not dispose of because of lack of jurisdiction, regarding oil received by Phillips under the purchase contract. The $92 million settlement ends all claims and counterclaims between Iran and Phillips, said Phillips spokesman George Minter. Phillips received a net payment Monday of $91 million because of a statutory fee of $1 million deducted by the U.S. Treasury Department.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Opens Higher in Tokyo, Stocks
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose slightly at the opening of trading in Tokyo Tuesday while stock prices slipped. The dollar started at 146.66 yen, up 0.24 yen from Monday's Tokyo close. Yoshitsuyu Hanada, a dealer at Mitsui Bank, said the U.S. currency picked up on the trend in New York trading, where the dollar climbed over the 146-yen barrier to 146.50 yen late Monday. However, the dollar's rise may lose steam, Hanada suggested. The boost given the dollar by instability in Eastern bloc nations has run its course, he said. Dealers also are edgy over an expected announcement by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan on U.S. interest rates, he said. The dollar is likely to remain within the 146-yen range as a result, he said. Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange lost some of their Monday gains in early trading. At 9:30 a.m., the Nikkei Stock Average was down 71.58 points, or 0.2 percent, at 37,185.43. It had gained 420.47 Monday to close at 37,257.01.

DOC.HEAD: Amoco Profits Slide in 4Q; Amerada Hess, Arco Earnings Rise
DOC.TEXT: Amoco Corp. said Monday its fourth-quarter earnings fell 15 percent because of special one-time gains in the previous year, while Arco said higher oil prices helped its quarterly earnings rise 3 percent and Amerada Hess Corp. posted a 7 percent rise in profits as exploration and production earnings surged. For the three months ended Dec. 31, Chicago-based Amoco earned $319 million, or 62 cents a share, down from $375 million, or 72 cents a share, in the comparable 1988 period. Revenue rose 10 percent to $6.8 billion from $6.2 billion. Amoco Chairman Richard Morrow said 1988 fourth-quarter earnings benefitted from one-time factors, mainly natural gas settlements. Without those factors, earnings in the latest quarter would have been about the same as in the 1988 quarter. For the year, Amoco's net income fell 22 percent to $1.6 billion, or $3.12 a share, from $2.1 billion, or $4 a share, in 1988. Revenue advanced 12 percent to $26.8 billion from $23.9 billion. Restructuring costs and provisions for environmental programs depressed earnings for the full year. Los Angeles-based Arco said its earnings rose 3 percent in the fourth quarter and 23 percent in the year, largely because of higher energy prices, lower interest expense and sale of a majority stake in a petrochemical subsidiary. The energy company, formerly Atlantic Richfield Co., said it earned $403 million, or $2.38 per share, in the quarter, up from $391 million, or $2.22 per share, for the fourth quarter of 1988. Quarterly revenues fell by 11.8 percent, to $4 billion from $4.5 billion. For the year Arco earned $1.95 billion, or $11.26 per share, compared to $1.58 billion, $8.78 per share, in fiscal 1988. Revenues fell 12.6 percent to $16.02 billion from $18.32 billion. Arco Chairman Lodwrick Cook said the company experienced higher worldwide crude oil and refined product prices _ for example, the average price for domestic crude oil rose to $13.13 a barrel last year from $9.90 in 1988. Increased natural gas volumes and lower interest expense also contributed to income growth, Cook said in a statement. ``We also realized a $634 million after-tax gain from the sale of a majority interest in Lyondell Petrochemical Co. in January,'' he said. ``At the same time, however, the 1989 results reflect a $345 million charge for future environmental expenses and other provisions, as well as 50 percent less contribution from the earnings of Lyondell.'' The sale of 50.1 percent of Lyondell caused Arco to report lower revenues in the fourth quarter and 1989. Lyondell accounted for $4.7 billion of Arco's revenues in 1988. Arco also said it spent a total of $827 million to repurchase 8.3 million shares of its stock in 1989. New York-based Amerada Hess earned $70.8 million, or 88 cents a share, up from $66.3 million, or 80 cents a share, in the comparable 1988 period. Revenue rose about 3 percent to $1.5 billion from $1.2 billion. For the year, Amerada Hess' net earnings more than doubled to $476 million, or $5.87 a share, from $124 million, or $1.51 a share. Revenue totaled $5.7 billion, up 33 percent from $4.3 billion in the previous year. Exploration and production earnings totaled $33.9 million in the fourth quarter compared with a loss of $300,000 in the 1988 quarter. Fourth-quarter 1988 results also included a charge of $30 million for capitalized exploration expenses related to properties for which the company had no development plans. While refining and marketing earnings declined in the fourth quarter, they more than doubled in the year, Amerada Hess reported.

DOC.HEAD: Failed Merger Bid Helps Boost BellSouth Profits
DOC.TEXT: BellSouth Corp. said Monday its fourth quarter net income rose 11.8 percent, boosted largely by termination fees stemming from its failed bid to acquire LIN Broadcasting Corp. Income rose to $469 million in the three months ended Dec. 31, or 97 cents a share, from $419.3 million, or 90 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. Revenues rose 1.1 percent to $3.62 billion from $3.58 billion. For all of 1989, net income rose 4.2 percent to $1.74 billion or $3.64 a share from $1.67 billion or $3.51 a share in 1988. Revenues for the year rose 2.9 percent to $14.0 billion from $13.6 billion in 1988. LIN paid BellSouth $89 million to get out of a proposed merger of cellular telephone operations. LIN scrapped the BellSouth deal in December in favor of a $3.38 billion combination with McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. BellSouth last April acquired Mobile Communications Corp. of America, a transaction that contributed to a 12-month loss of $5.2 million for BellSouth's domestic mobile communications information division. ``As we expected, our MCCA acquisition diluted earnings in 1989 but we continue to be pleased with the growth and vitality of the cellular markets we serve,'' said BellSouth Chairman John L. Clendenin. BellSouth, an Atlanta-based international telecommunications holding company, includes Southern Bell and South Central Bell, which together serve 70 percent of the population of nine Southeastern states.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovakia Asks to Join International Monetary Fund
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia has asked to join the International Monetary Fund, a major source of loans to countries in financial trouble, the fund announced Monday. China, Poland, Hungary and Yugoslavia are already members. Soviet leaders have said they would like to join the 152 countries that make up the organization. The U.S. government, which holds the biggest single block of votes, has said it does not consider the Soviets ready. The U.S. Central Intelligence Agency estimated Czechoslovakia's debt in 1988 at $6.1 billion, much less than Poland's $38.5 billion and less than that of most other Eastern European countries. One exception is Romania, which under the late President Nicolae Ceausescu paid off virtually all its foreign debt. The fund's announcement recalled that Czechoslovakia was one of the original members when the fund was organized just after World War II but withdrew in 1954 after the Communists took over the government. No difficulty is expected in winning membership approval for Czechoslovakia to rejoin. The country probably will need financial help as it shifts from state control of the economy to something closer to a market system. The IMF specializes in short-term loans for countries with payments difficulties. Membership in the fund also opens the way to membership in its sister organization, the World Bank, also based in Washington. The bank is the largest source of long-term development loans to the Third World. A loan from the IMF can open the way to borrowing from other lenders, including individual governments and private banks. The fund has negotiated a $710 million loan to Poland and approval by the member governments is expected soon. The application of Czechoslovakia and the prospect that East Germany, Romania and Bulgaria may follow, come as the fund is seeking a major increase in its resources _ now equivalent to about $117 billion. Michel Camdessus, the fund's French managing director, has asked for a doubling of quotas, as contributions are called, and most member countrties went along. But the United States, Britain and Saudi Arabia _ all influential members _ have argued for a smaller increase.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Official Sees End of Obstacles to Soviet Trade
DOC.TEXT: U.S. legal obstacles to trade with the Soviet Union will be gone by June, the president of the government's Export-Import Bank predicted Monday. ``It's important because our competitors have about $12 billion worth of trade business with the Soviets,'' Joseph D. Macomber told the Bankers' Association for Foreign Trade. ``We've got a lot of catching up to do.'' Macomber predicted that the obstacles will be abolished before President Bush meets the heads of other major industrialized nations for their annual summit this year in Houston. The Export-Import Bank, which lends to purchasers in foreign countries at subsidized rates to promote the sale of American industrial products, is barred by law from lending to the Soviet Union. The Bush administration has been waiting until the Supreme Soviet passes a new law on emigration before it moves to lift the restrictions, imposed by the 1975 Jackson-Vanik amendment. The object of the amendment was to encourage freer movement of Jews out of the Soviet Union. Another legal provision, the Stevenson amendment, sets a limit of $300 million on what the bank can lend or guarantee in loans to the Soviets. Macomber quoted one of his analysts as saying: ``That ought to get us through the first 30 days.'' A third restriction, the Byrd amendment, puts a limit of $40 million on what can be lent to help finance Soviet energy production.

DOC.HEAD: Great Western's 1989 Earnings Down
DOC.TEXT: Great Western Financial Corp., the nation's second-largest thrift, said Monday it posted its first quarterly loss in seven years, largely because of a $200 million charge for bad real commercial and real estate loans. The writedown and a year-end increase in loan-loss reserves helped produce a loss of $77.3 million or 59 cents a share in the fourth quarter of 1989, compared to earnings of $59.7 million or 47 cents a share a year earlier, the company said. For all of 1989, Great Western's earnings fell 58 percent to $100 million or 78 cents a share from $240 million or $1.95 a share in 1988. Securities analysts had expected Great Western, considered one of the nation's best-managed thrifts, to show some problems with sour real estate loans in Arizona, Florida and other states. Net interest income increased 15 percent in 1989 to $956 million, compared to $832 million in 1988. Real estate lending totaled $11.1 billion, down from $11.5 billion in 1988, the company said. New loans, including real estate and consumer lendig, totaled $13.1 billion for the year, slightly below 1988's $13.2 billion. Great Western's assets rose 12 percent to $37 billion at the end of 1989 from $33 billion a year earlier, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Student Found Guilty in Computer Tampering Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with comment from Morris and his father; minor editing thruout. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A jury Monday night convicted a suspended graduate student of federal computer tampering charges for unleashing a ``worm'' that crippled a nationwide network of thousands of computers. Robert T. Morris, 24, faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. He is the first person brought to trial under a 1986 federal computer fraud and abuse law that makes it a felony to break into a federal computer network and prevent authorized use of the system. The jury returned its verdict about 9:30 p.m. after nearly six hours of deliberation. U.S. District Court Judge Howard Munson did not set a sentencing date. Morris, from Arnold, Md., testified during his trial that he had made a programming error that caused a computer worm to go berserk and cripple the Internet system Nov. 2, 1988. The worm he designed immobilized an estimated 6,000 computers linked to Internet, including ones at NASA, military facilities and major universities. Morris would not comment as he hurried from the federal courthouse. But his father, also named Robert, said he did not think the verdict was unfair. ``I have a great deal of faith in the American judicial system and yet I'm still disappointed in the verdict,'' he said. Morris may not have intended his ``worm'' program to paralyze a nationwide computer network in 1988, but it was no accident that the worm attacked the network, U.S. Justice Department trial lawyer Mark Rasch said in closing statements earlier in the day. ``The worm didn't break in by accident or mistake. Robert Morris intended for the worm to break in,'' he said. Defense attorney Thomas Guidoboni argued that the suspended Cornell University graduate student made a programming error that caused the worm to go berserk and cripple the Internet system on Nov. 2, 1988. ``It's not the side effects, it's not the mistakes, but what he actually intended to do,'' said Guidoboni. ``He never intended to prevent authorized access.'' Prosecutor Ellen Meltzer reminded the jury in her summation that testimony showed Morris deliberately stole computer passwords from hundreds of people so the worm could break into as many computers as possible. She added that Morris took deliberate and conscious steps to make the rogue program difficult to detect and eradicate. He unleashed the worm from the computer system at Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, and made it look like it was sent by the University of California at Berkeley so authorship of the program could not be traced to him at Cornell, she said. Ms. Meltzer said at least six earlier versions of the worm were found on Morris' Cornell computer accounts and that his own comments on the worm program used the words ``break-in'' and ``steal.'' She told the jury that Morris' ``worm was not a juvenile prank. ... In no way was it a legitimate Cornell research project gone awry.'' Guidoboni insisted that Morris didn't intend to cause permanent damage to computer files. ``There was no work lost, work was delayed. That's the bottom line,'' he said. Morris took steps to limit the worm's growth, Guidoboni said. ``If he intended to bring the systems down, he didn't need to control the growth. He could have just let this thing go,'' he said. He stressed that once Morris realized the worm had gone berserk, he tried to stop it. While Guidoboni argued during the trial that Internet was chiefly a system used by researchers to swap information, including recipes and love letters, Meltzer contended it was far more important. She said it also involved research on acquired immune deficiency syndrome, weapons development, artificial intelligence and new drugs.
